The reliability of palpation in the assessment of tumours. Palpation is a commonly used technique in the clinical setting to assess the presence and characteristics of tumors. However, there is limited evidence on the reliability of palpation as a diagnostic tool for tumors. This study aimed to evaluate the reliability of palpation in the assessment of tumors.

A total of 100 patients with suspected tumors were included in the study. Two experienced clinicians independently palpated the patients' lesions and recorded their findings. These findings were compared with the gold standard, which was the histopathological diagnosis obtained through biopsy or surgery.

The results showed that the sensitivity of palpation in detecting tumors was 78%, with a specificity of 65%. The positive predictive value was 73%, while the negative predictive value was 70%. The overall accuracy of palpation in diagnosing tumors was 71%.

Furthermore, the inter-observer agreement between the two clinicians in their palpation findings was moderate, with a kappa value of 0.56. This indicates that there is a fair degree of agreement between the clinicians but also suggests some variability in their palpation assessments.

In conclusion, palpation appears to have moderate reliability in the assessment of tumors. While it can provide useful information in detecting tumors, its limitations in terms of sensitivity and specificity should be taken into consideration. Additional diagnostic techniques, such as imaging and biopsy, should be considered to complement and confirm the findings of palpation.

Tuberculosis of the esophagus.  Tuberculosis of the esophagus is rare. Tuberculosis (TB) of the esophagus is an uncommon manifestation of extrapulmonary tuberculosis. This retrospective study aimed to evaluate the clinical characteristics, diagnostic approach, and treatment outcomes of patients diagnosed with tuberculosis of the esophagus. A total of 32 patients with confirmed tuberculosis of the esophagus were identified over a period of 10 years. The most common symptoms included dysphagia (87.5%), weight loss (78.1%), and chest pain (59.4%). Endoscopy revealed various manifestations, including ulcers, strictures, and nodules. Diagnosis was confirmed by histopathological examination or positive acid-fast bacilli staining from biopsy specimens in all cases. Combination anti-tuberculosis therapy was administered to all patients, and surgical intervention was required in 6 cases with complicated disease. The overall treatment success rate was 87.5%. In conclusion, tuberculosis of the esophagus is a rare but potentially severe condition. Early diagnosis, prompt initiation of anti-tuberculosis treatment, and appropriate surgical intervention, when necessary, are essential for successful management of this disease.

Enhanced antitumor reactivity of tumor-sensitized T cells by interferon alfa. Interferon alfa (IFN-) has been widely used as an immunotherapy agent in various malignancies due to its potent antitumor effects. In this study, we aimed to investigate the impact of IFN- on the antitumor reactivity of tumor-sensitized T cells. Peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) were obtained from patients with solid tumors who had received autologous tumor lysate-pulsed dendritic cell vaccination. Tumor-sensitized T cells were activated ex vivo in the presence or absence of IFN-. Our results demonstrated that the addition of IFN- significantly enhanced the proliferation and cytotoxicity of tumor-sensitized T cells compared to controls. Moreover, IFN- treatment resulted in a significant increase in the production of proinflammatory cytokines such as interleukin-2 and interferon-. Mechanistically, IFN- upregulated the expression of major histocompatibility complex class I molecules on tumor cells, facilitating the recognition and killing of tumor cells by activated T cells. These findings suggest that IFN- can enhance the antitumor reactivity of tumor-sensitized T cells, highlighting its potential as an adjunct therapy in cancer immunotherapy.

Multiple intracranial mucoceles associated with phaeohyphomycosis of the paranasal sinuses. We report a rare case of multiple intracranial mucoceles associated with phaeohyphomycosis of the paranasal sinuses. A 54-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus and chronic sinusitis presented with recurrent headaches and progressive visual disturbances. Imaging studies revealed multiple well-defined cystic lesions in the frontal and ethmoid sinuses, extending into the intracranial cavity. Surgical excision of the lesions was performed, and histopathological examination confirmed the presence of phaeohyphomycosis. The patient was treated with antifungal therapy, and his symptoms gradually improved. Phaeohyphomycosis is a rare fungal infection caused by dematiaceous fungi. It typically presents as chronic sinusitis or cutaneous infections, but intracranial involvement is extremely rare. The association of phaeohyphomycosis with intracranial mucoceles has not been extensively reported in the literature. Our case highlights the importance of considering phaeohyphomycosis as a differential diagnosis in patients with chronic sinusitis, especially in those with predisposing factors such as diabetes mellitus. Prompt diagnosis and appropriate management are essential to prevent complications such as intracranial mucoceles.

Rett syndrome: findings suggesting axonopathy and mitochondrial abnormalities. Rett syndrome is a neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by severe cognitive and physical impairments, predominantly affecting females. Recent studies have suggested that there may be underlying axonopathy and mitochondrial abnormalities in individuals with Rett syndrome. 

Axonopathy, characterized by abnormal structural development and function of axons, has been hypothesized as a potential mechanism contributing to the neurological deficits observed in Rett syndrome. Studies utilizing advanced imaging techniques, such as diffusion tensor imaging, have provided evidence of disrupted white matter microstructure in affected individuals, supporting the presence of axonopathy. Furthermore, postmortem studies have revealed abnormal axonal morphology and reduced myelination in various brain regions.

Mitochondrial dysfunction has also been implicated in the pathophysiology of Rett syndrome. Studies have reported alterations in mitochondrial respiratory chain enzyme activities and reduced ATP production in individuals with the condition. Additionally, abnormalities in mitochondrial DNA integrity and oxidative stress markers have been observed.

Further research is needed to elucidate the precise mechanisms by which axonopathy and mitochondrial abnormalities contribute to the phenotypic manifestations of Rett syndrome. Understanding these underlying pathologies may help in the development of targeted therapeutic interventions for this devastating condition.

Indications and results of relaxing retinotomy. Relaxing retinotomy is a surgical procedure used to treat various vitreoretinal disorders, including proliferative vitreoretinopathy (PVR) and retinal detachment, that are refractory to standard treatments. This retrospective study aims to evaluate the indications and outcomes of relaxing retinotomy in a cohort of patients. A total of 35 eyes from 32 patients who underwent relaxing retinotomy between 2010 and 2020 were included in the analysis. The main indications for the procedure were PVR (n=21), tractional retinal detachment (n=10), and combined tractional-rhegmatogenous retinal detachment (n=4). The surgical technique involved creating a retinal break in the area of maximal traction to release the retinal forces. Anatomic success, defined as retinal reattachment, was achieved in 28 eyes (80%). Visual acuity improved or remained stable in 27 eyes (77%). Complications included intraoperative hemorrhage (n=2), postoperative retinal detachment (n=3), and epiretinal membrane formation (n=5). In conclusion, relaxing retinotomy is an effective surgical option for PVR and complex retinal detachments, with favorable anatomical and visual outcomes in our cohort.

Temporal movement control in patients with Parkinson's disease. Parkinson's disease is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by motor symptoms, including bradykinesia, rigidity, and tremor. Temporal movement control is a critical aspect of motor function that is often impaired in these patients. This study aimed to investigate the specific deficits in timing and synchronization of movements in individuals with Parkinson's disease. The researchers conducted tests on a cohort of Parkinson's patients and a control group, assessing their ability to time movements accurately and synchronize with external cues. Results showed that Parkinson's patients exhibited significant difficulties in both aspects compared to controls. Furthermore, the severity of these deficits correlated with disease progression and motor impairment. These findings suggest that temporal movement control is a specific impairment associated with Parkinson's disease. Understanding the underlying mechanisms and developing interventions to improve timing and synchronization skills may have important implications for rehabilitation strategies and the overall quality of life for individuals with Parkinson's disease. Further research is warranted to elucidate the neurological basis of these deficits and develop targeted interventions to address them effectively.

Risk factors for white matter changes detected by magnetic resonance imaging in the elderly. White matter changes (WMC) seen on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) are common in the elderly and have been associated with cognitive decline and increased risk of stroke. This study aimed to identify risk factors for WMC in the elderly population. A total of 200 participants aged 60 years or older underwent MRI brain scans and comprehensive assessments of medical history and lifestyle factors. Multivariate regression analysis revealed that age, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, smoking, and obesity were independent risk factors for the presence and severity of WMC. These findings highlight the importance of targeting these modifiable risk factors to prevent or delay the development of WMC and subsequent cognitive decline in the elderly.

Inflammatory breast cancer.  Historically, the prognosis of inflammatory breast cancer has been poor. Inflammatory breast cancer (IBC) is a rare and aggressive form of breast cancer. The purpose of this study was to evaluate the prognosis and outcomes of patients with IBC. The medical records of 100 patients diagnosed with IBC between 2000 to 2010 were retrospectively reviewed. The majority of patients presented with advanced stage disease and exhibited poor overall survival rates. The median overall survival was found to be 2.5 years, with a five-year survival rate of only 25%. Multivariate analysis showed that age, tumor size, lymph node involvement, and hormone receptor status were significant prognostic factors for survival in patients with IBC. These findings highlight the need for early detection and aggressive treatment strategies for IBC patients. Further research is warranted to identify novel effective therapies for this aggressive form of breast cancer.

The effect of enoximone and dobutamine on hemodynamic performance after open heart surgery.  A clinical comparison. In patients undergoing open heart surgery, the use of inotropic agents is crucial for optimizing hemodynamic performance. Enoximone and dobutamine are two commonly used drugs in this context; however, their comparative effectiveness remains uncertain. 

This study aimed to assess and compare the hemodynamic effects of enoximone and dobutamine in patients after open heart surgery. A total of 100 patients were randomized into two groups: one receiving enoximone and the other receiving dobutamine. Hemodynamic parameters including mean arterial pressure, cardiac output, pulmonary artery pressure, and systemic vascular resistance were measured at baseline and at different time points postoperatively.

The results showed that both enoximone and dobutamine significantly improved hemodynamic performance compared to baseline values. However, there were no significant differences in the measured parameters between the two treatment groups. Adverse events were minimal and comparable between the two groups.

In conclusion, both enoximone and dobutamine are effective in improving hemodynamic performance after open heart surgery. The choice between these two agents can be based on other factors such as cost and availability. Further research is warranted to determine any long-term differences in outcomes between the two drugs.

Cytologic criteria to distinguish hepatocellular carcinoma from nonneoplastic liver.  The authors reviewed a series of fine-needle aspiration biopsy (FNAB) specimens of the liver to identify useful cytologic criteria to distinguish hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) from nonneoplastic liver. Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is a challenging diagnosis to make on cytology, especially on fine-needle aspiration biopsy (FNAB) specimens of the liver. In this study, the authors aimed to identify cytologic criteria that can aid in distinguishing HCC from nonneoplastic liver. The authors reviewed a series of FNAB specimens from patients with known HCC and nonneoplastic liver conditions. Several cytologic criteria were identified that showed promise in distinguishing HCC from nonneoplastic liver, including nuclear enlargement, pleomorphism, hyperchromasia, and increased nucleocytoplasmic ratio. Additionally, the presence of multinucleated giant cells and keratin pearl-like structures were found to be highly indicative of HCC. These findings suggest that specific cytologic features can aid in the accurate diagnosis of HCC on FNAB, potentially leading to improved patient management and treatment outcomes.

The accuracy of predictions about progress of patients on a stroke unit. This study aimed to assess the accuracy of predictions made by healthcare professionals regarding the progress of patients on a stroke unit. A total of 100 patients admitted to the stroke unit were included in the study. Predictions regarding the patients' progress were made by a team of healthcare professionals, comprising physicians and nurses, at various time points during their hospital stay. The predictions were compared to the actual progress of the patients as measured by standardized outcome measures, including functional ability, cognitive function, and mortality rates.

Results showed that the overall accuracy of predictions made by the healthcare professionals was moderate. The accuracy varied depending on the specific outcome measure being predicted. Predictions regarding mortality rates had the highest accuracy, followed by functional ability and cognitive function. Factors such as age, initial stroke severity, and comorbidities were found to influence the accuracy of predictions.

These findings emphasize the importance of regular reassessment and adjustment of predictions for patients on a stroke unit. Healthcare professionals should be mindful of the potential limitations in their ability to accurately predict patient outcomes and should consider incorporating standardized outcome measures to guide their decision-making process. Further research is needed to identify additional factors that may improve the accuracy of predictions in this population.

Occipital condyle fracture presenting as retropharyngeal hematoma. Occipital condyle fractures are rare but potentially serious injuries, often associated with high-energy trauma. We present a case of a 54-year-old male who presented with severe neck pain and inability to swallow following a motor vehicle accident. Initial evaluation revealed a retropharyngeal hematoma on computed tomography (CT) scan, prompting concern for an esophageal injury. However, further imaging with magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) revealed an occipital condyle fracture with associated soft tissue swelling and hematoma. This case highlights the importance of considering occipital condyle fractures in the differential diagnosis of retropharyngeal hematomas and emphasizes the need for a multidisciplinary approach involving orthopedic and otolaryngology specialists. Treatment for occipital condyle fractures typically involves conservative management with cervical immobilization, but surgery may be indicated in cases with associated cranial or neurological deficits. Further research and case studies are needed to establish optimal treatment strategies and outcomes for this uncommon injury.

Toxicities in rats with free versus liposomal encapsulated cisplatin. Cisplatin is a widely used chemotherapy drug for the treatment of various malignancies. However, it is associated with dose-dependent nephrotoxicity and ototoxicity. Liposomal encapsulation of cisplatin is a novel approach that aims to reduce its systemic toxicities by altering its pharmacokinetics and biodistribution. In this study, we compared the toxicities of free cisplatin and liposomal encapsulated cisplatin in rats. Rats were divided into two groups and received either free cisplatin or liposomal encapsulated cisplatin at equimolar doses. Evaluation of nephrotoxicity was done by measuring serum creatinine and blood urea nitrogen levels, as well as by histopathological examination of kidney tissues. Ototoxicity was assessed by measuring auditory brainstem response thresholds. Our results showed that liposomal encapsulated cisplatin significantly reduced nephrotoxicity compared to free cisplatin, as evidenced by lower serum creatinine and blood urea nitrogen levels, as well as less severe histopathological changes in kidney tissues. Similarly, liposomal encapsulation of cisplatin resulted in a significant reduction in ototoxicity compared to free cisplatin, as indicated by higher auditory brainstem response thresholds. These findings suggest that liposomal encapsulation of cisplatin may be a promising strategy to mitigate its systemic toxicities, thereby improving its therapeutic index.

Chemical peritonitis secondary to intraperitoneal vancomycin. Chemical peritonitis is a rare complication of intraperitoneal vancomycin administration. We present a case of a 62-year-old male with a history of peritonitis undergoing peritoneal dialysis who developed chemical peritonitis following intraperitoneal vancomycin administration for the treatment of a methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) peritonitis. The patient presented with abdominal pain, fever, and cloudy peritoneal fluid, and was found to have elevated inflammatory markers. Imaging studies revealed no evidence of intra-abdominal infection. Cultures grew no organisms, indicating a chemical inflammatory reaction. Vancomycin was discontinued and the patient was started on intraperitoneal daptomycin. The patient's symptoms improved, and repeat peritoneal fluid analysis showed resolution of the inflammatory response. Chemical peritonitis is a diagnosis of exclusion, and clinicians should maintain a high index of suspicion in patients with peritoneal dialysis who present with abdominal pain and peritoneal fluid changes following vancomycin administration. Prompt discontinuation of vancomycin and initiation of alternative antibiotics can lead to resolution of symptoms and prevent unnecessary interventions.

Rhabdomyosarcomas in the head and neck: MR imaging evaluation. Rhabdomyosarcomas (RMS) are rare malignant tumors that commonly occur in the head and neck region in pediatric patients. This study aimed to evaluate the role of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) in the diagnosis and characterization of RMS in the head and neck. 

A retrospective analysis of MRI scans of 35 patients with histologically confirmed RMS was performed. The majority of tumors were observed in the orbit (42.9%), followed by the nasopharynx (20%). The MRI findings revealed well-defined soft tissue masses with heterogenous signal intensity on T1- and T2-weighted images, reflecting the presence of necrosis and hemorrhage. In addition, post-contrast images showed intense enhancement in most cases. Regional lymph node involvement was observed in 31.4% of patients. 

MRI proved to be a valuable tool in the evaluation of RMS in the head and neck, providing important information on tumor location, extent, and involvement of nearby structures. This information is crucial for accurate staging and treatment planning in these patients.

Suggestive evidence that pelvic endometriosis is a progressive disease, whereas deeply infiltrating endometriosis is associated with pelvic pain. Pelvic endometriosis and deeply infiltrating endometriosis are common gynecological conditions that significantly impact the quality of life of affected women. This study aimed to investigate the progression of pelvic endometriosis and its association with pelvic pain. A retrospective analysis of medical records of women diagnosed with endometriosis was conducted, and the severity of endometriosis was graded according to the revised American Society for Reproductive Medicine classification. The results revealed a positive correlation between the severity of pelvic endometriosis and the presence of pelvic pain. Additionally, deeply infiltrating endometriosis was found to be significantly associated with pelvic pain, suggesting a higher likelihood of symptom manifestation in these cases. These findings support the hypothesis that pelvic endometriosis may progress over time and provide valuable insights into the management and treatment of this complex condition. Further research is warranted to explore potential mechanisms underlying the progression of pelvic endometriosis and to develop targeted therapies for symptom alleviation and disease control.

Salivary flow rates in patients with head and neck cancer 0. Salivary flow rates were measured in patients with head and neck cancer using the modified Saxon test. A total of 50 patients were included in the study, with 25 patients having undergone radiation therapy and 25 patients being radiation-naive. The mean salivary flow rate in radiation-naive patients was found to be 1.2 ml/min, while in patients who had received radiation therapy, it was significantly reduced to 0.4 ml/min (p<0.05). Additionally, a significant correlation was observed between salivary flow rates and the severity of xerostomia symptoms, as measured by the Visual Analog Scale (VAS). These findings highlight the detrimental effect of radiation therapy on salivary gland function and emphasize the importance of monitoring and managing xerostomia in head and neck cancer patients.

Gallstone dissolution with methyl tert-butyl ether in 120 patients--efficacy and safety.  Of 612 patients with cholesterol gallbladder stones, 120 were eligible for percutaneous transhepatic litholysis with methyl tert-butyl ether (MTBE).  Puncture of the gallbladder was successful in 117/120 (97. The efficacy and safety of gallstone dissolution with methyl tert-butyl ether (MTBE) were evaluated in a sample of 120 patients with cholesterol gallbladder stones. Out of a total of 612 patients, 120 were deemed eligible for percutaneous transhepatic litholysis with MTBE. Successful puncture of the gallbladder was achieved in 117 out of the 120 patients (97.5% success rate). The dissolution of gallbladder stones was effective in 109 patients (90.8% efficacy rate). Adverse events were reported in 42 patients (35% incidence rate), with the most common being mild to moderate abdominal pain and transient elevation of liver enzymes. No serious complications or deaths were observed during the procedure or the follow-up period. These findings demonstrate the efficacy and acceptable safety profile of MTBE for the dissolution of cholesterol gallbladder stones, providing a potential alternative to surgical intervention in select patients. Further studies are warranted to optimize patient selection and identify predictors of treatment success.

Headaches and multiple sclerosis: a clinical study and review of the literature. Headache is a common symptom in patients with multiple sclerosis (MS), but the relationship between the two is still not well understood. This study aimed to evaluate the prevalence, characteristics, and impact of headaches in patients with MS and to review the existing literature on this topic. A total of 100 patients with MS were included in this cross-sectional study. The prevalence of headaches was found to be 56%, with tension-type headache being the most common type. Headaches were significantly associated with a higher disability score and a higher frequency of relapses. The literature review revealed a complex relationship between headaches and MS, with a bidirectional association and various underlying mechanisms. Overall, headaches are a significant and often overlooked issue in patients with MS, and further research is needed to better understand and manage this comorbidity.

A phase II multi-institutional trial of low-dose N-(phosphonacetyl)-L-aspartate and high-dose 5-fluorouracil as a short-term infusion in the treatment of adenocarcinoma of the pancreas.  A Southwest Oncology Group study. The objective of this phase II multi-institutional trial was to evaluate the efficacy and toxicity of low-dose N-(phosphonacetyl)-L-aspartate (PALA) and high-dose 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) as a short-term infusion in the treatment of adenocarcinoma of the pancreas. A total of 31 patients with metastatic or unresectable locally advanced disease were enrolled in the study conducted by the Southwest Oncology Group. The treatment regimen consisted of PALA administered as a loading dose followed by a continuous infusion over 96 hours, along with 5-FU given as a high-dose 24-hour infusion on days 1 and 2. The results showed an overall response rate of 6% and a disease control rate of 19%. Grade 3 or 4 toxicities were observed in 61% of patients, with the most common being neutropenia, thrombocytopenia, and diarrhea. Although this combination therapy showed limited efficacy, the high incidence of toxicities raises concerns about its feasibility as a treatment option for adenocarcinoma of the pancreas. Further investigation is warranted to explore more effective and tolerable treatment strategies for this disease.

Flow cytometric analysis of DNA content in partial hydatidiform moles with persistent gestational trophoblastic tumor.  Hydatidiform moles may be classified as partial or complete based on genetic and pathologic criteria. This study aims to investigate the DNA content in partial hydatidiform moles (PHMs) with persistent gestational trophoblastic tumor (GTT) using flow cytometric analysis. PHMs are a type of molar pregnancy that is characterized by abnormal growth of placental tissue. GTT refers to the persistent growth of trophoblastic cells after a molar pregnancy. The categorization of hydatidiform moles as partial or complete is based on both genetic and pathological factors. In this study, samples from patients with PHMs and persistent GTT were analyzed to determine their DNA content using flow cytometry. The results shed light on the genetic abnormalities associated with these conditions and contribute to a better understanding of their pathogenesis.

Transitional cell carcinomatous meningitis after M-VAC (methotrexate, vinblastine, doxorubicin, and cisplatin) chemotherapy. Transitional cell carcinomatous meningitis is a rare complication of chemotherapy, especially after treatment with the M-VAC regimen. We report a case of a 58-year-old male who developed meningitis after completing M-VAC chemotherapy for bladder cancer. The patient presented with symptoms suggestive of meningitis, including headache, fever, neck stiffness, and altered mental status. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis revealed increased white blood cells and malignant cells consistent with transitional cell carcinoma. The patient was started on intravenous antibiotics and underwent lumbar punctures for cerebrospinal fluid drainage. Despite aggressive treatment, the patient's condition deteriorated, and he succumbed to the disease. Transitional cell carcinomatous meningitis should be considered in patients with a history of M-VAC chemotherapy presenting with signs and symptoms of meningitis. Early recognition and prompt initiation of treatment are crucial for improving outcomes in this rare and aggressive complication of chemotherapy. Further research is needed to better understand the risk factors and optimal management of this condition.

Fetal death due to nonlethal maternal carbon monoxide poisoning. Carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning during pregnancy is a rare but potentially fatal event for both mother and fetus. We present a case of a 28-year-old pregnant woman who was exposed to nonlethal levels of CO resulting in the death of her fetus. Despite immediate cessation of exposure and administration of appropriate treatment, fetal demise occurred due to severe hypoxia. This case highlights the importance of early recognition and prompt intervention in pregnant women with suspected CO poisoning to prevent adverse outcomes. Additionally, it emphasizes the need for public education on the risks of CO exposure during pregnancy and the importance of proper ventilation and detection in households.

Resolution of inferior vena cava syndrome after embolization of a hepatic adenoma. A case is presented of a patient with inferior vena cava (IVC) syndrome caused by a hepatic adenoma, which was successfully treated using embolization therapy. The patient presented with symptoms of IVC syndrome, including lower extremity swelling, abdominal pain, and venous congestion. Imaging studies revealed a large hepatic adenoma compressing the IVC. Interventional radiology performed embolization of the hepatic artery supplying the adenoma, resulting in immediate relief of the patient's symptoms. Follow-up imaging demonstrated decreased size of the adenoma and resolution of IVC compression. This case highlights the efficacy of embolization as a treatment option for hepatic adenomas causing IVC syndrome, offering a less invasive alternative to surgical resection.

Prediction of variceal hemorrhage in cirrhosis: a prospective follow-up study. Variceal hemorrhage is a life-threatening complication of cirrhosis, and early identification of patients at high risk for bleeding is crucial for timely intervention. This study aimed to prospectively evaluate clinical and laboratory parameters for predicting variceal hemorrhage in cirrhotic patients. A total of 150 cirrhotic patients without a history of variceal hemorrhage were enrolled and followed up for a median duration of 24 months. Baseline characteristics, liver function tests, platelet count, spleen size, and endoscopic findings were recorded. During the follow-up period, 35 patients (23.3%) experienced variceal hemorrhage. Univariate analysis revealed that Child-Pugh class, platelet count, spleen size, and presence of large esophageal varices were significant predictors of variceal hemorrhage. Multivariate logistic regression analysis identified spleen size (odds ratio 3.41, 95% confidence interval 1.45-8.00, p=0.005) and presence of large esophageal varices (odds ratio 4.27, 95% confidence interval 1.79-10.20, p=0.001) as independent predictors. Combining spleen size and large esophageal varices increased the predictive accuracy (area under the receiver operating characteristic curve 0.79) compared to individual parameters. In conclusion, spleen size and the presence of large esophageal varices are reliable predictors of variceal hemorrhage in cirrhotic patients, providing valuable information for risk stratification and clinical management.

Optimal interpretation of the supine exercise electrocardiogram in patients with right bundle branch block. The interpretation of the supine exercise electrocardiogram (ECG) in patients with right bundle branch block (RBBB) is challenging and often leads to diagnostic uncertainty. This review aimed to provide guidance on the optimal interpretation of the supine exercise ECG in this patient population. RBBB is a common finding on ECG and can be associated with underlying cardiovascular diseases. However, the presence of RBBB on the exercise ECG can complicate the interpretation of ischemic changes, as it can mask or mimic myocardial ischemia. The review discusses the various electrocardiographic patterns seen in RBBB during exercise testing, including the presence of ST-segment changes, QRS duration, and T-wave abnormalities. It also explores the different diagnostic algorithms proposed to improve the accuracy of detecting myocardial ischemia in patients with RBBB. Ultimately, this review highlights the importance of a comprehensive evaluation, including clinical history and other cardiac imaging modalities, when interpreting the supine exercise ECG in patients with RBBB.

Surgical management of bile duct stones. Bile duct stones are a common cause of biliary obstruction and can lead to serious complications if left untreated. The optimal management of bile duct stones remains controversial, particularly regarding the choice of surgical method. In this abstract, we review the current literature on surgical management of bile duct stones and summarize the different surgical approaches and their outcomes. Several surgical techniques have been described, including open surgery, laparoscopic surgery, and endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography with stone extraction. Each technique has its advantages and disadvantages, and the choice of surgical method should be individualized based on patient characteristics and surgeon expertise. Overall, surgical intervention provides effective and durable treatment for bile duct stones, with low rates of stone recurrence and complications. Further research is needed to compare the long-term outcomes and cost-effectiveness of different surgical approaches for bile duct stones.

Pelvic pain: lessons from anatomy and physiology. Pelvic pain is a common symptom that can be caused by various anatomical and physiological factors. This study aimed to explore the relationship between pelvic pain and the underlying anatomy and physiology of the pelvic region. Anatomically, the pelvis is a complex structure containing various organs such as the uterus, bladder, and rectum, which can all contribute to pelvic pain when dysfunctional. Physiologically, the pelvic floor muscles play a crucial role in maintaining pelvic stability and function, and their dysfunction can lead to pain. Additionally, hormonal imbalances, inflammation, and nerve sensitization may also contribute to pelvic pain. Understanding the anatomy and physiology of the pelvis is essential in diagnosing and managing pelvic pain effectively. Further research is warranted to elucidate the mechanisms underlying pelvic pain and develop targeted therapeutic interventions.

Prevalence and association of asteroid hyalosis with systemic diseases.  We performed a cross-sectional study of 12,205 patients, which identified 101 patients (0. 1%) with asteroid hyalosis. The mean age of these patients was 68.3 years, and the majority were male (56.4%). Among the patients with asteroid hyalosis, 42.6% had at least one systemic disease. The most common systemic diseases associated with asteroid hyalosis were hypertension (21.8%), diabetes mellitus (15.8%), and cardiovascular disease (12.9%). Interestingly, there was a significant association between asteroid hyalosis and age, with an odds ratio of 1.09 (95% CI 1.06-1.12) for every one-year increase in age. Additionally, male gender was found to be significantly associated with asteroid hyalosis, with an odds ratio of 1.75 (95% CI 1.27-2.40) compared to females. These findings suggest that asteroid hyalosis may be a marker for systemic diseases, particularly in older individuals and males. Further research is needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and clinical implications of this association.

Ponderal index as a predictor of postoperative complications.  Four hundred sixty-eight patients undergoing elective surgery were prospectively followed for the development of postoperative complications. The Authors evaluated the utility of ponderal index as a predictor of postoperative complications in 468 patients undergoing elective surgery. Ponderal index, calculated as the weight in kilograms divided by height in meters cubed, was measured preoperatively. Postoperative complications, including wound infections, pneumonia, urinary tract infections, and surgical site complications, were recorded. The results showed that patients with a higher ponderal index had a significantly higher incidence of postoperative complications compared to those with a lower ponderal index (p<0.05). Furthermore, multivariate analysis indicated that higher ponderal index was independently associated with an increased risk of postoperative complications (p<0.05). Therefore, ponderal index may serve as a useful predictor of postoperative complications in patients undergoing elective surgery, allowing for preoperative risk stratification and optimization of perioperative care. Further studies are needed to validate these findings and determine the clinical implications of using ponderal index in the surgical setting.

Evaluating oxygen delivery and oxygen utilization with mixed venous oxygen saturation monitoring: a case study approach. Monitoring oxygen delivery and utilization is crucial for optimizing patient outcomes in critical care settings. This case study aimed to evaluate the utility of mixed venous oxygen saturation (SvO2) monitoring in assessing oxygen delivery and utilization in a patient with a severe respiratory illness. A 68-year-old male with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) was admitted to the intensive care unit. SvO2 monitoring was initiated using a pulmonary artery catheter to assess the global balance between oxygen delivery and consumption. Serial measurements of SvO2, along with other hemodynamic parameters, were recorded over the course of the patient's treatment. SvO2 proved to be a valuable tool in guiding therapeutic interventions, such as adjusting ventilator settings and optimizing fluid resuscitation. This case study highlights the importance of continuous SvO2 monitoring in critically ill patients and its potential to improve clinical management and patient outcomes.

Computerized tomography as an indicator of isolated mesenteric injury.  A comparison with peritoneal lavage. Isolated mesenteric injury, often caused by blunt abdominal trauma, can be challenging to diagnose. This study aimed to assess the utility of computerized tomography (CT) as an indicator of isolated mesenteric injury compared to peritoneal lavage. A retrospective analysis was conducted on patients presenting with blunt abdominal trauma and suspected isolated mesenteric injury. CT scans were reviewed by two independent radiologists who were blinded to the patients' clinical course. The results were compared to the findings obtained from peritoneal lavage. Of the 50 patients included in the study, 25 had confirmed isolated mesenteric injury. CT had a sensitivity of 92% and a specificity of 86% in detecting isolated mesenteric injury. The positive and negative predictive values were 84% and 94%, respectively. In contrast, peritoneal lavage had a sensitivity of 68% and a specificity of 92%. This study suggests that CT can be a reliable diagnostic tool for identifying isolated mesenteric injury, providing a less invasive alternative to peritoneal lavage.

Economic barriers to the use of oral rehydration therapy. Oral rehydration therapy (ORT) is a cost-effective and life-saving treatment for diarrheal diseases in low-resource settings. However, there are economic barriers that hinder its widespread use. This study aimed to identify and analyze the economic barriers to the use of ORT in these settings. A literature review was conducted to gather information on the economic factors influencing the utilization of ORT. The findings revealed several key barriers, including high costs of ORT solutions, lack of affordability for individuals and healthcare systems, limited availability and accessibility of ORT supplies, and inadequate reimbursement mechanisms. Additionally, cultural beliefs, misconceptions, and lack of awareness about ORT contribute to its underutilization. To overcome these economic barriers, targeted interventions should focus on reducing the cost of ORT solutions, improving affordability through subsidy programs, strengthening supply chains, and implementing education campaigns to raise awareness and promote proper use of ORT in low-resource settings.

Value of monoclonal anti-myeloperoxidase (MPO7) for diagnosing acute leukaemia.  The expression of myeloperoxidase (MPO) was studied in 100 cases of acute leukaemia (83 with acute myeloid leukaemia (AML) and 17 acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL) by both a conventional cytochemical method and the immunocytochemical antiperoxidase (APAAP) technique using the monoclonal antibody MPO7. The aim of this study was to evaluate the utility of monoclonal anti-myeloperoxidase (MPO7) in the diagnosis of acute leukemia. One hundred cases of acute leukemia, including 83 cases of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and 17 cases of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), were included in the study. The expression of myeloperoxidase (MPO) was assessed using both conventional cytochemical methods and the immunocytochemical antiperoxidase (APAAP) technique with the monoclonal antibody MPO7. MPO7 exhibited a high sensitivity (96%) and specificity (100%) in detecting MPO expression in AML cases, whereas conventional cytochemical methods showed a sensitivity of 94% and a specificity of 98%. In ALL cases, MPO7 demonstrated a sensitivity of 53% and a specificity of 100%, while conventional cytochemical methods had a sensitivity of 47% and a specificity of 100%. These findings suggest that MPO7 is a valuable tool for the accurate diagnosis of acute leukemia, particularly in AML cases.

Lyme disease: recommendations for diagnosis and treatment The incidence and the endemic range of Lyme disease in the United States have increased steadily since the disease was originally recognized in Lyme, Connecticut, in 1975. Lyme disease is a tick-borne illness caused by the bacterium Borrelia burgdorferi. As the incidence and endemic range of the disease continue to rise in the United States, it is crucial for healthcare professionals to be knowledgeable about its diagnosis and treatment. This abstract provides recommendations for both aspects. Diagnosis involves a combination of clinical evaluation, serologic testing, and consideration of epidemiologic factors. Treatment typically involves antibiotics, with doxycycline being the first-line agent for adults and children above 8 years, while amoxicillin or cefuroxime is preferred for children younger than 8 years or pregnant women. Early detection and appropriate treatment are essential to prevent complications and promote optimal patient outcomes.

Heart disease in Asians and Pacific-Islanders, Hispanics, and Native Americans. Heart disease is a leading cause of mortality among various ethnic groups, including Asians and Pacific-Islanders, Hispanics, and Native Americans. This study aimed to investigate the prevalence and risk factors associated with heart disease in these populations. Through a comprehensive review of existing literature and analysis of available data, it was observed that these ethnic groups exhibit a higher prevalence of heart disease compared to the general population. Additionally, traditional risk factors such as hypertension, diabetes, obesity, and smoking were found to contribute significantly to the increased incidence of heart disease in these populations. Further research is needed to better understand the underlying mechanisms and develop targeted prevention and management strategies for reducing the burden of heart disease in these populations.

The molecular biology of acute myeloid leukemia. Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a heterogeneous hematological malignancy characterized by the uncontrolled proliferation of myeloid precursor cells in the bone marrow. Recent advancements in molecular biology have shed light on the underlying genetic and molecular alterations that drive AML pathogenesis. Mutations in genes such as FLT3, NPM1, DNMT3A, and IDH1/2 have been identified as recurrent genetic abnormalities in AML, contributing to aberrant signaling pathways, altered epigenetic regulation, and impaired differentiation. Additionally, chromosomal aberrations, including translocations and inversions involving genes such as RUNX1, CEBPA, and MLL, further contribute to the dysregulation of key cellular processes. This comprehensive review aims to summarize the current understanding of the molecular biology of AML, highlighting the key genetic alterations, their impact on cellular processes, and their potential as therapeutic targets. Further research in this field is required to fully comprehend the complex biology of AML and develop novel targeted therapies for improved patient outcomes.

Recovery from vegetative state of six months' duration associated with Sinemet (levodopa/carbidopa). This case report describes a remarkable recovery from a vegetative state after six months of treatment with Sinemet (levodopa/carbidopa). The patient, a 45-year-old male who suffered a severe traumatic brain injury, showed no signs of consciousness or purposeful movement prior to the initiation of Sinemet. However, within weeks of starting the medication, he began to display improvements in his level of arousal and responsiveness. Over the course of the six-month treatment period, the patient regained the ability to follow simple commands and exhibit purposeful movement. These findings suggest that Sinemet may have played a crucial role in facilitating neurological recovery in this patient. Further research is needed to determine the underlying mechanisms and potential benefits of Sinemet in the management of individuals in a prolonged vegetative state.

The anatomical basis of the caecocentral scotoma. The caecocentral scotoma is a visual field defect characterized by a blind spot in the central portion of the visual field, with intact peripheral vision. This study aimed to explore the anatomical basis of the caecocentral scotoma using imaging techniques and histological analysis. Retrospective analysis of patients with caecocentral scotoma revealed a consistent lesion involving the temporal lobe, specifically the visual cortex and optic radiation. Magnetic resonance imaging showed focal lesions in the ventral and dorsal stream pathways, including the inferior occipitotemporal fasciculus, the lingual gyrus, and the optic radiations. Histological analysis confirmed the presence of gliosis in these regions. Additionally, electroretinography measurements revealed abnormal responses in the affected eyes, suggesting a dysfunction in retinal ganglion cells. These findings provide evidence for a specific anatomical basis for the caecocentral scotoma, which may aid in the diagnosis and management of patients with this visual field defect.

Endoscopic findings in Yersinia enterocolitica enterocolitis.  The endoscopic findings in the colon and terminal ileum in eight cases of Yersinia enterocolitica enterocolitis infection were studied. We present a study of the endoscopic findings in the colon and terminal ileum of eight cases of Yersinia enterocolitica enterocolitis infection. The patients, aged between 18 and 38 years, presented with symptoms of acute enterocolitis, including fever, abdominal pain, and diarrhea. All of them had positive stool cultures for Yersinia enterocolitica. Endoscopic examination revealed characteristic findings, including mucosal edema, erythema, and ulcerations in the colon and terminal ileum. Pseudomembranes were not observed. Biopsy specimens showed acute inflammatory changes with infiltration of neutrophils. These endoscopic findings are consistent with the diagnosis of Yersinia enterocolitica enterocolitis. Recognition of these characteristic findings may aid in the early diagnosis and appropriate management of this infection. Further studies are warranted to better understand the endoscopic features and clinical implications of Yersinia enterocolitica enterocolitis.

Surgical resection of intrinsic brain stem lesions: an overview. Intrinsic brain stem lesions pose a significant challenge for surgical resection due to the vital structures and delicate neural connections in this region. This study aims to provide an overview of surgical resection techniques and outcomes for such lesions. A comprehensive literature search was conducted, and articles reporting surgical resection of intrinsic brain stem lesions were included. Different surgical approaches, including the supracerebellar, infratentorial, and translabyrinthine approaches, were analyzed. The overall surgical success rate varied depending on the lesion type and location, ranging from 50% to 90%. Complications such as neurological deficits, cerebellar mutism, and hydrocephalus were reported in some cases. Preoperative imaging, intraoperative monitoring, and advancements in surgical navigation techniques have improved surgical outcomes and patient safety. Individual patient characteristics, such as age, tumor histology, and location, should be carefully considered when selecting the optimal surgical approach for intrinsic brain stem lesions. Further prospective studies with larger sample sizes are needed to determine the long-term outcomes and refine surgical techniques for these complex lesions.

Overt hepatic encephalopathy precipitated by zinc deficiency. We present a case of a 56-year-old man with hepatic encephalopathy (HE) that was precipitated by zinc deficiency. The patient had a history of chronic alcohol abuse and liver cirrhosis. He presented with altered mental status, asterixis, and elevated ammonia levels. Laboratory investigations revealed low zinc levels and elevated liver enzymes. HE was diagnosed, and the patient was started on lactulose and zinc supplementation. His mental status improved gradually over a period of weeks, and his ammonia levels normalized. HE precipitated by zinc deficiency is a rare but important cause of altered mental status in patients with liver cirrhosis. Early recognition and prompt treatment with zinc supplementation can lead to significant clinical improvement. Clinicians should consider zinc deficiency in the differential diagnosis of HE, especially in patients with risk factors such as alcohol abuse and malnutrition.

The cancer experience in the Framingham Heart Study cohort.  The almost 40-year records of The Framingham Heart Study (FHS) cohort were reviewed to establish the cancer experience of this noninstitutionalized group of white subjects. In total, 5,432 individuals aged 30 to 62 years were included in the analysis. Over the course of the study, 1,238 cases of cancer were identified, resulting in an overall incidence rate of 23 per 1,000 person-years. The most common cancers observed were lung, breast, colorectal, and prostate cancer. When stratified by gender, lung cancer was the leading cancer in men, while breast cancer was the leading cancer in women. Additionally, age was found to be a significant risk factor for cancer development, with the incidence rate increasing progressively with age. These findings provide valuable insights into the cancer burden in a predominantly white, community-based population, highlighting the need for continued surveillance and preventive measures.

Prognostic indicators of the resolution of nonimmune hydrops fetalis and survival of the fetus. Nonimmune hydrops fetalis is a rare condition characterized by abnormal fluid accumulation in two or more fetal compartments in the absence of maternal-fetal blood group incompatibility. Prognostic indicators for resolution of nonimmune hydrops fetalis and fetal survival are crucial for appropriate management and counseling. In this retrospective study, we analyzed the clinical records of 78 cases of nonimmune hydrops fetalis to identify prognostic indicators. Factors such as gestational age at diagnosis, the presence of structural anomalies, severity of hydrops, and specific etiologies were evaluated. Our results showed that earlier gestational age at diagnosis, absence of structural anomalies, milder hydrops, and idiopathic etiology were associated with a higher likelihood of resolution and improved fetal survival. Conversely, factors such as advanced gestational age, presence of structural anomalies, severe hydrops, and chromosomal abnormalities were associated with a poorer prognosis. This study provides valuable insights into prognostic indicators for the resolution of nonimmune hydrops fetalis, aiding clinicians in making informed decisions regarding management and counseling of affected pregnancies.

Computed tomography in the evaluation of the aorta in patients sustaining blunt chest trauma.  Computed tomography is used with increasing frequency to evaluate blunt chest trauma. Blunt chest trauma is a common cause of aortic injury and the evaluation of aortic injury is crucial in the management of these patients. This study aimed to determine the role of computed tomography (CT) in the evaluation of the aorta in patients with blunt chest trauma. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 100 patients who presented with blunt chest trauma and underwent CT imaging. The CT images were reviewed and the presence of aortic injury was assessed. Out of the 100 patients, 25% were found to have aortic injury on CT scan. CT scan demonstrated a sensitivity of 85% and a specificity of 95% for detecting aortic injury. Furthermore, CT scan accurately identified the location and severity of aortic injury in these patients. Therefore, CT scan plays a significant role in the evaluation of the aorta in patients sustaining blunt chest trauma, aiding in prompt and appropriate management decisions.

Gastro-oesophageal reflux during elective laparoscopy. Gastro-oesophageal reflux (GER) is a common problem encountered during laparoscopic surgery, and it may lead to various complications. This study aimed to evaluate the prevalence and risk factors associated with GER during elective laparoscopy. A total of 100 patients undergoing elective laparoscopic procedures were included in the study. GER was diagnosed using pH monitoring, and its prevalence was found to be 24%. Female gender, obesity, and the presence of hiatal hernia were identified as significant risk factors for GER during laparoscopy. Furthermore, patients with GER had a longer duration of surgery and higher intraabdominal pressure compared to non-GER patients. This study highlights the importance of identifying patients at risk for GER during elective laparoscopy and implementing preventive measures to minimize complications associated with GER.

Mucinous cystadenoma of the lung. Mucinous cystadenoma of the lung is a rare benign tumor that arises from the bronchial glands. We report a case of a 55-year-old male who presented with cough and hemoptysis. Imaging studies revealed a large cystic lesion in the left lower lobe of the lung. Surgical resection was performed, and histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of mucinous cystadenoma. The tumor was composed of cystic dilatation of bronchial glands lined by a layer of mucin-secreting columnar cells, surrounded by a fibrous stroma. The patient had an uneventful postoperative course and remained asymptomatic during the follow-up period. This case highlights the importance of considering mucinous cystadenoma as a differential diagnosis in patients presenting with cystic lung lesions.

Alzheimer's disease and related disorders in state mental hospitals: data from a nationwide survey. Alzheimer's disease and related disorders pose a significant burden on state mental hospitals. This study aimed to assess the prevalence and management of these conditions in such facilities through a nationwide survey. Data from 50 state mental hospitals were collected and analyzed. The results showed that Alzheimer's disease and related disorders accounted for a substantial portion of the patient population, with a prevalence of 32%. The majority of hospitals reported having specialized units or programs for the management of these conditions. However, there were variations in the availability and utilization of specific interventions and medications. Overall, this study emphasizes the need for improved resources and standardized approaches to address the challenges posed by Alzheimer's disease and related disorders in state mental hospitals.

A controlled trial of psychological treatment for the irritable bowel syndrome. This study aims to investigate the efficacy of psychological treatment for irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) through a controlled trial. Forty-eight patients diagnosed with IBS were randomly assigned to either a treatment group or a control group. The treatment group received a comprehensive psychological treatment program consisting of psychoeducation, stress management techniques, and cognitive-behavioral therapy, while the control group received standard medical management alone.

The results showed that the psychological treatment significantly reduced the severity and frequency of IBS symptoms compared to the control group. Additionally, patients in the treatment group experienced improved quality of life and reduced levels of anxiety and depression. The treatment effects were sustained at a three-month follow-up assessment.

These findings suggest that psychological interventions can be effective in reducing symptoms and improving overall well-being in patients with IBS. They highlight the importance of a multidisciplinary approach to managing IBS, integrating psychological treatments alongside medical management for optimal outcomes. Further research is needed to determine the long-term efficacy and cost-effectiveness of psychological interventions in the management of IBS.

Risk factors for white matter changes detected by magnetic resonance imaging in the elderly. White matter changes (WMC) detected by magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) are commonly observed in elderly individuals and have been associated with various risk factors. In this study, we aimed to identify specific risk factors for WMC in elderly participants. A total of 200 subjects aged 65 years and above underwent brain MRI scans, and the presence and severity of WMC were assessed using a standardized visual rating scale. We found that hypertension, diabetes, smoking, and advanced age were significantly associated with a higher prevalence and severity of WMC. These findings highlight the importance of managing modifiable risk factors to reduce the burden of WMC in the elderly population.

Radiologic staging of chest in testicular seminoma. Testicular seminoma is one of the most common testicular tumors in young males. Although it has a highly curable prognosis, the management and staging of this malignancy remain important. In this study, we aimed to evaluate the utility of radiologic staging of the chest in testicular seminoma. We retrospectively analyzed the medical records of 150 patients diagnosed with testicular seminoma between 2005 and 2020. Chest imaging, including computed tomography scans and chest X-rays, were performed for all patients. We found that chest imaging identified chest metastases in 23 patients (15.3%). Among these, 18 patients had isolated lung metastases, while 5 patients had concurrent lung and mediastinal lymph node involvement. Our results suggest that routine chest imaging is crucial in the staging and management of testicular seminoma, as it can detect early chest metastases and guide treatment decisions.

Autosomal recessive chronic granulomatous disease caused by deletion at a dinucleotide repeat. Autosomal recessive chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) is a rare primary immunodeficiency disorder characterized by a defect in the NADPH oxidase enzyme complex, leading to impaired generation of reactive oxygen species by phagocytes. The genetic basis of CGD has been extensively studied, with mutations in CYBB, NCF1, NCF2, and NCF4 genes being the most common causes. In this study, we report a unique case of autosomal recessive CGD caused by a deletion at a dinucleotide repeat in the CYBB gene. The patient presented with recurrent severe infections and granulomatous inflammation involving various organs. Immunological investigations revealed a defect in oxidative burst activity in neutrophils and monocytes. Genetic analysis identified a homozygous deletion at the (GT)n repeat site in exon 6 of the CYBB gene. This deletion resulted in a frame-shift mutation in the CYBB mRNA, leading to a premature termination codon. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report of a dinucleotide repeat deletion causing autosomal recessive CGD. Further functional studies are warranted to elucidate the precise molecular mechanism underlying this unique genetic defect and its impact on NADPH oxidase activity.

Treatment of chronic moccasin-type tinea pedis with terbinafine: a double-blind, placebo-controlled trial. Chronic moccasin-type tinea pedis is a common fungal infection characterized by a dry, scaly, and hyperkeratotic lesion on the plantar aspect of the foot. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of terbinafine in the treatment of this condition. In a double-blind, placebo-controlled trial, 100 patients with chronic moccasin-type tinea pedis were randomized to receive either terbinafine 250 mg daily or placebo for 12 weeks. The primary outcome measure was complete clinical cure, defined as absence of scaling, redness, and pruritus at the end of treatment. Secondary outcomes included mycological cure and adverse events. The results showed that terbinafine was significantly more effective than placebo in achieving complete clinical cure (p < 0.001). Mycological cure rates were also superior in the terbinafine group (p = 0.003). Adverse events were minimal and comparable between the two groups. In conclusion, terbinafine is a safe and effective treatment option for chronic moccasin-type tinea pedis.

Gentamicin iontophoresis in the treatment of bacterial otitis externa in the guinea pig model.  Pseudomonas otitis externa is one of the most common infections treated by otolaryngologists. Bacterial otitis externa is a common infection in otolaryngology practice, with Pseudomonas species being a frequent causative agent. The aim of this study was to evaluate the efficacy of gentamicin iontophoresis in the treatment of Pseudomonas otitis externa using the guinea pig model. A total of 24 guinea pigs were divided into three groups: control group, gentamicin iontophoresis group, and gentamicin topical application group. Pseudomonas aeruginosa was inoculated into the external ear canals of all animals to induce otitis externa. The animals in the gentamicin iontophoresis group received gentamicin solution via iontophoresis, while those in the topical application group received topical gentamicin drops. The control group received no treatment. Clinical and histopathological evaluations were performed at the end of the study. The results showed that gentamicin iontophoresis was more effective in reducing inflammation, eradicating bacterial infection, and promoting epithelialization compared to topical application. Therefore, gentamicin iontophoresis could be considered as a potential treatment option for bacterial otitis externa caused by Pseudomonas species.

Choroid plexus tumors in the breast cancer-sarcoma syndrome. The breast cancer-sarcoma syndrome is a rare condition characterized by the development of breast cancer and sarcomas in the same individual or in close relatives. In some cases, choroid plexus tumors have been reported in association with this syndrome. We present a case of a 45-year-old female with a history of breast cancer who was found to have a choroid plexus tumor on imaging studies. The patient underwent surgical resection of the tumor, and histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis. To our knowledge, this is the first reported case of a choroid plexus tumor in association with the breast cancer-sarcoma syndrome. Further studies are needed to better understand the underlying mechanisms and establish appropriate management guidelines for this rare association.

Major histocompatibility complex antigen expression in the affected tissues in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.  Monoclonal antibody immunocytochemistry was used to examine spinal cord and muscle in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis for changes that would indicate ongoing or potential immune activity. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a progressive neurodegenerative disease characterized by the selective degeneration of motor neurons in the spinal cord and brain. Although the etiology of ALS remains largely unknown, there is increasing evidence suggesting a potential role of immune dysregulation in the pathogenesis of the disease. In this study, we investigated the expression of major histocompatibility complex (MHC) antigens, which play a crucial role in immune responses, in affected tissues of ALS patients. Monoclonal antibody immunocytochemistry was performed on spinal cord and muscle specimens obtained from ALS patients. Our results showed increased expression of MHC antigens in both spinal cord and muscle tissues, indicating ongoing immune activity in these regions. Moreover, the degree of MHC antigen expression correlated with the severity of motor neuron loss, suggesting a potential link between immune activation and neuronal degeneration. These findings provide further insights into the underlying mechanisms of ALS and suggest potential therapeutic targets for the modulation of immune responses in this devastating disease.

Natural history of moderate aortic stenosis.  The natural history of severe, symptomatic aortic stenosis has been well documented. However, limited information is available regarding the natural history of moderate aortic stenosis. This study aimed to investigate the long-term prognosis and progression of moderate aortic stenosis in a cohort of patients. 

A total of 112 patients with moderate aortic stenosis were included in the study. Baseline characteristics, including age, gender, and comorbidities, were recorded. Echocardiographic parameters, such as aortic valve area, peak and mean transvalvular gradients, and left ventricular function, were also assessed. 

Follow-up was conducted for a mean duration of 5 years, during which clinical events were monitored. The primary endpoint of the study was a composite of cardiac death, need for aortic valve replacement, or development of severe aortic stenosis. 

Results showed that 37% of patients reached the primary endpoint during the follow-up period. The annual incidence rate of reaching the primary endpoint was 8.2%. Older age, female gender, and the presence of comorbidities were identified as risk factors for adverse outcomes. 

In conclusion, moderate aortic stenosis is associated with a significant risk of adverse clinical events. These findings highlight the importance of close monitoring and timely intervention in patients with moderate aortic stenosis to prevent disease progression and improve patient outcomes.

The effect of omental pedicle graft transfer on spinal microcirculation and laminectomy membrane formation.  The properties of the omentum and its effect on spinal neurologic disease was investigated. This study aimed to evaluate the effect of omental pedicle graft transfer on spinal microcirculation and laminectomy membrane formation. Twenty-five patients with spinal neurologic disease underwent laminectomy and were divided into two groups: the omental graft group and the control group. The omental graft group received omental pedicle graft transfer during laminectomy, while the control group did not. Microcirculation in the spinal cord was assessed using laser Doppler flowmetry, and laminectomy membrane formation was evaluated using histological analysis. Results showed that omental graft transfer significantly improved spinal microcirculation and inhibited laminectomy membrane formation. These findings suggest that omental pedicle graft transfer may be a promising technique to enhance spinal neurologic recovery and prevent complications following laminectomy.

Early-onset dementia and extrapyramidal disease: clinicopathological variant of Gerstmann-Straussler-Scheinker or Alzheimer's disease? A case of progressive dementia and extrapyramidal signs beginning at age 29, with a ten year course until death, is presented. The case of a patient presenting with early-onset dementia and extrapyramidal signs at age 29 is discussed in this study. The patient exhibited a progressive decline in cognitive function and motor skills over a span of ten years until death. The clinicopathological variant of the disease was examined, and the question of whether it was a manifestation of Gerstmann-Straussler-Scheinker or Alzheimer's disease was explored. The findings suggest a correlation between the two, but further research is needed to elucidate the precise nature of this association. This case highlights the importance of early recognition and diagnosis in managing these neurodegenerative diseases.

Management of macular puckers associated with retinal angiomas. Macular puckers are commonly associated with retinal angiomas, which can cause visual disturbances and affect patients' quality of life. This study aimed to evaluate the management of macular puckers associated with retinal angiomas. A retrospective review was conducted on ten patients who presented with macular puckers and retinal angiomas. All patients underwent a comprehensive ophthalmic examination, including optical coherence tomography (OCT), fluorescein angiography (FA), and visual acuity assessment. Surgical intervention, such as vitrectomy with epiretinal membrane peeling, was performed in eight patients, while two patients opted for observation. The surgical group showed significant improvement in visual acuity, reduction in central macular thickness, and resolution of retinal traction on OCT. Overall, surgical intervention appears to be an effective treatment option for macular puckers associated with retinal angiomas, improving visual outcomes and alleviating symptoms. Further studies with larger sample sizes are warranted to validate these findings.

Surgical results of intrathoracic gastric volvulus complicating hiatal hernia.  From 1981 to 1988, 138 patients with hiatal hernia were treated surgically at our centre. Hiatal hernia is a common condition characterized by the protrusion of the stomach through the diaphragmatic hiatus. Gastric volvulus, a potentially life-threatening complication, occurs when the stomach twists upon itself, leading to compromised blood supply and potential strangulation. In this study, we present the surgical outcomes of 138 patients with hiatal hernia, including those with gastric volvulus.

From 1981 to 1988, all patients underwent surgical intervention at our center. The surgical approach involved reduction of the herniated stomach, repair of the diaphragmatic defect, and, in cases of gastric volvulus, correction of the twist. Concurrent fundoplication was performed in patients with significant gastroesophageal reflux disease.

Of the 138 patients, 17 presented with gastric volvulus. Among these, 14 underwent emergent surgery due to acute symptoms, while the remaining three had chronic volvulus managed electively. Intraoperative findings revealed various degrees of gastric torsion, with Type III volvulus being the most common (n=9).

Overall, surgical intervention proved successful in all cases, with complete resolution of symptoms and no major postoperative complications. This study highlights the importance of early recognition and surgical management of gastric volvulus in patients with hiatal hernia.

Obesity and vaginal hysterectomy. Obesity is a well-established risk factor for various surgical complications. However, its impact on vaginal hysterectomy outcomes remains unclear. In this retrospective study, we aimed to evaluate the association between obesity and perioperative complications in women undergoing vaginal hysterectomy. We included 300 women who underwent vaginal hysterectomy between 2015 and 2020. They were categorized into two groups based on their body mass index (BMI): non-obese (BMI < 30 kg/m^2) and obese (BMI  30 kg/m^2). We found that obese women had a significantly higher incidence of perioperative complications, including surgical site infection, wound dehiscence, and urinary tract infection, compared to non-obese women. These findings emphasize the importance of careful consideration and management of obese patients undergoing vaginal hysterectomy to reduce postoperative complications.

Experience with the use of coronary autoperfusion catheter during complicated angioplasty. The use of coronary autoperfusion catheter during complicated angioplasty procedures has been reported to improve myocardial blood flow and reduce the risk of complications. This retrospective study aimed to evaluate the experiences with the use of coronary autoperfusion catheter in 45 patients undergoing complicated angioplasty. The study included patients who had total occlusions, severe calcifications, or angioplasty in high-risk locations. The results showed that the use of coronary autoperfusion catheter was associated with improved angiographic outcomes in 82% of patients and no major adverse events were reported. Overall, the study demonstrates the potential benefits of coronary autoperfusion catheter in complicated angioplasty procedures and provides valuable insights for its use in clinical practice.

The role of intracaval filters in patients with COPD and DVT. In patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and deep vein thrombosis (DVT), the use of intracaval filters is controversial. We conducted a retrospective analysis of 50 patients with COPD and DVT who underwent placement of an intracaval filter. The aim of this study was to evaluate the safety and efficacy of intracaval filters in this specific patient population. Our results showed that the use of intracaval filters was associated with a high rate of filter-related complications, including filter migration, fracture, and thrombus formation. Additionally, there was no significant difference in the incidence of recurrent DVT or pulmonary embolism between patients who received an intracaval filter and those who did not. These findings suggest that the routine use of intracaval filters in patients with COPD and DVT may not be justified and should be carefully considered on a case-by-case basis. Further prospective studies are needed to confirm these results.

Differential memory and executive functions in demented patients with Parkinson's and Alzheimer's disease. Dementia is a common and debilitating feature of Parkinson's disease (PD) and Alzheimer's disease (AD). This study aimed to compare differential memory and executive functions in demented patients with PD and AD. Twenty-five patients with PD dementia (PDD), 25 patients with AD, and 25 healthy controls were included in the study. Participants underwent comprehensive neuropsychological assessments measuring memory and executive functions. Results showed that both PDD and AD groups performed significantly worse than healthy controls across all memory and executive function tests. Furthermore, the PDD group performed significantly worse than the AD group in tests assessing executive functions. These findings suggest that PDD and AD exhibit distinct profiles of cognitive impairment, with executive dysfunction being more prominent in PDD. Further research is needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms contributing to these differences.

Intradural spinal cord tumor presenting as a subarachnoid hemorrhage: magnetic resonance imaging diagnosis. Intradural spinal cord tumors are a rare entity and are usually asymptomatic. We present a case of a 55-year-old male who presented with sudden onset severe neck pain radiating to the lower back, associated with headache, vomiting, and altered consciousness. Initial computed tomography scan of the head was unremarkable. However, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the spine showed a subarachnoid hemorrhage extending from the cervical to the lumbar levels, associated with an intradural tumor in the cervical region. The tumor displayed heterogeneous enhancement on post-contrast imaging. A diagnosis of subarachnoid hemorrhage secondary to an intradural spinal cord tumor was made. The patient underwent surgical resection of the tumor and made a good recovery, with resolution of symptoms and no recurrent bleeding on follow-up MRI. This case highlights the importance of considering intradural spinal cord tumors as a differential diagnosis in patients presenting with subarachnoid hemorrhage, and the utility of MRI in diagnosing such lesions.

Essential hypertension, metabolic disorders, and insulin resistance. Essential hypertension is a common medical condition characterized by chronic elevation of blood pressure without an identifiable cause. Metabolic disorders, including obesity, dyslipidemia, and insulin resistance, have been associated with an increased risk of developing essential hypertension. Insulin resistance, a key feature of metabolic syndrome, is characterized by reduced insulin sensitivity and impaired glucose metabolism. It is thought to contribute to the pathogenesis of hypertension through various mechanisms, including endothelial dysfunction, increased sympathetic activity, and sodium retention. This abstract aimed to review the current literature on the relationship between metabolic disorders, insulin resistance, and essential hypertension. Studies have consistently shown that individuals with metabolic disorders and insulin resistance are at an increased risk of developing hypertension. Managing insulin resistance through lifestyle modifications, such as weight reduction, physical activity, and dietary interventions, may have beneficial effects on blood pressure control. Further research is needed to explore the underlying mechanisms and potential targeted therapies for this complex relationship.

Hyponatraemia in patients with cirrhosis. Hyponatraemia is a common electrolyte disturbance in patients with cirrhosis and is associated with increased morbidity and mortality. This retrospective study aims to evaluate the prevalence and risk factors for hyponatraemia in patients with cirrhosis. Medical records of 256 cirrhotic patients admitted to a tertiary hospital over a two-year period were reviewed. The prevalence of hyponatraemia was found to be 38.3%. Multivariate analysis revealed ascites, hepatic encephalopathy, and serum albumin levels as independent risk factors for hyponatraemia. The mortality rate was significantly higher in patients with hyponatraemia compared to those without (17.5% vs. 6.4%). Moreover, patients with hyponatraemia had longer hospital stays and increased rates of complications.
