The outcomes were assessed in terms of functional and aesthetic outcomes, as well as the occurrence of complications. The results showed satisfactory functional and aesthetic outcomes in the majority of patients, with low complication rates. Mandibular reconstruction using titanium plates appears to be a viable option for irradiated patients with mandibular defects.

Apparent reduction in the size of one side of the face associated with a small retrosplenial haemorrhage. We report a case of apparent facial asymmetry in a patient with a small retrosplenial haemorrhage. A 54-year-old female presented with sudden-onset facial drooping and weakness on the left side. Magnetic resonance imaging revealed a small haemorrhage in the retrosplenial region of the brain. The patient's facial asymmetry was attributed to the direct compression of facial nerve fibers by the haemorrhage. No other neurological deficits were observed, and the patient's symptoms resolved with conservative management. Facial asymmetry can be a rare presenting symptom of a small retrosplenial haemorrhage, and clinicians should consider this possibility when evaluating patients with facial weakness. Further studies are needed to explore the underlying mechanisms of facial nerve involvement in cases of retrosplenial haemorrhage.

Work and power in gait of stroke patients. This study aimed to assess the relationship between work and power in the gait of stroke patients. Thirty-five patients with chronic hemiparesis due to stroke were included in the study. Gait analysis was conducted using a motion capture system and force plates to measure spatiotemporal parameters, joint kinematics and kinetics. Work and power were calculated for each lower limb joint during stance phase of gait. The results showed that stroke patients had significantly decreased work and power at the affected side compared to the unaffected side. There was also a significant correlation between work and power at the affected side and walking speed. Additionally, work and power were significantly correlated with muscle strength and motor impairment. These findings suggest that work and power measures can provide valuable information about the functional limitations in stroke patients and may be useful for evaluating the effectiveness of rehabilitation interventions.

Aggressive granulomatous lesions in cementless total hip arthroplasty.  We describe six patients with aggressive granulomatous lesions around cementless total hip prostheses. Aggressive granulomatous lesions in cementless total hip arthroplasty are a rare complication. In this case series, we report six patients who developed such lesions around their cementless total hip prostheses. The lesions presented as painful masses and were diagnosed through histopathological examination. The patients underwent surgical excision of the lesions and all were treated with long-term antibiotics. In addition, one patient required prosthesis revision.

The etiology of these granulomatous reactions remains unclear. It has been suggested that an immunological response to wear particles, infection, or a combination of both could be responsible. In our case series, three patients had evidence of infection, while the remaining three had non-infectious granulomas. Regardless of the etiology, early detection and appropriate management are crucial to prevent further complications and ensure favorable outcomes.

In conclusion, aggressive granulomatous lesions around cementless total hip arthroplasty can occur with variable etiologies. Prompt diagnosis, surgical excision, antibiotic treatment, and, if necessary, prosthesis revision are integral to achieving successful outcomes. Further studies are needed to better understand the pathogenesis and optimal management of these lesions.

Can the blood urea nitrogen/creatinine ratio distinguish upper from lower gastrointestinal bleeding? We wanted to know if the blood urea nitrogen to creatinine (BUN/Cr) ratio could help distinguish upper from lower gastrointestinal bleeding.  We analyzed retrospectively patients admitted to our hospital for gastrointestinal bleeding over the past 5 years. Upper gastrointestinal bleeding (UGIB) and lower gastrointestinal bleeding (LGIB) require different management strategies, making an accurate and prompt diagnosis crucial. This study aimed to determine whether the blood urea nitrogen to creatinine (BUN/Cr) ratio could serve as a differentiating factor between UGIB and LGIB. Retrospective analysis was performed on patients admitted to our hospital with gastrointestinal bleeding over a 5-year period. Data on BUN, Cr, and clinical characteristics were collected. A total of 245 patients were included, with 140 diagnosed with UGIB and 105 with LGIB. The mean BUN/Cr ratio was significantly higher in the UGIB group compared to the LGIB group (p<0.001). Logistic regression analysis revealed that the BUN/Cr ratio was an independent predictor of UGIB (odds ratio: 2.176, 95% confidence interval: 1.480-3.198, p<0.001). In conclusion, the BUN/Cr ratio may serve as a valuable tool in differentiating UGIB from LGIB and assisting in timely management decisions.

Acute syphilitic posterior placoid chorioretinitis.  Six patients with evidence of secondary syphilis presented with visual loss in both eyes caused by large, placoid, yellowish lesions with faded centers at the level of the pigment epithelium in the macula and juxtapapillary areas. All patients had positive serologic tests for syphilis, and cerebrospinal fluid examination revealed an elevated protein level or pleocytosis. None of the patients had a history of ocular symptoms. The visual acuity varied from counting fingers to 20/30. Fluorescein angiography showed early hypofluorescence followed by late hyperfluorescence in the macular lesions, suggestive of leakage from the retinal pigment epithelium. Optical coherence tomography demonstrated disruption of the outer retinal layers in the affected areas. Systemic treatment with penicillin led to resolution of the chorioretinal lesions and improvement in visual acuity in all patients. Acute syphilitic posterior placoid chorioretinitis should be considered in the differential diagnosis of visually significant posterior segment inflammation, particularly in patients with secondary syphilis.

Circadian variations in myocardial ischemia. The objective of this study was to investigate the circadian variations in myocardial ischemia in patients with coronary artery disease (CAD). We monitored continuous electrocardiographic recordings in 100 patients with stable CAD undergoing daily activities for a period of 48 hours. Ischemic episodes were identified by ST segment deviations of at least 1 mm. The occurrence of ischemic episodes was found to exhibit a circadian pattern, with a significant increase during the early morning hours (4am to 10am) compared to other time periods. Furthermore, the ischemic burden, measured as the total duration of ischemic episodes, was higher during the early morning hours compared to other time periods. These findings suggest that there is a significant circadian variation in myocardial ischemia in patients with CAD, with a peak in the early morning hours. The underlying mechanisms contributing to this circadian pattern warrant further investigation.

The immunoperoxidase localization of tumour markers in ovarian cancer: the value of CEA, EMA, cytokeratin and DD9. Ovarian cancer is a significant cause of morbidity and mortality, making accurate diagnosis essential for effective treatment. In this study, we investigated the immunoperoxidase localization of tumour markers carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), epithelial membrane antigen (EMA), cytokeratin, and DD9 in ovarian cancer patients. Tissue samples from 35 ovarian cancer cases were analyzed using immunohistochemical staining techniques. CEA, EMA, cytokeratin, and DD9 were found to be expressed in 80%, 65.7%, 88.6%, and 34.3% of cases, respectively. Co-expression of multiple markers was also observed. Synchronous expression of CEA and EMA was most common, occurring in 51.4% of cases. Additionally, cytokeratin and DD9 co-expression was present in 14.3% of cases. These findings suggest that immunoperoxidase localization of CEA, EMA, cytokeratin, and DD9 can aid in the accurate diagnosis of ovarian cancer. Furthermore, the identification of co-expression patterns may provide insight into the molecular mechanisms underlying ovarian cancer progression and potential therapeutic targets.

Fibromyalgia in human immunodeficiency virus infection. Fibromyalgia is a chronic pain disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain, fatigue, sleep disturbances, and cognitive impairments. It has been associated with various medical conditions, including human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection. This study aimed to investigate the prevalence and clinical characteristics of fibromyalgia in individuals with HIV. A total of X HIV-positive individuals were included in the study, with X% of them meeting the criteria for fibromyalgia. The prevalence of fibromyalgia in HIV-infected individuals was significantly higher compared to the general population. Additionally, HIV-infected individuals with fibromyalgia had poorer quality of life, increased pain severity, and higher levels of depression and anxiety compared to those without fibromyalgia. These findings suggest a strong association between HIV infection and fibromyalgia, highlighting the need for comprehensive management strategies to address the complex symptomatology and improve the overall well-being of this patient population.

Radical vulvectomy with partial rectal resection and temporary colostomy as primary therapy for selected patients with vulvar carcinoma. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of radical vulvectomy with partial rectal resection and temporary colostomy as the primary therapy for selected patients with vulvar carcinoma. A total of 15 patients with vulvar carcinoma were included in the study. All patients underwent radical vulvectomy with partial rectal resection and temporary colostomy. The surgical procedure was successful in all patients, with complete resection of the tumor achieved. The mean follow-up period was 24 months. The overall survival rate at 2 years was 80%, and the disease-free survival rate was 60%. Postoperative complications occurred in 40% of the patients, including wound infections and colostomy-related complications. However, these complications were manageable and did not significantly affect the overall outcomes. Radical vulvectomy with partial rectal resection and temporary colostomy can be considered as an effective and safe primary therapy for selected patients with vulvar carcinoma, providing good oncological outcomes and acceptable morbidity. Further studies with larger sample sizes are warranted to confirm these findings.

Cytogenetic damage induced by folate deficiency in mice is enhanced by caffeine. This study investigated the effect of caffeine on cytogenetic damage induced by folate deficiency in mice. Male Swiss albino mice were divided into four groups: control, folate deficient, caffeine treated, and folate deficient plus caffeine treated. Folate deficiency was induced by a folate-free diet for 15 weeks, while caffeine was administered orally at a dose of 20mg/kg/day for the same duration. Cytogenetic analysis was performed on bone marrow cells using micronucleus assay and chromosomal aberration analysis. The results showed that folate deficiency increased the frequency of micronuclei and chromosomal aberrations, indicating genotoxicity. Additionally, caffeine treatment further enhanced the cytogenetic damage induced by folate deficiency. These findings suggest that caffeine consumption may aggravate the genotoxic effects of folate deficiency and underscore the importance of adequate folate intake in maintaining genomic stability. Further studies are warranted to elucidate the underlying mechanisms.

Pericardial metastasis from testicular seminoma: appearance and disappearance by echocardiography. We present a rare case of pericardial metastasis from testicular seminoma, which was identified and monitored using echocardiography. A 35-year-old male with a history of testicular seminoma underwent surveillance imaging, which revealed a pericardial mass. Echocardiography was performed to assess the extent and characteristics of the tumor. The echocardiogram showed a well-defined, hypoechoic mass along the pericardial surface, consistent with pericardial metastasis. The patient was started on chemotherapy, and follow-up echocardiography revealed a marked decrease in the size of the pericardial mass. This case highlights the utility of echocardiography in diagnosing and monitoring pericardial metastasis, allowing for timely intervention and treatment of this rare complication.

Heart weights of white men 20 to 39 years of age.  An analysis of 218 autopsy cases. The average heart weight of white men between the ages of 20 to 39 years was analyzed in 218 autopsy cases. The mean heart weight was found to be 311 grams, with a standard deviation of 40 grams. The range of heart weights observed was between 220 grams and 400 grams. No statistically significant difference in heart weight was found between the different age subgroups within the 20 to 39-year age range. However, a positive correlation was observed between heart weight and body weight. The findings from this study contribute to the existing knowledge regarding heart weights in the specific demographic population of young white men. Further research is necessary to explore the potential implications of these findings in the context of cardiovascular health.

Hypertension in African-Americans. Hypertension is a prevalent health condition in African-Americans, and it is associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease and mortality. The etiology of hypertension in this population is complex and multifactorial, involving a combination of genetic, environmental, and socio-economic factors. African-Americans have a higher prevalence of hypertension compared to other racial/ethnic groups, and they also tend to develop hypertension at an earlier age and experience more severe complications. Understanding the underlying mechanisms and identifying effective strategies for prevention and treatment are crucial for reducing the burden of hypertension in African-Americans. This abstract aims to provide an overview of the current knowledge regarding hypertension in African-Americans, including its epidemiology, risk factors, pathophysiology, and management options. Further research is needed to elucidate the specific genetic and environmental factors contributing to hypertension in this population and to develop tailored interventions for prevention and control.

The importance of calcium regulation in toxic cell injury. Calcium plays a crucial role in the regulation of cellular processes and its dysregulation can lead to toxic cell injury. This review article explores the importance of calcium regulation in various pathological conditions associated with toxic cell injury. It discusses the role of calcium in apoptosis, necrosis, and mitochondrial dysfunction, as well as its involvement in the disruption of intracellular signaling pathways and oxidative stress generation. The article also emphasizes the impact of calcium dysregulation in a wide range of diseases such as ischemia-reperfusion injury, neurodegenerative disorders, and cardiovascular diseases. Furthermore, it discusses potential therapeutic strategies targeting calcium regulation to prevent or attenuate toxic cell injury. Overall, understanding and modulating calcium dynamics may offer promising avenues for the development of novel therapeutic interventions in the context of toxic cell injury.

Neurologic and psychiatric manifestations of HIV disease. Neurologic and psychiatric manifestations are common in individuals with HIV disease. These manifestations can occur throughout the course of the disease and can have a significant impact on the patient's quality of life. Neurologic manifestations can range from cognitive impairment and motor deficits to peripheral neuropathy and opportunistic infections such as HIV-associated dementia. Psychiatric manifestations include mood disorders, anxiety, and psychosis, which can be the result of both the direct effects of the virus and the psychosocial stressors associated with living with an incurable disease. Diagnosis and management of these manifestations require a multidisciplinary approach involving neurologists, psychiatrists, and infectious disease specialists. Antiretroviral therapy has significantly improved the outcomes for individuals with HIV, but there is still a need for further research and advancements in treatment options for neurologic and psychiatric manifestations.

Carcinoid tumors.  The authors carried out a retrospective study of 32 patients (23 M, 9 F) with carcinoid tumors who were diagnosed and treated at Harlem Hospital Center, New York, from 1967 to 1988. This study aimed to evaluate the characteristics and management outcomes of patients with carcinoid tumors at Harlem Hospital Center in New York. A total of 32 patients were included, with 23 males and 9 females. The medical records from 1967 to 1988 were retrospectively reviewed.

The results of the study showed that the majority of patients presented with gastrointestinal symptoms, such as abdominal pain and diarrhea. Other common symptoms included flushing and bronchospasm. The histopathological examination revealed that the most common primary site of the tumor was the appendix.

Treatment modalities varied among the patients, with surgical resection being the most common approach. Some patients also underwent chemotherapy and/or radiation therapy. Overall, the majority of patients had a good prognosis, with a 5-year survival rate of 75%. However, patient outcomes were dependent on tumor stage, with advanced-stage tumors being associated with a worse prognosis.

In conclusion, this study provides valuable insights into the characteristics and management outcomes of patients with carcinoid tumors at Harlem Hospital Center. Further research is needed to better understand and improve the management of this rare and challenging malignancy.

Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma of the brain after Hodgkin's disease. Case report. This report presents a rare case of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma (NHL) developing in the brain following a previous diagnosis of Hodgkin's disease (HD). A 32-year-old male, previously treated for stage II HD with chemotherapy and radiotherapy, presented with progressive neurological symptoms. Magnetic resonance imaging revealed a single lesion in the frontal lobe. Histopathological analysis of the resected specimen confirmed the presence of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, a type of NHL. This case highlights the importance of considering secondary malignancies in long-term survivors of HD. Although the development of NHL after HD is rare, it should be considered in patients presenting with new neurological symptoms. Collaboration between oncologists and neurosurgeons is crucial for early detection, accurate diagnosis, and appropriate management of such cases. Further studies are warranted to explore the underlying pathogenesis and optimal treatment strategies for NHL in patients with a history of HD.

Endoscopic management of early supraglottic cancer. The incidence of early supraglottic cancer has been increasing in recent years. Endoscopic techniques are being increasingly used for the management of these cases. We reviewed the outcomes of endoscopic management in a cohort of 50 patients with early supraglottic cancer. The main objective was to evaluate the efficacy and safety of endoscopic treatment. All patients underwent endoscopic evaluation and were staged according to the TNM classification. Most patients (n=40) had stage I disease, while 10 had stage II disease. Endoscopic resection was performed using various techniques, including transoral laser microsurgery and endoscopic cordectomy. The majority of patients (n=45) had complete tumor resection, while 5 had residual disease. The overall local control rate was 92%. Complications included temporary dysphonia in 20% of cases and aspiration pneumonia in 8%. Our findings suggest that endoscopic management is a safe and effective treatment option for early supraglottic cancer, allowing for complete tumor resection and good local control rates. Further studies with larger sample sizes are warranted to confirm these results.

Comparative efficacy of short-term versus long-term cefoxitin prophylaxis against postoperative infection after radical hysterectomy: a prospective study.  We report the results of a randomized, double-blind comparison of short-term versus long-term cefoxitin prophylaxis against infections after radical abdominal hysterectomy with pelvic and para-aortic lymphadenectomy. In this prospective study, the efficacy of short-term versus long-term cefoxitin prophylaxis in preventing postoperative infections after radical hysterectomy was compared. The study included a total of XX patients who underwent radical abdominal hysterectomy with pelvic and para-aortic lymphadenectomy. The patients were randomly assigned to receive either short-term or long-term cefoxitin prophylaxis. The occurrence of postoperative infections, including surgical site infections and systemic infections, was monitored during the postoperative period. The results of the study will provide valuable insights into the optimal duration of cefoxitin prophylaxis for preventing postoperative infections after radical hysterectomy, which can aid in improving patient outcomes and optimizing healthcare resources.

Spindle and epithelioid cell nevus (Spitz nevus). Spindle and epithelioid cell nevus, also known as Spitz nevus, is a benign melanocytic tumor that primarily affects children and adolescents. It is characterized by a dome-shaped papule or nodule on the skin, typically presenting on the face, neck, or extremities. While Spitz nevus shares some histological features with malignant melanoma, it has a distinct clinical presentation and favorable prognosis. The challenge lies in distinguishing Spitz nevus from melanoma, as they can exhibit overlapping clinical and histological features. Dermoscopy and histopathological examination play crucial roles in differentiating these entities. However, there is ongoing debate regarding the optimal management approach for Spitz nevus due to its varied clinical behavior and uncertain malignant potential. Close follow-up and dermatological surveillance are recommended, as some cases may show atypical features or progress to melanoma. Further research is needed to elucidate the optimal management strategies for Spitz nevus and refine its classification.

Leukocyte alkaline phosphatase score in patients with cerebrovascular disease and in patients with primary and metastatic brain tumors. The leukocyte alkaline phosphatase (LAP) score has been widely used as a marker of neutrophil function and activation. This study aimed to investigate the LAP score in patients with cerebrovascular disease (CVD) and in patients with primary and metastatic brain tumors. The LAP score was measured in peripheral blood samples obtained from 100 patients with CVD, 50 patients with primary brain tumors, and 50 patients with metastatic brain tumors. Additionally, 50 healthy individuals were included as controls. The results showed that the LAP score was significantly higher in patients with CVD compared to both groups of brain tumor patients and healthy controls. Furthermore, there was no significant difference in the LAP score between patients with primary brain tumors and those with metastatic brain tumors. These findings suggest that the LAP score may have potential as a diagnostic marker for CVD, but further studies are needed to validate its clinical utility in this context.

Enhanced expression of c-myc and H-ras oncogenes in Letterer-Siwe disease. The aim of this study was to investigate the expression of c-myc and H-ras oncogenes in patients with Letterer-Siwe disease. A total of 30 patients were included in the study. Immunohistochemical staining was performed on skin biopsy specimens to assess the expression of c-myc and H-ras oncogenes. The results showed enhanced expression of both oncogenes in the lesional skin of patients with Letterer-Siwe disease. In particular, c-myc expression was significantly increased compared to normal skin controls. These findings suggest that c-myc and H-ras oncogenes may play a role in the pathogenesis of Letterer-Siwe disease. Further studies are warranted to explore the specific mechanisms by which these oncogenes contribute to the development and progression of this rare disease.

Gastric contents retained in rat stomach following mild irritant exposure contribute to adaptive cytoprotection.  Fluid retained in the gastric lumen immediately preceding the administration of a damaging product will dilute that product and decrease its injurious capacity. In this study, we investigated the role of gastric contents in adaptive cytoprotection following mild irritant exposure. Male rats were divided into two groups: one group received mild irritant exposure by administration of 0.6 M HCl, and the other group served as controls. Gastric contents were collected immediately before the administration of the irritant and analyzed for pH and volume. The results showed that the gastric contents retained in the stomach prior to the administration of the irritant significantly affected its injurious capacity. Dilution of the irritant by the retained gastric fluid resulted in decreased gastric injury in the experimental group compared to the control group. Our findings suggest that the presence of gastric contents in the stomach before exposure to damaging products plays a crucial role in adaptive cytoprotection, providing a potential target for therapeutic interventions in gastric mucosal injury.

Non-vesicular release of glutamate from glial cells by reversed electrogenic glutamate uptake. Glutamate is a major excitatory neurotransmitter in the central nervous system, and its release is tightly regulated by neurons and glial cells. While vesicular release of glutamate from neurons has been extensively studied, there is growing evidence that glial cells also contribute to glutamate release through non-vesicular mechanisms. In this study, we investigated the role of reversed electrogenic glutamate uptake in non-vesicular glutamate release from glial cells. We found that blocking the glial glutamate transporter GLT-1 with specific inhibitors resulted in an increase in extracellular glutamate levels. Furthermore, using electrophysiological techniques, we demonstrated that glial cells exhibit a reversal potential for glutamate uptake, indicating the presence of a reversed electrogenic glutamate uptake mechanism. Our findings suggest that glial cells can release glutamate into the extracellular space through a non-vesicular process involving reversed electrogenic glutamate uptake. Further understanding of these mechanisms may have implications for the regulation of glutamate homeostasis and excitatory neurotransmission in the brain.

Major histocompatibility complex antigen expression in the affected tissues in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.  Monoclonal antibody immunocytochemistry was used to examine spinal cord and muscle in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis for changes that would indicate ongoing or potential immune activity. The authors investigated major histocompatibility complex (MHC) antigen expression in affected tissues of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) using monoclonal antibody immunocytochemistry. They examined the spinal cord and muscle tissues for changes indicative of ongoing or potential immune activity. In ALS patients, abnormal MHC antigen expression was observed in both spinal cord and muscle tissues. The expression pattern suggested the activation of immune responses, specifically in the form of a focal and diffuse distribution of MHC antigens in affected neurons and glial cells. These findings support the hypothesis that neuroinflammation plays a role in the pathogenesis of ALS. The presence of MHC antigens in muscle tissue suggests potential immune-mediated muscle damage. Understanding the immune processes involved in ALS may provide insights into disease mechanisms and help identify potential therapeutic targets.

Management of selected cystic adnexal masses in postmenopausal women by operative laparoscopy: a pilot study.  Twenty-five postmenopausal patients were predicted to have benign masses by screening criteria that included ultrasonographic findings of a cystic adnexal mass less than 10 cm with distinct borders and no evidence of irregular solid parts, thick septa, ascites, or matted bowel, and a normal serum CA 125 value (less than 35 U/ml). All patients underwent operative laparoscopy for definitive diagnosis and management of the cystic adnexal masses. The laparoscopic procedure was successful in confirming the benign nature of the masses in all 25 patients. There were no intraoperative complications or conversions to laparotomy. Postoperative outcomes were favorable, with no cases of postoperative infection, hematoma, or other surgical complications. This pilot study suggests that operative laparoscopy can be a safe and effective approach for the management of selected cystic adnexal masses in postmenopausal women, enabling accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment while minimizing potential risks associated with more invasive procedures.

Perivascular innervation of the cerebral arteries in spontaneously hypertensive rats--an immunohistochemical study. This study aimed to investigate the perivascular innervation of cerebral arteries in spontaneously hypertensive rats (SHR) through immunohistochemical analysis. The SHR model is a well-established model for studying hypertension-related vascular changes. We examined the distribution and density of perivascular nerves in the cerebral arteries of SHR and compared them with normotensive control rats. Using specific markers for nerve fibers, we observed a significant increase in perivascular innervation in the cerebral arteries of SHR compared to controls. Additionally, we found alterations in the distribution pattern and density of sympathetic and sensory nerve fibers in the hypertensive rats. These findings suggest that the perivascular innervation plays a crucial role in the pathophysiology of hypertension and may provide insights into the development of novel therapeutic approaches targeting the neurovascular system in hypertensive conditions.

Lung injury in a surfactant-deficient lung is modified by indomethacin. Surfactant deficiency is a common cause of acute lung injury and respiratory distress syndrome in neonates. This study aimed to investigate the effect of indomethacin, a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug, on lung injury in a surfactant-deficient lung. Twenty-four neonatal rabbits were divided into three groups: control, surfactant-deficient, and surfactant-deficient with indomethacin treatment. Lung injury was induced by intra-tracheal administration of saline in the surfactant-deficient groups. The surfactant-deficient group showed significant histological changes indicative of lung injury compared to the control group. However, the surfactant-deficient group with indomethacin treatment had significantly reduced lung injury compared to the surfactant-deficient group. This was evidenced by histological improvements, decreased lung wet-to-dry weight ratio, and reduced levels of inflammatory cytokines. These findings suggest that indomethacin may have a protective effect against lung injury in surfactant-deficient lungs, providing a potential therapeutic option for neonates with respiratory distress syndrome. Further studies are warranted to elucidate the underlying mechanisms of this protective effect.

The acute lupus hemophagocytic syndrome [published erratum appears in Ann Intern Med 1991 Jun 1;114(11):993] OBJECTIVE: To characterize an unusual mode of presentation of systemic lupus erythematosus: acute and severe pancytopenia related to reactive hemophagocytosis.  DESIGN: Retrospective case series. The objective of this retrospective case series is to characterize the unusual mode of presentation of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) known as acute lupus hemophagocytic syndrome (ALHS). ALHS is characterized by acute and severe pancytopenia related to reactive hemophagocytosis. A review of medical records was conducted to identify patients with this presentation and collect relevant clinical data. The study identified eight cases of ALHS, with all patients presenting with fever, cytopenias, and evidence of hemophagocytosis on bone marrow examination. Other common findings included hepatosplenomegaly and hyperferritinemia. Treatment with glucocorticoids and immunosuppressive agents resulted in improvement in all cases. In conclusion, ALHS is a rare but important manifestation of SLE, and prompt recognition and appropriate management are crucial for patient outcomes. Further research is needed to better understand the pathogenesis and optimal treatment strategies for this condition.

Early-onset dementia and extrapyramidal disease: clinicopathological variant of Gerstmann-Straussler-Scheinker or Alzheimer's disease? A case of progressive dementia and extrapyramidal signs beginning at age 29, with a ten year course until death, is presented. This case report presents a rare variant of early-onset dementia and extrapyramidal disease in a patient who developed symptoms at the age of 29. The patient experienced progressive dementia and extrapyramidal signs for a duration of ten years until death. Differential diagnoses considered were Gerstmann-Straussler-Scheinker (GSS) disease and Alzheimer's disease. Pathological examination revealed plaques and neurofibrillary tangles consistent with Alzheimer's disease, with no evidence of prion protein deposition typical of GSS disease. This case highlights the challenge of diagnosing and distinguishing between these two conditions, and the importance of neuropathological confirmation to guide clinical management and further research.

Plasma histamine in patients with chronic renal failure and nephrotic syndrome. In patients with chronic renal failure (CRF) and nephrotic syndrome (NS), there is a known disruption in the regulation of histamine release. This study aimed to measure plasma histamine levels in patients with CRF and NS and compare them to a control group. A total of 60 patients with CRF and NS and 30 healthy controls were included in the study. Plasma histamine levels were measured using enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA). The results showed significantly higher plasma histamine levels in patients with CRF and NS compared to the control group (p<0.05). Additionally, there was a positive correlation between plasma histamine levels and the severity of NS (p<0.001). These findings suggest that dysregulation of histamine release may contribute to the pathogenesis and progression of renal dysfunction in patients with CRF and NS. Further research is warranted to investigate the underlying mechanisms and potential therapeutic interventions targeting histamine regulation in these patients.

Value of ventricular electrogram recordings in the diagnosis of arrhythmias precipitating electrical device shock therapy. The use of implantable electrical devices for the management of arrhythmias has become increasingly common. However, the occurrence of inappropriate device shock therapy is not uncommon. This study aimed to evaluate the value of ventricular electrogram recordings in the diagnosis of arrhythmias that precipitate device shock therapy. 

Twenty-four patients who received inappropriate device shock therapy were included in the study. Ventricular electrogram recordings were analyzed retrospectively and arrhythmias were classified as ventricular tachycardia (VT), ventricular fibrillation (VF), or other. 

Amongst the patients, 15 had VT, 5 had VF, and 4 had other arrhythmias. The vast majority of arrhythmias were monomorphic and sustained. The ventricular electrogram recordings provided valuable information in determining the underlying mechanism of arrhythmias precipitating shock therapy. 

In conclusion, ventricular electrogram recordings are a valuable diagnostic tool in the evaluation of arrhythmias leading to inappropriate electrical device shock therapy. Further studies are warranted to determine if these recordings can improve patient outcomes by guiding appropriate therapy selection.

A controlled trial of psychological treatment for the irritable bowel syndrome. The efficacy of psychological treatment for irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) remains controversial, with limited evidence supporting its use. In this controlled trial, we aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of psychological treatment in patients with IBS. A total of 100 patients were randomly assigned to either a psychological treatment group or a control group receiving standard medical care. The psychological treatment group received individual cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) sessions focusing on stress management, coping strategies, and relaxation techniques. The control group received medical treatment alone. Outcome measures included IBS symptoms, quality of life, and psychological distress. After 12 weeks of treatment, patients in the psychological treatment group showed significant improvements in IBS symptoms, quality of life, and psychological distress compared to the control group. These results suggest that psychological treatment, specifically CBT, can be a beneficial adjunctive therapy for patients with IBS. Further research is needed to confirm these findings and explore the underlying mechanisms of this treatment approach.

Clot-trapper device for transjugular thrombectomy from the inferior vena cava. This study presents the use of a novel clot-trapper device for transjugular thrombectomy from the inferior vena cava (IVC). Thrombectomy is often necessary in cases of IVC thrombosis, but traditional techniques can be challenging and associated with significant complications. The clot-trapper device offers a new approach to thrombectomy, allowing for more efficient and safer retrieval of thrombi from the IVC.

The study included 25 patients with IVC thrombosis who underwent transjugular thrombectomy using the clot-trapper device. The procedure was successful in all cases, with complete removal of the thrombus achieved in 92% of patients. The mean procedure time was 67 minutes, with a mean hospital stay of 4 days. There were no major complications observed, and minor complications were limited to transient bradycardia in two patients.

The clot-trapper device demonstrated excellent efficacy and safety in transjugular thrombectomy from the IVC. Its unique design allowed for effective capturing and removal of thrombi, reducing the risk of embolization and minimizing the need for additional interventions. This device shows promising potential in improving the management of IVC thrombosis and warrants further investigation in larger, controlled studies.

Intrapericardial extralobar pulmonary sequestration in a neonate. Intrapericardial extralobar pulmonary sequestration is a rare congenital anomaly characterized by the presence of non-functioning lung tissue in the pericardial cavity. We report a case of a neonate presenting with respiratory distress and cyanosis shortly after birth. Echocardiography revealed a large, cystic mass adjacent to the heart. Surgical excision was performed, and histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of intrapericardial extralobar pulmonary sequestration. The neonate made a full recovery following surgery. To our knowledge, this is one of the few reported cases of intrapericardial extralobar pulmonary sequestration in a neonate. The rarity of this condition and its atypical presentation underscore the importance of maintaining a high index of suspicion in neonates with respiratory distress and cyanosis. Early diagnosis and prompt surgical intervention are crucial in ensuring a favorable outcome for these patients.

Comparison of four pulse oximeters: effects of venous occlusion and cold-induced peripheral vasoconstriction. This study aimed to compare the performance of four different pulse oximeters in detecting peripheral oxygen saturation (SpO2) levels during venous occlusion and cold-induced peripheral vasoconstriction. Twenty healthy volunteers participated in the study. Each participant had their SpO2 levels monitored simultaneously using the four pulse oximeters. Results showed that during venous occlusion, three of the pulse oximeters accurately detected SpO2 levels, while one showed consistently lower values. During cold-induced peripheral vasoconstriction, all four pulse oximeters demonstrated a decrease in SpO2 levels, but there were significant differences in the magnitude of the decrease. These findings suggest that pulse oximeters may vary in their accuracy and sensitivity under different physiological conditions, highlighting the importance of selecting an appropriate device for accurate SpO2 monitoring.

Early carcinoma of the gallbladder: macroscopic features and US findings. This study aimed to investigate the macroscopic features and ultrasonography (US) findings of early carcinoma of the gallbladder (ECGB). A total of 56 patients with pathologically confirmed ECGB were included in this retrospective analysis. The macroscopic features of ECGB were classified into five types: nodular, polypoid, ulcerative, papillary, and diffuse infiltrative. The most common type was the polypoid type (44.6%), followed by the ulcerative type (28.6%). US examination revealed various findings in ECGB patients, including gallbladder wall thickening (94.6%), intramural hypoechoic nodules (82.1%), irregular gallbladder lumen (71.4%), and gallbladder stones (39.3%). Among these findings, gallbladder wall thickening and intramural hypoechoic nodules were significantly associated with ECGB. In addition, the presence of gallbladder stones was more frequently observed in patients with ECGB compared to those without ECGB. These findings suggest that US examination can play a valuable role in the detection and diagnosis of ECGB.

Intravenous immunoglobulin treatment in patients with chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy. Chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (CIDP) is a rare immune-mediated disorder characterized by progressive weakness and sensory loss. Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) therapy has been shown to be effective in treating CIDP, but the optimal dosing regimen and treatment duration remains unclear. In this retrospective study, we evaluated the efficacy of IVIG treatment in 50 patients diagnosed with CIDP. Patients received IVIG infusions at a dose of 2 g/kg divided over 5 consecutive days. Clinical improvement was observed in 88% of patients, with a significant increase in grip strength and improvement in overall disability scores. However, 12% of patients did not respond to IVIG treatment. Adverse effects were mild and transient, with the most common being headache and fever. Our findings support the use of IVIG as an effective treatment option for CIDP, highlighting the need for further research to optimize dosing and treatment duration.

Magnetic resonance imaging in neurological disorders. In recent years, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) has become a valuable tool in the diagnosis and management of various neurological disorders. This review examines the role of MRI in different neurological conditions including neurodegenerative diseases, stroke, brain tumors, and multiple sclerosis. MRI provides detailed anatomical images of the brain and spinal cord, allowing for the identification of structural abnormalities and the assessment of disease progression. Additionally, advanced MRI techniques such as diffusion-weighted imaging, perfusion imaging, and magnetic resonance spectroscopy offer functional and metabolic information, aiding in the early detection and monitoring of neurological disorders. Furthermore, the use of contrast agents in MRI enhances the visualization of lesions and facilitates the differentiation between benign and malignant tumors. Overall, MRI plays a crucial role in the accurate diagnosis, treatment planning, and follow-up of patients with neurological disorders.

Dysplasia and DNA aneuploidy in a pelvic pouch. Dysplasia and DNA aneuploidy are known risk factors for the development of colorectal cancer. In patients with a pelvic pouch, formed after restorative proctocolectomy for ulcerative colitis, the presence of these abnormalities can be of significant concern. This study aimed to assess the prevalence and clinical significance of dysplasia and DNA aneuploidy in pelvic pouches.

A total of 52 patients who underwent pouchoscopy and pouch biopsies were included in the study. Dysplasia was identified in 14 patients (26.9%) and DNA aneuploidy was detected in 12 patients (23.1%). Among these patients, 7 had concurrent dysplasia and DNA aneuploidy. The presence of dysplasia or DNA aneuploidy was associated with longer duration of pouch existence and a history of pouchitis.

Furthermore, patients with dysplasia or DNA aneuploidy had a significantly higher risk of developing subsequent pouch-related neoplasia compared to those without these abnormalities.

These findings suggest that dysplasia and DNA aneuploidy are prevalent in pelvic pouches and may serve as important risk factors for pouch-related neoplasia. Regular surveillance and appropriate management strategies should be considered for patients with these findings to ensure early detection and intervention.

Successful treatment of recurrent corneal erosion with Nd:YAG anterior stromal puncture I used a new technique to create anterior corneal stromal punctures for the treatment of traumatic recurrent corneal erosions that had not responded to conventional therapy. Nd:YAG anterior stromal puncture was found to be a successful treatment option for patients suffering from recurrent corneal erosion that did not improve with conventional therapy. The technique involved creating anterior corneal stromal punctures using a new method. A total of X number of patients with traumatic recurrent corneal erosions were included in the study. The results showed a significant improvement in symptoms and reduction in the frequency of erosions following the procedure. No major complications or adverse effects were observed. Nd:YAG anterior stromal puncture may be considered as an effective alternative for managing recurrent corneal erosion resistant to conventional treatment methods.

DNA analysis of multiple synchronous renal cell carcinomas.  The authors used retrospective quantitative DNA analysis to study interrelationships between multiple synchronous renal cell carcinomas in seven patients. The study aimed to investigate the interrelationships between multiple synchronous renal cell carcinomas (RCC) through retrospective quantitative DNA analysis. The authors examined seven patients diagnosed with multiple RCCs and evaluated the DNA content in tumor samples using flow cytometry. The analysis revealed a high concordance in DNA content among the synchronous RCCs within each patient, suggesting a clonal origin for these tumors. In addition, the authors identified chromosomal aberrations and alterations in the DNA content, indicating genomic instability within individual tumors. The findings suggest that multiple synchronous RCCs might arise from a common clonal origin and undergo genetic changes independently, leading to divergent tumor evolution within the same patient. These results highlight the importance of understanding the clonal relationships and genomic heterogeneity in multiple RCCs, which could have implications for prognosis and treatment strategies.

Macroscopic hematuria and proteinuria preceding renal IgA deposition in patients with IgA nephropathy. We retrospectively analyzed the clinical data of 70 patients diagnosed with IgA nephropathy to investigate the relationship between macroscopic hematuria and proteinuria and the subsequent development of renal IgA deposition. Among the patients, 48 (68.6%) presented with macroscopic hematuria and 25 (35.7%) had proteinuria at the time of diagnosis. Follow-up renal biopsies revealed that 44 (62.9%) patients developed renal IgA deposition. Statistical analysis indicated a significant correlation between the presence of macroscopic hematuria and subsequent renal IgA deposition (p < 0.001). Additionally, proteinuria at diagnosis was found to be significantly associated with the development of renal IgA deposition (p = 0.006). Our findings suggest that macroscopic hematuria and proteinuria may serve as potential indicators for predicting the progression of IgA nephropathy and the development of renal IgA deposition. Early detection and intervention in patients presenting with these symptoms may help prevent disease progression and renal damage.

Alanine aminotransferase in clinical practice.  A review. Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) is a liver enzyme that plays a crucial role in the metabolism of amino acids. It is commonly used as a marker of hepatocellular injury and liver function. This review aims to provide an overview of the clinical significance of ALT and its role in various disease states. ALT levels are elevated in conditions such as viral hepatitis, alcoholic liver disease, non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, and drug-induced liver injury. Monitoring ALT levels can help in the diagnosis, assessment of disease severity, and monitoring the response to treatment in these conditions. However, it is important to consider factors that can influence ALT levels, such as age, sex, race, and comorbidities. Additionally, different laboratory techniques and reference ranges should be taken into account when interpreting ALT results. Overall, understanding the clinical implications of ALT can aid clinicians in making accurate diagnoses and managing liver-related disorders effectively.

Botulinum treatment of childhood strabismus.  Four hundred thirteen children ranging in age from 2 months to 12 years were treated for strabismus by botulinum injection of extraocular muscles. A retrospective study was conducted to evaluate the efficacy and safety of botulinum injection in the management of childhood strabismus. Four hundred thirteen children, aged 2 months to 12 years, received botulinum treatment for strabismus involving the extraocular muscles. Improvement in ocular alignment was observed in 85% of cases, with a mean reduction in deviation angle of 12.5 prism diopters. The treatment success rate was higher in children aged 2-5 years compared to older children. Complications were rare, with only two cases of transient ptosis reported. Botulinum injection proved to be an effective and safe alternative for the management of childhood strabismus, particularly in younger children. Further studies are warranted to determine long-term outcomes and optimal dosing strategies.

Factors associated with soft- and hard-tissue compromise of endosseous implants. Implant failure can occur due to various factors, including soft- and hard-tissue compromise around the implant site. This study aimed to identify the factors associated with such complications. A total of 120 patients who received endosseous implants were included in the analysis. Data on patient demographics, implant characteristics, and oral hygiene practices were collected. Soft-tissue compromise was defined as mucositis, peri-implantitis, or fistula formation, while hard-tissue compromise was defined as bone loss or implant mobility. Logistic regression analysis revealed that smoking, poor oral hygiene, and the presence of systemic diseases were significantly associated with soft-tissue compromise. On the other hand, implant length, diameter, and osseointegration were found to be significantly associated with hard-tissue compromise. These findings highlight the importance of patient education and strict oral hygiene practices to minimize the risk of implant failure.

Bilateral phrenic nerve palsy associated with open-heart surgery.  The incidence of phrenic nerve palsy after open-heart surgery has been estimated at 10%, but it is usually unilateral and does not cause symptoms. Bilateral phrenic nerve palsy is a rare but serious complication following open-heart surgery. This study aims to assess the incidence of bilateral phrenic nerve palsy and its clinical presentation. A retrospective analysis of patients who underwent open-heart surgery between January 2010 and December 2018 was conducted. Of the 245 patients included in the study, 8 (3.3%) developed bilateral phrenic nerve palsy. All cases presented with dyspnea and decreased exercise tolerance. The mean time to symptom onset was 7.5  3.2 days post-surgery. Chest X-ray and pulmonary function tests confirmed the diagnosis in all cases. Prompt recognition and management of bilateral phrenic nerve palsy are essential to prevent respiratory compromise and optimize patient outcomes.

Rupture of atheromatous plaque as a cause of thrombotic occlusion of stenotic internal carotid artery. Thrombotic occlusion of the internal carotid artery is a common cause of ischemic stroke. However, the underlying mechanisms leading to this occlusion remain unclear. This study aimed to investigate the role of rupture of atheromatous plaque in the development of thrombotic occlusion in stenotic internal carotid artery. 

A total of 80 patients with symptomatic internal carotid artery stenosis were enrolled in this study. All patients underwent carotid endarterectomy, and the retrieved plaques were carefully examined. Histopathological analysis revealed a ruptured plaque in 45% of the cases. These ruptured plaques were significantly associated with the occurrence of thrombotic occlusion (p < 0.05). Furthermore, the presence of intraplaque hemorrhage and inflammation was more commonly observed in the ruptured plaque group. 

In conclusion, these findings suggest that rupture of atheromatous plaque plays a vital role in the development of thrombotic occlusion in stenotic internal carotid artery. Further studies are warranted to explore potential therapeutic strategies targeting plaque stability to prevent ischemic stroke.

Untying the gordian knot: the genetics of Tourette syndrome. Tourette syndrome (TS) is a neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by involuntary motor and vocal tics. Despite being recognized for over a century, its underlying genetic basis remains elusive. Recent advancements in genomic technologies have identified multiple genetic variants associated with TS, shedding light on the complex genetic architecture of the disorder. This review aims to provide an overview of the genetic landscape of TS, including the identification of risk genes, the role of rare and common variants, and the potential biological pathways implicated in its pathogenesis. Understanding the genetics of TS is crucial for improving diagnosis, developing targeted treatments, and elucidating the underlying mechanisms of this debilitating condition.

Prophylaxis of deep venous thrombosis after acute abdominal operation. Deep venous thrombosis (DVT) is a common complication after abdominal surgery, leading to significant morbidity and mortality. The objective of this study was to evaluate the effectiveness of prophylaxis for DVT after acute abdominal operation. A total of 200 patients who underwent acute abdominal surgery were enrolled and randomized into two groups: the prophylaxis group (n=100) and the control group (n=100). The prophylaxis group received perioperative low molecular weight heparin injections, while the control group did not receive any prophylaxis. The occurrence of DVT was assessed using Doppler ultrasonography at 7 days and 30 days postoperatively. The results showed that the incidence of DVT was significantly lower in the prophylaxis group compared to the control group at both 7 days (p<0.05) and 30 days (p<0.01) postoperatively. Therefore, prophylaxis with low molecular weight heparin effectively reduces the occurrence of DVT after acute abdominal operation, highlighting the importance of this preventive strategy in improving patient outcomes.

Cytomegalovirus colitis and wasting. Cytomegalovirus (CMV) colitis is a common opportunistic infection that occurs in immunocompromised individuals, particularly those with HIV/AIDS. This study aims to evaluate the relationship between CMV colitis and wasting syndrome, a condition characterized by unintentional weight loss and muscle wasting. The authors conducted a retrospective analysis of patients diagnosed with CMV colitis and compared them to a control group without CMV infection. They found that patients with CMV colitis had a significantly higher prevalence of wasting syndrome compared to the control group. Additionally, the severity of wasting syndrome correlated with the extent of CMV colitis. These findings suggest that CMV colitis may contribute to the development and progression of wasting syndrome in immunocompromised individuals. Further research is needed to better understand the underlying mechanisms and develop targeted therapeutic interventions.

Adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma of the tongue. Adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma (ATLL) is a rare and aggressive form of lymphoid malignancy associated with human T-cell leukemia virus type 1 (HTLV-1). While involvement of the tongue is unusual, we present a case of ATLL presenting primarily as a mass on the tongue. A 58-year-old male presented with a painless, ulcerated mass on the tongue. Biopsy revealed infiltration of atypical lymphoid cells with immunohistochemical staining positive for CD3, CD4, CD25, and HTLV-1. Flow cytometry analysis confirmed the diagnosis of ATLL. The patient underwent a combination of chemotherapy and antiretroviral therapy, but unfortunately, succumbed to disease progression after six months. This case highlights the importance of considering ATLL in the differential diagnosis of tongue masses, particularly in areas endemic for HTLV-1 infection. Early diagnosis and aggressive treatment are crucial for improving outcomes in this aggressive disease.

Long-term outcome of massive small bowel resection.  The long-term outcome for seven patients 4-17 yr (mean 7. 4 yr) after massive small bowel resection was evaluated. The primary indication for surgery was short bowel syndrome caused by various etiologies, including necrotizing enterocolitis, malrotation with midgut volvulus, and intestinal atresia. Long-term follow-up included assessments of growth, nutritional status, gastrointestinal function, and quality of life. Six out of seven patients had chronic intestinal failure requiring parenteral nutrition. Four of these patients developed recurrent line infections and three required liver transplantation due to parenteral nutrition-associated liver disease. Growth was suboptimal in all patients, with five out of seven having height and weight below the 3rd percentile for age. Only two patients had normal gastrointestinal function, while the rest experienced chronic diarrhea or malabsorption. Overall, the long-term outcome after massive small bowel resection showed significant challenges in nutritional status, gastrointestinal function, and quality of life.

Long-term medical consequences of incest, rape, and molestation. Incest, rape, and molestation are traumatic experiences that can have long-term medical consequences. The physical and psychological effects of these forms of abuse can be severe and persistent. Physical consequences may include injuries, sexually transmitted infections, chronic pain, gynecological problems, and complications related to pregnancies resulting from the abuse. Psychological consequences may manifest as post-traumatic stress disorder, depression, anxiety, substance abuse, eating disorders, self-harm, and suicidal tendencies. The impacts of incest, rape, and molestation can significantly affect the overall well-being and quality of life of survivors. It is crucial for healthcare providers to be aware of these potential consequences, provide appropriate support and intervention, and collaborate with other professionals to address the complex needs of survivors.

Estimation of PR and ER by immunocytochemistry in breast cancer.  Comparison with radioligand binding methods. In this study, we evaluated the feasibility of using immunocytochemistry to estimate the levels of progesterone receptor (PR) and estrogen receptor (ER) in breast cancer cells, comparing its results with those obtained from radioligand binding methods. Archival breast cancer samples from 50 patients were analyzed using both immunocytochemistry and radioligand binding assays. We found a strong correlation between the two methods for both PR and ER, indicating that immunocytochemistry can be a reliable alternative to radioligand binding assays. Additionally, immunocytochemistry offered the advantage of visualizing the expression patterns of PR and ER within individual tumor cells, allowing for a better understanding of their distribution and localization. These findings suggest that immunocytochemistry could be a valuable tool for assessing PR and ER status in breast cancer, providing clinicians with important prognostic and therapeutic information.

LDH isoenzymes in cerebrospinal fluid in various brain tumours.  This study examined the isoenzymatic pattern of LDH in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) as well as the ratio between the five fractions of LDH among patients with various brain tumours, carcinomatous meningitis and control groups. In this study, the isoenzymatic pattern of lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) was investigated in patients with different types of brain tumors, carcinomatous meningitis, and control groups. The relative proportions of the five fractions of LDH were also determined. A total of 120 participants were included in the study. The results demonstrated significant variations in LDH isoenzymes among the different brain tumor types, suggesting that LDH isoenzymes in the CSF could potentially serve as diagnostic markers for specific brain tumors. The ratios of LDH fractions differed between the brain tumor patients and the control group. These findings contribute to a better understanding of the pathophysiology and diagnosis of brain tumors and carcinomatous meningitis.

Analgesic use: a study of treatments used by patients for migraine prior to attending the City of London Migraine Clinic. This study aimed to evaluate the analgesic treatments used by patients for migraine prior to attending the City of London Migraine Clinic. A retrospective analysis was conducted on medical records of 200 patients who visited the clinic over a six-month period. Results showed that 70% of patients had used over-the-counter analgesics, while 30% had used prescription medications prior to their clinic visit. The most commonly used analgesics were nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) followed by acetaminophen. Interestingly, only 10% of patients reported using triptans, which are recommended as first-line treatment for migraines. This suggests a potential underutilization of specific migraine medications. Further education regarding appropriate treatment options may be necessary to optimize management and improve patient outcomes.

Biological correlates of mental activity studied with PET. Positron emission tomography (PET) has revolutionized the investigation of brain function by providing insights into the biological correlates of mental activity. This review aims to summarize recent advancements in this field. PET imaging allows for the visualization and quantification of regional cerebral blood flow, glucose metabolism, neurotransmitter binding, and receptor availability, providing a comprehensive understanding of the neural mechanisms underlying mental processes. In particular, PET studies have contributed significantly to our understanding of psychiatric disorders such as schizophrenia, depression, and anxiety disorders, by identifying abnormalities in neurotransmitter systems and their associated brain regions. PET has also been instrumental in studying the effects of therapeutic interventions on brain function. Future developments in PET technology, including the use of novel radiotracers and advanced imaging techniques, hold great promise for further advancements in our understanding of the complex relationship between biology and mental activity.

A model of pneumococcal pneumonia in chronically intoxicated rats. Pneumococcal pneumonia is a common and serious respiratory infection that causes significant morbidity and mortality worldwide. Chronic alcohol intoxication is known to increase the susceptibility to infections, including pneumonia. In this study, a model of pneumococcal pneumonia in chronically intoxicated rats was developed to investigate the interactions between alcohol intoxication and the immune response to bacterial infection.

Rats were subjected to chronic alcohol intoxication through a liquid diet containing ethanol for a period of 12 weeks prior to infection. Pneumococcal pneumonia was induced by intranasal inoculation of Streptococcus pneumoniae. The rats were then monitored for clinical signs, lung histopathology, bacterial burden, and immune response parameters.

The results showed that chronically intoxicated rats exhibited increased susceptibility to pneumococcal pneumonia compared to control rats. These intoxicated rats displayed more severe clinical signs, including higher mortality rates, and had greater bacterial burden in the lungs. Histopathological analysis revealed more extensive lung inflammation and damage in intoxicated rats. Furthermore, the immune response in intoxicated rats was characterized by impaired phagocytic activity, decreased pro-inflammatory cytokine production, and altered expression of immune cell surface markers.

In conclusion, this model of pneumococcal pneumonia in chronically intoxicated rats highlights the detrimental effects of alcohol intoxication on the immune response to bacterial infection. The findings provide valuable insights into the pathogenesis of pneumonia in individuals with chronic alcohol abuse, and may aid in the development of targeted interventions and therapies for this high-risk population.

Combined hepatic and vena caval resection with autogenous caval graft replacement. We present a case report of a patient with advanced hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) involving the hepatic vein and caval vein, who underwent a combined hepatic and vena caval resection with autogenous caval graft replacement. The patient initially presented with abdominal pain and jaundice, and radiological evaluation revealed a large HCC infiltrating the hepatic and caval veins. Despite the advanced stage of the disease, the patient underwent an aggressive surgical approach, which included en bloc resection of the tumor along with the involved hepatic and caval veins. A segment of autogenous vein was harvested and utilized as a graft to replace the resected caval vein. The patient had an uneventful postoperative course and demonstrated long-term survival without evidence of disease recurrence. This case highlights the feasibility and potential benefits of a combined resection with caval graft replacement in select patients with advanced HCC involving the hepatic and caval veins.

Effects of radiation therapy on skeletal growth in childhood. Radiation therapy is an essential treatment modality for various pediatric malignancies; however, its effects on skeletal growth warrant attention. This retrospective study aimed to examine the impact of radiation therapy on skeletal growth in childhood. The medical records of 100 pediatric patients who received radiation therapy for different malignancies were reviewed. Height and bone age data were collected at regular intervals over a five-year period following radiation therapy completion. Results revealed a significant reduction in skeletal growth velocity post-radiation therapy compared to pre-treatment values (p<0.001). Furthermore, a delayed skeletal age was observed, with an average delay of 2.5 years (p<0.05). The severity of growth retardation was influenced by several factors, including radiation dose, treatment duration, and age at the initiation of therapy. Additionally, site-specific effects, such as vertebral column irradiation, were associated with more profound growth impairment. Notably, higher doses of radiation delivered to the growth plates and younger age at the initiation of therapy were major determinants of growth retardation. These findings emphasize the importance of monitoring skeletal growth in pediatric patients receiving radiation therapy and the need for appropriate management strategies to mitigate potential growth impairment.

Clinical spectrum of leber's congenital amaurosis in the second to fourth decades of life. Leber's congenital amaurosis (LCA) is a rare inherited retinal dystrophy characterized by severe visual impairment from early infancy. However, there is limited knowledge about the clinical presentation of LCA beyond childhood. This study aimed to investigate the clinical spectrum of LCA in individuals aged between their second and fourth decades of life. 

A total of 50 patients with genetically confirmed LCA were included in this retrospective case series. Clinical data, including visual acuity, fundus examination, electroretinography, and molecular genetic analysis, were collected and analyzed.

The results showed a wide range of phenotypic variability in this age group. While the majority of patients (70%) still had severely impaired vision, a significant proportion (30%) had stable or even improved visual acuity compared to childhood. Additionally, a subset of patients displayed atypical fundus changes and had additional ocular and non-ocular features.

This study highlights the need for further investigation to better understand the progression and clinical features of LCA beyond childhood. Improved knowledge of the clinical spectrum of LCA in older individuals may aid in the development of targeted interventions and management strategies for this group of patients.

Quadriceps myopathy: forme fruste of Becker muscular dystrophy. Quadriceps myopathy is a rare disorder characterized by weakness and wasting of the quadriceps muscles. We present a case report of a 35-year-old male with bilateral quadriceps weakness and wasting, suggestive of quadriceps myopathy. Genetic testing revealed a deletion mutation in the dystrophin gene, confirming the diagnosis of Becker muscular dystrophy (BMD). BMD is a subtype of muscular dystrophy characterized by progressive muscle weakness and wasting, typically affecting the proximal lower limb muscles. However, in our case, the presentation was atypical with isolated involvement of the quadriceps muscles. This represents a forme fruste or milder variant of BMD, further highlighting the phenotypic heterogeneity of this condition. Clinicians should consider BMD in the differential diagnosis of patients presenting with isolated quadriceps myopathy, as early recognition and appropriate management can significantly improve patient outcomes.

Response of spinal cord blood flow and motor and sensory evoked potentials to aortic ligation. Aortic ligation can lead to significant changes in spinal cord blood flow and impair motor and sensory function. In this study, we evaluated the response of spinal cord blood flow and motor and sensory evoked potentials to aortic ligation in a group of 30 patients. Aortic ligation resulted in a significant decrease in spinal cord blood flow, with a mean reduction of 45%. Motor and sensory evoked potentials were also significantly affected, with a mean decrease of 50% compared to baseline. The severity of these changes correlated with the duration of aortic ligation. These findings highlight the importance of monitoring spinal cord blood flow and evoked potentials during aortic surgeries to prevent spinal cord ischemia and minimize the risk of post-operative neurological deficits.

Prediagnostic serum levels of carotenoids and vitamin E as related to subsequent cancer in Washington County, Maryland. The relationship between prediagnostic serum levels of carotenoids and vitamin E and the risk of developing cancer was investigated in a cohort study conducted in Washington County, Maryland. A total of 500 participants were followed for a median of 10 years. Serum samples were collected at baseline and analyzed for levels of carotenoids (including alpha-carotene, beta-carotene, lycopene, and beta-cryptoxanthin) and vitamin E (alpha-tocopherol). Incident cases of cancer were identified through linkage to cancer registries.

After adjusting for potential confounders, higher serum levels of carotenoids and vitamin E were associated with a significant reduction in the risk of developing cancer. Specifically, participants in the highest quartile of carotenoid and vitamin E levels had a 30% lower risk of cancer compared to those in the lowest quartile. 

These findings suggest that higher levels of carotenoids and vitamin E may have a protective effect against cancer development. Further research is needed to elucidate the mechanisms underlying this association and to explore potential interventions for cancer prevention.

Recovery from vegetative state of six months' duration associated with Sinemet (levodopa/carbidopa). We present a case of a patient who experienced a remarkable recovery from a vegetative state after receiving Sinemet (levodopa/carbidopa) therapy. The patient had been in this state for six months following a traumatic brain injury. Sinemet was initiated as a trial treatment for possible dopamine deficiency, although there was limited evidence supporting its use in this context. Surprisingly, the patient demonstrated significant improvements in arousal, language comprehension, and motor function within two weeks of starting Sinemet. These improvements persisted over a one-year follow-up period. This case suggests that Sinemet may have a potential role in the recovery of patients with prolonged vegetative state and warrants further investigation into its mechanism of action in this population.

Treatment of pyoderma gangrenosum with cyclosporine: results in seven patients. Pyoderma gangrenosum (PG) is a rare, debilitating skin disorder characterized by painful, necrotic ulcers that can lead to severe complications. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of cyclosporine in the treatment of PG. Seven patients with refractory PG were enrolled and treated with oral cyclosporine. The primary outcome measure was the rate of complete healing of ulcers, and secondary outcomes included pain relief and adverse events. The results showed that cyclosporine effectively promoted healing in all seven patients, with complete ulcer closure observed within a median duration of 8 weeks. Additionally, cyclosporine provided significant pain relief and was well-tolerated without any serious adverse events. These findings suggest that cyclosporine is a promising treatment option for patients with refractory PG. Further studies are warranted to validate these results and determine optimal dosing regimens.

Randomised single blind trial to compare the toxicity of subconjunctival gentamicin and cefuroxime in cataract surgery.  Comparatively little attention has been paid to the conjunctival toxicity of antibiotics administered at the time of cataract surgery. This randomized single-blind trial aimed to compare the conjunctival toxicity of subconjunctival gentamicin and cefuroxime in patients undergoing cataract surgery. A total of 80 eyes from 40 patients were included in the study. The patients were randomly assigned to receive either subconjunctival gentamicin or cefuroxime at the end of the surgery. Conjunctival toxicity was evaluated by assessing conjunctival redness, chemosis, and discharge at postoperative day one, three, and seven. The results showed that the incidence of conjunctival toxicity was significantly higher in the gentamicin group compared to the cefuroxime group. These findings warrant further consideration in the selection of antibiotics for prophylaxis in cataract surgery to minimize conjunctival toxicity.

Neuropsychological aspects of learning disabilities in epilepsy. Learning disabilities are common in individuals with epilepsy and can affect various cognitive domains. In this review, we explore the neuropsychological aspects of learning disabilities in epilepsy. We discuss the impact of epilepsy on cognitive functions such as attention, memory, executive functions, language, and visual-spatial skills. Additionally, we examine the neurobiological mechanisms underlying these learning disabilities, including structural and functional brain abnormalities, as well as the role of antiepileptic medications. Furthermore, we highlight the importance of early identification and intervention in managing learning disabilities in individuals with epilepsy. Understanding the neuropsychological aspects of learning disabilities in epilepsy is crucial for optimizing educational, social, and psychological outcomes in this population.

Longitudinal histopathologic assessment of rejection after bladder-drained canine pancreas allograft transplantation. This study aimed to evaluate the longitudinal histopathologic changes associated with rejection following bladder-drained canine pancreas allograft transplantation. Ten dogs underwent pancreas transplantation with subsequent bladder drainage. Biopsy specimens were obtained at regular intervals post-transplantation and evaluated for histopathologic changes. Rejection episodes were identified based on the Banff criteria.
During the observation period, six out of ten dogs developed rejection episodes. The histopathologic assessment revealed varying degrees of inflammation, including mononuclear infiltration, interstitial edema, and acinar cell damage. The rejection episodes were classified as mild to moderate, with no severe cases observed. The histopathologic changes were most prominent during the early post-transplant period and tended to stabilize over time.
These findings suggest that bladder-drained canine pancreas allograft transplantation is associated with a risk of rejection. Longitudinal histopathologic assessment provides valuable insights into the progression and severity of rejection episodes. Further studies are warranted to explore potential therapeutic interventions to prevent or manage rejection in pancreas allograft transplantation.

Postoperative pancreatic abscess due to Plesiomonas shigelloides.  Plesiomonas shigelloides is being recognized with increasing frequency as a human pathogen. Postoperative pancreatic abscess is a rare but serious complication following surgery. Plesiomonas shigelloides is an emerging pathogen that has been implicated in various infections. Here, we present a case of postoperative pancreatic abscess caused by Plesiomonas shigelloides in a 65-year-old male patient who underwent gastrointestinal surgery.
