In this randomized study, we investigated the efficacy of methanol-extraction residue of bacille Calmette-Guerin (BCG-MER) as a postsurgical adjuvant therapy for uveal melanoma. Uveal melanoma is the most common primary intraocular malignancy and has high rates of metastasis. The study included patients who underwent surgical resection of uveal melanoma and were randomly assigned to receive either BCG-MER or no adjuvant therapy. The primary outcome measure was the recurrence rate of uveal melanoma within a 5-year follow-up period. Secondary outcome measures included overall survival rate, metastasis-free survival rate, and treatment-related adverse events. Preliminary results show that BCG-MER significantly reduced the recurrence rate of uveal melanoma compared to the control group. These findings suggest that BCG-MER may serve as a potential therapeutic option for postsurgical adjuvant therapy in uveal melanoma patients. Further studies are warranted to validate these results and explore the underlying mechanisms of action.

Correction of subclavian artery stenosis by percutaneous angioplasty. Subclavian artery stenosis is a common vascular disease that can lead to significant morbidity and mortality. Traditional treatment involves surgical bypass or endarterectomy, but percutaneous angioplasty has emerged as a less invasive alternative. In this study, we present our experience with percutaneous angioplasty for the correction of subclavian artery stenosis in a cohort of patients. A total of 30 patients underwent the procedure, and successful dilation was achieved in all cases. Follow-up angiography showed resolution of stenosis in the majority of patients, with only a small number requiring repeat intervention. Additionally, we observed a significant improvement in symptoms and blood pressure measurements post-procedure. Our results demonstrate that percutaneous angioplasty is a safe and effective treatment option for subclavian artery stenosis, offering a less invasive alternative to traditional surgical approaches.

Angioplasty of occluded coronary arteries: use of thin shaft balloon over-the-wire system without pre-dilatation. To evaluate the feasibility and outcomes of angioplasty using a thin shaft balloon over-the-wire system without pre-dilatation in the treatment of occluded coronary arteries, a retrospective analysis of 56 patients was conducted. The procedure was performed in patients with total occlusion or inadequate collateral circulation. The primary endpoints were successful revascularization and procedural complications. Secondary endpoints included major adverse cardiac events during follow-up. The thin shaft balloon over-the-wire system was successfully used in all cases, with a high rate of successful revascularization (89%). There were no major procedural complications, and only one patient experienced a minor complication of transient bradycardia. During follow-up, only one patient experienced a major adverse cardiac event. The findings suggest that angioplasty using a thin shaft balloon over-the-wire system without pre-dilatation is a safe and effective approach for the treatment of occluded coronary arteries.

The role of infection in the morbidity and mortality of patients with head and neck cancer undergoing multimodality therapy.  Cancer of the head and neck is a common cancer worldwide. Head and neck cancer is a prevalent and debilitating condition globally. This study aims to investigate the impact of infection on the morbidity and mortality of patients with head and neck cancer undergoing multimodality therapy. A retrospective analysis was conducted on a cohort of patients with head and neck cancer who received treatment at a tertiary referral center. Data on infection-related outcomes, including incidence, types of infection, and treatment outcomes, were collected and analyzed. The results showed that infection was a significant contributor to morbidity and mortality in this patient population. Respiratory tract infections were the most common type of infection observed. Infection-related complications were associated with a higher incidence of treatment interruptions and incomplete treatment regimens. Furthermore, patients with infection had a higher overall mortality rate compared to those without infection. These findings emphasize the importance of infection prevention and management strategies in improving the outcomes of patients with head and neck cancer undergoing multimodality therapy.

The epidemiology of cancer among Hispanic women. This study aimed to investigate the epidemiology of cancer among Hispanic women. A retrospective analysis of cancer cases among Hispanic women was conducted using data from a cancer registry database. A total of 2,534 cases were included in the analysis. The demographic characteristics, including age, ethnicity, and socio-economic status, were examined. The distribution of cancer types and stages at diagnosis were documented. Additionally, information on risk factors such as smoking, alcohol consumption, and family history of cancer were collected. The results showed that breast cancer was the most common cancer among Hispanic women, followed by cervical and colorectal cancer. The majority of cases were diagnosed at an advanced stage, suggesting a need for improved early detection strategies. Socio-economic factors and access to healthcare were found to play a significant role in cancer outcomes among Hispanic women. These findings provide important insights into the epidemiology of cancer in this population and can guide future efforts to reduce cancer burden among Hispanic women.

Senile dementia and healthy aging: a longitudinal CT study. This longitudinal study aimed to investigate the progression of senile dementia in a population of elderly individuals and compare it to the effects of healthy aging. A total of 100 subjects aged 65 years and above were enrolled and followed for a period of 5 years. The participants underwent annual CT scans to assess changes in brain structure and volume. Additionally, cognitive assessments and medical evaluations were performed at each follow-up visit.

Results showed a significant decline in cognitive function in the senile dementia group compared to the healthy aging group. The CT scans revealed progressive atrophy in key brain regions associated with memory and cognition in the dementia group, whereas minimal changes were observed in the healthy aging group. Furthermore, the rate of decline in cognitive abilities was found to be significantly associated with the degree of brain atrophy.

These findings highlight the pathological changes underlying senile dementia and demonstrate the utility of CT scans in tracking disease progression. Further studies are warranted to investigate potential therapeutic interventions for slowing the progression of senile dementia and promoting healthy aging.

Hemodynamic effects of lobar pulmonary artery occlusion in a porcine sepsis model. Lobar pulmonary artery occlusion can occur in various clinical scenarios, such as thromboembolism or iatrogenic injury. The hemodynamic consequences of such occlusions, particularly in the setting of sepsis, remain poorly understood. This study aimed to investigate the hemodynamic effects of lobar pulmonary artery occlusion in a porcine sepsis model. Eighteen pigs were randomized to receive either sepsis induction with intravenous lipopolysaccharide or saline control. Following sepsis induction, selective occlusion of the left or right lower lobar pulmonary artery was performed. Hemodynamic parameters were continuously monitored and recorded at baseline, during occlusion, and after release. We found that lobar pulmonary artery occlusion resulted in a significant increase in pulmonary arterial pressure, and a decrease in systemic arterial pressure and cardiac output, regardless of the occluded side. These findings suggest that lobar pulmonary artery occlusion in the setting of sepsis can lead to significant hemodynamic compromise, emphasizing the importance of early recognition and appropriate management of this condition.

Prolonged confusion following convulsions due to generalized nonconvulsive status epilepticus.  Among patients with a prolonged confusional state after convulsive seizure, we diagnosed 8 cases as generalized nonconvulsive status epilepticus. Generalized nonconvulsive status epilepticus (GNSE) is a potentially life-threatening condition characterized by altered mental status without motor convulsions. In this study, we present 8 cases of prolonged confusion following convulsions that were diagnosed as GNSE. The patients ranged in age from 18 to 65 years and had a history of epilepsy. They all experienced convulsive seizures prior to the onset of prolonged confusion. Electroencephalography (EEG) was the key diagnostic tool in identifying GNSE, revealing continuous epileptiform activity during the confusional state. Treatment with intravenous antiepileptic drugs led to rapid resolution of the confusion in all cases. This study highlights the importance of considering GNSE as a differential diagnosis in patients presenting with prolonged confusion after convulsions, and emphasizes the role of EEG in confirming the diagnosis and guiding appropriate management. Early recognition and treatment of GNSE is crucial to prevent potential complications and improve patient outcomes.

Flow cytometric determination of breast tumor heterogeneity. Breast tumor heterogeneity is associated with varying clinical outcomes and response to therapy. The purpose of this study was to determine the heterogeneity of breast tumors using flow cytometry. Fresh tumor samples were obtained from 50 patients with invasive breast cancer, and single-cell suspensions were prepared. Cells were stained with a panel of antibodies targeting different tumor markers, including estrogen receptor (ER), progesterone receptor (PR), human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2), and Ki-67. Flow cytometry analysis revealed distinct subpopulations of cells based on their expression of these markers. Furthermore, the presence of multiple subpopulations within a tumor sample suggested intratumoral heterogeneity. These findings highlight the importance of flow cytometry in assessing breast tumor heterogeneity, which may have implications for treatment planning and prognostication. Further studies are needed to investigate the clinical significance of such heterogeneity and its impact on therapeutic response.

Protective role of vitamin E in biological systems. Vitamin E is a well-known antioxidant that has shown potential protective effects in various biological systems. This review aims to provide an overview of the mechanisms by which vitamin E exerts its protective actions and the current understanding of its importance in maintaining optimal cellular function. Numerous studies have demonstrated the ability of vitamin E to scavenge free radicals, prevent lipid peroxidation, and inhibit inflammation, thereby reducing oxidative stress and cellular damage. Furthermore, vitamin E has been shown to modulate gene expression, regulate redox signaling pathways, and enhance immune function. The multifaceted nature of vitamin E's protective properties suggests its potential use in the prevention and treatment of various diseases associated with oxidative stress, such as cardiovascular disorders, neurodegenerative diseases, and cancer. However, further research is warranted to fully elucidate the mechanisms underlying the protective role of vitamin E and to establish optimal dosage and duration for therapeutic interventions.

Primary care patients who refuse specialized mental health services. Refusal of specialized mental health services by primary care patients is a significant concern, as it may lead to inadequate treatment and poorer health outcomes. This study aimed to identify factors associated with the refusal of specialized mental health services among primary care patients. A retrospective chart review was conducted on a sample of primary care patients who had been referred to specialized mental health services but subsequently refused the referral. Demographic and clinical characteristics, as well as reasons for refusal, were examined. Results indicated that younger age, male gender, lower socioeconomic status, and perceived stigma were associated with a higher likelihood of refusing specialized mental health services. These findings underscore the need for targeted interventions to address barriers to mental health care access and to promote the importance of timely and appropriate treatment.

The natural history of non-arteritic anterior ischaemic optic neuropathy.  Seventy one patients with non-arteritic anterior ischaemic optic neuropathy were studied retrospectively. This retrospective study aimed to investigate the natural history of non-arteritic anterior ischaemic optic neuropathy (NAION) in a cohort of 71 patients. The patients' medical records were reviewed to assess visual outcomes and disease progression over time. The results revealed that NAION had a variable course, with significant variability in visual acuity outcomes and disease progression among the patients. Approximately one-third of the patients experienced spontaneous improvement in visual acuity, while approximately one-third had stable visual acuity, and the remaining one-third experienced further decline in visual acuity. The visual field defects also showed variability, with some patients showing improvement or stabilization, while others showed progression of defects. Despite the variability in outcomes, no patient in the cohort developed bilateral NAION during the follow-up period. This study highlights the unpredictable nature of NAION and emphasizes the need for long-term monitoring and management in patients with this condition.

The opposite pupil in herniation. The occurrence of an opposite pupil in herniation is a rare phenomenon, and its underlying mechanism remains poorly understood. A retrospective analysis of patients with herniation-related opposite pupil was conducted to investigate its clinical characteristics and possible etiology. Among 32 patients included in the study, 85.7% presented with unilateral opposite pupil dilation, while 14.3% had bilateral opposite pupil dilation. Other common clinical findings included altered consciousness, abnormal motor responses, and signs of elevated intracranial pressure. The etiology of opposite pupil in herniation is believed to be related to compression of the oculomotor nerve or its connections within the midbrain. Further studies are warranted to elucidate the pathophysiological mechanisms and management strategies for this intriguing clinical presentation.

Upper gastrointestinal bleeding in relation to previous use of analgesics and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.  Catalan Countries Study on Upper Gastrointestinal Bleeding To assess the risk of upper gastrointestinal bleeding associated with the use of individual non-narcotic analgesics and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), a multicentre study of 875 cases of upper gastrointestinal bleeding and 2682 hospital controls was done.  With control for confounding factors, the overall odds ratio estimate for aspirin taken at least once during the week before the first symptom was 7. 2 (95% confidence interval 5. The study aimed to investigate the association between the use of non-narcotic analgesics and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and the risk of upper gastrointestinal bleeding. A multicentre study was conducted involving 875 cases of upper gastrointestinal bleeding and 2682 hospital controls. After controlling for confounding factors, it was found that the odds ratio estimate for the use of aspirin at least once in the week prior to the onset of symptoms was 7.2, with a 95% confidence interval of 5. The results suggest a significant association between the use of aspirin and an increased risk of upper gastrointestinal bleeding. Further research is needed to explore this relationship and its potential clinical implications.

Mixed connective tissue disease with arterial thrombosis, antiphospholipid antibodies and heparin induced thrombocytopenia. Mixed connective tissue disease (MCTD) is a systemic autoimmune disorder characterized by the presence of overlapping clinical features of various connective tissue diseases. Arterial thrombosis is a rare but severe complication of MCTD. In this case report, we present a patient with MCTD who developed arterial thrombosis, positive antiphospholipid antibodies, and heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT). This triad of conditions poses significant challenges in management and requires a multidisciplinary approach. The patient was successfully treated with anticoagulation therapy, and immunosuppressive medications were adjusted to control disease activity. The case highlights the importance of recognizing and managing these rare complications in patients with MCTD to prevent further thrombotic events and optimize outcomes.

Superficial esophageal carcinoma.  Surgical treatment and the results.  We report 92 patients treated with esophagectomy for superficial esophageal carcinoma (SEC; 9. ) in a district general hospital. The mean age of the patients was 56 years, with a male to female ratio of 2:1. The most common symptom was dysphagia, followed by weight loss. The majority of patients had early-stage disease, with 77% classified as stage T1a and 23% as T1b. 

All patients underwent esophagectomy, with 91 cases (99%) undergoing a minimally invasive procedure. There were no perioperative deaths. The median length of hospital stay was 10 days, with a range of 6 to 22 days. Postoperative complications occurred in 28 patients (30%), with the most common being anastomotic leak (n=10) and respiratory complications (n=8). 

At a median follow-up of 36 months, the overall survival rate was 87%, with a disease-specific survival rate of 92%. The 5-year overall survival rate was 81%. Of the 10 patients with an anastomotic leak, 7 required surgical intervention but all eventually healed. 

In conclusion, surgical treatment for superficial esophageal carcinoma in a district general hospital is safe and effective. Minimally invasive procedures can be performed with low morbidity and mortality rates. Close postoperative monitoring and management of complications, particularly anastomotic leaks, are crucial for optimal outcomes. Further studies are needed to evaluate long-term outcomes and compare different surgical approaches.

The recalcitrant perineal wound after rectal extirpation.  Applications of muscle flap closure. Perineal wound dehiscence is a common complication following rectal extirpation surgery. Despite various treatment modalities, the management of recalcitrant perineal wounds remains challenging. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of muscle flap closure in the treatment of these complex wounds. A retrospective analysis was performed on patients who underwent muscle flap closure for recalcitrant perineal wounds after rectal extirpation. Patient demographics, wound characteristics, surgical details, and postoperative outcomes were recorded. The study included 25 patients with persistent perineal wounds. The majority of patients had primary rectal carcinoma. Various muscle flaps, including gracilis, rectus abdominis, and gluteus maximus flaps, were used for wound closure. The mean follow-up period was 12 months. Muscle flap closure resulted in successful wound healing in 91% of cases, with a low rate of complications. The use of muscle flaps provides a reliable and effective option for the management of recalcitrant perineal wounds following rectal extirpation. Further studies with larger patient populations are warranted to confirm these findings.

Prostate specific antigen for assessing response to ketoconazole and prednisone in patients with hormone refractory metastatic prostate cancer. Prostate specific antigen (PSA) levels are commonly used to monitor treatment response in patients with hormone refractory metastatic prostate cancer. However, the utility of PSA as a biomarker for assessing response to specific treatment regimens, such as ketoconazole and prednisone, remains unclear. In this study, we aimed to evaluate the usefulness of PSA as a response indicator in patients receiving ketoconazole and prednisone therapy. A total of 50 patients were enrolled and followed for a median duration of 12 months. PSA levels were regularly measured before and during treatment. Our results showed a significant decrease in PSA levels in 70% of patients, indicating a favorable response to ketoconazole and prednisone therapy. Additionally, patients with greater PSA declines had longer progression-free survival and overall survival. Therefore, PSA is a valuable tool for assessing treatment response and predicting clinical outcomes in patients with hormone refractory metastatic prostate cancer receiving ketoconazole and prednisone therapy.

Intravascular ultrasound: a new potential modality for angioplasty guidance. Intravascular ultrasound (IVUS) is an emerging technology that has shown promise as a potential modality for guiding angioplasty procedures. This abstract aims to discuss the benefits and limitations of using IVUS during angioplasty, based on current literature.

IVUS allows for real-time visualization of the arterial wall and lumen, providing detailed information about plaque morphology, vessel dimensions, and stenosis severity. This enables more accurate assessment of lesion characteristics and determination of optimal balloon size and deployment strategy. IVUS also helps evaluate the immediate procedural results by assessing stent apposition, expansion, and potential complications such as dissection or thrombus formation.

Furthermore, IVUS can guide decision-making in complex lesions, such as calcified or eccentric plaques, where angiography alone may be insufficient. It may also aid in the treatment of bifurcation lesions, by evaluating side branch compromise and optimizing stent placement.

However, there are some limitations to IVUS. It requires additional equipment and expertise, which may increase procedural time and cost. There is also a learning curve associated with interpreting IVUS images accurately. Additionally, IVUS is not readily available in all centers, limiting its widespread use.

In conclusion, IVUS has the potential to improve the outcomes of angioplasty procedures by providing detailed intravascular imaging. Its ability to assess lesion characteristics, guide stent selection, and evaluate post-procedural results make it a valuable tool in the field of interventional cardiology. However, further research and advancements are needed to overcome its limitations and determine its true impact on clinical outcomes.

Tumefactive fibroinflammatory lesions of the head and neck. Tumefactive fibroinflammatory lesions (TFILs) are rare entities that can occur in various head and neck regions. This retrospective study aims to evaluate the clinical, radiological, and histopathological features of TFILs in the head and neck. A total of 22 patients diagnosed with TFILs were included in the study. The most common presenting symptom was a painless swelling, followed by dysphagia and hoarseness. Radiographic examination revealed a well-demarcated soft tissue mass with heterogeneous enhancement. Histopathological analysis demonstrated diffuse and dense fibrosis with a variable inflammatory infiltrate. Surgical excision was the mainstay of treatment, with good outcomes and low recurrence rates. TFILs should be considered in the differential diagnosis of head and neck masses.

Reversal of cardiac dysfunction secondary to type 1 primary hyperoxaluria after combined liver-kidney transplantation. Primary hyperoxaluria type 1 (PH1) is a rare inheritable disorder characterized by overproduction of oxalate, leading to systemic deposition of calcium oxalate crystals and multiorgan dysfunction. Cardiac involvement in PH1 is uncommon but can result in severe cardiac dysfunction. Here, we present a case of a 25-year-old male with PH1 and end-stage renal disease who developed significant cardiomyopathy. Despite optimal medical management, his cardiac function continued to decline. Subsequently, he underwent combined liver-kidney transplantation, which resulted in resolution of his renal and cardiac dysfunction. This case highlights the potential reversibility of cardiac dysfunction in PH1 following combined organ transplantation. Early recognition and timely intervention are crucial in improving outcomes for these patients. Further research is warranted to explore the underlying mechanisms and optimal management strategies for cardiac involvement in PH1.

Unsuspected syphilitic hepatitis in a patient with low-grade proteinuria and abnormal liver function A 25-year-old patient was found to have cholestatic liver enzyme abnormalities during assessment for asymptomatic low-grade proteinuria at the US Naval Hospital in Portsmouth, Virginia. Further investigation revealed a positive treponemal antibody test, indicating the presence of Treponema pallidum infection. Serologic testing confirmed the diagnosis of syphilis. The patient denied any symptoms suggestive of syphilis, including genital ulcers or rash. However, liver biopsy revealed the characteristic changes of syphilitic hepatitis. Syphilitic hepatitis is a rare manifestation of late-stage syphilis, and its diagnosis can be challenging due to its nonspecific clinical presentation and lack of specific serologic markers. This case highlights the importance of considering syphilis in the differential diagnosis of abnormal liver function in patients with risk factors, even in the absence of typical symptoms. Prompt recognition and treatment of syphilitic hepatitis are crucial to prevent further complications and to effectively manage the underlying syphilis infection.

Percutaneous balloon dilatation of benign biliary strictures. Benign biliary strictures can cause significant morbidity and mortality if not properly managed. Percutaneous balloon dilatation has emerged as an effective alternative to surgical intervention in selected cases. This study aimed to assess the safety and efficacy of percutaneous balloon dilatation in the treatment of benign biliary strictures. The medical records of 82 patients who underwent the procedure between 2008 and 2018 were retrospectively reviewed. Technical success was achieved in 79 patients (96.3%) with a single session of dilatation. Clinical success, defined as symptom resolution and normalization of laboratory markers, was observed in 74 patients (90.2%). Three patients experienced minor complications, including self-limited bleeding or edema, which were successfully managed conservatively. No major complications or mortality were reported. Median follow-up time was 2 years (range 1-10 years), with 72 patients (87.8%) maintaining persistent relief of symptoms. Percutaneous balloon dilatation is a safe and effective treatment option for benign biliary strictures, providing durable symptom resolution and avoiding the need for surgical interventions in the majority of cases.

Results of transsphenoidal extirpation of craniopharyngiomas and Rathke's cysts.  Fourteen patients undergoing transsphenoidal extirpation of craniopharyngiomas or Rathke's cysts underwent endocrinological evaluation before and after surgery. This study aimed to evaluate the endocrinological outcomes of transsphenoidal extirpation in patients with craniopharyngiomas or Rathke's cysts. Fourteen patients were included in the study and underwent preoperative and postoperative endocrinological evaluations. The results showed that transsphenoidal extirpation led to a significant improvement in endocrine function in most patients. Specifically, hormone deficiencies related to pituitary dysfunction, such as growth hormone deficiency and hypogonadism, were ameliorated following surgery. Additionally, some patients who had diabetes insipidus experienced a reduction in symptoms postoperatively. However, the study also identified a subset of patients who did not experience improved endocrine function after surgery. These findings suggest that while transsphenoidal extirpation can be effective in improving endocrine function in patients with craniopharyngiomas or Rathke's cysts, individualized treatment plans and careful monitoring of hormone levels postoperatively are necessary to optimize outcomes.

Pearson's marrow-pancreas syndrome. Pearson's marrow-pancreas syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by a combination of hematologic abnormalities and exocrine pancreatic dysfunction. This study aimed to investigate the clinical and laboratory features of patients with Pearson's marrow-pancreas syndrome. Medical records of 12 patients diagnosed with Pearson's marrow-pancreas syndrome were retrospectively reviewed. The most common presenting symptoms were failure to thrive (83.3%) and anemia (66.7%). Laboratory findings showed normocytic anemia (91.7%), neutropenia (75%), and thrombocytopenia (50%). Pancreatic dysfunction was confirmed by abnormal fecal elastase-1 levels and/or pancreatic exocrine insufficiency in all patients. Genetic testing identified mtDNA deletions in 75% of patients. Treatment primarily consisted of supportive care with blood transfusions and pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy. Two patients received hematopoietic stem cell transplantation. Overall, the prognosis was poor, with a high mortality rate (58.3%). In conclusion, Pearson's marrow-pancreas syndrome is a severe multisystem disorder with significant morbidity and mortality. Early recognition and appropriate management are crucial for improving outcomes in affected individuals. Further research is needed to better understand the underlying mechanisms and develop novel treatment approaches.

Retinal arterial macroaneurysms: risk factors and natural history.  A case control study was conducted to identify the systemic and ocular risk factors for retinal arterial macroaneurysms.  Forty-three patients with 52 photographically confirmed macroaneurysms were located. The study aimed to identify the risk factors and natural history of retinal arterial macroaneurysms (RAMs). Forty-three patients with 52 photographically confirmed RAMs were included in a case control study. Systemic and ocular risk factors were evaluated through medical history, laboratory tests, and ophthalmic examinations. The results showed that hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and smoking were significantly associated with the development of RAMs. Additionally, a positive family history of RAMs was observed in some cases. The natural history of RAMs revealed that most lesions remained stable or spontaneously regressed without any intervention. However, some cases experienced progression, leading to visual impairment or retinal hemorrhage. These findings shed light on the etiology and prognosis of RAMs and emphasize the importance of controlling systemic risk factors to prevent their occurrence and progression. Further research is warranted to validate these findings and develop targeted interventions for managing RAMs.

Mechanical restraint use among residents of skilled nursing facilities. This study aimed to investigate the prevalence and factors associated with mechanical restraint use among residents of skilled nursing facilities (SNFs). Data was collected from 12 SNFs, involving 783 residents. The prevalence of mechanical restraint use was found to be 8.3%. Factors significantly associated with mechanical restraint use included older age, male gender, a history of falls, and the presence of cognitive impairment. In addition, residents who were physically aggressive or exhibited disruptive behaviors were more likely to be restrained. These findings highlight the need for strategies to reduce the use of mechanical restraints in SNFs, including the implementation of non-pharmacological interventions and staff education on alternative approaches to behavior management.

Computed tomography for evaluation of puerperal infections. Puerperal infections, also known as postpartum infections, are a significant cause of morbidity and mortality among women. In this study, the role of computed tomography (CT) in the evaluation of puerperal infections was investigated. A total of 134 patients with suspected puerperal infections underwent CT imaging.

The findings revealed that CT was highly effective in detecting various types of puerperal infections, including endometritis, pelvic abscess, and septic thrombophlebitis. The sensitivity and specificity of CT in diagnosing these infections were 92% and 98%, respectively.

Furthermore, CT provided valuable information regarding the extent and severity of the infections, allowing for appropriate treatment planning. It also enabled the identification of complications, such as uterine perforation or peritonitis, which may require surgical intervention.

In conclusion, CT is a valuable imaging modality in the evaluation of puerperal infections. Its high sensitivity and specificity make it an essential tool for accurate diagnosis and management of these potentially life-threatening conditions. Further research is warranted to explore the potential of CT in guiding targeted interventions and improving patient outcomes.

Central nervous system involvement in patients with facial palsy due to borrelial infection. Facial palsy is a common manifestation of Lyme borreliosis, caused by infection with Borrelia burgdorferi. This study aimed to investigate the central nervous system (CNS) involvement in patients with facial palsy due to borrelial infection. Thirty patients diagnosed with facial palsy were included in the study and underwent extensive neurological evaluation, including cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain. CSF analysis revealed pleocytosis and elevated protein levels in a subset of patients, suggestive of CNS involvement. MRI findings showed various abnormalities, including white matter hyperintensities, focal cortical atrophy, and leptomeningeal gadolinium enhancement. These findings support the hypothesis that borrelial infection may lead to CNS involvement in patients with facial palsy. Therefore, routine CSF analysis and MRI evaluation should be considered in patients with facial palsy, especially in endemic areas for Lyme borreliosis, to assess for potential CNS involvement and guide appropriate management.

Driving in Parkinson's disease.  Altered motor or mental skills in Parkinson's disease (PD) could adversely affect driving ability. Driving ability in individuals with Parkinson's disease (PD) may be compromised due to the altered motor and mental skills associated with the condition. This abstract aims to explore the impact of PD on driving performance. Studies have shown that individuals with PD have impaired motor coordination, reduced reaction times, and difficulties with attention and decision-making, all of which are critical skills required for safe driving. These deficits have been found to worsen as the disease progresses. Furthermore, individuals with PD are more prone to experiencing freezing of gait episodes, which can be especially hazardous while operating a vehicle. Assessing the driving abilities and providing guidance to individuals with PD on whether to continue or restrict their driving privileges is crucial to ensure the safety of both the patient and the general public.

Standard v lightweight wheelchair propulsion in spinal cord injured patients.  Twenty-six male SCI subjects (six quadriplegics, eight "high paraplegics," and 12 "low paraplegics") propelled both standard and lightweight wheelchairs at a "sprint pace" (Sp) for 400 feet, and at a "duration pace" (Du) for four continuous minutes. This study aimed to compare the propulsion efficiency and subjective experience of standard versus lightweight wheelchairs in spinal cord injured (SCI) patients. Twenty-six male SCI subjects, categorized into quadriplegics, high paraplegics, and low paraplegics, participated in the study. The subjects propelled both standard and lightweight wheelchairs at a sprint pace for 400 feet and at a duration pace for four continuous minutes. Data regarding propulsion efficiency, including speed and energy expenditure, were collected and compared between the two types of wheelchairs. Additionally, subjective feedback from the participants regarding comfort, maneuverability, and overall preference of the wheelchairs was obtained. The results of this study will provide valuable insights into the benefits and limitations of standard and lightweight wheelchairs for SCI patients.

Comparative yield of Salmonella typhi from blood and bone marrow cultures in patients with fever of unknown origin. Salmonella typhi is the causative agent of typhoid fever, a systemic infection characterized by fever of unknown origin. The diagnosis of typhoid fever is traditionally confirmed by the isolation of S. typhi from blood cultures. However, recent studies have suggested that bone marrow cultures may have a higher yield in detecting S. typhi. In this retrospective study, we compared the yield of S. typhi from blood and bone marrow cultures in patients with fever of unknown origin. Our findings demonstrate that bone marrow cultures have a significantly higher yield in detecting S. typhi compared to blood cultures. Therefore, we recommend considering bone marrow cultures as a diagnostic tool in patients with fever of unknown origin suspected of having typhoid fever.

Systemic hypertension in sleep apnea syndrome. Sleep apnea syndrome is a common sleep disorder characterized by intermittent cessation of airflow during sleep. It is associated with various comorbidities, including systemic hypertension. This case report presents a 45-year-old male with a history of snoring and daytime sleepiness who was diagnosed with moderate obstructive sleep apnea syndrome. Despite treatment with continuous positive airway pressure therapy, the patient continued to experience high blood pressure. Further evaluation revealed secondary causes of hypertension were unlikely. Polysomnography confirmed persistent obstructive sleep apnea, indicating that untreated or inadequately treated sleep apnea may contribute to the development or worsening of systemic hypertension. Therefore, clinicians should consider sleep apnea as a potential underlying cause in patients with hypertension resistant to conventional therapy.

Measurement of resistance versus flow in assessing efficiency of aortocoronary bypass grafts.  Measurement of flow in saphenous bypass grafts with an electromagnetic flowmeter is complicated and poorly reproducible. This study aimed to assess the efficiency of aortocoronary bypass grafts by measuring resistance versus flow. A total of 60 patients who underwent aortocoronary bypass surgery were included in the study. Flow measurements in saphenous bypass grafts were done using an electromagnetic flowmeter. The results showed that measuring flow in saphenous bypass grafts was complicated and poorly reproducible due to various technical factors. However, resistance measurements were found to be more reliable and consistent in assessing graft efficiency. The study also identified a significant correlation between resistance measurements and graft patency, with higher resistance values indicating lower graft flow and potential graft failure. This finding suggests that resistance measurement may be a valuable tool in evaluating the functionality of aortocoronary bypass grafts. Further research is needed to validate these findings and explore alternative methods for assessing graft efficiency.

Changes in physician practice for the prevention of cardiovascular disease.  To determine recent changes in physicians' practices for cardiovascular disease risk reduction, a randomly selected sample of practicing primary care physicians in the upper Midwest was interviewed by telephone in 1987 and again in 1989 (response rates, greater than 90%; N = 241). The purpose of this study was to assess changes in physician practices for cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk reduction over a two-year period. A random sample of primary care physicians in the upper Midwest was interviewed by phone in 1987 and again in 1989. A total of 241 physicians participated in both interviews, resulting in response rates exceeding 90%. The interviews focused on the use of preventive practices such as smoking cessation advice, blood pressure measurement, lipid profile screening, and prescription of cholesterol-lowering medications. The results showed significant improvements in physician practices between 1987 and 1989. There was a marked increase in the recommendation of smoking cessation (from 72% to 91%), blood pressure measurement (from 80% to 94%), lipid profile screening (from 62% to 85%), and prescription of cholesterol-lowering medications (from 47% to 72%). These findings indicate positive changes in physician practices for CVD risk reduction over a two-year period.

Orbital compartment syndrome.  Direct measurement of orbital tissue pressure: 1. Orbital compartment syndrome (OCS) is a potentially sight-threatening condition caused by increased pressure within the orbit. In this study, direct measurement of orbital tissue pressure was performed in 15 patients with OCS. The average peak orbital pressure was found to be 30.5 mmHg, with a range of 20 to 45 mmHg. Patients presented with symptoms such as severe pain, proptosis, decreased visual acuity, and ophthalmoplegia. Immediate decompression was performed in all cases, leading to a significant reduction in orbital pressure and resolution of symptoms. Visual acuity improved in all patients, with none experiencing permanent visual loss. The results highlight the importance of early recognition and intervention in OCS to prevent irreversible damage to the optic nerve and preserve vision. Direct measurement of orbital tissue pressure provides valuable information for guiding treatment decisions in OCS.

The neuromuscular pathology of the Eosinophilia-Myalgia syndrome.  The Eosinophilia-Myalgia Syndrome (EMS) is a recently reorganized disorder in patients ingesting pharmacologic doses of L-tryptophan. The Eosinophilia-Myalgia Syndrome (EMS) is a disorder that has been recently reclassified and is associated with the ingestion of high doses of L-tryptophan. This article examines the neuromuscular pathology of EMS. A review of the literature was conducted to identify the clinical and pathological features of EMS. The main pathological findings include widespread muscle necrosis and inflammation, vascular changes, and peripheral nerve involvement. These findings suggest a multifactorial etiology for the development of EMS symptoms. The exact mechanism by which L-tryptophan leads to these pathological changes is unclear, but it is believed to involve multiple factors, including direct toxicity and immune-mediated responses. Further research is needed to fully understand the neuromuscular pathology of EMS and its potential treatment options.

Survival rates from out-of-hospital cardiac arrest: recommendations for uniform definitions and data to report. Survival rates from out-of-hospital cardiac arrest (OHCA) vary widely among different studies due to differences in definitions and reporting. This lack of standardization hinders accurate comparison and interpretation of data. To address this issue, a group of experts convened to develop recommendations for uniform definitions and data reporting for OHCA survival rates. The recommendations include standardized definitions for key terms such as return of spontaneous circulation, survival to hospital admission, and survival to hospital discharge. In addition, the experts propose a set of core data elements that should be collected in all studies, including information on patient demographics, cardiac arrest characteristics, prehospital care, and post-resuscitation care. These recommendations aim to improve the consistency and quality of data on OHCA survival rates, allowing for better comparison and interpretation, and ultimately facilitating the development of evidence-based strategies to improve outcomes in patients with OHCA.

Delayed death from aortic root trauma. Delayed death from aortic root trauma is a rare but potentially fatal complication of blunt chest trauma. This case report describes the delayed death of a 32-year-old man who suffered traumatic aortic root injury following a motor vehicle accident. Initial evaluation revealed no signs of aortic injury, and the patient was discharged. However, three weeks later, he presented with severe chest pain and hemodynamic instability. Imaging studies revealed a rupture of the ascending aorta, resulting in massive hemorrhage and subsequent death. Delayed death from aortic root trauma should be considered in patients with a history of chest trauma, especially if there is a delay in the onset of symptoms. Early recognition and prompt surgical intervention are crucial to prevent fatal outcomes.

Acute epididymitis: why patient and consort must be investigated. Acute epididymitis is a common condition characterized by inflammation of the epididymis, typically caused by a bacterial infection. It can present with symptoms such as scrotal pain, swelling, and fever. Prompt diagnosis and treatment are important to prevent complications and transmission of infection to sexual partners. In this case report, we describe a patient who presented with acute epididymitis and subsequently underwent appropriate evaluation and treatment. However, his sexual partner also experienced symptoms suggestive of a urinary tract infection. Further investigation revealed that she was a carrier of the same pathogenic bacteria responsible for the patient's epididymitis. This highlights the importance of investigating both the patient and their sexual partner in cases of acute epididymitis to ensure appropriate management and prevent reinfection. Clinicians should consider screening and treating sexual partners to minimize the risk of recurrent infection and its potential complications.

Mucosal characteristics of pelvic ileal pouches. Pelvic ileal pouch surgery is a common procedure for patients with ulcerative colitis or familial adenomatous polyposis. This study aimed to evaluate the mucosal characteristics of pelvic ileal pouches using endoscopy and histopathology. Thirty patients who underwent pelvic ileal pouch surgery were included in the study. Endoscopic examination revealed that pouch mucosa appeared normal in 23 patients, but showed signs of inflammation in 7 patients. Histopathological analysis confirmed these findings, with the majority of patients (n=28) showing normal pouch mucosa, while 2 patients demonstrated signs of chronic inflammation. Furthermore, the presence of pouchitis was observed in 4 patients. Overall, this study highlights the importance of endoscopic and histopathological evaluation in assessing the mucosal characteristics of pelvic ileal pouches. Further research is warranted to explore the implications of these findings for patient outcomes and management strategies.

Diabetic retinopathy in blacks. Diabetic retinopathy is a common complication of diabetes and is a leading cause of blindness in many populations. However, there is limited information on the prevalence and characteristics of diabetic retinopathy in black populations. This study aimed to investigate the prevalence and risk factors associated with diabetic retinopathy in black individuals with diabetes. A cross-sectional study was conducted on 500 black patients with diabetes who underwent ophthalmic examination, including fundus photography, at a specialist eye clinic. The prevalence of diabetic retinopathy was found to be 45%, with proliferative diabetic retinopathy being the most common type observed. Risk factors associated with diabetic retinopathy included longer duration of diabetes, poor glycemic control, and hypertension. These findings highlight the importance of regular ophthalmic screening and targeted management strategies for black individuals with diabetes to prevent and manage diabetic retinopathy effectively.

Microdochectomy for discharge from a single lactiferous duct. Microdochectomy is a surgical procedure commonly used for the treatment of discharge from a single lactiferous duct. This discharge, also known as nipple discharge, can be a cause of concern for patients as it may indicate an underlying pathology such as intraductal papilloma or ductal carcinoma in situ. In this report, we present a series of five cases where microdochectomy was performed for the management of persistent nipple discharge. The patients were followed up for a period of six months post-surgery and evaluated for any recurrence or complications. Our results demonstrate that microdochectomy is an effective and safe treatment option for patients with discharge from a single lactiferous duct, providing symptomatic relief and reducing the risk of future complications. Further studies are warranted to establish the long-term outcomes of this procedure and its impact on the quality of life of patients.

1990 AcroMed Award in basic science.  Cauda equina anatomy. The Cauda equina is a bundle of nerves located at the lower end of the spinal cord. It plays a crucial role in transmitting sensory and motor signals to and from the lower extremities. Understanding its anatomy is essential for diagnosing and treating various neurological conditions affecting this region.

This study aims to provide an in-depth analysis of the Cauda equina anatomy, highlighting its intricate organization and relationship with neighboring structures. Through a comprehensive review of literature and dissection of cadaveric specimens, the gross anatomy of the Cauda equina will be elucidated. Additionally, histological examinations will be conducted to determine the microstructure of the nerve roots, myelin sheaths, and surrounding tissues.

The findings of this study will contribute to the existing knowledge of Cauda equina anatomy, facilitating accurate localization of lesions, surgical planning, and improved outcomes in patients with cauda equina syndrome, herniated discs, or other spinal pathologies. Moreover, the identification of anatomical variations or anomalies may aid in the development of innovative surgical techniques and therapeutic interventions. Overall, this research aims to enhance the understanding and clinical management of conditions related to the Cauda equina.

Retrospective application of prognostic indices to pancreatitis discovered at necropsy. Pancreatitis is a complex and challenging condition, often with severe clinical consequences. Prognostic indices have been developed to aid in predicting the outcome of pancreatitis cases, but their application has primarily been in the clinical setting. Retroactively applying these prognostic indices to pancreatitis cases discovered at necropsy can provide valuable insights into the accuracy and efficacy of these indices in a postmortem setting. By examining the clinical history, laboratory data, and histopathological findings of necropsy-confirmed pancreatitis cases, researchers can determine the ability of these indices to accurately predict the severity and prognosis of the disease. Furthermore, comparing the results of the retroactive application of prognostic indices to clinical outcomes can uncover potential discrepancies and limitations of these indices. This retrospective analysis can contribute to the refinement and improvement of prognostic indices, ultimately enhancing the management and treatment of pancreatitis in clinical practice.

Ultrastructural changes in impotent penile tissue: a comparison of 65 patients. This study aimed to investigate the ultrastructural changes in impotent penile tissue by comparing the histopathological findings of 65 patients. Tissue samples were obtained from patients who underwent penile biopsy, with 35 patients diagnosed with organic impotence and 30 patients serving as controls. Electron microscopy was used to examine the samples for alterations in smooth muscle and collagen content, as well as endothelial cell morphology. The results revealed significantly higher amounts of fibrosis and collagen deposition in the impotent group compared to the control group. Additionally, an increased prevalence of smooth muscle damage and abnormal endothelial cell features was observed in the impotent group. These findings provide valuable insights into the cellular changes associated with impotence and may aid in the development of targeted therapeutic strategies.

Transitional cell carcinomatous meningitis after M-VAC (methotrexate, vinblastine, doxorubicin, and cisplatin) chemotherapy. Transitional cell carcinoma (TCC) is a common type of bladder cancer that can occasionally spread to other parts of the body, including the central nervous system. We report a case of a patient who developed TCC meningitis following treatment with M-VAC chemotherapy, which consists of methotrexate, vinblastine, doxorubicin, and cisplatin. The patient presented with severe headaches, neck stiffness, and neurological deficits consistent with meningitis. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis revealed the presence of malignant cells, confirming the diagnosis of TCC meningitis. The patient received intrathecal chemotherapy and underwent whole-brain radiation therapy, resulting in significant improvement of symptoms. However, the overall prognosis for TCC meningitis remains poor, with a median survival of less than six months. Early recognition and prompt treatment are crucial in improving outcomes for this rare complication of TCC, which should be considered in patients presenting with neurological symptoms after chemotherapy.

Safe use of codeine in the recovering alcoholic or addict. Codeine is a commonly used analgesic, but its use in patients with a history of alcoholism or addiction can pose unique challenges. This article reviews the literature and provides recommendations on the safe use of codeine in this patient population. The potential risks, such as relapse or increased sensitivity to opioids, are discussed. Strategies to minimize these risks, including close monitoring, dose adjustments, and alternative analgesic options, are also highlighted. The importance of a multidisciplinary approach, involving pain management specialists and addiction specialists, is emphasized. Overall, while codeine can be used in recovering alcoholics or addicts with caution, it is crucial to assess each patient's individual risk-benefit profile and consider alternative analgesic options when appropriate.

Surgical complications with the cochlear multiple-channel intracochlear implant: experience at Hannover and Melbourne. The cochlear multiple-channel intracochlear implant is a widely used device for auditory rehabilitation in patients with severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss. However, it is not without complications. This study aims to evaluate the surgical complications associated with the implant and compare the experiences from two different centers, Hannover and Melbourne.

A total of 250 patients who underwent cochlear implantation between January 2010 and December 2015 were included in the study. Demographic and clinical data, as well as surgical details and postoperative complications, were analyzed.

The overall surgical complication rate was 12.8%, with the most common complication being electrode migration (6.4%), followed by facial nerve injury (3.6%), device failure (1.6%), and infection (1.2%). There was no significant difference in the overall complication rate between the two centers. However, the type and frequency of complications varied. 

The results of this study highlight the importance of careful patient selection, meticulous surgical technique, and regular follow-up to minimize complications associated with the cochlear multiple-channel intracochlear implant. Collaboration and sharing of experiences between different centers can provide valuable insight into improving surgical outcomes and patient care.

Incidence and survival rates of children and young adults with osteogenic sarcoma.  Gender-specific and race-specific incidence and survival rates of osteogenic sarcoma over a 14-year period are presented for persons aged 0 to 24 years from eight Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results (SEER) registries. This study aimed to examine the gender-specific and race-specific incidence and survival rates of osteogenic sarcoma among children and young adults. A population-based analysis was conducted using data from eight SEER registries over a 14-year period. The study included individuals aged 0 to 24 years diagnosed with osteogenic sarcoma. Incidence rates were calculated using population denominators, and survival rates were estimated using the Kaplan-Meier method. A total of [number] cases were identified during the study period. The results revealed variations in the incidence and survival rates of osteogenic sarcoma based on gender and race. These findings contribute to our understanding of the epidemiology and outcomes of this rare malignancy in young individuals.

Racial differences in the anterior circulation in cerebrovascular disease. This study aimed to investigate racial differences in the anterior circulation in cerebrovascular disease. A total of 300 patients, including 150 Caucasians and 150 African Americans, were included in the study. The patients underwent magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) to assess the presence of cerebrovascular disease and to determine its extent and severity in the anterior circulation. Additionally, clinical characteristics and risk factors were assessed, including age, gender, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, smoking status, and cholesterol levels. 

The results revealed that African Americans had a higher prevalence and severity of cerebrovascular disease in the anterior circulation compared to Caucasians. Furthermore, African Americans displayed a higher incidence of hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and smoking, which are known risk factors for cerebrovascular disease. However, after adjusting for these confounding factors, racial differences in the anterior circulation remained significant. 

These findings suggest that racial disparities exist in the anterior circulation in cerebrovascular disease, with African Americans experiencing a higher burden of disease. Further research is needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms contributing to these racial differences and to develop targeted interventions to mitigate these disparities.

Dysplasia and DNA aneuploidy in a pelvic pouch. Pelvic pouch surgery is a widely accepted treatment for patients with chronic ulcerative colitis. However, long-term surveillance of the pouch is crucial due to the risk of dysplasia and cancer development. We present a case of a 51-year-old male who underwent pelvic pouch surgery for ulcerative colitis and subsequently developed dysplasia within the pouch. Endoscopic evaluation showed multiple polypoid lesions with irregular architecture and variable sizes in the pouch. Histopathological analysis confirmed moderate to severe dysplasia in these lesions. Additionally, DNA flow cytometry revealed aneuploidy in the dysplastic areas, suggesting genetic instability. These findings highlight the importance of regular endoscopic surveillance of pelvic pouches, especially in patients with a history of chronic colitis. Special attention should be given to polypoid lesions, as they may indicate dysplasia or cancer development. Close monitoring and appropriate intervention can aid in early detection and management of neoplastic transformations in pelvic pouches.

Survival after hypertonic saline resuscitation from hemorrhage.  There has been recent increased interest in hypertonic saline resuscitation from shock and hemorrhage. The aim of this study was to evaluate the survival outcomes of patients who underwent hypertonic saline resuscitation following hemorrhage. A retrospective analysis was conducted on a cohort of trauma patients who received hypertonic saline for resuscitation after hemorrhagic shock. The primary outcome measure was survival at 30 days post-resuscitation. Secondary outcomes included length of hospital stay, time to discharge, and complications. A total of 58 patients were included in the study, with a mean age of 45 years. The overall survival rate at 30 days was 69%, with the majority of deaths occurring within the first 24 hours. The mean length of hospital stay was 12 days, and the median time to discharge was 9 days. Complications were observed in 25% of the patients, including hypernatremia and renal dysfunction. In conclusion, hypertonic saline resuscitation appears to be a promising strategy for improving survival in patients with hemorrhagic shock. Further prospective studies are warranted to validate these findings and optimize the resuscitative protocol.

The cellular composition of basal cell adenoma of the parotid gland: an immunohistochemical analysis. Basal cell adenoma (BCA) is a benign neoplasm commonly found in the parotid gland. This study aimed to explore the cellular composition of BCA using immunohistochemical analysis. A total of 20 paraffin-embedded tissue samples from patients with BCA were examined. Immunohistochemical staining was performed using antibodies targeting cytokeratin 14 (CK14), smooth muscle actin (SMA), S100 protein, p63, and Ki-67. The majority of cases (90%) exhibited strong positivity for CK14, indicating the presence of myoepithelial cells. SMA staining was observed in 80% of cases, confirming the presence of myoepithelial cells as well. S100 protein staining was positive in 70% of cases, suggesting the presence of neural cells. P63 staining also showed positive results in 60% of cases, further supporting the presence of myoepithelial cells. Ki-67 staining revealed low proliferative indices in all cases. In conclusion, BCA primarily consists of myoepithelial cells, with a distinct presence of neural cells. Further research is warranted to fully understand the pathogenesis of BCA and its potential diagnostic value.

Mammographic measurements before and after augmentation mammaplasty. We conducted a retrospective study to evaluate mammographic changes before and after augmentation mammaplasty. Mammograms of patients who underwent breast augmentation surgery were reviewed and analyzed. Measurements of breast parenchymal density, breast volume, and implant position were recorded before surgery and during post-operative follow-up visits. Our results showed a significant increase in breast volume post-operatively, reflecting the successful augmentation procedure. Additionally, there was a noticeable decrease in breast parenchymal density, indicating improved visibility of breast tissue on mammograms. Implant position remained stable in the majority of cases, with no evidence of migration or displacement. These findings suggest that augmentation mammaplasty does not interfere with mammographic assessments and does not compromise the ability to detect breast abnormalities. Further studies with larger sample sizes and longer follow-up periods are warranted to validate our findings and assess the long-term impact of breast augmentation on mammographic measurements.

Postoperative hypertension: a prospective, placebo-controlled, randomized, double-blind trial, with intravenous nicardipine hydrochloride.  Nicardipine hydrochloride, a new calcium channel blocker for intravenous use, has been compared with placebo in a prospective, randomized, double-blind trial on postoperative hypertension. Postoperative hypertension is a common occurrence after surgery and can lead to serious complications if left untreated. In this study, we evaluated the effectiveness and safety of intravenous nicardipine hydrochloride, a new calcium channel blocker, in managing postoperative hypertension. A total of 100 patients were randomly assigned to receive either nicardipine hydrochloride or placebo. Blood pressure measurements were recorded at regular intervals during the postoperative period. Results showed that patients in the nicardipine hydrochloride group had a significantly greater reduction in blood pressure compared to those in the placebo group. Furthermore, there were no significant adverse effects observed with the administration of nicardipine hydrochloride. These findings suggest that intravenous nicardipine hydrochloride is a promising treatment option for postoperative hypertension.

Two-dimensional echocardiographic features of double outlet left ventricle. Double outlet left ventricle (DOLV) is a congenital heart defect characterized by both great arteries arising from the left ventricle. Although it is a rare condition, it is associated with significant morbidity and mortality. This study aims to describe the two-dimensional echocardiographic features of DOLV. The study included 50 patients diagnosed with DOLV who underwent echocardiography. The echocardiographic findings demonstrated a malaligned ventricular septal defect, overriding aorta, and subaortic ventricular septal hypertrophy in all patients. Other common findings included atrial septal defect, pulmonary stenosis or atresia, and aortic arch anomalies. Additionally, anomalies of the mitral valve, tricuspid valve, and coronary arteries were observed in some cases. These echocardiographic features in patients with DOLV provide valuable diagnostic information and aid in guiding management decisions.

Cholecystectomy and right colon cancer in Puerto Rico. The relationship between cholecystectomy and right colon cancer in Puerto Rico was investigated in this study. A total of 456 patients diagnosed with right colon cancer between 2005 and 2015 were included, with 187 of them having undergone cholecystectomy prior to the cancer diagnosis. The control group consisted of 675 individuals without colon cancer. Age, gender, and other relevant factors were matched between the two groups. The results showed that cholecystectomy was associated with an increased risk of right colon cancer in Puerto Rico, with an odds ratio of 1.72 (95% confidence interval, 1.29-2.30). Further analysis revealed that the risk was more pronounced in individuals who underwent cholecystectomy at a younger age (<50 years). These findings suggest a potential link between cholecystectomy and the development of right colon cancer in the Puerto Rican population, highlighting the importance of further investigation and surveillance in this area.

Late cholangitis after successful surgical repair of biliary atresia.  Bacterial cholangitis is a frequent complication of successful surgical repair of biliary atresia, occurring in 93% of patients before the age of 1 year, but thought to be rare after 2 years of age. We report two cases of late cholangitis occurring in patients who underwent successful surgical repair of biliary atresia. Both cases presented with recurrent episodes of fever and abdominal pain, and were found to have evidence of cholestasis and elevated liver enzymes. Biliary imaging revealed strictures and dilatation of the intrahepatic bile ducts, consistent with cholangitis. Microbiological cultures from bile samples grew Escherichia coli and Klebsiella pneumoniae, confirming the diagnosis. Both patients were treated with parenteral antibiotics and underwent endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography with sphincterotomy and biliary stenting. Follow-up showed resolution of symptoms and improvement in liver function tests. These cases highlight the importance of considering late cholangitis as a potential complication in patients who have undergone surgical repair of biliary atresia, even beyond the age of 2 years. Furthermore, prompt recognition and appropriate management are crucial for preventing long-term complications and preserving liver function.

Hyperplastic polyps seen at sigmoidoscopy are markers for additional adenomas seen at colonoscopy.  Asymptomatic individuals undergoing screening flexible sigmoidoscopy were prospectively studied. To determine the predictive value of hyperplastic polyps visualized during sigmoidoscopy in detecting additional adenomas, a prospective study was conducted in asymptomatic individuals undergoing screening flexible sigmoidoscopy. A total of 250 participants were included, and all hyperplastic polyps observed during sigmoidoscopy were confirmed histologically. Subsequently, these individuals underwent colonoscopy to assess the presence of additional adenomas. The findings revealed that 62 participants had at least one hyperplastic polyp, and among them, 73% were found to have additional adenomas during colonoscopy. In contrast, only 29% of individuals without hyperplastic polyps on sigmoidoscopy had additional adenomas on colonoscopy. This result suggests that the presence of hyperplastic polyps during sigmoidoscopy serves as a predictive marker for the likelihood of detecting additional adenomas during colonoscopy. Therefore, close surveillance and thorough evaluation are necessary for individuals with hyperplastic polyps to accurately detect and manage potential colorectal adenomas.

Interventional radiology of the biliary tract. Interventional radiology plays a vital role in the diagnosis and management of various biliary tract disorders. This abstract reviews the current interventional radiological techniques used in the evaluation and treatment of biliary tract pathologies. These techniques include percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography (PTC), percutaneous biliary drainage (PBD), balloon dilation of strictures, and placement of biliary stents. Additionally, the use of image-guided biopsy and ablation techniques in the biliary tract is discussed. The advantages of these minimally invasive procedures include their ability to provide accurate and timely diagnosis, relieve symptoms, and potentially avoid the need for more invasive surgical interventions. This abstract emphasizes the importance of interventional radiology in the comprehensive management of biliary tract disorders.

Does age affect outcomes of out-of-hospital cardiopulmonary resuscitation? We examined the relation between age and outcomes in patients treated for out-of-hospital cardiac arrest in Seattle, Wash. A total of 458 patients who received out-of-hospital cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) were included in this study. The patients were divided into three age groups: younger than 60, 60-79, and 80 years or older. The primary outcome measure was survival to hospital discharge. Secondary outcomes measures included return of spontaneous circulation (ROSC), 24-hour survival, and neurologic outcomes at discharge.

The results showed that older age was associated with lower rates of survival to hospital discharge (p < 0.001). Specifically, patients aged 60-79 years had a lower rate of survival compared to those younger than 60 years (adjusted odds ratio [OR] 0.63, 95% confidence interval [CI] 0.41-0.97, p = 0.035), while patients aged 80 years or older had the lowest rate of survival (adjusted OR 0.21, 95% CI 0.12-0.38, p < 0.001).

Furthermore, older age was also associated with lower rates of ROSC (p < 0.001) and 24-hour survival (p < 0.001). Among survivors, older age was associated with poorer neurologic outcomes at discharge (p = 0.023).

In conclusion, older age is a significant factor influencing outcomes of out-of-hospital CPR. As age increases, the chances of survival to hospital discharge, ROSC, and 24-hour survival decrease, while the likelihood of poor neurologic outcomes at discharge increases. These findings highlight the importance of considering age as a prognostic factor in the management of out-of-hospital cardiac arrest patients.

Increased microvascular permeability in vivo in response to intradermal injection of neutrophil-activating protein (NAP-2) in rabbit skin. We investigated the in vivo effects of neutrophil-activating protein (NAP-2) on microvascular permeability in rabbit skin. Intradermal injection of NAP-2 resulted in a dose-dependent increase in microvascular permeability, as demonstrated by extravasation of Evans blue dye. The increase in microvascular permeability was observed within 30 minutes of NAP-2 injection and reached maximum levels at 60 minutes. Pretreatment with indomethacin, a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug that inhibits prostaglandin synthesis, significantly attenuated the NAP-2-induced increase in microvascular permeability, suggesting an involvement of prostaglandins in this response. In addition, pretreatment with a rabbit anti-NAP-2 antibody was also able to attenuate the NAP-2-induced increase in microvascular permeability, confirming the specificity of the NAP-2 effect. These findings demonstrate that NAP-2 can induce an increase in microvascular permeability in rabbit skin, likely through the release of prostaglandins, and suggest a potential role for NAP-2 in the regulation of inflammation and tissue injury.

Beta-carotene's effects on serum lipoproteins and immunologic indices in humans. Several studies have investigated the effects of beta-carotene supplementation on serum lipoproteins and immunologic indices in humans. In a double-blind, placebo-controlled trial, 50 healthy male volunteers received either 50 mg of beta-carotene or placebo daily for 12 weeks. Serum lipoproteins, including total cholesterol, low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol, and high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol, were measured before and after supplementation. Immunologic indices, such as lymphocyte subset counts and cytokine levels, were also assessed. 

The results showed that beta-carotene supplementation did not significantly affect total cholesterol, LDL cholesterol, or HDL cholesterol levels compared to the placebo group. However, a significant increase in serum beta-carotene levels was observed in the supplementation group. 

In terms of immunologic indices, no significant differences were found between the beta-carotene and placebo groups in terms of lymphocyte subset counts or cytokine levels. 

Overall, these findings suggest that beta-carotene supplementation does not have substantial effects on serum lipoproteins or immunologic indices in healthy individuals. Further research is needed to determine whether beta-carotene may have different effects in specific populations or disease states.

Pulmonary malakoplakia in a patient with the acquired immunodeficiency syndrome. This case report describes a rare presentation of pulmonary malakoplakia in a patient with the acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS). A 38-year-old male, known to have AIDS with a low CD4 count, presented with cough, chest pain, and shortness of breath. Computed tomography (CT) scan of the chest revealed multiple nodules in both lungs. A transbronchial biopsy was performed, and histopathological examination revealed the presence of characteristic Michaelis-Gutmann bodies, confirming the diagnosis of pulmonary malakoplakia. The patient was started on appropriate antibiotics and antiretroviral therapy, resulting in symptomatic improvement. Pulmonary malakoplakia is a rare granulomatous disease, commonly seen in immunocompromised individuals. However, its association with AIDS has rarely been reported. This case highlights the importance of considering unusual opportunistic infections in patients with AIDS, as early diagnosis and management can lead to improved outcomes. Increased awareness among healthcare professionals is essential to ensure timely recognition and proper treatment of pulmonary malakoplakia in this vulnerable population.

Rigid spine syndrome with respiratory failure. Rigid spine syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by progressive muscle stiffness and contractures, predominantly affecting the axial muscles and respiratory system. We present a case of a 46-year-old male who presented with respiratory failure and was subsequently diagnosed with rigid spine syndrome. Respiratory muscle weakness was the main contributor to his respiratory compromise, requiring mechanical ventilation support. Upon further evaluation, the patient exhibited classic clinical features such as rigidity and limited range of motion in the spine, as well as joint contractures and scoliosis. Genetic testing confirmed a mutation in the SEPN1 gene, consistent with rigid spine syndrome. Treatment involved a multidisciplinary approach, including respiratory support, physical therapy, and management of associated complications. Clinicians should consider rigid spine syndrome in the differential diagnosis of patients presenting with respiratory failure and an underlying neuromuscular condition. Early recognition and treatment initiation can significantly improve patient outcomes.

Use of plasmid profiles in the investigation of a patient with Helicobacter pylori infection and peptic ulcer disease. The use of plasmid profiles in the investigation of Helicobacter pylori infection and peptic ulcer disease has shown promising results. Plasmids are extrachromosomal DNA molecules that can play a role in antibiotic resistance and virulence. In this study, plasmid profiles were analyzed in a patient with H. pylori infection and peptic ulcer disease to determine the presence of specific plasmids associated with these conditions. The results revealed the presence of multiple plasmids, suggesting the potential for increased antibiotic resistance and virulence. This finding highlights the importance of understanding the role of plasmids in H. pylori infection and peptic ulcer disease, and further research is needed to fully elucidate their significance and potential as diagnostic or therapeutic targets.

Microspectrophotometric DNA analysis in ulcerative colitis with special reference to its application in diagnosis of carcinoma and dysplasia.  The deoxyribonucleic (DNA) content was measured by microspectrophotometry in 100 specimens from 60 patients with ulcerative colitis, including six patients in whom the colitis was associated with carcinoma. Ulcerative colitis (UC) is a chronic inflammatory bowel disease that carries an increased risk of developing colorectal carcinoma and dysplasia. Accurate diagnosis and surveillance for these complications are essential for proper management and patient outcomes. In this study, microspectrophotometric DNA analysis was performed on 100 specimens from 60 patients with UC, including six patients with associated carcinoma. 

The objective was to evaluate the potential application of microspectrophotometric DNA analysis in the diagnosis of carcinoma and dysplasia in UC patients. The DNA content was measured, and statistical analysis was conducted to determine any significant differences in DNA content between different diagnostic groups.

The findings of this study demonstrated that microspectrophotometric DNA analysis can effectively differentiate between normal colonic mucosa, dysplasia, and carcinoma in UC patients. The DNA content was significantly higher in dysplastic and carcinoma specimens compared to normal mucosa, providing a potential biomarker for the identification of high-risk lesions. 

The application of microspectrophotometric DNA analysis in the surveillance and diagnosis of carcinoma and dysplasia in UC patients holds promise for improving early detection and guiding appropriate management strategies.
