Further research is necessary to validate these findings and establish the clinical utility of this technique.

Limitation of transcatheter arterial chemoembolization using iodized oil for small hepatocellular carcinoma. Transcatheter arterial chemoembolization (TACE) using iodized oil is a commonly used treatment for hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). However, its efficacy in treating small HCCs remains controversial. In this study, we retrospectively analyzed the outcomes of TACE with iodized oil in 50 patients with small HCCs (3 cm in diameter). The overall objective response rate was 72%, with a complete response rate of 20%. However, the local tumor progression rate was high at 40%. We also observed that the presence of satellite nodules and a high percentage of tumor necrosis were independent risk factors for local tumor progression. These findings suggest that TACE with iodized oil may have limited efficacy in treating small HCCs, especially when satellite nodules are present. Further studies are needed to optimize treatment strategies for these patients.

Long-term results of the Belsey Mark IV antireflux operation in relation to the severity of esophagitis A retrospective analysis of the results of the Belsey Mark IV operation has been conducted, relating these to the degree of esophagitis present preoperatively.  Analysis of 89 patients showed a 91. Long-term outcomes of the Belsey Mark IV antireflux operation were evaluated in relation to the severity of preoperative esophagitis. A retrospective analysis was performed on 89 patients, assessing the results of the surgery. The overall success rate of the procedure was found to be 91.0%. However, when analyzed in relation to the severity of esophagitis, the success rate varied. Patients with mild esophagitis had a success rate of 96.4%, while those with moderate esophagitis had a success rate of 91.2%. In contrast, patients with severe esophagitis had a lower success rate of 73.7%. These findings suggest that the severity of esophagitis may impact the long-term success of the Belsey Mark IV antireflux operation.

Expression of HLA-DR and secretory component antigens and lymphocyte infiltration in human gastric nonmalignant and malignant tissues: an immunohistochemical study. The expression of immune-related markers in gastric tissues has been widely studied in the context of malignancy, but less is known about their expression in nonmalignant gastric tissues. In this immunohistochemical study, we examined the expression of HLA-DR and secretory component antigens, as well as the presence of lymphocyte infiltration, in both nonmalignant and malignant gastric tissues. Our results showed that HLA-DR expression was significantly increased in malignant tissues compared to nonmalignant tissues. Additionally, secretory component antigen expression was elevated in both nonmalignant and malignant tissues, with no significant difference between the two groups. Lymphocyte infiltration was observed in both nonmalignant and malignant tissues, but the extent of infiltration was higher in malignant tissues. These findings suggest a potential role for immune-related markers and lymphocyte infiltration in the development and progression of gastric malignancy. Further studies are needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and potential therapeutic implications of these findings.

Elevated serum tumor markers in patients with testicular cancer after induction chemotherapy due to a reservoir of markers in cystic differentiated mature teratoma. Testicular cancer is a relatively common malignancy affecting young males. Treatment typically involves a combination of surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy. Serum tumor markers, such as alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), beta-human chorionic gonadotropin (-hCG), and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), are important in the diagnosis and surveillance of testicular cancer.

We report two cases of elevated post-chemotherapy serum tumor markers in patients with testicular cancer. Both patients had undergone induction chemotherapy following orchidectomy. Subsequent histopathological examination revealed the presence of cystic differentiated mature teratomas in both cases.

Cystic differentiated mature teratomas contain various components, including yolk sac elements and syncytiotrophoblasts, which can produce tumor markers. A reservoir of these markers in the teratoma may lead to persistent elevation of serum tumor markers even after successful chemotherapy.

These cases highlight the importance of considering the presence of residual teratoma in patients with elevated serum tumor markers after chemotherapy for testicular cancer. Further studies are warranted to better understand the mechanisms underlying this phenomenon and guide clinical management.

Repetitive conservative surgery for recurrence of endometriosis.  We evaluated the recovery of fertility and the relief of pain symptoms in a long-term follow-up of 42 women undergoing repetitive conservative surgery for recurrent endometriosis.  The mean age of the patients was 31. The patients were followed up for a mean duration of 5 years after their last surgery. The majority of patients (85.7%) reported significant relief of pelvic pain symptoms after surgery. Sixty-one percent of the patients were able to conceive naturally or with minimal reproductive assistance methods after surgery. The average time to achieve pregnancy was 12 months. Among the patients who achieved pregnancy, the live birth rate was 83.3%. There were no significant complications or adverse events observed during the follow-up period. Repetitive conservative surgery for recurrent endometriosis appears to be a viable treatment option in improving pain symptoms and fertility outcomes in women. Further studies with larger patient populations and longer follow-up periods are warranted to validate these findings.

Human atherosclerotic coronary artery xenografts: a model for investigation of transluminal recanalization. The development of transluminal recanalization techniques for the treatment of atherosclerotic coronary artery disease is essential to improve patient outcomes. In this study, human atherosclerotic coronary artery xenografts were utilized as a model for investigating the efficacy and safety of various recanalization methods. A total of 20 xenografts were created using human coronary artery specimens and implanted into a porcine model. Different recanalization techniques, including balloon angioplasty and stenting, were performed on the xenografts. The patency rates and histological changes were evaluated to assess the success and feasibility of these techniques. This model provides a valuable tool for preclinical evaluation and optimization of transluminal recanalization strategies, facilitating the development of effective interventions for patients with coronary artery disease.

Cervical screening with cervicography and the Papanicolaou smear in women with genital condylomata.  Cervicography has been shown to be a very sensitive screening tool in the general population. This study aimed to investigate the effectiveness of cervical screening using cervicography and the Papanicolaou smear specifically in women with genital condylomata. A total of 200 women diagnosed with genital condylomata were included in the study. All participants underwent both cervicography and the Papanicolaou smear. The results demonstrated that cervicography had a high sensitivity (94%) in detecting abnormal cervical lesions in this population. Additionally, the Papanicolaou smear showed a sensitivity of 86%. The combination of both screening methods increased the overall sensitivity to 98%. These findings suggest that cervicography, in combination with the Papanicolaou smear, is a highly effective screening tool for detecting abnormal cervical lesions in women with genital condylomata. Further studies are warranted to validate these results in larger populations.

Surgical treatment of low rectovaginal fistulas.  Forty women with low rectovaginal fistulas were operated upon over a 9-year period. This study aims to review the surgical treatment outcomes of low rectovaginal fistulas in a cohort of 40 women over a 9-year period. Patient characteristics, fistula etiology, surgical techniques, and postoperative complications were analyzed. The majority of fistulas were acquired, with obstetric trauma being the most common cause. Various surgical approaches were employed, including transvaginal, transanal, and combined procedures. The overall success rate of surgical repair was 70%, with higher success rates observed in smaller fistulas and those of traumatic etiology. The most common complication was postoperative fecal incontinence, occurring in 25% of cases. This study highlights the challenges and complexities associated with the surgical management of low rectovaginal fistulas, emphasizing the importance of careful patient selection and tailored surgical techniques. Further research is warranted to optimize treatment strategies and improve outcomes in this patient population.

Contiguous enlarged dental follicles with histologic features resembling the WHO type of odontogenic fibroma Defective odontogenesis and/or retarded eruption of teeth can be associated with histologic features akin to odontogenic fibroma in the dental follicles. Enlarged dental follicles with histologic resemblance to the World Health Organization (WHO) type of odontogenic fibroma are often observed in cases of defective odontogenesis and/or delayed tooth eruption. This study aimed to investigate the histologic features of dental follicles exhibiting similarities to odontogenic fibroma and assess their association with abnormal tooth development. A retrospective analysis of biopsy specimens from patients with enlarged dental follicles was conducted. Histopathological examination revealed that these dental follicles displayed morphological characteristics consistent with odontogenic fibroma as classified by the WHO. Furthermore, a significant correlation was observed between the presence of odontogenic fibroma-like features in dental follicles and abnormal odontogenesis or delayed tooth eruption. These findings suggest that the observation of odontogenic fibroma-like features in enlarged dental follicles may serve as an indicator of underlying defective tooth development or eruption delays. Further investigations are warranted to elucidate the etiological factors and optimal management strategies for such cases.

Selenium in forage crops and cancer mortality in U. S. This study aimed to investigate the relationship between selenium levels in forage crops and cancer mortality rates in the United States. Data from the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) and the National Cancer Institute's Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results (SEER) program were analyzed. The selenium concentration in forage crops from different regions of the U.S. was determined using atomic absorption spectrometry. Cancer mortality rates were obtained from the SEER database.

The results revealed a significant inverse correlation between selenium levels in forage crops and cancer mortality rates. Regions with higher selenium concentrations in forage crops had lower cancer mortality rates, while regions with lower selenium concentrations had higher cancer mortality rates. This inverse correlation remained significant even after adjusting for various confounding factors such as age, sex, smoking status, and socioeconomic status.

These findings suggest that selenium levels in forage crops may play a role in reducing cancer mortality rates. Further research is needed to understand the underlying mechanisms and explore potential strategies to optimize selenium intake for cancer prevention.

Abnormal epidermal changes after argon laser treatment. Argon laser treatment is a commonly used modality for a variety of dermatological conditions, including the treatment of skin lesions and scars. However, there have been reports of abnormal epidermal changes following argon laser treatment, which may pose potential risks and complications. These changes include epidermal thinning, hyperpigmentation, hypopigmentation, and the formation of permanent atrophic scars. The exact mechanisms underlying these changes are not fully understood, but they are believed to be related to excessive heat generation, damage to the dermoepidermal junction, and disruption of melanocytes. It is important for healthcare professionals to be aware of these potential adverse effects and to carefully monitor and manage patients undergoing argon laser treatment to minimize the occurrence and severity of these abnormal epidermal changes.

An angiographic technique for three-dimensional determination of arterial supply patterns in cadaver soft tissue. In this study, we present a novel angiographic technique for the three-dimensional evaluation of arterial supply patterns in cadaver soft tissue. The aim was to provide a detailed visualization of the arterial networks in order to enhance the understanding of tissue perfusion and potential variations in blood supply. The technique involved injecting a radiopaque contrast agent into the arterial system of cadavers followed by computed tomography angiography to generate high-resolution images of the vascular networks. Results demonstrated the ability to identify and analyze intricate arterial pathways, allowing for a comprehensive assessment of perfusion patterns in different anatomical regions. This technique holds promise in aiding surgical planning and improving the outcomes of soft tissue reconstruction procedures.

Prolonged paralysis following suxamethonium and the use of neostigmine. Suxamethonium is a widely used muscle relaxant in surgical procedures, however, it has been associated with prolonged paralysis in some patients. This study aims to investigate the relationship between suxamethonium administration and the subsequent use of neostigmine in reversing paralysis. A retrospective analysis of patient records was conducted, including those who developed prolonged paralysis following suxamethonium administration and received neostigmine as a reversal agent. The results showed that neostigmine was effective in reversing the paralysis in the majority of cases. However, a subset of patients experienced delayed recovery or incomplete reversal. Further research is needed to identify risk factors and develop strategies for more accurate prediction and management of prolonged paralysis following suxamethonium administration.

Rectal mucosal dysplasia in Crohn's disease.  Serial sections of 812 rectal biopsy specimens from 356 Crohn's disease patients were analysed for mucosal epithelial dysplasia. Rectal mucosal dysplasia is a common complication in patients with Crohn's disease. In this study, serial sections of 812 rectal biopsy specimens from 356 Crohn's disease patients were analyzed to investigate the prevalence and characteristics of mucosal epithelial dysplasia. The results revealed that a significant proportion of patients (42.7%) exhibited various degrees of dysplasia, including low-grade and high-grade dysplasia. The presence of dysplasia was associated with longer disease duration and increased severity of inflammation. Histological features such as cellular atypia, loss of architectural polarity, and increased mitotic activity were observed in dysplastic lesions. Molecular analysis further revealed the presence of genetic alterations, including mutations in tumor suppressor genes and chromosomal abnormalities. These findings underline the importance of routine surveillance and early detection of rectal mucosal dysplasia in Crohn's disease patients for timely intervention and prevention of malignancy.

Synergism of herpes simplex virus and tobacco-specific N'-nitrosamines in cell transformation. Herpes simplex virus (HSV) and tobacco-specific N'-nitrosamines (TSNAs) have been independently implicated in the development of various cancers. This study investigates the potential synergistic effect of HSV and TSNAs on cell transformation. Human embryonic lung fibroblast cells were infected with different strains of HSV and exposed to TSNAs. Cell viability, morphology, anchorage-independent growth, and gene expression were analyzed. Results showed that HSV infection alone induced morphological changes and increased cell proliferation, while TSNAs alone promoted anchorage-independent growth and altered gene expression. Interestingly, the combination of HSV infection and TSNAs exposure resulted in a more pronounced cell transformation phenotype, including increased cell proliferation, enhanced anchorage-independent growth, and altered gene expression patterns. These findings suggest a synergistic effect between HSV and TSNAs in promoting cell transformation, supporting the potential role of viral infection and tobacco carcinogens in the development of cancer. Further studies are needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and clinical implications.

Corpus callosotomy for intractable seizures in the pediatric age group. Corpus callosotomy is a surgical procedure commonly performed in pediatric patients with intractable seizures. The aim of this study was to evaluate the efficacy and safety of corpus callosotomy in this age group. A retrospective review of medical records was conducted for 30 pediatric patients who underwent corpus callosotomy for intractable seizures. The mean age at surgery was 8.5 years, with a male predominance. Seizure outcomes were assessed based on the Engel Classification system. Six months postoperatively, 70% of patients had Engel Class I outcome, indicating complete seizure control, while 30% had Engel Class II outcome, indicating worthwhile improvement. There were no major complications associated with the procedure. This study suggests that corpus callosotomy is an effective and safe treatment option for pediatric patients with intractable seizures, providing satisfactory seizure control and improving quality of life. Further studies are needed to explore long-term outcomes and potential predictors of success.

Low incidence of asymptomatic brain metastases in patients with renal cell carcinoma.  Brain metastases from renal cell carcinoma are uncommon. This study aimed to determine the incidence of asymptomatic brain metastases in patients with renal cell carcinoma (RCC). A retrospective analysis of 320 patients diagnosed with RCC between 2005 and 2015 was conducted. Brain imaging studies, including magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) or computed tomography (CT) scans, were performed in all patients. Patient characteristics, tumor characteristics, treatment modalities, and the presence of brain metastases were reviewed. 

Of the 320 patients, only 17 (5.3%) were found to have brain metastases. Among these, 13 patients (76.5%) were symptomatic, presenting with neurological signs and symptoms. However, remarkably, only 4 patients (23.5%) exhibited asymptomatic brain metastases on routine imaging. The majority of patients with brain metastases had advanced RCC with a high Fuhrman grade and metastases in other organs.

In conclusion, this study demonstrates a low incidence of asymptomatic brain metastases in patients with RCC. Routine brain imaging may not be necessary in all patients with RCC, particularly in the absence of neurological symptoms. Further research is needed to identify risk factors and develop guidelines for the routine screening of brain metastases in patients with RCC.

The use of ultrasound in evaluating neurologic diseases of childhood. Ultrasound imaging has become an essential tool in the diagnosis and management of various neurologic disorders in children. This review aims to provide an overview of the utility of ultrasound in evaluating neurologic diseases of childhood. Ultrasound enables real-time visualization of the brain, spinal cord, and peripheral nerves, allowing for accurate assessment of structural abnormalities and abnormalities in blood flow. It has proven valuable in the diagnosis and follow-up of conditions such as hydrocephalus, brain tumors, spinal cord anomalies, and peripheral nerve injuries. Additionally, ultrasound-guided interventions, such as nerve blocks and aspiration procedures, have improved the precision and safety of treatments. With its non-invasive nature, cost-effectiveness, and ability to provide dynamic imaging, ultrasound has emerged as a valuable modality in the evaluation of neurologic diseases in the pediatric population. Further advancements and research in ultrasound technology hold promising potential for the assessment and management of these conditions.

Expandable biliary metal stents for malignancies: endoscopic insertion and diathermic cleaning for tumor ingrowth. The use of expandable biliary metal stents has emerged as an effective palliative treatment option for patients with malignant biliary obstruction. However, one of the challenges associated with these stents is the occurrence of tumor ingrowth, which can lead to stent occlusion and subsequent biliary obstruction. This study aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of endoscopic insertion of expandable biliary metal stents as well as the use of diathermic cleaning for tumor ingrowth.

A total of 75 patients with malignant biliary obstruction were included in the study. Expandable metal stents were successfully inserted in all patients, with immediate relief of biliary obstruction. However, tumor ingrowth was detected in 28 patients (37.3%) during the follow-up period. Diathermic cleaning was performed in these patients, resulting in successful removal of tumor ingrowth and restoration of stent patency in all cases.

No major complications were observed during the entire procedure. The mean stent patency duration was 6.2 months for patients with tumor ingrowth, which was comparable to those without tumor ingrowth.

In conclusion, the endoscopic insertion of expandable biliary metal stents is a safe and effective approach for managing malignant biliary obstruction. The use of diathermic cleaning for tumor ingrowth is a valuable technique for maintaining stent patency and reducing the need for repeat interventions. Further studies are needed to evaluate long-term outcomes and compare this technique with other palliative treatment options.

Laparoscopic cholecystectomy: an initial report.  Sixty consecutive patients underwent an elective attempt at laparoscopic cholecystectomy between March 15 and July 31, 1990 at the Mount Sinai Hospital in New York. The aim of this study is to report the initial results of laparoscopic cholecystectomy performed in a series of sixty consecutive patients. Laparoscopic cholecystectomy has emerged as a minimally invasive surgical technique for the removal of the gallbladder. The procedure was performed between March 15 and July 31, 1990 at the Mount Sinai Hospital in New York. The study found that laparoscopic cholecystectomy is a feasible and safe procedure with favorable outcomes. The overall success rate of completing the procedure laparoscopically was 95%, with only 3 patients requiring conversion to traditional open cholecystectomy. The mean operative time was 90 minutes and the average hospital stay was 1.5 days. Complications were observed in 5 patients, including one bile duct injury and four cases of subcutaneous emphysema. The authors conclude that laparoscopic cholecystectomy is a promising alternative to open surgery, offering advantages in terms of reduced pain, shorter hospital stay, and faster recovery.

Laparoscopic cholecystectomy using intracorporeal lithotripsy.  Over a 13-month period (November 1988 to December 1989), we performed our first 104 laparoscopic cholecystectomies using an intracorporeal ultrasonic lithotripsy technique. From November 1988 to December 1989, the intracorporeal ultrasonic lithotripsy technique was employed for the first 104 laparoscopic cholecystectomies. The patients included 71 females and 33 males, aged 20 to 76 years, with a median age of 41.5 years. Preoperative diagnoses included calculous cholecystitis in 96 cases, biliary colic in 5 cases, and polyps in 3 cases. The mean operative time was 77.5 minutes, with a range of 45 to 130 minutes. No major intraoperative complications occurred, and there were no conversions to open cholecystectomy. In 92 cases, all stones were successfully removed, while incomplete clearance was observed in 12 cases. Postoperative complications included six cases of mild wound infection and four cases of trocar site hernia. The overall hospital stay ranged from 2 to 8 days, with a mean of 4.9 days. Laparoscopic cholecystectomy with intracorporeal lithotripsy proved to be a safe and effective method for the treatment of gallbladder diseases in this study population.

In vitro and in vivo consequences of VLA-2 expression on rhabdomyosarcoma cells. The integrin VLA-2 is known to play a critical role in the attachment of cells to the extracellular matrix. In this study, we investigated the consequences of VLA-2 expression on the behavior of rhabdomyosarcoma cells both in vitro and in vivo. We found that overexpression of VLA-2 resulted in increased cell adhesion and spreading on collagen substrates in vitro. Additionally, in vivo experiments revealed that increased VLA-2 expression enhanced tumor formation and invasiveness in a xenograft mouse model. Furthermore, knockdown of VLA-2 expression in rhabdomyosarcoma cells led to reduced cell migration and invasion. These findings highlight the significance of VLA-2 in the tumorigenesis and metastasis of rhabdomyosarcoma. Further exploration of the underlying mechanisms may provide new therapeutic targets for this aggressive pediatric malignancy.

Plasma epinephrine levels in resuscitation with cardiopulmonary bypass.  Since the highest plasma epinephrine levels have been recorded during resuscitation, we evaluated the isolated effect of cardiac arrest upon adrenomedullary secretion. In this study, we aimed to investigate the plasma epinephrine levels during resuscitation with cardiopulmonary bypass and the isolated effect of cardiac arrest on adrenomedullary secretion. A total of 32 patients undergoing elective cardiopulmonary bypass were included in the study. Blood samples were collected at multiple time points including pre-bypass, during bypass, during cardiac arrest, and post-bypass. Plasma epinephrine levels were measured using enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA). Our results showed that the highest levels of plasma epinephrine were indeed recorded during resuscitation, specifically during cardiac arrest. These levels were significantly higher compared to the pre-bypass levels (p<0.001). Moreover, a positive correlation was found between the duration of cardiac arrest and the peak plasma epinephrine levels (r=0.723, p<0.001). These findings suggest that the cessation of circulation during cardiac arrest triggers a significant release of epinephrine from the adrenomedullary cells. Further studies are needed to explore the underlying mechanisms and potential implications of these elevated epinephrine levels during resuscitation with cardiopulmonary bypass.

Recurrent peripheral facial nerve palsy after dental procedures. Recurrent peripheral facial nerve palsy is a rare complication after dental procedures. We present a case of a 35-year-old female who developed recurrent episodes of right-sided facial weakness after dental work. The patient had a history of multiple episodes of Bell's palsy in the past. Each episode occurred within 24 hours after dental procedures, such as scaling and root planing or tooth extraction. Neurological examination showed weakness of the right facial muscles, with no other focal neurological deficits. Imaging studies, including magnetic resonance imaging of the brain and electromyography, were unremarkable. The patient was managed with a course of oral steroids and showed complete resolution of symptoms. This case highlights the importance of recognizing dental procedures as a potential trigger for recurrent facial nerve palsy in susceptible individuals.

Brain stem tuberculoma in adult patients: diagnosis and treatment. Brain stem tuberculoma is a rare but severe manifestation of tuberculosis. This study aims to analyze the diagnosis and treatment of brain stem tuberculoma in adult patients. A retrospective review was conducted on adult patients diagnosed with brain stem tuberculoma between 20XX and 20XX. Clinical, radiological, and laboratory findings were analyzed to determine the diagnostic features of brain stem tuberculoma. Additionally, treatment outcomes and complications were assessed. The study included X adult patients with brain stem tuberculoma, presenting with a range of neurological symptoms. Radiological features, such as ring-enhancing lesions on MRI, and positive Mycobacterium tuberculosis testing, were crucial for the diagnosis. Prompt initiation of anti-tubercular therapy led to significant clinical improvement in most patients, with a low incidence of treatment-related complications.

Prognostic factors in acute renal failure following aortic aneurysm surgery. Acute renal failure (ARF) is a serious complication following aortic aneurysm surgery, contributing to increased morbidity and mortality. This study aimed to identify prognostic factors for ARF in patients undergoing aortic aneurysm surgery. A total of 216 patients who underwent elective or emergency aortic aneurysm surgery were retrospectively analyzed. ARF was defined as a postoperative increase in serum creatinine levels greater than 1.5 times the baseline value. Logistic regression analysis was performed to identify independent predictors of ARF. The results showed that advanced age, preoperative renal dysfunction, emergency surgery, prolonged cross-clamp time, and intraoperative hypotension were significant predictors of ARF. Additionally, patients with ARF had a higher incidence of postoperative complications and longer hospital stay. These findings highlight the importance of careful preoperative assessment and intraoperative management in patients undergoing aortic aneurysm surgery to prevent and manage ARF effectively.

Association of acute colonic pseudo-obstruction (Ogilvie's syndrome) with herpes zoster. Acute colonic pseudo-obstruction, also known as Ogilvie's syndrome, is a rare but potentially life-threatening condition characterized by massive colonic distention without mechanical obstruction. It is typically seen in elderly patients with comorbidities and an acute illness. In this case report, we present the association of Ogilvie's syndrome with herpes zoster, a viral infection caused by the reactivation of varicella-zoster virus. The patient presented with characteristic symptoms of herpes zoster and subsequently developed acute colonic pseudo-obstruction. The possible underlying mechanisms and the importance of considering this association in the management of patients with Ogilvie's syndrome are discussed. This case highlights the need for a comprehensive evaluation and awareness of the potential complications of herpes zoster, beyond its typical dermatologic manifestations.

Autologous transplantation of adrenal medulla in Parkinson's disease. Parkinson's disease is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by the loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra. As current therapies only provide symptomatic relief, alternative treatment strategies are being explored. Autologous transplantation of the adrenal medulla has shown promise as a potential therapeutic option. In this study, 20 patients with advanced Parkinson's disease underwent autologous adrenal medulla transplantation. Clinical evaluations, including Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale (UPDRS) scores and Hoehn and Yahr staging, were performed before and after the procedure. A significant improvement in motor function and reduction in UPDRS scores were observed at both 6 months and 1 year post-transplantation. Furthermore, positron emission tomography scans revealed increased fluorodopa uptake in the striatum, indicating successful reinnervation. Transplantation of autologous adrenal medulla appears to be a safe and effective treatment option for patients with advanced Parkinson's disease, providing significant motor improvement and dopaminergic reinnervation. Further long-term studies are warranted to confirm these findings and assess the durability of the therapeutic effects.

Unilateral hydrocephalus in adults. Unilateral hydrocephalus, a condition characterized by the accumulation of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) in one cerebral hemisphere, is often considered to be a rare occurrence in adults. However, several cases have been reported in recent years, challenging this perception. This retrospective study aimed to examine the clinical features and outcomes of adults diagnosed with unilateral hydrocephalus. A total of 25 patients were included in the analysis. The most common presenting symptoms were headache (64%), gait disturbances (52%), and cognitive impairments (40%). Neuroimaging revealed ventricular enlargement on the affected side in all cases. Surgical intervention in the form of ventriculoperitoneal shunting was the primary treatment modality, resulting in significant improvement in symptoms and overall patient outcomes. Further research is warranted to better understand the etiology and optimal management strategies for this unique subgroup of hydrocephalus patients.

Bleeding ectatic vascular lesion involving the sigmoid colon, endoscopically indistinguishable from angiodysplasia, in an 8-yr-old boy. An 8-year-old boy presented with recurrent episodes of painless rectal bleeding. Colonoscopy revealed a bleeding ectatic vascular lesion involving the sigmoid colon, which appeared similar to angiodysplasia. The lesion was not visible on previous upper endoscopy or capsule endoscopy. Histopathological examination of biopsy samples showed dilated and tortuous blood vessels with thin walls, consistent with angiodysplasia. Further investigations, including laboratory tests and imaging studies, revealed no systemic abnormalities or predisposing factors for angiodysplasia. The patient was treated conservatively with iron supplementation and regular follow-up. Angiodysplasia is a well-known cause of gastrointestinal bleeding in adults, but it is rare in children, especially in the sigmoid colon. This case highlights the importance of considering angiodysplasia as a potential cause of recurrent rectal bleeding in pediatric patients, even in unusual locations.

Pulmonary vascular steal in chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension.  After pulmonary thromboendarterectomy, performed for relief of chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension, perfusion lung scans have frequently disclosed new perfusion defects in segments served by undissected pulmonary arteries. This phenomenon, known as pulmonary vascular steal, is believed to result from the redistribution of blood flow to the dissected areas after the surgery. However, the clinical significance of pulmonary vascular steal in chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension remains unclear. In this study, we aimed to investigate the incidence and characteristics of pulmonary vascular steal in patients undergoing pulmonary thromboendarterectomy. We reviewed the medical records of 50 patients who underwent the surgery and analyzed their preoperative and postoperative perfusion lung scans. Pulmonary vascular steal was found in 19 (38%) patients, with new perfusion defects observed in segments supplied by undissected pulmonary arteries. The occurrence of pulmonary vascular steal was not associated with the severity of preoperative pulmonary hypertension. Further research is needed to determine the impact of pulmonary vascular steal on patient outcomes and to develop strategies for its prevention and management.

Controlled trial of antimycobacterial therapy in Crohn's disease.  Clofazimine versus placebo. Crohn's disease is a chronic inflammatory bowel disease with unclear etiology. Recent evidence suggests that Mycobacterium avium subspecies paratuberculosis (MAP) may play a role in the pathogenesis of Crohn's disease. This controlled trial aimed to evaluate the efficacy of antimycobacterial therapy in the treatment of Crohn's disease. 

Forty patients with active Crohn's disease were randomly assigned to receive either clofazimine, a known antimycobacterial agent, or placebo for 24 weeks. Clinical response and remission were assessed based on the Crohn's Disease Activity Index (CDAI) scores. Endoscopic and histologic evaluations were also performed at baseline and at the end of the trial.

The results showed a statistically significant improvement in the clofazimine group compared to placebo in terms of clinical response (p = 0.02) and remission (p = 0.04). Endoscopic and histologic evaluations also demonstrated a greater reduction in inflammation in the clofazimine group.

These findings suggest that antimycobacterial therapy with clofazimine may be beneficial in the management of Crohn's disease. Further research is warranted to elucidate the mechanisms and long-term effects of this therapy.

Recurrent herpetic keratitis: failure to detect herpes simplex virus infection using the Syva MicroTrak HSV1/HSV2 direct specimen identification/typing test. Recurrent herpetic keratitis is a common ocular condition characterized by the reactivation of the herpes simplex virus (HSV) in the cornea. Diagnosis of HSV infection in the cornea is crucial for appropriate management, as antiviral therapy can help prevent or reduce recurrent episodes. The Syva MicroTrak HSV1/HSV2 direct specimen identification/typing test is commonly used for the detection and typing of HSV in clinical specimens. However, this study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of this test in detecting HSV infection in patients with recurrent herpetic keratitis. It was found that the Syva MicroTrak assay had a low sensitivity and failed to detect HSV infection in the majority of patients. Therefore, alternative diagnostic methods should be considered for accurate detection and typing of HSV in patients with recurrent herpetic keratitis.

Obstructive sleep apnea presenting with nocturnal angina, heart failure, and near-miss sudden death. Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is a common sleep disorder characterized by repetitive episodes of partial or complete upper airway obstruction during sleep. We report a case of OSA presenting with atypical symptoms including nocturnal angina, heart failure, and near-miss sudden death. A 58-year-old male presented with recurrent episodes of chest pain and dyspnea during sleep, accompanied by pulmonary congestion and significant desaturation on pulse oximetry. Polysomnography showed severe OSA with an apnea-hypopnea index of 78 events per hour. Continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) therapy was initiated, resulting in resolution of the patient's symptoms and improvement in cardiac function. This case highlights the importance of considering OSA as a potential etiology in patients presenting with nocturnal angina and heart failure, as prompt diagnosis and treatment with CPAP can improve symptoms and prevent cardiovascular complications. Healthcare providers should maintain a high index of suspicion for OSA in patients with atypical symptoms related to sleep and initiate appropriate diagnostic and therapeutic interventions.

Late metastases of cutaneous melanoma: case report and literature review.  The development of delayed metastases, although rare, is well documented in patients with invasive cutaneous melanoma. We present a case of late metastases of cutaneous melanoma and provide a review of the literature on this topic. The patient, a 54-year-old male, initially presented with a localized tumor on his back, which was successfully excised. However, 16 years later, he developed metastases to the lung and liver. Despite aggressive treatment including surgery and systemic therapy, the patient's condition deteriorated, and he eventually succumbed to the disease. Literature review identified several cases of late metastases in cutaneous melanoma, with a median time to metastasis of 11 years. This highlights the importance of long-term follow-up and surveillance for patients with a history of cutaneous melanoma, even after successful primary tumor removal.

Resolved and unresolved issues in the prevention and treatment of coronary artery disease: a workshop consensus statement. This workshop consensus statement addresses the current status and future directions in the prevention and treatment of coronary artery disease (CAD). The workshop, consisting of leading experts in the field, reviewed the available evidence and identified both resolved and unresolved issues in CAD management. Resolved issues include the importance of lifestyle modifications, such as smoking cessation, healthy diet, and regular exercise, in reducing the risk of CAD. Additionally, the efficacy of pharmacological interventions, such as statins and antiplatelet therapy, in preventing CAD progression and reducing cardiovascular events was confirmed.

However, several unresolved issues remain. These include the optimal management of patients with comorbidities, such as diabetes and chronic kidney disease, and the management of patients with stable angina. The workshop also highlighted the need for further research to elucidate the role of emerging interventions, such as novel anti-inflammatory agents and genetic testing, in CAD prevention and treatment.

In conclusion, while significant progress has been made in the prevention and treatment of CAD, there are still several unresolved issues that require further investigation. Collaboration between researchers, clinicians, and policymakers is essential to address these challenges and improve patient outcomes in CAD.

Audit of results of operations for infantile pyloric stenosis in a district general hospital Because of the proposal that infants with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis should only be treated by surgeons with an interest in paediatric surgery, we carried out a retrospective study to audit our experience in a district general hospital. In this retrospective study, we aimed to audit the results of operations for infantile pyloric stenosis in a district general hospital, in response to the proposal that only surgeons with a focus on pediatric surgery should treat this condition. We analyzed the data of infants who underwent surgery for hypertrophic pyloric stenosis over a specific time period. Measures of surgical outcome, such as complications and length of hospital stay, were assessed. Our findings suggest that the outcomes of operations for infantile pyloric stenosis in our hospital compare favorably with those reported in the literature. These results support the capability of surgeons in a district general hospital to effectively manage this condition, thus challenging the proposed restriction of treatment to specialized pediatric surgeons.

Cup containment and orientation in cemented total hip arthroplasties.  We reviewed the radiographs of 864 Charnley and STH (Zimmer) cemented total hip arthroplasties with a mean follow-up of seven years (maximum 16 years). In this study, we sought to evaluate the importance of proper cup containment and orientation in cemented total hip arthroplasties (THAs) using the Charnley and STH (Zimmer) systems. A total of 864 THAs were included in this retrospective review, with a mean follow-up duration of seven years (maximum 16 years). Radiographs were analyzed to determine the presence and severity of cup malpositioning, including excessive anteversion, retroversion, and tilt. We found that 12.5% of the THAs exhibited malpositioned cups, with excessive anteversion being the most common deviation. Furthermore, we observed a significant association between cup malpositioning and postoperative complications, such as dislocation and impingement. Additionally, patients with malpositioned cups demonstrated higher rates of component loosening. These findings emphasize the importance of meticulous surgical technique and appropriate intraoperative cup assessment to ensure accurate containment and orientation, promoting better long-term outcomes and reducing the risk of complications in cemented THAs.

Inner ear cholesteatoma and the preservation of cochlear function. Inner ear cholesteatoma is a rare but potentially debilitating condition that can result in hearing loss and vestibular dysfunction. Surgical intervention is often necessary to remove the cholesteatoma and prevent further damage to the cochlea. However, the preservation of cochlear function during surgery remains a challenge. In this retrospective study, we aimed to evaluate the outcomes of cochlear function preservation techniques in patients undergoing surgery for inner ear cholesteatoma. Our findings demonstrated that meticulous dissection and removal of cholesteatoma, coupled with the use of specialized instruments and intraoperative monitoring of cochlear function, resulted in satisfactory preservation of hearing in the majority of cases. Additionally, the use of adjunctive measures such as cochlear implants or hearing aids in patients with preexisting hearing loss improved postoperative auditory outcomes. These results highlight the importance of a multidisciplinary approach and tailored surgical techniques to optimize cochlear function preservation in patients with inner ear cholesteatoma.

Urodynamic morbidity and dysuria prophylaxis. This study aimed to determine the impact of urodynamic morbidity on dysuria prophylaxis in patients undergoing urodynamic testing. A total of 120 patients were included in the analysis. Urodynamic testing was performed using standard techniques, and dysuria prophylaxis was administered prior to the procedure. The incidence of dysuria was assessed at various time points following urodynamic testing. Results showed that 25% of patients experienced dysuria, with the majority of cases occurring within the first 24 hours post-procedure. Dysuria prophylaxis was found to significantly reduce the incidence of dysuria in patients undergoing urodynamic testing. However, it was also observed that certain patient characteristics, such as age and comorbidities, influenced the effectiveness of prophylaxis. These findings highlight the importance of individualized dysuria prophylaxis strategies in patients undergoing urodynamic testing to minimize urodynamic morbidity.

Indium-111-antimyosin scintigraphy after doxorubicin therapy in patients with advanced breast cancer Indium-111-antimyosin (111In-antimyosin) scans were performed in 20 women with advanced breast cancer after 10 cycles of chemotherapy consisting of cyclophosphamide, 5-fluorouracil and doxorubicin (total cumulative dose of doxorubicin of 500 mg/m2).  Antimyosin uptake in the myocardium was quantified by means of a heart-to-lung ratio (HLR).  Antimyosin uptake in the myocardium was observed in 17/20 (85%) patients, and HLR after chemotherapy was 1. In this study, we assessed the cardiac toxicity of doxorubicin therapy in 20 women with advanced breast cancer using Indium-111-antimyosin (111In-antimyosin) scans. After 10 cycles of chemotherapy consisting of cyclophosphamide, 5-fluorouracil, and doxorubicin, with a total cumulative dose of doxorubicin of 500 mg/m2, we quantified antimyosin uptake in the myocardium using a heart-to-lung ratio (HLR). Our results showed that 85% of the patients (17/20) had detectable antimyosin uptake in the myocardium, indicating myocardial injury. The HLR after chemotherapy was 1, suggesting no significant increase in myocardial damage compared to baseline. These findings provide valuable insight into the cardiac safety profile of doxorubicin therapy in patients with advanced breast cancer.

Prevention of hypotension following spinal anaesthesia for elective caesarean section by wrapping of the legs.  Twenty-four parturients undergoing elective Caesarean section were allocated randomly to have the legs wrapped with elasticated Esmarch bandages immediately following spinal anaesthesia or to serve as controls. Hypotension is a common complication following spinal anesthesia for elective cesarean section. Various methods have been explored to prevent or minimize this effect. In this study, we evaluated the efficacy of leg wrapping using elasticated Esmarch bandages in preventing hypotension in parturients undergoing elective cesarean section. A total of twenty-four parturients were randomly allocated to either have their legs wrapped immediately after spinal anesthesia or to serve as controls. The occurrence of hypotension, defined as a decrease in systolic blood pressure by more than 20% from baseline, was compared between the two groups. Our results showed that leg wrapping significantly reduced the incidence of hypotension in the intervention group compared to the control group. This simple and non-invasive preventive measure may be a valuable addition to the management of spinal anesthesia for elective cesarean section to improve maternal hemodynamic stability.

Fatal sepsis following intravesical bacillus Calmette-Guerin administration for bladder cancer.  Intravesical administration of bacillus Calmette-Guerin has been shown to be highly effective treatment of superficial bladder cancer. However, this treatment is not without risks, as this case report highlights. A 70-year-old male with a history of superficial bladder cancer received intravesical bacillus Calmette-Guerin administration as part of his treatment regimen. Within 48 hours of administration, he developed symptoms of sepsis, including fever, hypotension, and altered mental status. Despite immediate medical intervention, the patient deteriorated rapidly and eventually succumbed to septic shock. Blood cultures obtained during the patient's hospitalization grew Mycobacterium bovis, confirming the diagnosis of fatal sepsis secondary to bacillus Calmette-Guerin administration. This case emphasizes the importance of considering sepsis as a potential complication of intravesical bacillus Calmette-Guerin treatment and highlights the need for prompt recognition and aggressive management in these cases. Further research is needed to better understand the risk factors and develop strategies to prevent this potentially life-threatening complication.

Intravesical condyloma acuminatum with progression to verrucous carcinoma. We present a rare case of intravesical condyloma acuminatum that progressed to verrucous carcinoma in a 56-year-old male. The patient initially presented with lower urinary tract symptoms and hematuria. Cystoscopy revealed multiple papillary lesions in the bladder, which were biopsied and diagnosed as condyloma acuminatum. Over the next few years, despite multiple treatment modalities including transurethral resection, laser ablation, and intravesical immunotherapy, the lesions gradually transformed into verrucous carcinoma. Histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis. Verrucous carcinoma is a distinct variant of squamous cell carcinoma, characterized by slow growth, absence of metastasis, and limited potential for invasion. Treatment options for verrucous carcinoma of the bladder are limited and primarily include surgery. Regular surveillance is crucial given the potential for malignant transformation. Further understanding of the genetic and molecular mechanisms underlying this progression is warranted.

Fatal pulmonary embolism caused by streptokinase treatment of deep venous thrombosis of the leg? During the last 10 years, four of 150 (2. This abstract discusses a case report and literature review on primary bronchial malignant melanoma, a rare type of cancer that occurs in the lower respiratory tract. The case involves a 34-year-old woman who presented with a persistent cough and was diagnosed with a polypoid mass obstructing the left mainstem bronchus. Biopsies revealed a malignant epithelioid tumor resembling an atypical carcinoid, but further analysis confirmed it to be melanoma. The patient underwent surgery to remove the tumor, but 19 months later, a similar tumor was found in her left adrenal gland. The literature review highlights that melanoma in the lower respiratory tract is typically found in adults and tends to present as a central polypoid growth, which can be treated with surgical resection.

Plasma thrombin-antithrombin III complexes in the diagnosis of primary hepatocellular carcinoma complicating liver cirrhosis. The aim of this study was to evaluate the usefulness of plasma thrombin-antithrombin III (TAT) complexes as a diagnostic marker for primary hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in patients with liver cirrhosis. A total of 67 patients with liver cirrhosis, including 35 with HCC and 32 without HCC, were enrolled in this study. Plasma TAT complexes were measured using an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay. The results showed that the levels of plasma TAT complexes were significantly higher in patients with HCC compared to those without HCC (p < 0.05). Furthermore, the sensitivity and specificity of plasma TAT complexes for the diagnosis of HCC were 74.3% and 78.1%, respectively. The positive predictive value was 71.8% and the negative predictive value was 81.3%. Our findings suggest that plasma TAT complexes may serve as a useful diagnostic marker for primary HCC complicating liver cirrhosis. Further studies with larger sample sizes are needed to validate these results.

Dwarf locus mutants lacking three pituitary cell types result from mutations in the POU-domain gene pit-1. Mutations in the POU-domain gene pit-1 have been found to be responsible for dwarf locus mutants that lack three pituitary cell types. These mutants exhibit stunted growth and impaired hormone production due to the absence of somatotrophs, lactotrophs, and thyrotrophs in the pituitary gland. Pit-1 plays a crucial role in the differentiation and development of these specific cell types, and its mutations lead to a disruption in their formation. This discovery provides valuable insights into the genetic basis of pituitary gland development and may contribute to the understanding and treatment of dwarfism and related endocrine disorders.

Steroid anabolic drugs and arterial complications in an athlete--a case history. We present the case of a 26-year-old male athlete who developed arterial complications following the misuse of steroid anabolic drugs. The patient had been self-administering high doses of anabolic steroids for muscle gain and performance enhancement for several months. He subsequently developed symptoms including severe pain, discoloration, and coolness of the upper extremities. Diagnostic imaging revealed multiple arterial occlusions, most notably in the brachial and radial arteries. The patient underwent urgent arterial thrombectomy and was started on anticoagulation therapy. This case highlights the potential vascular complications associated with the misuse of anabolic steroids and emphasizes the need for education and intervention to prevent such adverse events in athletes.

The "numb cheek-limp lower lid" syndrome. We present a case series of three patients who developed a unique syndrome characterized by a numb cheek and a limp lower lid following cosmetic injections of dermal fillers. All patients had a history of prior facial cosmetic procedures with no previous complications. Examination revealed isolated sensory loss in the affected cheek and weakness of the orbicularis oculi muscle resulting in a droopy lower eyelid. Neurological evaluation, including imaging studies, was unremarkable. Symptoms persisted for an average of 6 months before gradually improving. This novel syndrome supports the need for caution in facial filler injections and highlights the importance of recognizing and managing potential complications in aesthetic procedures.

Epidemiology of primary osteogenic sarcoma in the San Francisco Bay Area of California. We conducted an epidemiological study to investigate the incidence and demographic characteristics of primary osteogenic sarcoma in the San Francisco Bay Area of California. A retrospective analysis of medical records from five major hospitals in the region revealed a total of 82 cases diagnosed between January 2010 and December 2019. The annual incidence of primary osteogenic sarcoma was estimated to be 0.8 cases per million population. The mean age at diagnosis was 17 years, with a slight male preponderance (56% males, 44% females). The most common site of tumor occurrence was the femur (52%), followed by the tibia (21%) and humerus (11%). Of the cases, 25% were classified as localized disease, 45% had regional spread, and 30% were diagnosed with distant metastases. The overall 5-year survival rate was determined to be 52%. These findings provide valuable insights into the epidemiology and clinical characteristics of primary osteogenic sarcoma in the San Francisco Bay Area, aiding in the development of targeted prevention and treatment strategies.

A prospective randomized evaluation of chronic peritoneal catheters.  Insertion site and intraperitoneal segment. Chronic peritoneal catheters are commonly used in patients requiring long-term peritoneal dialysis. However, the optimal insertion site and intraperitoneal segment of these catheters remain unclear. In this study, we conducted a prospective randomized evaluation to compare the outcomes of chronic peritoneal catheters inserted either through the periumbilical or the lateral abdominal wall, and positioned in the pelvic or subdiaphragmatic region.

A total of 150 patients undergoing chronic peritoneal dialysis were randomly assigned to one of four groups: periumbilical pelvic (PP), periumbilical subdiaphragmatic (PS), lateral pelvic (LP), or lateral subdiaphragmatic (LS). The primary outcomes included catheter-related complications, such as infection, leakage, and obstruction, as well as overall catheter survival. Secondary outcomes included dialysis adequacy, hospitalization rates, and patient discomfort.

Preliminary results suggest that the periumbilical insertion site was associated with a lower incidence of catheter-related complications compared to the lateral abdominal wall (p<0.001). There was no significant difference in catheter survival or dialysis adequacy between the two insertion sites. However, patients in the periumbilical groups reported less postoperative pain and discomfort compared to those in the lateral abdominal wall groups (p=0.002).

Further analysis is ongoing to determine the optimal intraperitoneal segment for chronic peritoneal catheter placement. This study provides valuable insights into improving the outcomes and patient experience in peritoneal dialysis.

Neurofibromatosis type 2: report of a family and review of current evaluation and treatment. Neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2) is a rare autosomal dominant genetic disorder characterized by the development of bilateral vestibular schwannomas and other central nervous system tumors. This study presents a case report of a family affected by NF2 and provides an overview of the current evaluation and treatment options available for this condition. The family members displayed classic clinical features including bilateral acoustic neuromas and presence of cutaneous schwannomas. Genetic testing confirmed the presence of a mutation in the NF2 gene. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and audiological evaluations were performed to assess tumor burden and hearing status. Treatment options such as surgical resection, radiation therapy, and auditory rehabilitation were discussed with the patients and their families. Continued research and advancements in management strategies are essential for improving outcomes in patients with NF2.

Dysgeusia, gustatory sweating, and crocodile tears syndrome induced by a cerebellopontine angle meningioma. We present the case of a 45-year-old female who developed dysgeusia, gustatory sweating, and crocodile tears syndrome as a result of a cerebellopontine angle meningioma. These symptoms are rare and are considered to be characteristic of cranial nerve dysfunction. The patient initially presented with facial pain, hearing loss, and imbalance. Imaging revealed a mass lesion in the cerebellopontine angle. Surgical resection of the tumor was performed, and histopathology confirmed the diagnosis of meningioma. Following surgery, the patient experienced resolution of facial pain and improvement in hearing loss and imbalance. However, she subsequently developed dysgeusia, gustatory sweating, and crocodile tears syndrome, which were attributed to disruption of the facial nerve fibers by the tumor. This case highlights the importance of considering cranial nerve dysfunction as a potential presentation of cerebellopontine angle meningiomas and the possible development of these unique symptoms following tumor resection. Early recognition and appropriate management are crucial to optimize patient outcomes.

Low-dose aspirin does not influence the clinical course of women with mild pregnancy-induced hypertension. In this study, we investigated the effect of low-dose aspirin on the clinical course of women with mild pregnancy-induced hypertension.  1. A total of 100 pregnant women with mild hypertension were randomly divided into two groups: the aspirin group, receiving 100 mg of aspirin daily, and the control group, receiving a placebo.  2. Blood pressure, proteinuria levels, and other clinical parameters were monitored throughout the study.  3. There were no significant differences in blood pressure, proteinuria levels, or any other clinical parameters between the two groups.  4. Furthermore, the incidence of complications such as preeclampsia, preterm birth, and fetal growth restriction did not differ between the two groups.  5. Overall, our findings suggest that low-dose aspirin does not influence the clinical course of women with mild pregnancy-induced hypertension.

Prolonged response to carboplatin in an infant with brain stem glioma.  Adults and children with brain stem gliomas have a mean survival time of 15 months after radiation therapy (XRT). We report the case of a 10-month-old infant with a brain stem glioma who had a prolonged response to carboplatin therapy. The patient initially presented with symptoms including cranial nerve palsies and ataxia, and imaging studies revealed a diffuse infiltrative brain stem lesion. A biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of a high-grade glioma. The patient received radiation therapy, but experienced disease progression after 6 months. Carboplatin was then initiated as salvage therapy, and repeat imaging showed stabilization of the tumor. The patient continued to receive carboplatin for a total of 20 cycles, and at the time of last follow-up, the tumor remained stable without evidence of disease progression. This case highlights the potential benefit of carboplatin in the treatment of brain stem gliomas and suggests that further investigation is warranted.

Pyogenic spinal sepsis in adults.  Twenty adult patients presented with bacteriologically and histologically proven nontuberculous spinal sepsis. The majority of patients (80%) had pre-existing risk factors such as diabetes mellitus, intravenous drug use, or immunosuppression. The most common presenting symptoms were localized back pain, fever, and neurological deficits. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) was used as the primary diagnostic modality and showed evidence of spinal infection in all patients. The most frequently isolated pathogens were Staphylococcus aureus and Escherichia coli. Surgical intervention was required in all cases, with decompression and debridement of the affected spinal segments. Antibiotic therapy was administered for an average duration of six weeks. The overall mortality rate was 20%, mainly attributed to delayed diagnosis and presence of multiple comorbidities. Complications included persistent neurological deficits, wound infection, and vertebral collapse. This study highlights the importance of early diagnosis and prompt surgical intervention in the management of pyogenic spinal sepsis to improve patient outcomes.

Plaque morphology and pathologic changes in arteries from patients dying after coronary balloon angioplasty Morphologic correlates of pathologic success or failure were studied at autopsy in 28 patients with 40 coronary arteries that had been subjected to balloon angioplasty.  The presence of the following histologic features was evaluated: plaque concentricity or eccentricity, calcification, fibrous or fibropultaceous plaque, medial disruption, luminal thrombus and inflammation. This study examined the plaque morphology and pathologic changes in arteries of patients who died after undergoing coronary balloon angioplasty. Autopsy analysis was conducted on 28 patients, with a total of 40 coronary arteries that had undergone the procedure. The histologic features evaluated included plaque concentricity or eccentricity, calcification, fibrous or fibropultaceous plaque, medial disruption, luminal thrombus, and inflammation. The presence of these features was assessed as potential correlates of pathologic success or failure. The findings provide insight into the morphological characteristics associated with balloon angioplasty outcomes and contribute to a better understanding of the pathological mechanisms underlying this procedure.

Embryologic fusion planes and the spread of cutaneous carcinoma: a review and reassessment. Skin carcinomas, including basal cell carcinoma (BCC) and squamous cell carcinoma (SCC), are among the most common types of cancer. It has long been known that these cancers often spread along embryologic fusion planes, but the exact mechanisms and implications of this phenomenon remain unclear. This paper provides a comprehensive review and reassessment of the literature regarding the spread of cutaneous carcinoma along fusion planes. The authors analyze various studies that investigate the relationship between the embryologic fusion planes and the spread of BCC and SCC. They discuss the potential implications of these findings in terms of tumor staging, surgical planning, and prognosis. The paper also highlights areas for future research, such as the identification of specific molecular markers or genetic mutations that may play a role in the spread of cutaneous carcinoma along embryologic fusion planes. Overall, this review aims to enhance our understanding of the mechanisms underlying the spread of skin carcinomas and inform clinical practice in the management of these cancers.

Duodenal ulcer is associated with low dietary linoleic acid intake.  It has been suggested that the falling incidence and virulence of duodenal ulcer is related to increased dietary polyunsaturated essential fatty acid intake. The association between dietary linoleic acid intake and the development of duodenal ulcer was investigated in a study. The results revealed that low dietary linoleic acid intake was significantly associated with an increased risk of developing duodenal ulcer. It was also observed that the incidence and virulence of duodenal ulcer have been decreasing, which may be attributed to the increased intake of dietary polyunsaturated essential fatty acids. These findings suggest that a higher intake of linoleic acid, as part of a diet rich in polyunsaturated essential fatty acids, may have a protective effect against the development and severity of duodenal ulcer. Further research is needed to explore the underlying mechanisms of this relationship.

Epidemiologic risk factors for children with acute lower respiratory tract infection in Buenos Aires, Argentina: a matched case-control study. Acute lower respiratory tract infection (ALRTI) is a major cause of morbidity and mortality in children worldwide, particularly in developing countries. This study aimed to identify epidemiologic risk factors associated with ALRTI in children in Buenos Aires, Argentina. A matched case-control study was conducted, including children aged 1 month to 5 years. Cases were children hospitalized with ALRTI, and controls were age- and sex-matched children without ALRTI, attending well-child clinics. Data on potential risk factors, including socio-demographic characteristics, household factors, maternal factors, and child factors, were collected through interviews with caregivers. Multivariate logistic regression analysis was performed to identify independent risk factors for ALRTI. Results showed that overcrowding, low maternal education, low socioeconomic status, indoor cooking with solid fuels, and parental smoking were significantly associated with increased risk of ALRTI. These findings highlight the importance of addressing social determinants of health, improving living conditions, promoting smoke-free environments, and implementing interventions to decrease ALRTI burden in children in Buenos Aires, Argentina. Further research is warranted to evaluate the effectiveness of targeted interventions to reduce ALRTI in this population.

De novo carcinoma of the lower urinary tract in renal allograft recipients. De novo carcinoma of the lower urinary tract is a rare but important complication in renal allograft recipients. This study aimed to evaluate the incidence, risk factors, and outcomes of de novo carcinoma in this population. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 120 renal allograft recipients who underwent regular follow-up examinations over a period of 10 years. Ten patients (8.3%) were diagnosed with de novo carcinoma of the lower urinary tract, with a mean time to diagnosis of 5.2 years post-transplantation. Multiple logistic regression analysis identified male gender, older age at transplantation, and a history of smoking as significant risk factors for de novo carcinoma development. The outcomes of patients with de novo carcinoma were found to be poor, with high rates of metastasis and mortality. Therefore, careful surveillance and early detection strategies are recommended for renal allograft recipients to improve outcomes and survival in this population.

Orthostatic hypotension after spinal cord injury: treatment with fludrocortisone and ergotamine. Orthostatic hypotension (OH) is a common complication of spinal cord injury (SCI) that can significantly impact patients' quality of life. In this study, we evaluate the efficacy of a combination therapy consisting of fludrocortisone and ergotamine in the treatment of OH in SCI patients.

A total of 25 SCI patients with OH were enrolled in this prospective study. The patients received oral fludrocortisone (0.1 mg/day) and ergotamine (2 mg/day) for a duration of 12 weeks. The primary outcome measure was the change in mean arterial pressure (MAP) upon standing, assessed using continuous non-invasive blood pressure monitoring.

Following the 12-week treatment period, significant improvements in MAP upon standing were observed in the study population. The mean increase in MAP was 15 mmHg (p < 0.001), indicating a substantial reduction in orthostatic hypotension. Furthermore, the combination therapy was well-tolerated, with no significant adverse effects reported.

In conclusion, the combination therapy of fludrocortisone and ergotamine appears to be an effective treatment option for orthostatic hypotension in SCI patients. Further studies with larger sample sizes and longer follow-up periods are warranted to confirm these findings and establish optimal dosing regimens.

Longitudinal histopathologic assessment of rejection after bladder-drained canine pancreas allograft transplantation. Longitudinal histopathologic assessment is crucial in evaluating rejection after bladder-drained canine pancreas allograft transplantation. This study aimed to assess the rejection process over time in a canine model of pancreas transplantation. A total of ten pancreas transplantation procedures were performed, and bladder-drainage was used as the method of monitoring graft function. Histopathologic evaluation was conducted at various time points post-transplantation, ranging from one week to six months. The results showed a progressive increase in rejection severity over time, with acute cellular rejection observed in all grafts. Additionally, chronic rejection, characterized by interstitial fibrosis and lymphocytic infiltrates, was observed in the later time points. The assessment of rejection severity provided valuable insights into the progression and characteristics of rejection in bladder-drained canine pancreas allograft transplantation. This knowledge can contribute to improving immunosuppressive strategies and ultimately enhancing graft survival in clinical pancreas transplantation.

Insulinoma after streptozotocin therapy for metastatic gastrinoma: natural history or iatrogenic complication? Islet cell carcinoma frequently produces more than one chemical product, although its clinical expression is usually restricted to a single hormone. We present a case of a patient who developed an insulinoma after receiving streptozotocin therapy for metastatic gastrinoma. Islet cell carcinoma, including gastrinoma, has been known to produce multiple hormone products, but typically only exhibits symptoms related to a single hormone. This case raises the question of whether the development of an insulinoma in our patient was a natural progression of the disease or an iatrogenic complication of streptozotocin therapy. Further studies are needed to understand the underlying mechanisms and determine the appropriate management for such cases.

Survival rates from out-of-hospital cardiac arrest: recommendations for uniform definitions and data to report. Survival rates from out-of-hospital cardiac arrest (OHCA) vary widely across studies, making it difficult to compare outcomes and assess the effectiveness of interventions. In an effort to standardize reporting and improve data accuracy, the International Liaison Committee on Resuscitation (ILCOR) has developed recommendations for uniform definitions and data reporting for OHCA survival rates. These recommendations include a standardized definition of OHCA survival, the use of common data elements, and the establishment of a minimum dataset for reporting. By adopting these recommendations, researchers can ensure consistency in reporting OHCA survival rates and facilitate comparisons between different populations and interventions. Furthermore, these recommendations will enable the identification of knowledge gaps and areas for improvement in cardiac arrest care and research. Implementation of these standardized definitions and data reporting is crucial for advancing OHCA research and ultimately improving patient outcomes.

The Hastings bipolar hemiarthroplasty for subcapital fractures of the femoral neck. Subcapital fractures of the femoral neck are common in the elderly population and often require surgical intervention. The aim of this study was to evaluate the outcomes of the Hastings bipolar hemiarthroplasty as a treatment option for these fractures. A retrospective analysis of patients who underwent this procedure between 2010 and 2015 was conducted. The mean age of the patients was 78 years, with a majority being females. The overall complication rate was low, with only two cases of dislocation and one case of infection. Functional outcomes were evaluated using the Harris Hip Score and showed significant improvement postoperatively. Radiographic assessment demonstrated good implant positioning and union of the fracture in all cases. The Hastings bipolar hemiarthroplasty is a reliable treatment option for subcapital fractures of the femoral neck, providing good functional outcomes and low complication rates. Further prospective studies are needed to validate these findings.

A case-control study of Alzheimer's disease in Australia. This case-control study aimed to investigate the association between Alzheimer's disease (AD) and various risk factors in an Australian population. A total of 200 AD cases and 200 age and sex-matched controls were included in the study. Participants underwent comprehensive neurological and neuropsychological evaluations to confirm the diagnosis of AD.

Results showed a significant association between AD and increasing age, with older individuals having a higher risk of developing the disease. Additionally, a family history of AD was found to be a significant risk factor, suggesting a genetic predisposition to the disease. Other risk factors such as smoking, alcohol consumption, and education level did not show a significant association with AD.

These findings highlight the importance of age and family history as important risk factors for AD in the Australian population. Further research is needed to explore other potential risk factors and their interactions in the development of AD.

Thirty-six month follow-up of a contemporary phakic intraocular lens for the surgical correction of myopia.  Twenty-three eyes underwent implantation of a glass anterior chamber phakic myopic intraocular lens by one of the surgeon co-authors. The purpose of this study was to assess the long-term safety and efficacy of a contemporary phakic intraocular lens (IOL) for the correction of myopia. A total of 23 eyes of 15 patients underwent implantation of a glass anterior chamber phakic myopic IOL. Follow-up examinations were conducted at 1, 6, 12, 24, and 36 months postoperatively. The mean preoperative refractive error was -8.3 diopters. At the 36-month follow-up, the mean postoperative refractive error was -0.2 diopters, indicating stable and successful correction of myopia. No serious complications or adverse events were observed during the follow-up period. In conclusion, the contemporary phakic IOL appears to be a safe and effective option for the surgical correction of myopia with favorable long-term outcomes.

Ki-67 immunostaining in uveal melanoma.  The effect of pre-enucleation radiotherapy. Uveal melanoma is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in adults. Pre-enucleation radiotherapy has been used as an adjuvant treatment for uveal melanoma to reduce the risk of tumor seeding during enucleation. This study aimed to investigate the effect of pre-enucleation radiotherapy on Ki-67 immunostaining in uveal melanoma. The study included 24 patients who underwent enucleation for uveal melanoma, with 12 patients receiving pre-enucleation radiotherapy and 12 patients not receiving any adjuvant treatment. Ki-67 immunostaining was performed on the tumor sections, and the proliferative index was determined. The results showed that the mean Ki-67 proliferative index was significantly lower in the pre-enucleation radiotherapy group compared to the control group (p<0.05). This suggests that pre-enucleation radiotherapy may have a suppressive effect on tumor cell proliferation in uveal melanoma. Further studies are needed to explore the potential role of Ki-67 immunostaining as a prognostic marker in uveal melanoma and the impact of pre-enucleation radiotherapy on long-term outcomes.

Sympathomimetics for acute severe asthma: should only beta 2-selective agonists be used? Sympathomimetics have become a mainstay of the treatment of acute asthma. Sympathomimetics, specifically beta 2-selective agonists, have been widely used as the primary treatment option for acute severe asthma. However, the question remains as to whether only beta 2-selective agonists should be utilized or if other sympathomimetics could provide additional benefits.
