This review aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of various sympathomimetics in the management of acute severe asthma. Several studies comparing beta 2-selective agonists with non-selective sympathomimetics such as epinephrine and isoproterenol have shown comparable outcomes in terms of bronchodilation and symptom relief. Furthermore, non-selective sympathomimetics may offer advantages such as increased bronchodilation and systemic effects, which could be beneficial in severe cases. However, caution should be exercised due to the potential for cardiovascular side effects. Further research is needed to establish clear guidelines regarding the use of non-selective sympathomimetics in the treatment of acute severe asthma.

Practice effects on the preprogramming of discrete movements in Parkinson's disease. Parkinson's disease is characterized by motor symptoms such as bradykinesia and rigidity, which can severely affect the ability to perform voluntary movements. The present study aimed to investigate the practice effects on the preprogramming of discrete movements in individuals with Parkinson's disease. A total of 30 patients with Parkinson's disease and 30 age-matched healthy controls participated in the study. Participants performed a finger tapping task, and the movement times and error rates were recorded. The results showed that patients with Parkinson's disease exhibited longer movement times and higher error rates compared to healthy controls. Additionally, the practice effects were found to be significantly reduced in the patient group. This suggests that Parkinson's disease affects the preprogramming of discrete movements, leading to impaired motor performance and limited practice-related improvements. Further research is needed to develop effective interventions to enhance movement preprogramming in individuals with Parkinson's disease.

Multimodality therapy for advanced and recurrent vulvar squamous cell carcinoma.  A pilot project. This study aimed to evaluate the outcomes of multimodality therapy in patients with advanced and recurrent vulvar squamous cell carcinoma (VSCC). A pilot project was conducted on 20 patients who received a combination of surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy. The median age of the patients was 60 years. Complete or partial response to therapy was observed in 85% of the patients, with a median overall survival of 32 months. The most common treatment-related adverse events were mild to moderate hematologic toxicities and dermatologic reactions. No treatment-related mortalities were observed. The combination of surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy appears to be a feasible and effective treatment option for patients with advanced and recurrent VSCC. Further studies with larger sample sizes are warranted to confirm these findings and to optimize the treatment protocol for this patient population.

A rare case of renovascular hypertension due to iatrogenic thoracoabdominal aortic dissection. We report a rare case of renovascular hypertension caused by iatrogenic thoracoabdominal aortic dissection. A 47-year-old male with a history of chronic kidney disease and hypertension underwent an endovascular repair of a thoracic aortic aneurysm. Post-procedure, he developed severe hypertension and acute kidney injury. Imaging studies revealed a dissection extending from the thoracoabdominal aorta to the left renal artery. The patient underwent an emergent open surgical repair with re-implantation of the left renal artery. Following the procedure, his blood pressure normalized and renal function improved. Renovascular hypertension due to iatrogenic thoracoabdominal aortic dissection is a rare but important complication that should be considered in patients with new-onset or worsening hypertension following aortic interventions. Timely recognition and prompt surgical intervention can lead to positive outcomes in these patients.

Neonatal intracranial choriocarcinoma. Neonatal intracranial choriocarcinoma is an extremely rare and aggressive tumor that affects the central nervous system of newborns. The presentation of symptoms varies and can include hydrocephalus, seizures, and intracranial hemorrhage. Early diagnosis is challenging due to the nonspecific nature of symptoms and the rarity of the condition. Imaging studies, such as computed tomography (CT) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), are essential for identifying the tumor's location and extent. Histopathological examination of a biopsy is required for confirming the diagnosis. Prompt and aggressive treatment is crucial and typically involves a combination of surgical resection, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy. The prognosis for neonatal intracranial choriocarcinoma remains poor, with high mortality rates due to the tumor's aggressive behavior and the limited effectiveness of currently available treatments. Further research is needed to improve early detection, develop more targeted therapies, and ultimately improve outcomes for affected infants.

Cerebrospinal fluid neopterin in human immunodeficiency virus type 1 infection. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) neopterin has been proposed as a marker of immune activation in various central nervous system (CNS) diseases. We investigated the levels of CSF neopterin in patients with human immunodeficiency virus type 1 (HIV-1) infection and its correlation with CNS involvement. CSF neopterin levels were significantly higher in HIV-1-infected patients with CNS involvement compared to those without CNS involvement (p<0.001). Furthermore, CSF neopterin levels were positively correlated with CSF HIV-1 RNA levels (p=0.002) and negatively correlated with CD4+ T-cell counts (p=0.006). These findings suggest that CSF neopterin may serve as a useful biomarker for monitoring immune activation and CNS involvement in HIV-1-infected patients. Future studies are needed to determine the potential role of CSF neopterin in predicting disease progression and guiding therapeutic interventions in this population.

Retroperitoneal mobilization of the vas deferens in the complex vasovasostomy. Background: Vasovasostomy is a common procedure performed for the treatment of vasectomy-induced infertility. However, in cases where there is a long obstruction gap, a complex vasovasostomy technique involving retroperitoneal mobilization of the vas deferens may be necessary to achieve successful reconnection.

Methods: A retrospective analysis was performed on a cohort of patients who underwent complex vasovasostomy with retroperitoneal mobilization of the vas deferens. Surgical technique, outcomes, and complications were evaluated.

Results: A total of 23 patients were included in the study. The retroperitoneal mobilization technique allowed for successful reconnection of the vas deferens in all cases, with a mean operative time of 72 minutes. Overall, 87% of patients achieved postoperative sperm return, indicating successful patency. Complication rates were low, with only one case of postoperative hematoma requiring intervention.

Conclusion: Retroperitoneal mobilization of the vas deferens is a reliable and effective technique for complex vasovasostomy in cases with long obstruction gaps. The procedure provides excellent outcomes with low complication rates, making it a valuable option for infertility treatment.

Biliary cholesterol transport and precipitation: introduction and overview of conference.  Cholesterol is secreted into bile as cholesterol-phospholipid vesicles. In this conference proceedings, an introduction and overview of the topic of biliary cholesterol transport and precipitation is provided. The process of cholesterol secretion into bile as cholesterol-phospholipid vesicles is outlined. The conference aimed to bring together researchers and clinicians to discuss the latest advances in understanding the mechanisms underlying biliary cholesterol transport and the factors influencing cholesterol precipitation.

Several key topics were covered during the conference, including the role of hepatic ATP-binding cassette (ABC) transporters in mediating the efflux of cholesterol into bile, the modulation of biliary cholesterol secretion by lipoproteins and bile acids, and the impact of genetic and environmental factors on biliary cholesterol metabolism. Additionally, the conference highlighted the clinical implications of impaired biliary cholesterol transport and precipitation, such as the development of gallstones and the increased risk of cardiovascular disease.

Overall, this conference provided a comprehensive overview of the current knowledge and ongoing research in the field of biliary cholesterol transport and precipitation, with the aim of advancing our understanding of these processes and their clinical relevance.

Laser angioplasty: results of a prospective, multicenter study at 3-year follow-up.  A prospective multicenter trial was initiated to evaluate the efficacy and safety of laser angioplasty. The objective of this study was to assess the long-term outcomes of laser angioplasty in patients with peripheral arterial disease. A prospective multicenter trial was conducted, enrolling participants with symptomatic lower extremity arterial stenosis. The primary endpoint of the study was the occurrence of major adverse cardiovascular events (MACE), including death, myocardial infarction, and target lesion revascularization. Secondary endpoints included procedural success, improvement in symptoms, and patency rates. 

A total of 150 patients were included in the study, and follow-up was conducted at 3 years. The results showed a procedural success rate of 92%, with significant improvement in symptoms observed in most patients. However, the occurrence of MACE was high, with 35% of patients experiencing at least one event during the follow-up period. The patency rate at 3 years was 64%. Complications related to laser angioplasty, such as dissection and perforation, were observed in a small proportion of patients.

In conclusion, laser angioplasty was found to be effective in improving symptoms and achieving procedural success in patients with peripheral arterial disease. However, the occurrence of MACE and the relatively low patency rate highlight the need for further optimization of this technique and the importance of careful patient selection.

Disseminated, nonmeningeal gastrointestinal cryptococcal infection in an HIV-negative patient. Cryptococcal infections are commonly seen in immunocompromised individuals, particularly those with HIV. However, such infections in HIV-negative patients are rare and often present with atypical manifestations. We report a case of disseminated gastrointestinal cryptococcal infection in an HIV-negative patient.

A 42-year-old male with a history of hypertension presented with a 3-month history of abdominal pain and weight loss. Initial investigations including blood tests and imaging revealed nonspecific findings. However, subsequent endoscopy and histopathological examination of gastric biopsies demonstrated numerous encapsulated yeast cells consistent with Cryptococcus species.

Further evaluation, including lumbar puncture, cerebrospinal fluid analysis, and serum cryptococcal antigen titer, all yielded negative results. The patient was initiated on antifungal therapy with fluconazole and showed a significant improvement in symptoms after 2 weeks. Genetic testing of the isolate confirmed Cryptococcus neoformans.

This case highlights that clinicians should consider disseminated cryptococcal infection in the differential diagnosis of patients presenting with gastrointestinal symptoms, regardless of their HIV status. Early recognition and appropriate management are crucial to improve outcomes in these patients.

Therapeutic dilemmas associated with antenatally detected ovarian cysts. The aim of this study was to evaluate the therapeutic dilemmas associated with antenatally detected ovarian cysts. A retrospective analysis was conducted on pregnant women who were diagnosed with ovarian cysts during routine ultrasound examinations. The study included 38 cases of antenatally detected ovarian cysts, of which 17 were unilateral and 21 were bilateral. The majority of the cysts were simple in nature (76.3%), with only a few cases presenting with complex features. The main dilemma was the decision regarding appropriate management, with options including expectant management, surgical intervention, or a combination of both. Factors such as cyst size, morphology, and associated symptoms were taken into consideration when making the therapeutic decision. This study highlights the challenges faced by clinicians in managing antenatally detected ovarian cysts and emphasizes the need for individualized patient care.

Nasolacrimal obstruction after inferior meatus nasal antrostomy. Inferior meatus nasal antrostomy (IMNA) is a common surgical procedure to treat chronic maxillary sinusitis. However, complications such as nasolacrimal obstruction can arise. This retrospective study evaluated the incidence and management of nasolacrimal obstruction after IMNA. A total of 78 patients who underwent IMNA between 2015 and 2019 were included. Four patients (5.1%) developed nasolacrimal obstruction postoperatively. Symptoms included epiphora, discharge, and tearing. All patients were managed conservatively initially with topical medications, but two patients required nasolacrimal duct probing and stenting due to persistent symptoms. One patient underwent endoscopic dacryocystorhinostomy. The mean follow-up period was 16 months, with three patients experiencing complete resolution of symptoms. Understanding the risk and appropriate management of nasolacrimal obstruction after IMNA is crucial for otolaryngologists and ophthalmologists. Further studies are needed to determine optimal preventive measures and identify factors contributing to its development.

Itraconazole in opportunistic mycoses: cryptococcosis and aspergillosis. Opportunistic mycoses, such as cryptococcosis and aspergillosis, pose a significant threat to immunocompromised patients. This study aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of itraconazole in the treatment of these fungal infections. A total of 78 patients with confirmed cryptococcosis or aspergillosis were enrolled and treated with itraconazole. The clinical response was assessed based on the resolution of symptoms, radiographic improvement, and mycological clearance. The overall response rate was 82%, with 75% in cryptococcosis and 88% in aspergillosis. Adverse events of gastrointestinal nature were the most common, reported in 25% of patients. No serious drug-related adverse events were observed. Itraconazole demonstrates promising efficacy and safety for the management of cryptococcosis and aspergillosis.

Improved early detection of recurrence in prostatic carcinoma following hormonal therapy.  Combined use of palpation and fine needle aspiration cytology. Prostate carcinoma is a common malignancy in men, and hormonal therapy is a widely used treatment approach. Recurrence of prostate carcinoma following hormonal therapy poses a significant challenge in clinical management. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of combined palpation and fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) in detecting early recurrence in prostatic carcinoma after hormonal therapy. A total of 120 patients who underwent hormonal therapy for prostatic carcinoma were enrolled in this prospective study. Follow-up examinations were conducted at 3-month intervals for a duration of 2 years. Results showed that combined palpation and FNAC had a sensitivity of 85% and specificity of 92% in detecting recurrence. Furthermore, the positive predictive value and negative predictive value were 80% and 94%, respectively. The study highlights the importance of combined palpation and FNAC in early detection of recurrence in prostatic carcinoma following hormonal therapy, thereby enabling timely intervention and improved patient outcomes. Further studies are warranted to validate these findings and explore the potential of other diagnostic modalities in this context.

Surgical aspects of sclerosing encapsulating peritonitis. Sclerosing encapsulating peritonitis (SEP) is a rare but potentially life-threatening condition characterized by progressive fibrotic encapsulation of the small bowel and other abdominal organs. The objective of this study was to investigate the surgical aspects and outcomes of SEP. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 32 patients who underwent surgery for SEP between 2006 and 2019. The median age of the patients was 45 years, and the most common underlying cause was chronic peritoneal dialysis. The surgical procedures performed included adhesiolysis, enterolysis, resection of diseased bowel segments, and peritoneal lavage. Postoperatively, 84.4% of patients experienced resolution of their symptoms, while the remaining 15.6% had persistent or recurrent symptoms requiring further interventions. Surgical complications occurred in 31.3% of patients, with the most common being wound infection and intra-abdominal abscess. In conclusion, surgical intervention plays a crucial role in the management of SEP, providing symptom relief and disease control in the majority of cases. However, clinicians should be aware of the potential for surgical complications and the need for close postoperative monitoring.

A multifocal schwannoma of the masseteric nerve causing hemicrania. Schwannomas are benign tumors originating from Schwann cells of peripheral nerves. They are commonly found in the head and neck region but are rare in the masseteric nerve. Here, we report a case of a multifocal schwannoma involving the masseteric nerve presenting as hemicrania. The patient presented with severe headache predominantly affecting the right temple. Imaging studies revealed multiple well-defined lesions around the masseteric nerve. Surgical excision of the tumors was performed, and histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of schwannoma. The patient experienced complete resolution of the hemicranial pain postoperatively. This case emphasizes the importance of considering schwannoma in the differential diagnosis of hemicrania and highlights the successful surgical management of this rare entity. Long-term follow-up is recommended to monitor for potential recurrence.

Treatment of leptomeningeal carcinomatosis with continuous intraventricular infusion of recombinant interleukin-2.  A 42-year-old man developed leptomeningeal carcinomatosis 6 years after treatment of a malignant melanoma. Leptomeningeal carcinomatosis is a rare and devastating complication of advanced malignancies. It is associated with a poor prognosis and limited treatment options. We present a case of a 42-year-old man who developed leptomeningeal carcinomatosis six years after treatment for malignant melanoma. Initial treatment with intrathecal chemotherapy provided temporary relief, but the disease progressed rapidly. As a salvage therapy, the patient underwent continuous intraventricular infusion of recombinant interleukin-2. This novel treatment approach resulted in clinical improvement, with resolution of neurological symptoms and stabilization of disease progression. Continuous intraventricular infusion of recombinant interleukin-2 may represent a potential treatment option for patients with leptomeningeal carcinomatosis refractory to conventional therapies. Further studies are needed to evaluate its efficacy and safety in larger cohorts.

Delayed-onset dystonia due to perinatal or early childhood asphyxia. Delayed-onset dystonia is a movement disorder that typically appears several months to years after perinatal or early childhood asphyxia. We report on three cases of delayed-onset dystonia in children who experienced perinatal or early childhood asphyxia. All three patients presented with progressive, generalized dystonia, which started between the ages of 3 and 7 years. Neurological examination revealed abnormal postures, involuntary movements, and dystonic features. Brain imaging showed bilateral basal ganglia involvement in all cases. Despite extensive diagnostic workup, no genetic abnormalities or metabolic disturbances were identified. Treatment with oral medications, including anticholinergics and dopamine-depleting agents, led to partial improvement in motor symptoms. Delayed-onset dystonia should be considered in children with a history of perinatal or early childhood asphyxia presenting with progressive dystonic symptoms. Further research is needed to better understand the pathophysiology and optimize treatment strategies for this condition.

Medical treatment and prevention of peptic ulcer disease.  Many agents seem to be equally effective for the treatment of peptic ulcer disease. These agents include proton pump inhibitors (PPIs), histamine-2 receptor antagonists (H2RAs), and antibiotics for the eradication of Helicobacter pylori (H. pylori) infection. The choice of treatment depends on the underlying cause of the peptic ulcer, presence of H. pylori infection, and individual patient factors. PPIs are the most effective in healing and preventing recurrence of ulcers, while H2RAs provide symptom relief but may be less effective in long-term ulcer healing. Combination therapy with PPIs and antibiotics is recommended for H. pylori eradication to reduce the risk of recurrence. Lifestyle modifications, such as smoking cessation and avoiding nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, are also important in the management and prevention of peptic ulcer disease. Regular monitoring and follow-up are necessary to assess treatment response and prevent complications.

Radiographic identification by mastoid sinus and arterial pattern. This study aimed to assess the feasibility of using mastoid sinus radiographic identification in combination with arterial pattern analysis for accurate diagnosis of patients presenting with pulmonary hypertension. A total of 25 patients with confirmed pulmonary hypertension and 25 control subjects were included in the study. Radiographic examination of the mastoid sinus and arterial pattern was performed and analyzed by experienced radiologists. Results showed that patients with pulmonary hypertension exhibited significant abnormalities in both the mastoid sinus and arterial pattern compared to controls. The combination of these two radiographic identification methods had a sensitivity of 92% and a specificity of 88% in diagnosing pulmonary hypertension. This suggests that the use of mastoid sinus radiographic identification in combination with arterial pattern analysis could be a valuable tool in the accurate diagnosis of pulmonary hypertension.

Ovarian neoplasms and the risk of adnexal torsion.  Previous reports examining adnexal torsion suggested that benign ovarian neoplasms are more likely to undergo torsion than malignant ovarian neoplasms. However, there is limited research and inconsistent findings regarding the association between ovarian neoplasms and the risk of adnexal torsion. This study aimed to investigate this association and determine the prevalence and characteristics of adnexal torsion among patients with ovarian neoplasms. A retrospective analysis was conducted on a large population-based database, including women who were diagnosed with ovarian neoplasms. The results showed that the risk of adnexal torsion was significantly higher among patients with benign ovarian neoplasms compared to those with malignant neoplasms. These findings highlight the importance of considering adnexal torsion as a potential complication in women with benign ovarian neoplasms.

585 nm for the treatment of port-wine stains. Port-wine stains (PWS) are vascular malformations that present as congenital red or purple discolorations on the skin. Laser therapy has been commonly used for their treatment, with varying success rates. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a specific laser wavelength, 585 nm, for the treatment of PWS lesions. A total of 50 patients with PWS lesions were treated with a pulsed dye laser emitting at 585 nm. Clinical photographs were taken before and after treatment, and the degree of improvement was assessed by two independent dermatologists. The results showed that 76% of patients achieved more than 50% improvement in the color and texture of their PWS lesions after a mean of 5 treatment sessions. Adverse effects such as mild pain and transient erythema were reported in a small number of patients. Overall, the findings suggest that 585 nm pulsed dye laser is effective and safe for the treatment of PWS lesions. Further research is needed to optimize treatment protocols and determine long-term outcomes.

Stress and sodium intake in neural control of renal function in hypertension. Hypertension is a major risk factor for the development of renal dysfunction. The neural control of renal function plays a crucial role in the regulation of blood pressure. This review examines the impact of stress and sodium intake on the neural control of renal function in hypertension. Stress-related sympathetic activation can lead to increased renal vasoconstriction and reduced renal blood flow, exacerbating renal dysfunction. Additionally, high sodium intake can increase sympathetic activity and impair renal function through volume expansion and inflammation. Understanding the complex interactions between stress, sodium intake, and the neural control of renal function in hypertension is important for the development of targeted therapeutic strategies to improve renal outcomes in hypertensive patients.

Choledocholithiasis in Chinese immigrants with cholelithiasis.  During the period from January 1987 to December 1989, admissions for biliary tract disease at the New York Infirmary--Beekman Downtown Hospital were split almost evenly between Chinese immigrants from southeast Asia and all other ethnic groups (Caucasian, Hispanic, black, et cetera). In this study, we examined the prevalence of choledocholithiasis in Chinese immigrants with cholelithiasis compared to other ethnic groups. A retrospective analysis was conducted on admissions for biliary tract disease from January 1987 to December 1989 at a New York hospital. The results showed that almost half of the admissions were Chinese immigrants from southeast Asia, indicating a higher prevalence of biliary tract disease in this population. Specifically, choledocholithiasis was found to be more common in Chinese immigrants with cholelithiasis than in other ethnic groups. This finding suggests that there may be genetic or environmental factors contributing to the increased risk of choledocholithiasis in Chinese immigrants. Further research is needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and develop targeted interventions for this at-risk population.

Oral findings in HIV-infected patients attending a department of internal medicine: the contribution of intraoral examination towards the clinical management of HIV disease The occurrence of oral mucosal lesions was studied in 70 consecutive human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)-infected patients, including 35 patients with AIDS, who had been admitted to a Department of Internal Medicine. This study aimed to assess the occurrence of oral mucosal lesions in HIV-infected patients attending a department of internal medicine and evaluate the contribution of intraoral examination in the clinical management of HIV disease. A total of 70 HIV-infected patients, including 35 with AIDS, were included in this study. Intraoral examination revealed oral mucosal lesions in 65 patients (93%), with the most common lesions being Candidiasis (59%), oral hairy leukoplakia (29%), and periodontal disease (27%). The presence of these oral lesions provided important diagnostic and prognostic information for the management of HIV disease. The findings highlight the importance of routine intraoral examination in the comprehensive care of HIV-infected individuals.

Isolated trigeminal sensory loss secondary to a distal anterior inferior cerebellar artery aneurysm: case report.  A previously healthy 25-year-old woman suddenly developed right-sided facial numbness and a headache. We present a case of isolated trigeminal sensory loss secondary to a distal anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA) aneurysm in a previously healthy 25-year-old woman. The patient experienced sudden onset right-sided facial numbness and a headache. Neurological examination revealed decreased sensation in all three branches of the right trigeminal nerve without any other neurological deficits. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) identified a small aneurysm arising from a distal branch of the AICA. The patient underwent successful endovascular coiling of the aneurysm, resulting in complete resolution of the facial numbness. Isolated trigeminal nerve deficits are rare and can present a diagnostic challenge. A thorough evaluation including neuroimaging is essential to identify the underlying etiology. In this case, the prompt recognition and treatment of the distal AICA aneurysm led to a favorable outcome. Clinicians should be aware of this uncommon cause of trigeminal sensory loss to ensure timely diagnosis and appropriate management.

Augmentation mentoplasty using Mersilene mesh.  Many different materials are available for augmentation mentoplasty. Mersilene mesh is a commonly used material for augmentation mentoplasty, a surgical procedure aimed at enhancing the contour and projection of the chin. This retrospective study evaluated the outcomes of 50 consecutive patients who underwent augmentation mentoplasty using Mersilene mesh at a single institution. Patient satisfaction and complications were assessed through medical records and follow-up evaluations. The mean follow-up period was 12 months (range: 6-24 months). The overall patient satisfaction rate was 92%, with a high level of improvement in both aesthetic appearance and self-confidence reported by the majority of patients. Complication rate was low, with only one case of infection and two cases of mild asymmetry requiring revision surgery. No cases of extrusion or rejection of the Mersilene mesh were observed. Augmentation mentoplasty using Mersilene mesh is a safe and effective option for chin augmentation, providing satisfactory outcomes and minimal complications. Further studies with larger sample sizes and longer follow-up periods are warranted to confirm these findings.

Magnetic resonance imaging of cardiac rhabdomyosarcoma. Cardiac rhabdomyosarcoma (RMS) is a rare and aggressive malignant tumor that primarily affects children. This study aims to evaluate the role of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) in the diagnosis and characterization of cardiac RMS. A retrospective analysis of 15 pediatric patients with histopathologically confirmed cardiac RMS was conducted. MRI findings included the location, size, extent of tumor invasion, and presence of distant metastasis. The most common location of cardiac RMS was the left ventricle (60%), followed by the right ventricle (26.7%). Tumor invasion into adjacent structures, including the pericardium and myocardium, was observed in all cases. Distant metastasis was identified in 33.3% of patients. MRI proved valuable in accurately delineating the extent of tumor involvement, aiding surgical planning, and guiding therapeutic management. In conclusion, MRI plays a crucial role in the detection and characterization of cardiac RMS, enabling early diagnosis and appropriate treatment.

Multiple myeloma and acute megakaryoblast leukemia in spent phase polycythemia vera. Polycythemia vera (PV) is a myeloproliferative disorder characterized by an increased production of blood cells. The disease can progress to various hematological malignancies, including multiple myeloma (MM) and acute megakaryoblast leukemia (AMKL). We report a case of a patient with PV who developed MM and AMKL in the spent phase. The patient presented with anemia, hepatosplenomegaly, and bone pain. Laboratory investigations revealed an elevated white blood cell count, thrombocytopenia, and elevated lactate dehydrogenase levels. Bone marrow aspiration and biopsy confirmed the presence of plasma cell infiltration, consistent with MM, as well as megakaryoblast infiltration, indicative of AMKL. The co-occurrence of MM and AMKL in PV is a rare and aggressive scenario, highlighting the need for comprehensive monitoring and timely intervention in patients with PV to detect and manage potential complications.

A complex ileovaginal fistula with associated obstructive uropathy in a patient with Crohn's disease: technical considerations and review of the literature. We present a case report of a complex ileovaginal fistula in a 43-year-old female with Crohn's disease. The patient presented with symptoms of obstructive uropathy, including urinary retention and flank pain. Imaging studies revealed a connection between the ileum and vagina, resulting in the formation of the fistula. The patient underwent a multidisciplinary surgical approach, including resection of the diseased bowel segment, repair of the fistula, and urinary diversion. The postoperative course was uneventful, and the patient experienced resolution of her symptoms. This case highlights the technical challenges and considerations involved in managing complex fistulas in Crohn's disease patients and underscores the importance of a multidisciplinary approach for optimal outcomes.

Suggestive evidence that pelvic endometriosis is a progressive disease, whereas deeply infiltrating endometriosis is associated with pelvic pain. Pelvic endometriosis and deeply infiltrating endometriosis (DIE) are common conditions that can cause significant morbidity and decrease quality of life for affected individuals. However, the pathogenesis and clinical significance of these conditions are not fully understood. In this study, we aimed to investigate the progression of pelvic endometriosis and its association with pelvic pain compared to DIE. Patients diagnosed with pelvic endometriosis (n=60) and DIE (n=60) were followed up for a 5-year period. The patients were assessed for the severity of endometriosis, presence of pelvic pain, and occurrence of related complications. Our findings suggest that pelvic endometriosis may be a progressive disease, with a significant increase in severity over time (p<0.001). Furthermore, we found that DIE was significantly associated with pelvic pain (p=0.003), indicating a possible correlation between the extent of disease infiltration and symptom severity. These results provide valuable insights into the understanding and management of pelvic endometriosis and highlight the importance of early diagnosis and intervention to prevent disease progression and alleviate pelvic pain.

Detection of somatic DNA alterations in ovarian cancer by DNA fingerprint analysis. Ovarian cancer is a highly lethal malignancy with a critical need for improved diagnostic tools. This study aimed to explore the potential of DNA fingerprint analysis as a detection method for somatic DNA alterations in ovarian cancer. 
Using next-generation sequencing, we analyzed genomic DNA isolated from tumor tissues and matched normal tissues of 100 ovarian cancer patients. A panel of somatic DNA alterations, including single nucleotide variants, insertions, deletions, and copy number variations, was identified and used to generate a DNA fingerprint for each tumor sample. 
Our results showed that DNA fingerprint analysis successfully detected somatic DNA alterations in ovarian cancer patients, with a sensitivity and specificity of 92% and 89%, respectively. Moreover, the DNA fingerprint profiles provided additional information regarding tumor heterogeneity and clonality. 
In conclusion, DNA fingerprint analysis holds promise as a novel and non-invasive approach for the detection of somatic DNA alterations in patients with ovarian cancer. Further validation studies are warranted to confirm its clinical utility and potential for early diagnosis.

Delayed facial nerve palsy after temporal lobectomy for epilepsy: report of four cases and discussion of possible mechanisms.  Four cases of idiopathic peripheral facial nerve palsy were documented after 110 consecutive resections of the temporal lobe for intractable epilepsy. Facial nerve palsy is a rare but known complication of temporal lobectomy for epilepsy. Four cases of delayed facial nerve palsy following temporal lobectomy are reported, occurring after a total of 110 consecutive procedures. All patients underwent resections of the temporal lobe for the treatment of intractable epilepsy. The onset of facial nerve palsy ranged from 14 to 68 days after surgery. All patients experienced unilateral facial weakness and decreased facial muscle function. Comprehensive examination, including electromyography, ruled out other causes of facial nerve palsy. The mechanism for the delayed onset of facial nerve palsy following temporal lobectomy remains unclear. Possible explanations include direct trauma to the facial nerve during surgery, compression of the nerve by postoperative edema, or ischemic injury. Awareness of this rare complication is crucial for early recognition and appropriate management. Further studies are needed to elucidate the exact pathophysiology and determine optimal treatment strategies for delayed facial nerve palsy following temporal lobectomy for epilepsy.

Small bowel enteroscopy: an early experience in gastrointestinal bleeding of unknown origin.  Peroral small intestinal enteroscopy was performed in 35 consecutive patients with gastrointestinal bleeding of unknown origin by using a prototypic Sonde-type enteroscope. The aim of this study was to evaluate the usefulness and safety of peroral small bowel enteroscopy for the investigation of gastrointestinal bleeding of unknown origin. A total of 35 patients with gastrointestinal bleeding of unknown origin were included in the study. Peroral small intestinal enteroscopy was performed using a prototypic Sonde-type enteroscope. The procedure was well-tolerated in all patients with no major complications reported. Bleeding was identified in 26 patients (74.3%), with the source localized to the small bowel in 23 patients (65.7%). Lesions causing bleeding were mainly found in the jejunum (73.9%) and ileum (21.7%). The most common lesions were angioectasias (39.1%), followed by ulcers (34.8%) and tumors (13.0%). This study demonstrates that peroral small bowel enteroscopy using a Sonde-type enteroscope is a safe and effective method for diagnosing and localizing the source of gastrointestinal bleeding in patients with unknown origin.

Malignant melanoma presenting as nasal obstruction.  Mucosal melanomas arising in the nasal cavity are rare tumors comprising less than 1 percent of all melanomas. Mucosal melanomas originating in the nasal cavity are extremely uncommon and account for less than 1% of all melanomas. We report a case of a 45-year-old male presenting with nasal obstruction and subsequent diagnosis of malignant melanoma. Immunohistochemical analysis confirmed the presence of melanoma with positive staining for S-100 protein and melan-A. The nasal cavity is an atypical location for melanoma, and the nonspecific symptoms of nasal obstruction may delay diagnosis. Healthcare professionals should be aware of the possibility of melanoma in patients presenting with nasal obstruction to ensure early detection and appropriate management. Further studies are required to better understand the pathogenesis and optimal treatment strategies for this rare presentation of melanoma.

Cardiac echinococcosis: the diagnostic value of computed tomography scanning. Cardiac echinococcosis is a rare but potentially fatal condition that requires prompt and accurate diagnosis for effective management. In this study, we investigated the diagnostic value of computed tomography (CT) scanning in detecting cardiac echinococcosis. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 35 patients with suspected cardiac echinococcosis, who underwent both CT scanning and surgical exploration. CT scanning showed a sensitivity of 89.7% and specificity of 94.1% in the detection of cardiac echinococcosis. The presence of characteristic findings such as cystic lesions with daughter cysts and calcifications on CT scan correlated well with the surgical findings. Based on our results, CT scanning is a reliable diagnostic tool for detecting cardiac echinococcosis, allowing for timely and appropriate management of this condition. Further studies are warranted to validate these findings and explore the potential of CT scanning in guiding treatment planning.

Impairment of sequences of memory-guided saccades after supplementary motor area lesions. This study aimed to investigate the effects of supplementary motor area (SMA) lesions on the memory-guided saccades performance. Eight patients with SMA lesions and eight healthy control participants were evaluated using a memory-guided saccades task. The task required participants to fixate on a central target, followed by the presentation of a peripheral target that had to be remembered for subsequent saccadic eye movements. The results showed that patients with SMA lesions exhibited impaired performance in the memory-guided saccades task compared to the control group. Specifically, the patients demonstrated significant deficits in the accuracy and latency of their saccadic eye movements. These findings suggest that SMA lesions can lead to impairments in the ability to memorize and execute sequences of saccadic eye movements, highlighting the critical role of SMA in motor planning and execution.

Antenatal spontaneous perforation of the extrahepatic biliary tree. Case report. Antenatal spontaneous perforation of the extrahepatic biliary tree is an extremely rare condition with poor prognosis. This report presents a case of antenatal spontaneous perforation of the extrahepatic biliary tree in a full-term neonate. A 35-year-old pregnant woman presented with clinical features suggestive of fetal distress. Emergency cesarean section was performed, and the neonate was delivered. Intraoperatively, a large amount of bilious fluid was found in the peritoneal cavity. Further exploration revealed a perforation in the extrahepatic biliary tree. The perforation was primarily repaired, and a drain was placed. The neonate was admitted to the neonatal intensive care unit for postoperative care, including antibiotics and enteral nutrition. Long-term follow-up showed good biliary system function and normal development. Early recognition and prompt surgical intervention are crucial for favorable outcomes in cases of antenatal spontaneous perforation of the extrahepatic biliary tree. Further research is warranted to understand the etiology and optimal management strategies of this rare condition.

Disseminated Pneumocystis carinii infection with hepatic involvement in a patient with the acquired immune deficiency syndrome.  Extrapulmonary infection with Pneumocystis carinii (P. carinii), commonly seen in patients with the acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS), primarily affects the lungs. However, extrapulmonary manifestations of the infection can occur, with hepatic involvement being rare. We report a case of disseminated P. carinii infection with hepatic involvement in a 42-year-old male with AIDS. The patient presented with abdominal pain, hepatomegaly, and deranged liver function tests. Imaging studies revealed multiple hypodense lesions in the liver. Microbiological evaluation of liver tissue confirmed the presence of P. carinii organisms. The patient was started on systemic anti-Pneumocystis therapy and showed improvement in symptoms and liver function tests. This case highlights the importance of considering P. carinii infection in the differential diagnosis of hepatic involvement in patients with AIDS and the need for prompt initiation of appropriate treatment.

Delayed subcapsular hematoma after percutaneous liver biopsy as a manifestation of warfarin toxicity.  Guidelines for the management of patients receiving chronic anticoagulation therapy who require liver biopsy are not clearly defined. This report describes a case of delayed subcapsular hematoma after percutaneous liver biopsy in a patient on chronic warfarin therapy. A 56-year-old male with atrial fibrillation and a mechanical mitral valve presented with increasing abdominal pain two days after undergoing a liver biopsy procedure. Imaging studies revealed a subcapsular hematoma in the liver, which was managed conservatively with close monitoring and discontinuation of warfarin therapy. The patient had a delayed recovery and required a longer hospital stay. This case highlights the need for clear guidelines in the management of patients on chronic anticoagulation therapy who undergo liver biopsy, as the risk of bleeding and complications are increased. Timely monitoring and appropriate management strategies are crucial to prevent serious complications in these patients.

Pemoline-associated hepatic injury. Pemoline, a central nervous system stimulant used in the treatment of attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), has been associated with rare cases of severe hepatic injury. The United States Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has received reports of pemoline-related liver failure, necessitating liver transplantation or resulting in death. The mechanism underlying pemoline-induced hepatotoxicity remains unknown, and routine liver function monitoring has not been found to reliably predict or prevent hepatic injury. Based on the reported cases, the FDA recommends close monitoring of liver function, especially during the first several months of treatment, and prompt discontinuation of pemoline in patients who develop signs or symptoms of liver dysfunction.

Postmortem chorionic villus sampling is a better method for cytogenetic evaluation of early fetal loss than culture of abortus material. Postmortem chorionic villus sampling (PM CVS) is a valuable technique for cytogenetic evaluation in cases of early fetal loss. This study aimed to compare the effectiveness of PM CVS with the conventional method of culture of abortus material (CAM) in detecting chromosomal abnormalities. A total of 71 cases of early fetal loss were included in this retrospective study, with 37 cases undergoing PM CVS and 34 cases undergoing CAM. Chromosomal abnormalities were detected in 26 out of 37 (70.3%) cases using PM CVS, compared to only 18 out of 34 (52.9%) cases using CAM. These results demonstrate that PM CVS is a superior method for detecting chromosomal abnormalities in cases of early fetal loss. Its higher detection rate highlights its potential as a valuable tool for genetic counseling and management decisions in couples experiencing recurrent early fetal loss.

Delayed pharyngoesophageal perforation: a complication of anterior spine surgery.  Stabilization of the cervical spine is often accomplished via an anterior cervical approach. Delayed pharyngoesophageal perforation is a rare but serious complication of anterior spine surgery. The anterior cervical approach is commonly used for stabilization of the cervical spine. We present a case of a 58-year-old male who underwent anterior cervical discectomy and fusion for cervical disc herniation. Two weeks postoperatively, the patient developed a sudden onset of cervical pain, fever, and difficulty swallowing. Imaging studies revealed pharyngoesophageal perforation. Emergent surgical repair was performed, and the patient had a satisfactory outcome. Delayed pharyngoesophageal perforation should be considered in patients presenting with postoperative cervical pain and difficulty swallowing. Prompt diagnosis and surgical intervention are crucial to prevent serious complications and achieve favorable outcomes. Surgeons should be aware of this potential complication and take preventive measures during anterior spine surgery.

Reduction of mortality, sudden death and non-fatal reinfarction with beta-adrenergic blockers in survivors of acute myocardial infarction: a new hypothesis regarding the cardioprotective action of beta-adrenergic blockade. The use of beta-adrenergic blockers in survivors of acute myocardial infarction (AMI) has been shown to reduce mortality, sudden death, and non-fatal reinfarction. The traditional hypothesis for the cardioprotective action of beta-adrenergic blockade suggests that it acts by reducing myocardial oxygen demand and improving myocardial perfusion. However, recent evidence suggests that the beneficial effects of beta-blockers may be due to their anti-inflammatory and anti-arrhythmic properties.

This study aimed to propose a new hypothesis regarding the cardioprotective action of beta-adrenergic blockade in survivors of AMI. The hypothesis suggests that beta-blockers exert their beneficial effects by modulating the immune response and reducing inflammation, resulting in a decrease in myocardial injury and remodeling. Additionally, beta-blockers may stabilize cardiac membranes and reduce arrhythmogenesis, further contributing to their cardioprotective effects.

Further research is needed to fully understand the underlying mechanisms and to determine the optimal use of beta-blockers in the management of AMI. However, this new hypothesis provides a novel perspective on the potential benefits of beta-adrenergic blockade in this patient population.

Diclofenac-associated hepatotoxicity Diclofenac sodium, a phenylacetic acid-derived nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) recently released in the United States, was associated with the development of significant hepatitis in seven patients, with one associated death. Diclofenac sodium, a widely used nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID), has been associated with hepatotoxicity. This study reports on seven patients who developed significant hepatitis following diclofenac sodium use, with one resultant death. The patients presented with symptoms such as jaundice, liver enzyme elevation, and hepatomegaly. Liver biopsies showed evidence of severe necrosis and inflammatory infiltrate. Upon discontinuation of diclofenac sodium, liver enzymes returned to normal levels and patients experienced clinical improvement. The exact mechanism of diclofenac-associated hepatotoxicity remains unclear, but it is believed to involve the formation of reactive metabolites and subsequent immune-mediated injury. Healthcare professionals should be aware of this potential adverse effect and consider alternative treatment options in patients with underlying liver disease.

Simultaneous presentation of adenocarcinoma of prostate and transitional cell carcinoma of bladder.  Simultaneous presentation of transitional cell carcinoma of the bladder and adenocarcinoma of the prostate is not uncommon. The simultaneous presentation of adenocarcinoma of the prostate and transitional cell carcinoma of the bladder is not uncommon. Both malignancies arise from different origins and have distinct histological features. The coexistence of these two cancers poses challenges in diagnosis and management. This case report describes a rare presentation of adenocarcinoma of the prostate and transitional cell carcinoma of the bladder in a 64-year-old male. The patient presented with lower urinary tract symptoms and hematuria. Diagnostic workup, including transrectal ultrasound, cystoscopy, and histopathological examination, confirmed the presence of both malignancies. Treatment options were discussed with the patient, and a multidisciplinary approach was adopted, including radical prostatectomy and transurethral resection of the bladder tumor. Follow-up revealed no evidence of recurrence or metastasis. This case highlights the importance of considering simultaneous malignancies in patients presenting with genitourinary symptoms and emphasizes the need for a comprehensive evaluation and individualized treatment plan.

Etiologic importance of the intimal flap of the external carotid artery in the development of postcarotid endarterectomy stroke. Ischemic stroke is a known complication following carotid endarterectomy (CEA), and the etiology is often attributed to embolic events from plaque disruption. However, recent studies have suggested that the presence of an intimal flap in the external carotid artery (ECA) may play a significant role in the development of post-CEA stroke. This abstract aims to evaluate the etiologic importance of the intimal flap in the occurrence of post-CEA stroke.

The intimal flap is believed to occur due to shearing forces during CEA, leading to dissection and subsequent flap formation. This flap has the potential to act as a nidus for thrombus formation and embolization, thereby contributing to post-CEA stroke. The authors review the existing literature on the prevalence, characteristics, and clinical implications of the intimal flap in relation to stroke occurrence. Additionally, they discuss possible prevention and management strategies for reducing the risk of post-CEA stroke associated with the intimal flap. Further research is needed to fully understand the pathophysiological mechanisms and determine optimal strategies for prevention and treatment.

Total bladder replacement using detubularized sigmoid colon: technique and results.  We performed total bladder replacement with a detubularized segment of sigmoid colon in patients after cystoprostatectomy. Total bladder replacement using detubularized sigmoid colon is a surgical technique used in patients who have undergone cystoprostatectomy. The procedure involves utilizing a section of the sigmoid colon and creating a neobladder to replace the excised bladder. This abstract presents the technique and results of total bladder replacement using detubularized sigmoid colon.

The procedure was performed on a cohort of patients who had undergone cystoprostatectomy due to bladder cancer. A segment of the sigmoid colon was isolated and detubularized to create a new bladder. The new bladder was then anastomosed to the urethra to restore urinary function. Post-operative follow-up was conducted to assess the outcomes and complications associated with the procedure.

Preliminary results indicate that total bladder replacement using detubularized sigmoid colon is a viable option for patients after cystoprostatectomy. Patients reported improved urinary function and quality of life post-surgery. Complications such as urinary leakage and urinary tract infections were observed in a small percentage of cases. Further long-term follow-up is needed to evaluate the durability and functional outcomes of this procedure.

Prostatic-type epithelium in urinary bladder. Prostatic-type epithelium in the urinary bladder is a rare finding that can lead to diagnostic confusion and potential mismanagement. This study aimed to investigate the clinical characteristics and outcomes of patients with prostatic-type epithelium in the urinary bladder. A retrospective analysis of patient records identified 25 cases of prostatic-type epithelium in the urinary bladder. The cohort primarily consisted of males, with a mean age of 62 years. The most common clinical presentation was hematuria. Diagnostic evaluation included cystoscopy, imaging, and histopathological examination. The majority of patients underwent transurethral resection of the bladder tumor for treatment. Follow-up assessments showed favorable outcomes, with no evidence of disease recurrence or progression. This study highlights the importance of careful evaluation and appropriate management in patients with prostatic-type epithelium in the urinary bladder.

Anterior cervical discectomy and fusion. Anterior cervical discectomy and fusion (ACDF) is a widely used surgical procedure for the treatment of cervical degenerative disc disease. This abstract aims to provide an overview of the surgical technique, clinical outcomes, and potential complications associated with ACDF. The procedure involves the removal of the damaged intervertebral disc through an anterior approach, followed by the placement of a bone graft, typically sourced from the patient's own iliac crest or a cadaveric donor, to promote fusion between adjacent vertebrae. ACDF has shown favorable outcomes in terms of pain relief, neurological improvement, and restoration of cervical stability. However, complications such as graft failure, infection, dysphagia, and adjacent segment degeneration may occur. Careful patient selection, meticulous surgical technique, and postoperative management are crucial for achieving successful outcomes and minimizing complications in ACDF.

Medical dissolution of gallstones.  Clinical experience of d-limonene as a simple, safe, and effective solvent. Gallstones are a common condition that can cause significant morbidity and mortality. The traditional treatment for symptomatic gallstones is cholecystectomy, which carries its own risks and potential complications. In recent years, medical dissolution of gallstones using various solvents has been explored as an alternative approach. D-limonene, a natural solvent derived from citrus fruits, has shown promise in dissolving gallstones without the need for surgery. In this study, we present our clinical experience with d-limonene as a simple, safe, and effective solvent for gallstone dissolution. Our results demonstrate a high success rate in gallstone dissolution, with minimal adverse effects reported. D-limonene offers a non-invasive and potentially cost-effective treatment option for patients with symptomatic gallstones. Further studies are warranted to validate these findings and establish optimal dosing and treatment protocols.

Iatrogenic saphenous neuralgia: successful therapy with neuroma resection. Iatrogenic saphenous neuralgia is a rare complication that can occur following surgery involving the saphenous nerve, leading to persistent neuropathic pain in the distribution of the nerve. In this case report, we present a 47-year-old female who developed iatrogenic saphenous neuralgia following a varicose vein surgery. The patient presented with severe burning pain and numbness along the medial aspect of her lower leg, which was refractory to conservative management. Surgical exploration revealed a neuroma formation at the site of previous surgical trauma. The neuroma was resected and the patient experienced complete resolution of symptoms. This case highlights the importance of considering iatrogenic saphenous neuralgia as a potential cause of persistent neuropathic pain following surgery involving the saphenous nerve and suggests that surgical intervention in the form of neuroma resection can be an effective treatment option in these cases.

Endocrine function in children with human immunodeficiency virus infection. Children with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection often experience endocrine abnormalities, which can have a significant impact on growth and development. This study aimed to assess the prevalence and characteristics of endocrine dysfunction in children with HIV infection. A total of 96 HIV-infected children aged 5-16 years were included in the study. Evaluation of endocrine function included measurements of growth parameters, thyroid function tests, adrenal function tests, and gonadal function tests. The results showed that 62% of the children had at least one abnormal endocrine parameter. Growth failure was the most commonly observed abnormality, affecting 48% of the children. Thyroid dysfunction, adrenal insufficiency, and gonadal dysfunction were also observed in a significant number of children. These findings highlight the importance of regular endocrine screening and early intervention in children with HIV infection to optimize growth and development outcomes. Further research is needed to better understand the pathophysiology and management of endocrine abnormalities in this population.

Tissue-expanded radial forearm free flap in neck burn contracture. Neck burn contractures are debilitating conditions that often require surgical intervention for functional and aesthetic restoration. The tissue-expanded radial forearm free flap is a reliable and effective technique for the treatment of neck burn contracture. This procedure involves the harvest of a radial forearm flap from the patient's non-dominant forearm, followed by tissue expansion to create a larger flap that can adequately cover the defect in the neck. The advantages of this technique include its versatility, excellent vascularity, and minimal donor site morbidity. Additionally, the radial forearm free flap allows for the re-establishment of neck contour and mobility. However, careful patient selection and preoperative planning are crucial to achieve optimal outcomes. Further studies are warranted to evaluate long-term functional and aesthetic results of this technique.

Current concepts of cholesterol transport and crystal formation in human bile.  The presence of vesicles in human bile probably accounts almost entirely for the frequently observed, but hitherto unexplained, phenomenon of metastable cholesterol supersaturation. Cholesterol transport and crystal formation in human bile have been subjects of extensive research due to their contribution to the development of gallstones. This study aimed to explore the current concepts regarding these processes. It was found that the presence of vesicles in human bile is the main factor responsible for the commonly observed metastable cholesterol supersaturation, which had previously lacked an explanation. These vesicles serve as platforms for cholesterol nucleation and crystal growth. Furthermore, it was discovered that the vesicles originate from the liver and are then modified in the gallbladder. The importance of biliary glycoproteins and phospholipids in regulating cholesterol solubility was also highlighted. Understanding the mechanisms behind cholesterol transport and crystal formation in human bile provides valuable insights into the pathogenesis of gallstones and may pave the way for future preventative and therapeutic strategies.

Auditory hallucinations and smaller superior temporal gyral volume in schizophrenia. OBJECTIVE: This study aimed to investigate the association between auditory hallucinations and superior temporal gyral (STG) volume in patients with schizophrenia. 
DESIGN: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scans were obtained from a group of schizophrenia patients with auditory hallucinations and a control group without hallucinations. The STG volume was measured using voxel-based morphometry analysis. 
PARTICIPANTS: Twenty schizophrenia patients with auditory hallucinations and twenty age-, gender-, and education-matched controls participated in the study. 
MEASUREMENTS AND RESULTS: The results revealed that patients with auditory hallucinations showed significantly smaller STG volume compared to controls. Furthermore, the severity of hallucinations was negatively correlated with STG volume. 
CONCLUSION: These findings suggest a potential role of STG volume reduction in the manifestation of auditory hallucinations in schizophrenia. Further research is needed to determine the underlying mechanisms and implications for treatment.

Uses and complications of uvulopalatopharyngoplasty.  Uvulopalatopharygoplasty has become widely performed for chronic snoring and for cases of obstructive sleep apnoea. Uvulopalatopharyngoplasty (UPPP) is a surgical procedure commonly used for the treatment of chronic snoring and obstructive sleep apnea. This abstract aims to provide an overview of the uses and complications associated with UPPP. UPPP involves the removal of excessive tissue from the uvula, soft palate, and pharynx in order to increase the airway space and reduce airway obstruction during sleep. Studies have shown that UPPP can effectively alleviate snoring and improve symptoms of obstructive sleep apnea in select patients. However, like any surgical procedure, UPPP is associated with potential complications. These complications include but are not limited to pain, bleeding, infection, velopharyngeal insufficiency, and obstructive sleep apnea recurrence. Careful patient selection and thorough preoperative evaluation are important in determining the appropriateness of UPPP as a treatment option. Additionally, close postoperative monitoring and adequate follow-up are necessary to manage and address any potential complications that may arise.

Ten years' experience with continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis. This retrospective study aimed to evaluate the outcomes and complications of continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis (CAPD) over a ten-year period. The medical records of 150 patients who underwent CAPD were analyzed. The median age of the patients was 55 years, with a male predominance. The most common underlying cause of end-stage renal disease was diabetic nephropathy. The overall technique survival rate was 80%, with peritonitis being the most frequent reason for technique failure. The median duration of CAPD was 36 months. The incidence of peritonitis was 1.2 episodes per patient-year, with the most common causative organism being Staphylococcus aureus. Other complications included tunnel infections, catheter malfunction, and hernias. Despite the complications, CAPD provided a reasonable long-term dialysis option for patients with end-stage renal disease. Regular surveillance and management of complications are necessary to ensure optimal outcomes.

Central corpectomy for cervical spondylotic myelopathy: a consecutive series with long-term follow-up evaluation.  Since 1984, a consecutive series of patients with cervical spondylotic myelopathy has been treated by central corpectomy and strut grafting. This study aimed to evaluate the long-term outcomes of central corpectomy with strut grafting in patients with cervical spondylotic myelopathy (CSM). A consecutive series of patients with CSM who underwent central corpectomy and strut grafting since 1984 were included in this study. Clinical and radiographic data were collected and analyzed. A total of [number] patients were included, with a mean follow-up duration of [duration] years. The majority of patients showed significant improvement in neurological function postoperatively. Radiographic evaluation revealed satisfactory fusion rates and maintenance of cervical alignment in most cases. The complication rate was found to be [percentage]. Overall, central corpectomy with strut grafting showed long-term efficacy and safety in the treatment of CSM. This procedure should be considered as a viable surgical option for patients with CSM. Further studies with larger sample sizes are warranted to confirm these findings.

Evaluation of tumor progression by repeated fine needle biopsies in prostate adenocarcinoma: modal deoxyribonucleic acid value and cytological differentiation. Prostate adenocarcinoma is a common malignancy in males and the evaluation of tumor progression is crucial for determining appropriate treatment strategies. This study aimed to investigate the utility of repeated fine needle biopsies in assessing tumor progression based on modal deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) value and cytological differentiation. A total of 50 patients with prostate adenocarcinoma were enrolled and underwent repeated fine needle biopsies at different time points. The modal DNA value and cytological differentiation were analyzed and compared between initial and subsequent biopsies. Our results indicated that the modal DNA value exhibited a significant increase in 60% of the patients, suggesting tumor progression. Additionally, cytological differentiation worsened in 48% of the patients, further supporting the use of repeated biopsies for evaluating tumor progression in prostate adenocarcinoma.

Neuropsychological aspects of learning disabilities in epilepsy. Learning disabilities are common in individuals with epilepsy, but the neuropsychological aspects of these disabilities remain poorly understood. This study aimed to explore the neuropsychological profile of learning disabilities in epilepsy. Thirty children with epilepsy and learning disabilities were assessed using a battery of neuropsychological tests. The results demonstrated deficits in various cognitive domains, including attention, memory, executive functions, and language. These deficits were found to be more pronounced in children with uncontrolled seizures and those with a longer duration of epilepsy. Furthermore, the presence of comorbid psychiatric disorders was found to further exacerbate the cognitive impairments. These findings highlight the complex nature of learning disabilities in epilepsy and emphasize the importance of comprehensive neuropsychological evaluations for tailored educational interventions and treatment planning.

Flow cytometric DNA content of adenoid cystic carcinoma of submandibular gland.  Correlation of histologic features and prognosis. Adenoid cystic carcinoma (ACC) is a rare malignancy arising from the salivary glands, with the submandibular gland being one of the commonly affected sites. This study aimed to investigate the correlation between the flow cytometric DNA content of ACC of the submandibular gland and its histologic features, as well as its prognostic implications. Forty-five patients with ACC of the submandibular gland were included in the study. Flow cytometry was performed on fresh tumor tissues to assess DNA content. Histologic features, including grade, tumor stage, perineural invasion, and lymphovascular invasion, were evaluated. Patients were followed up for a median duration of 5 years to determine their prognostic outcomes. The results revealed a correlation between aneuploidy (abnormal DNA content) and advanced tumor stage, high-grade tumors, perineural invasion, and lymphovascular invasion. Furthermore, patients with aneuploid ACC had a significantly worse prognosis compared to those with diploid ACC. These findings suggest that flow cytometric DNA analysis may serve as a valuable tool in predicting the prognosis of ACC of the submandibular gland based on its histologic features.

Ondansetron: a new entity in emesis control. Ondansetron, a selective 5-HT3 receptor antagonist, has emerged as a promising therapeutic option in the control of emesis. This abstract provides an overview of the pharmacological profile, clinical efficacy, and safety profile of ondansetron in the treatment of nausea and vomiting. Ondansetron acts by inhibiting the binding of serotonin to its receptors in the gastrointestinal tract and central nervous system, thus alleviating the symptoms of emesis. Clinical trials have demonstrated the effectiveness of ondansetron in various settings, including chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting, post-operative nausea and vomiting, and radiation-induced nausea and vomiting. The drug has shown superior efficacy compared to traditional anti-emetics such as metoclopramide and prochlorperazine, with a favorable side effect profile. Despite its proven efficacy, caution should be exercised in prescribing ondansetron in patients with certain risk factors, including a history of long QT syndrome or concurrent use of drugs that prolong QT interval.

Ultrasound in the investigation of the right iliac fossa mass.  Patients presenting with a right iliac fossa (RIF) mass are a diagnostic problem. Ultrasound is a commonly used imaging modality in the investigation of right iliac fossa (RIF) masses. This study aims to evaluate the diagnostic utility of ultrasound in identifying the etiology of RIF masses. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 100 patients presenting with RIF masses. Ultrasound findings were compared with surgical pathology or clinical follow-up as the gold standard. The results showed that ultrasound had a high sensitivity (98%) and specificity (95%) in detecting appendicitis, the most common cause of RIF masses. Other common etiologies identified by ultrasound included ovarian cysts, lymphadenopathy, and diverticulitis. However, ultrasound had limited sensitivity and specificity in diagnosing less common etiologies such as neoplasms and intussusception. Therefore, while ultrasound is a valuable tool in the initial evaluation of RIF masses, further imaging or invasive procedures may be required for accurate diagnosis in certain cases.

Thrombosis in a congenitally bifurcated superior sagittal sinus. Thrombosis in a congenitally bifurcated superior sagittal sinus is a rare condition that can lead to serious complications. We present a case of a 35-year-old female who presented with severe headache and visual disturbances. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) revealed thrombosis within a congenitally bifurcated superior sagittal sinus. The patient was immediately started on anticoagulant therapy, and her symptoms gradually improved over the course of several weeks. This case highlights the importance of considering congenital anatomical variations when evaluating patients with cerebral venous thrombosis. Prompt diagnosis and appropriate management are crucial in preventing the progression of thrombosis and potential complications such as cerebral infarction or hemorrhage. Further research is needed to better understand the underlying mechanisms and optimal treatment strategies for this rare condition.

Association between neuroepithelial tumor and multiple intestinal polyposis (Turcot's syndrome): report of a case and critical analysis of the literature. Turcot's syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the presence of both neuroepithelial tumors, particularly glioblastomas, and multiple intestinal polyposis. We report a case of a 45-year-old male who presented with neurological symptoms and was diagnosed with a glioblastoma multiforme. During the diagnostic workup, he was found to have multiple adenomatous polyps in the colon. Genetic testing showed a mutation in the adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) gene, confirming the diagnosis of Turcot's syndrome. A comprehensive review of the literature revealed 64 reported cases of Turcot's syndrome, highlighting the association between APC germline mutations and neuroepithelial tumors. Early recognition and management of Turcot's syndrome are crucial for optimal patient outcomes.

Unknown primary squamous cell carcinoma metastatic to the neck. Metastatic squamous cell carcinoma to the neck from an unknown primary site presents a diagnostic and therapeutic challenge. This retrospective study aimed to evaluate the clinical characteristics, treatment outcomes, and prognostic factors of patients with this condition. A total of 52 patients were included in the analysis. The median age at diagnosis was 61 years, and the male-to-female ratio was 3:1. The most common presenting symptom was a painless neck mass. The majority of patients (77%) had bilateral neck involvement at presentation. The most frequently involved lymph node level was level II. The overall survival rate at 2 years was 32.7%. Multivariate analysis revealed that extracapsular spread, age >60 years, and high-grade tumor were independent prognostic factors associated with poorer survival outcomes. These findings highlight the importance of aggressive treatment and close surveillance in patients with unknown primary squamous cell carcinoma metastatic to the neck.

Natural death as viewed by the medical examiner: a review of 1000 consecutive autopsies of individuals dying of natural disease.  A study of 1000 consecutive autopsies of individuals dying of natural disease was conducted. The purpose of this study was to examine the findings and interpretations of medical examiners regarding natural deaths in a sample of 1000 consecutive autopsies. All cases included in the study involved individuals who had died of natural disease. The results indicated that the most common natural causes of death were cardiovascular diseases, followed by respiratory diseases and cancer. The study found that in approximately 75% of cases, the cause of death was accurately identified by the medical examiner. However, in a significant number of cases, there were discrepancies between the initial cause of death determined by the medical examiner and the final cause of death determined through autopsy. These findings highlight the importance of autopsies in confirming and further elucidating the cause of death in cases of natural disease.

Carcinoma of the pancreas: a retrospective review.  Eighty-five patients with adenocarcinoma of the pancreas were reviewed in order to evaluate the efficacy of our methods of diagnosis and treatment. In this retrospective review, we evaluated the efficacy of our methods of diagnosis and treatment in 85 patients with adenocarcinoma of the pancreas. The mean age of the patients was 62.4 years, with a male to female ratio of 1.3:1. The most common presenting symptoms were abdominal pain (68.2%), weight loss (58.8%), and jaundice (52.9%). The majority of patients (74.1%) had unresectable tumors at the time of diagnosis. Among the patients who underwent curative resection, the mean survival time was 16.5 months, with a 1-year and 3-year survival rate of 62.5% and 28.1%, respectively. The main complications associated with the surgical procedure were pancreatic fistula (17.6%) and postoperative bleeding (10.6%). Our findings suggest that early diagnosis and curative resection remain the best strategies for improving the prognosis of patients with adenocarcinoma of the pancreas.

Threshold perimetry in tilted disc syndrome.  Twelve consecutive patients (17 eyes) with tilted disc syndrome underwent quantified visual field examination with the G1 Octopus program (Interzeag AG, Schlieren, Switzerland). Tilted disc syndrome, characterized by an abnormal tilting of the optic disc, can lead to visual field defects. We aimed to investigate the visual field characteristics in patients with tilted disc syndrome using quantified visual field examination. 
Twelve consecutive patients (17 eyes) with tilted disc syndrome were included in this study. The patients underwent visual field examination using the G1 Octopus program. Each eye was evaluated separately, and the threshold perimetry results were analyzed. 
The results demonstrated various visual field defects in the studied eyes. The most common defect observed was an arcuate scotoma, followed by nasal steps and paracentral scotomas. Peripheral constriction and central scotomas were less frequently seen. The severity of the defects varied among the patients, ranging from mild to severe. These findings provide valuable information about the visual field characteristics in tilted disc syndrome, which can aid in the diagnosis and management of this condition.

Diabetes insipidus associated with craniopharyngioma in pregnancy. We report a case of diabetes insipidus (DI) associated with craniopharyngioma in pregnancy. A 34-year-old pregnant woman presented with polyuria, polydipsia, and weight loss. Laboratory investigations revealed a low urine specific gravity and high serum osmolality, confirming the diagnosis of DI. Magnetic resonance imaging detected a suprasellar mass consistent with craniopharyngioma. The patient underwent surgical resection of the tumor, and histopathology confirmed the diagnosis. The postoperative course was uneventful, and the woman's DI symptoms gradually resolved. She delivered a healthy baby at 38 weeks gestation.
