Furthermore, a higher incidence of overall cancer and respiratory cancer was observed among individuals with lower single-breath nitrogen test indices. These findings suggest that the single-breath nitrogen test may serve as a useful prognostic tool for assessing mortality risk, overall cancer incidence, and respiratory cancer incidence in men.

How long can a coronary reperfusion catheter be placed in acute coronary occlusion following failed transluminal coronary angioplasty? A case report. Coronary reperfusion catheters are considered as a salvage therapy for acute coronary occlusion when transluminal coronary angioplasty fails. This case report presents a 52-year-old male with an acute myocardial infarction who underwent unsuccessful transluminal coronary angioplasty. Subsequently, a coronary reperfusion catheter was inserted and remained in place for an extended period of time. The catheter was left in place for 36 hours until reestablishing coronary blood flow and achieving optimal reperfusion. This case highlights the potential for prolonged placement of coronary reperfusion catheters in cases where immediate revascularization cannot be achieved. However, caution should be exercised to minimize the risk of catheter-related complications, such as infection or thrombosis. Further research is necessary to determine the optimal duration of placement for these catheters in such cases.

Ventricular arrhythmias in ischemic heart disease. Ventricular arrhythmias are a common and potentially life-threatening complication of ischemic heart disease (IHD). This abstract reviews the current understanding and management of ventricular arrhythmias in patients with IHD. The arrhythmias, including ventricular tachycardia and ventricular fibrillation, often arise from regions of scar tissue in the myocardium resulting from ischemic injury. The pathophysiology involves altered electrical conduction and automaticity due to structural and electrical remodeling. Risk factors for ventricular arrhythmias in IHD include previous myocardial infarction, left ventricular dysfunction, and heart failure. The management of ventricular arrhythmias in this population includes antiarrhythmic drugs, implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) placement, catheter ablation, and revascularization procedures. The use of ICDs has significantly reduced mortality in patients with IHD and high-risk arrhythmias. However, there are challenges in balancing the risks and benefits of ICD placement, especially in patients with comorbidities. Ongoing research aims to identify predictors of ventricular arrhythmias in IHD and develop novel therapeutic strategies. Improved understanding and management of ventricular arrhythmias in IHD are vital for enhancing patient outcomes and reducing mortality rates.

The acute and insidious onset of pulmonary metastatic transitional cell carcinoma. Pulmonary metastatic transitional cell carcinoma (TCC) is a rare manifestation of bladder cancer and its presentation can vary from an acute to an insidious onset. Here, we present a case of a 58-year-old male who developed acute onset dyspnea and hemoptysis secondary to extensive pulmonary metastatic TCC. The patient was initially misdiagnosed with a pulmonary infection, leading to delayed treatment initiation. This case serves as a reminder of the importance of considering metastatic disease in patients with a history of TCC, even in the absence of classic symptoms. Early recognition and prompt initiation of appropriate treatment are crucial in improving the outcomes for patients with pulmonary metastatic TCC.

Using a state cancer registry to increase screening behaviors of sisters and daughters of breast cancer patients. Breast cancer is a prevalent disease with a significant genetic component. It is crucial to promote screening behaviors among sisters and daughters of breast cancer patients to detect the disease at earlier stages and improve prognosis. This study aimed to investigate the effectiveness of utilizing a state cancer registry to increase screening behaviors among this high-risk population. A total of 100 sisters and daughters of breast cancer patients were enrolled and provided with educational materials and reminders through the cancer registry. Results showed a significant increase in mammography and genetic counseling utilization compared to baseline data. This highlights the potential of using cancer registries as a valuable tool for promoting early detection and prevention strategies among high-risk individuals.

A tongue force measurement system for the assessment of oral-phase swallowing disorders. Oral-phase swallowing disorders can significantly impact a person's overall quality of life. This study aims to evaluate the efficacy of a tongue force measurement system in assessing these disorders. A total of 30 patients with known or suspected oral-phase swallowing difficulties were included in the study. The tongue force measurement system allowed for quantification of maximum tongue pressure, tongue strength, and swallowing efficiency. Results showed that patients with oral-phase swallowing disorders had significantly lower tongue force measurements compared to healthy individuals. Furthermore, tongue force measurements correlated with clinical assessments of swallowing function. The use of this tongue force measurement system provides valuable objective data for the assessment and management of oral-phase swallowing disorders, enabling targeted interventions and improved patient care.

Misdiagnosis of the Zollinger-Ellison syndrome due to hyperlipidemia. We report a case of misdiagnosis of Zollinger-Ellison syndrome (ZES) due to hyperlipidemia. A 42-year-old male presented with recurrent abdominal pain, weight loss, and diarrhea. Initial clinical evaluation suggested ZES, and fasting serum gastrin levels were significantly elevated. However, further investigations revealed coexisting hyperlipidemia, which can interfere with serum gastrin assays and mimic the elevated levels seen in ZES. Lipid-lowering therapy was initiated, and follow-up gastrin levels returned to normal. This case highlights the importance of considering hyperlipidemia as a potential confounder in the diagnosis of ZES and the need for careful interpretation of gastrin levels in patients with coexisting metabolic abnormalities. Clinicians should be cautious in attributing symptoms solely to ZES based on elevated gastrin levels and should consider comprehensive evaluation to avoid misdiagnosis and unnecessary treatment.

Heart transplantation in patients with severe pulmonary hypertension and increased pulmonary vascular resistance.  Irreversibly increased pulmonary vascular resistance is a contraindication for cardiac transplantation. Patients with severe pulmonary hypertension and increased pulmonary vascular resistance often face limited treatment options, as cardiac transplantation is contraindicated in these cases. We present a case series of three patients with severe pulmonary hypertension who underwent successful heart transplantation despite the presence of irreversibly increased pulmonary vascular resistance. Preoperative evaluation using invasive hemodynamic monitoring and lung perfusion scans revealed severe pulmonary vascular disease in all patients. However, aggressive medical management including the use of prostacyclin analogs and endothelin receptor antagonists was initiated to optimize hemodynamics and reduce right ventricular strain. Following extensive multidisciplinary discussion and careful patient selection, the patients underwent heart transplantation with meticulous intraoperative management to minimize pulmonary vascular injury. Postoperative outcomes were favorable, with no evidence of right heart failure or acute rejection. Our experience suggests that selected patients with severe pulmonary hypertension and increased pulmonary vascular resistance may be suitable for heart transplantation with careful preoperative evaluation and optimization of medical management.

Epidemiology of acute respiratory tract infections among Guatemalan ambulatory preschool children.  Acute respiratory tract infections (ARI) were studied during a 2-year period in 521 preschool children living in a marginal area of Guatemala City. The aim of this study was to determine the epidemiology of acute respiratory tract infections (ARI) among ambulatory preschool children in Guatemala. A total of 521 children living in a marginal area of Guatemala City were included in the study over a 2-year period. ARI episodes were identified based on clinical symptoms and confirmed by laboratory testing for respiratory pathogens. The overall incidence rate of ARI was found to be 3.6 episodes per child-year, with peaks occurring during the rainy season. The most common pathogens identified were respiratory syncytial virus, influenza virus, and Streptococcus pneumoniae. Risk factors for ARI included younger age, lower socioeconomic status, and exposure to tobacco smoke. The study also found a high prevalence of malnutrition among the children, which was associated with an increased risk of ARI. These findings highlight the significant burden of ARI among Guatemalan preschool children and emphasize the need for targeted interventions to reduce morbidity and mortality associated with ARI in this population.

Dacron fabric-enveloped hydroxyapatite prosthesis for sternal tumor defect: an autopsy report. This autopsy report presents a case of a 58-year-old male who underwent resection of a sternal tumor using a Dacron fabric-enveloped hydroxyapatite prosthesis. The patient had a history of local recurrence of a primary sternal chondrosarcoma, which necessitated a wide resection of the sternum. The defect was then reconstructed using the Dacron fabric-enveloped hydroxyapatite prosthesis.

At autopsy, the prosthesis was found to be well-integrated within the surrounding tissues without evidence of infection or displacement. Microscopic examination revealed a fibrous capsule surrounding the prosthesis with evidence of foreign body giant cell reaction. Formation of woven bone and remodeling of the hydroxyapatite granules were observed within the prosthesis. These findings indicate successful incorporation and biocompatibility of the prosthesis.

Overall, this case demonstrates the utility and effectiveness of the Dacron fabric-enveloped hydroxyapatite prosthesis for reconstruction of sternal defects. Further studies are needed to evaluate the long-term outcomes and complications associated with this surgical technique.

Recovery of CD3+ and CD5- lymphocyte subpopulation after autologous bone marrow transplantation and chemotherapy. The recovery of CD3+ and CD5- lymphocyte subpopulation after autologous bone marrow transplantation (BMT) and chemotherapy was investigated in 30 patients with hematologic malignancies. Flow cytometry analysis was used to assess the levels of CD3+ and CD5- lymphocytes at various time points after BMT and chemotherapy. 

The results showed that the levels of CD3+ lymphocytes gradually increased over time, with a median time of 30 days for recovery to normal levels. In contrast, the recovery of CD5- lymphocytes was delayed, with a median time of 60 days for recovery to normal levels. Additionally, the recovery of CD3+ lymphocytes was significantly faster than the recovery of CD5- lymphocytes (p<0.05).

These findings suggest that the recovery of CD3+ and CD5- lymphocyte subpopulations occurs at different rates after autologous BMT and chemotherapy. Monitoring the levels of these lymphocyte subsets may provide important information about immune reconstitution and prognosis in patients undergoing these treatments. Further studies are warranted to explore the clinical implications of these findings.

MRI findings in neuro-Behcet's disease. Neuro-Behcet's disease (NBD) is a rare inflammatory disorder affecting the central nervous system. However, little is known about the specific MRI findings in this condition. This retrospective study aimed to describe the characteristic MRI features of NBD. A total of 25 NBD patients were included, and MRI scans were analyzed by two experienced neuroradiologists. The most common finding was multifocal white matter lesions (92%), followed by brainstem involvement (56%) and cranial nerve enhancement (52%). These findings suggest that NBD primarily affects the white matter and can involve the brainstem and cranial nerves. Understanding the MRI patterns in NBD can aid in its early diagnosis and appropriate treatment, leading to improved patient outcomes. Further prospective studies are needed to validate these findings.

Dysgeusia, gustatory sweating, and crocodile tears syndrome induced by a cerebellopontine angle meningioma. We present a case of a 52-year-old female who developed dysgeusia, gustatory sweating, and crocodile tears syndrome (CTS) as a result of a cerebellopontine angle meningioma. The patient initially presented with altered taste sensation, primarily experiencing a metallic taste in her mouth. She also noticed sweating on the affected side of her face during meals. A diagnosis of dysgeusia and gustatory sweating was made, and further investigation revealed a tumor in the cerebellopontine angle. Surgical resection of the meningioma was performed, and postoperative recovery was uneventful. Subsequently, the patient developed CTS, experiencing lacrimation during meals. CTS was managed through conservative measures, including the use of anticholinergic eye drops and counseling regarding mealtime strategies. This case highlights the rare association between a cerebellopontine angle meningioma and the development of dysgeusia, gustatory sweating, and CTS. Awareness of these symptoms can aid in the early detection and management of underlying pathology.

Islet cell carcinoma of the pancreas presenting as bleeding from isolated gastric varices.  Report of a case and review of the literature. Islet cell carcinoma of the pancreas is a rare neuroendocrine tumor that can present with various symptoms. We report a case of a 55-year-old male who presented with sudden onset of upper gastrointestinal bleeding. Endoscopic examination revealed isolated gastric varices, which were successfully treated with endoscopic variceal band ligation. Further investigations, including computed tomography and magnetic resonance imaging, identified a mass in the pancreas consistent with islet cell carcinoma. The patient underwent surgical resection of the tumor with subsequent adjuvant chemotherapy. Islet cell carcinoma causing bleeding from isolated gastric varices is an extremely rare presentation, with only a few cases reported in the literature. Clinicians should consider this diagnosis in patients presenting with gastrointestinal bleeding and investigate further for underlying pancreatic pathology.

The long-term effects of radiation therapy on patients with ovarian dysgerminoma.  A retrospective chart review and questionnaire study was undertaken to look at the long-term effects of radiation therapy in ovarian dysgerminoma patients. A total of 58 patients diagnosed with ovarian dysgerminoma and treated with radiation therapy between 1990 and 2010 were included in this study. The mean follow-up period was 15 years. The retrospective chart review revealed that 40 patients (69%) had received radiation therapy as their primary treatment modality, while 18 patients (31%) had undergone surgery followed by adjuvant radiation therapy. The questionnaire study revealed that 25 patients (43%) reported long-term complications related to radiation therapy. The most commonly reported complications were secondary malignancies (n=9), infertility (n=7), and cardiovascular disorders (n=6). Additionally, 12 patients (21%) reported experiencing emotional distress and reduced quality of life as a result of their treatment. These findings highlight the importance of long-term surveillance and management of patients treated with radiation therapy for ovarian dysgerminoma.

Adenomyomatosis of the gallbladder. Adenomyomatosis of the gallbladder is a benign condition characterized by hyperplastic changes within the gallbladder wall. It is typically an incidental finding on imaging studies and is often asymptomatic. This condition is believed to be associated with chronic inflammation and cholecystitis. The exact etiology and pathogenesis of adenomyomatosis are not well understood. Clinical presentation can vary, with symptoms ranging from nonspecific abdominal pain to more severe complications such as biliary colic, cholecystitis, or cholangitis. Diagnosis is typically made through imaging studies, with ultrasonography being the modality of choice. Treatment options for adenomyomatosis include watchful waiting, dietary modifications, and cholecystectomy. Surgical intervention is usually reserved for symptomatic cases or in the presence of complications. Further research is needed to better understand the natural history and optimal management of this condition.

Evidence of heterogeneous mechanisms in lipoprotein lipid alterations in hyperandrogenic women. Women with hyperandrogenism often exhibit lipid abnormalities, including dyslipidemia and high levels of low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C). However, the mechanisms underlying these lipid alterations remain unclear. In this study, we aimed to investigate the presence of heterogeneous mechanisms contributing to lipoprotein lipid abnormalities in hyperandrogenic women. A total of 82 hyperandrogenic women, diagnosed with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) or non-classical adrenal hyperplasia (NCAH), were recruited. Lipid profiles were assessed, including total cholesterol, triglycerides, high-density lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL-C), LDL-C, and apolipoprotein B (apoB) levels. Furthermore, genetic mutations in relevant lipoprotein metabolism genes were analyzed. Our results revealed distinct patterns of lipid abnormalities in hyperandrogenic women, suggesting heterogeneous mechanisms. While some individuals exhibited elevated LDL-C levels, others had elevated triglycerides or low HDL-C levels. Genetic mutations in lipoprotein metabolism genes were observed in a subset of patients, further supporting the idea of varying etiologies for lipid abnormalities in hyperandrogenic women. These findings provide valuable insights into the complexity of lipid alterations in this population and emphasize the importance of individualized approaches to diagnosis and treatment.

Brain abscess associated with congenital pulmonary arteriovenous fistula. Brain abscess is a serious condition that can result in significant morbidity and mortality if not promptly diagnosed and treated. We report a case of a brain abscess in a patient with a previously undiagnosed congenital pulmonary arteriovenous fistula (PAVF). PAVF is a rare vascular anomaly that causes an abnormal direct communication between pulmonary arteries and veins. This case highlights the importance of considering PAVF as a potential underlying cause of brain abscess, especially in patients without any identifiable risk factors. Prompt diagnosis and management of PAVF, including embolization of the abnormal vessel, can prevent further complications such as recurrent abscess formation. Clinicians should have a high index of suspicion for PAVF in patients presenting with brain abscess, particularly in the absence of other predisposing factors.

Impaired awareness of behavioral limitations after traumatic brain injury.  Sixty-four traumatically brain injured patients were divided into three groups. The aim of this study was to investigate the impaired awareness of behavioral limitations in patients with traumatic brain injury (TBI). Sixty-four TBI patients were categorized into three groups based on their level of awareness: intact awareness (Group A, n=22), partial awareness (Group B, n=24), and impaired awareness (Group C, n=18). Cognitive and behavioral assessments were performed using standardized neuropsychological tests and rating scales. The results revealed that patients in Group C had significantly lower cognitive function and displayed more severe behavioral limitations compared to the other two groups. Furthermore, impaired awareness was associated with poorer functional outcomes and increased caregiver burden. These findings emphasize the importance of assessing awareness levels in TBI patients and developing interventions to improve insight into behavioral limitations, which could potentially enhance treatment outcomes and promote independence in daily functioning.

Beneficial effects of colestipol-niacin on coronary atherosclerosis.  A 4-year follow-up. This study aimed to investigate the long-term effects of colestipol-niacin treatment on coronary atherosclerosis. The study included 120 patients with established coronary artery disease who were randomly assigned to receive either colestipol-niacin treatment or placebo. Coronary angiography was performed at baseline and after 4 years to assess the progression of atherosclerosis. The primary endpoint was the change in the percent diameter stenosis (%DS) of the coronary arteries. Secondary endpoints included changes in minimal luminal diameter (MLD) and the occurrence of major adverse cardiac events (MACE). 

After 4 years, the colestipol-niacin group showed a significant reduction in %DS compared to the placebo group (p<0.001). The MLD was also significantly increased in the colestipol-niacin group (p=0.002). Furthermore, the incidence of MACE was lower in the colestipol-niacin group, although this difference did not reach statistical significance (p=0.076). 

In conclusion, colestipol-niacin treatment was associated with a favorable effect on coronary atherosclerosis, as evidenced by a reduction in %DS and an increase in MLD. These findings support the use of colestipol-niacin in the management of coronary artery disease. Further studies are warranted to assess its long-term efficacy and safety.

Mechanism of intermittent preexcitation in the Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome. The Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome is characterized by the presence of an aberrant electrical pathway between the atria and ventricles, known as an accessory pathway. This pathway bypasses the normal conduction system, resulting in rapid conduction of impulses from the atria to the ventricles, causing preexcitation. However, the mechanism of intermittent preexcitation in WPW syndrome remains unclear. In this study, we sought to investigate the mechanism of intermittent preexcitation by analyzing electrocardiograms (ECGs) of patients with WPW syndrome. We found that intermittent preexcitation was primarily caused by changes in the refractory period of the accessory pathway. During periods of preexcitation, the refractory period of the accessory pathway was significantly shorter, allowing for rapid conduction. Conversely, during periods of normal conduction, the refractory period was longer, preventing conduction through the accessory pathway. Our findings suggest that the mechanism of intermittent preexcitation in WPW syndrome is primarily related to alterations in the refractory period of the accessory pathway. Further studies are warranted to explore potential therapeutic strategies targeting this mechanism.

The reproducibility of intravascular ultrasound imaging in vitro. Intravascular ultrasound (IVUS) imaging has become an essential tool in assessing and guiding interventions for coronary artery disease. However, the reproducibility of IVUS measurements is crucial for accurate interpretation of data and clinical decision making. This study aimed to evaluate the reproducibility of IVUS imaging in vitro. We performed multiple IVUS scans on 10 randomly selected human cadaveric coronary arteries using a commercially available IVUS system. Several measurements, including lumen diameter, plaque burden, and minimal lumen area, were obtained from each scan. Intraclass correlation coefficients were calculated to assess the agreement between repeated measurements. The results demonstrated excellent reproducibility for all IVUS measurements, with intraclass correlation coefficients ranging from 0.87 to 0.98. These findings support the reliability of IVUS imaging in providing consistent and accurate measurements, further enhancing its utility in clinical practice.

Window operation: an alternative treatment method for Bartholin gland cysts and abscesses Recently, we developed the "window operation" as a more effective way to treat Bartholin gland cysts and abscesses. Bartholin gland cysts and abscesses are common benign gynecologic conditions that can cause significant discomfort and morbidity in women. The current treatment options, such as incision and drainage or marsupialization, have limitations in terms of recurrence rates and patient satisfaction. In this study, we propose the "window operation" as a novel and more effective treatment method for Bartholin gland cysts and abscesses. The procedure involves creating a small window in the cyst wall to allow continuous drainage and prevent reaccumulation of fluid. We present a series of cases in which the window operation was successfully performed, leading to improved symptom relief and reduced recurrence rates compared to traditional treatment methods. This innovative approach shows promise in addressing the unmet needs of women suffering from Bartholin gland cysts and abscesses.

Hepatitis B virus nucleocapsid/pre-S2 fusion proteins expressed in attenuated Salmonella for oral vaccination.  Hybrid HBV nucleocapsid-pre-S(2) fusion proteins were stably expressed in several aromatic-dependent attenuated Salmonella typhimurium and Salmonella dublin strains. The development of an effective oral vaccine against Hepatitis B virus (HBV) is necessary for widespread immunization. In this study, we engineered attenuated strains of Salmonella typhimurium and Salmonella dublin to express hybrid HBV nucleocapsid-pre-S2 fusion proteins. These fusion proteins were stable and successfully expressed in the attenuated Salmonella strains. The expression of the nucleocapsid-pre-S2 fusion proteins was confirmed through Western blot analysis. Furthermore, oral vaccination of mice with these engineered Salmonella strains resulted in the induction of specific immune responses against HBV. These findings suggest that the use of attenuated Salmonella strains as delivery vehicles for HBV fusion proteins may be a promising strategy for the development of an effective oral vaccine against HBV infection.

Lateral medullary infarction: prognosis in an unselected series.  We describe the acute and long-term prognosis in 43 patients with lateral medullary infarction (LMI) collected from a population-based stroke registry from 1982 to July 1988. Lateral medullary infarction (LMI), also known as Wallenberg syndrome, is a rare but significant cause of stroke. In this study, we aim to determine the acute and long-term prognosis of LMI in an unselected series of 43 patients. Data was collected from a population-based stroke registry from 1982 to July 1988. Our findings indicate that patients with LMI have a varied prognosis, with some experiencing significant recovery while others facing persistent disabilities. Factors such as age, extent of infarction, and the presence of comorbidities were found to be associated with prognosis. These findings contribute to the understanding of LMI and can aid clinicians in prognosticating and managing patients with this condition.

Why are autism and the fragile-X syndrome associated? Conceptual and methodological issues. The association between autism and Fragile-X syndrome has been well established; however, the underlying reasons for this correlation remain unclear. This paper explores both conceptual and methodological issues regarding this association. Conceptually, researchers have speculated that common genetic and neurobiological factors contribute to the development of both disorders. Methodologically, challenges arise in accurately diagnosing autism in individuals with Fragile-X syndrome, as the cognitive and behavioral symptoms of Fragile-X can mask or mimic those of autism. Furthermore, studying this association requires large sample sizes and appropriate control groups. Despite these challenges, understanding the relationship between autism and Fragile-X syndrome is crucial for improving diagnosis and treatment strategies for individuals with either condition. Further research should focus on elucidating the shared mechanisms underlying these disorders.

The modified superior based pharyngeal flap. The modified superior based pharyngeal flap is a surgical technique used in the treatment of velopharyngeal insufficiency (VPI) and related speech disorders. VPI is a condition characterized by the incomplete closure of the velopharyngeal port during speech production, leading to nasal air escape and abnormal speech resonance. The traditional superior pharyngeal flap has been the gold standard for the surgical management of VPI, but it is associated with complications such as obstructive sleep apnea and hypernasal speech. The modified superior based pharyngeal flap is a modification of the traditional technique that aims to reduce these complications. This abstract reviews the surgical technique, indications, outcomes, and complications associated with the modified superior based pharyngeal flap in the treatment of VPI. Further research is needed to evaluate the long-term outcomes and compare this technique with other surgical approaches for VPI management.

Upper gastrointestinal pathology in familial adenomatous polyposis: results from a prospective study of 102 patients.  Multiple gastric and duodenal biopsy specimens from 102 asymptomatic patients with familial adenomatous polyposis, taken during a prospective endoscopic screening programme were examined. Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) is an autosomal dominant genetic disorder characterized by the development of numerous adenomatous polyps in the gastrointestinal tract. While colorectal cancer is the most common malignancy associated with FAP, upper gastrointestinal (GI) pathology has also been reported. In this prospective study, we examined multiple gastric and duodenal biopsy specimens from 102 asymptomatic FAP patients as part of an endoscopic screening program. Histopathological analysis revealed varying degrees of gastric and duodenal inflammation, ranging from mild to severe. Gastric adenomas and duodenal adenomas were identified in 14% and 10% of patients, respectively. Additionally, gastric hyperplastic polyps were found in 23% of patients. Our findings suggest that upper GI pathology is common in FAP patients, emphasizing the importance of regular endoscopic screening in these individuals to detect and manage potential neoplastic changes. Further studies are warranted to determine the optimal management and surveillance strategies for upper GI pathology in FAP.

Influence of otitis media on the correlation between rectal and auditory canal temperatures.  In a noninterventional, controlled, single-blinded trial, 251 children were examined in a university hospital emergency department setting to study the influence of acute otitis media on the relationship between rectal and auditory canal temperatures. The accuracy of measuring body temperature is crucial in diagnosing and managing various medical conditions. In this study, we aimed to investigate the influence of acute otitis media, a common childhood infection, on the correlation between rectal and auditory canal temperatures. A total of 251 children were enrolled in a noninterventional, controlled, single-blinded trial conducted in a university hospital emergency department. The results show a significant difference in temperatures between children with and without acute otitis media. Specifically, the correlation between rectal and auditory canal temperatures was significantly lower in children with acute otitis media compared to those without. These findings suggest that the presence of acute otitis media may distort the accuracy of temperature measurements, highlighting the importance of considering this factor when assessing patients with suspected infection or inflammation.

Systolic Hypertension of the Elderly Program (SHEP).  Part 10: Analysis. The Systolic Hypertension of the Elderly Program (SHEP) is a landmark study that aimed to determine the optimal treatment strategy for elderly individuals with systolic hypertension. In Part 10 of the study, the analysis was conducted to assess the effectiveness of the treatment interventions. A total of 4,736 participants were randomized to receive either active treatment or placebo. The active treatment group received a low-dose diuretic as well as antihypertensive medications, while the placebo group received inactive pills. The primary outcome measured was the incidence of fatal and nonfatal stroke. The results showed a significant reduction in the incidence of stroke in the active treatment group compared to the placebo group (P<0.001). Additionally, there were significant reductions in cardiovascular events and all-cause mortality in the active treatment group. The findings of this study support the implementation of antihypertensive treatment in elderly individuals with systolic hypertension to reduce the risk of stroke and other cardiovascular events.

Chronic arterial occlusion with PGE1-resistant skin lesions treated by glycosaminoglycan compound--case reports. We report two cases of chronic arterial occlusion with skin lesions resistant to prostaglandin E1 (PGE1) treatment, successfully managed with a glycosaminoglycan (GAG) compound. Both patients presented with non-healing ulcers and rest pain in the lower extremities, despite ongoing PGE1 therapy. After the inclusion of a GAG compound in their treatment regimen, both patients showed significant improvement in pain relief, wound healing, and skin condition. The GAG compound was administered topically and orally, and no adverse effects were observed. These cases suggest that the addition of GAG compounds may be a valuable therapeutic option for patients with PGE1-resistant skin lesions due to chronic arterial occlusion. Further studies are warranted to examine the efficacy and safety of GAG compounds in this patient population.

Recurrence rate after discontinuation of long-term mebendazole therapy in alveolar echinococcosis (preliminary results).  The recurrence rate was investigated in 19 patients with non-resectable alveolar echinococcosis after discontinuation of a long-term therapy with mebendazole (average treatment 4. 7 years). Patients were followed up for a mean duration of 2.3 years after stopping mebendazole treatment. Recurrence of alveolar echinococcosis was assessed using radiological and serological parameters. Out of the 19 patients, 6 (31.6%) experienced recurrence of the disease. The median time to recurrence was 1.8 years. Recurrence was observed in both patients who received adjuvant treatment after discontinuation of mebendazole and those who did not. There was no significant difference in the recurrence rate between patients who received a longer duration of mebendazole therapy (5 years) and those who received a shorter duration (<5 years). These preliminary results suggest that there is a considerable risk of recurrence after discontinuation of long-term mebendazole therapy in patients with non-resectable alveolar echinococcosis.

Life-threatening complications during anaesthesia in a patient with a ventriculo-atrial shunt and pulmonary hypertension [published erratum appears in Anaesthesia 1991 Mar;46(3):241] A 6-year-old patient with hydrocephalus who underwent revision of a ventriculo-atrial shunt is described. We present a case of a 6-year-old patient with hydrocephalus and a ventriculo-atrial shunt who developed life-threatening complications during anesthesia due to pulmonary hypertension. The patient underwent revision of the shunt, and during the procedure, sudden hemodynamic instability occurred. Prompt and aggressive management, including optimization of ventilation and hemodynamics, was necessary to stabilize the patient. The case highlights the challenges encountered during anesthesia in patients with ventriculo-atrial shunts and pulmonary hypertension, emphasizing the importance of close monitoring and rapid intervention in such cases to ensure patient safety.

Increase in native valve endocarditis caused by coagulase negative staphylococci: an Anglo-French clinical and microbiological study. Native valve endocarditis (NVE) caused by coagulase negative staphylococci (CoNS) has been increasing in frequency, posing a challenge in diagnosis and management. This study aims to evaluate the clinical and microbiological characteristics of NVE caused by CoNS in Anglo-French patients. 

A multicenter retrospective analysis was performed on patients diagnosed with NVE caused by CoNS between 2010 and 2020. Clinical data, echocardiographic findings, and microbiological profiles were collected and analyzed. 

A total of 105 cases were included, with a significant increase observed over the study period. CoNS was the leading cause of NVE in 28% of cases, surpassing other pathogens. Patients with CoNS-related NVE were more likely to have previous cardiac device implantation and healthcare-associated infections. 

Microbiological analysis revealed a high proportion of methicillin resistance among CoNS isolates, emphasizing the importance of antibiotic susceptibility testing. Additionally, the presence of multiple CoNS species in a single patient was observed in a substantial number of cases, suggesting potential polymicrobial infections. 

In conclusion, NVE caused by CoNS is on the rise, particularly in patients with cardiac device implantation. A comprehensive understanding of the clinical and microbiological characteristics of CoNS-related NVE is crucial for appropriate management and antimicrobial stewardship.

Endoscopic laser surgery.  A single-center comprehensive experience. Endoscopic laser surgery is a commonly performed procedure for various medical conditions. In this retrospective study, we aimed to assess the outcomes and complications associated with endoscopic laser surgery in a single-center setting. A total of 256 patients who underwent endoscopic laser surgery between 2010 and 2018 were included in the analysis. The majority of patients (68.8%) had benign conditions, while the remaining had malignant or premalignant lesions. The overall success rate of endoscopic laser surgery was 89.8%, with a low complication rate of 6.3%. Notably, patients with malignant lesions had a higher complication rate compared to those with benign conditions (9.7% vs 5.1%). Our findings suggest that endoscopic laser surgery is a safe and effective treatment option, particularly for benign lesions. However, careful patient selection and close monitoring are crucial in cases of malignant lesions to minimize the risk of complications. Further research is needed to validate these findings in larger cohorts.

T cell subsets (Tc, Th, Ts, Tsi) and IL2 receptor-bearing cells in peripheral blood of patients in the acute phase of alcoholic hepatitis. Alcoholic hepatitis is a severe and potentially life-threatening condition associated with chronic alcohol abuse. Immune dysfunction plays a key role in the pathogenesis of this disease, but the specific alterations in T cell subsets and IL2 receptor-bearing cells in these patients remain poorly understood. This study aimed to investigate the peripheral blood levels of T cell subsets (Tc, Th, Ts, Tsi) and IL2 receptor-bearing cells in patients with acute alcoholic hepatitis. Peripheral blood samples were collected from 78 patients with acute alcoholic hepatitis and 40 healthy controls. Flow cytometry analysis showed that patients with alcoholic hepatitis had significantly lower levels of Tc cells, Th cells, and Tsi cells compared to healthy controls. In contrast, the levels of Ts cells were significantly increased in patients with alcoholic hepatitis. Furthermore, IL2 receptor-bearing cells were significantly decreased in patients with alcoholic hepatitis compared to healthy controls. These findings suggest that alterations in T cell subsets and IL2 receptor-bearing cells may contribute to the immune dysfunction observed in patients with alcoholic hepatitis, providing potential targets for future therapeutic interventions.

Internuclear ophthalmoplegia in the Chiari type II malformation. Chiari type II malformation is a congenital condition characterized by herniation of the cerebellar vermis and brainstem through the foramen magnum. While the majority of patients with Chiari type II malformation present with neurological symptoms such as hydrocephalus and spasticity, less common manifestations have also been reported. We describe the case of a 15-year-old female with Chiari type II malformation who presented with acute onset internuclear ophthalmoplegia. Magnetic resonance imaging demonstrated tonsillar herniation and brainstem compression, confirming the diagnosis. To our knowledge, this is the first reported case of internuclear ophthalmoplegia as the initial manifestation of Chiari type II malformation. This case highlights the importance of considering Chiari malformation in the differential diagnosis of internuclear ophthalmoplegia, especially in pediatric patients. Early recognition and appropriate management of Chiari malformation are crucial in preventing potentially serious neurological complications.

Xeroderma pigmentosum: review and report of a case. This medical abstract presents a review of xeroderma pigmentosum, a rare genetic disorder characterized by extreme photosensitivity and an increased risk of skin cancer. Additionally, a case report is provided to further illustrate the clinical features and management of this condition. Xeroderma pigmentosum is caused by defective DNA repair mechanisms, leading to the accumulation of DNA damage upon exposure to ultraviolet radiation. The case report describes a 16-year-old male with xeroderma pigmentosum who presented with numerous cutaneous lesions and a history of multiple skin cancers. The diagnosis was confirmed through genetic testing. The management of xeroderma pigmentosum involves strict photoprotection measures, including avoidance of sun exposure and the use of sunscreen and protective clothing. Regular skin surveillance and early treatment of skin lesions are crucial for minimizing the risk of malignancies. Genetic counseling and support for affected individuals and their families are important aspects of comprehensive care.

Radiation therapy for intraductal carcinoma.  Is it an equal alternative? Of 213 consecutive patients with intraductal carcinoma, 109 were selectively treated with mastectomy and 104 with radiation therapy. This retrospective study aimed to compare the effectiveness of mastectomy versus radiation therapy as treatment options for intraductal carcinoma. A total of 213 patients diagnosed with intraductal carcinoma were included in the study, with 109 patients undergoing mastectomy and 104 patients receiving radiation therapy.

Overall, both treatment modalities were found to be effective in the management of intraductal carcinoma. The mastectomy group had a significantly lower recurrence rate compared to the radiation therapy group (p<0.05). However, the radiation therapy group had a higher rate of breast preservation, with a substantial proportion of patients achieving excellent cosmetic outcomes.

Further analysis revealed that patients with larger tumor sizes and higher nuclear grades had better outcomes with mastectomy, while those with smaller tumor sizes and lower nuclear grades had comparable outcomes with radiation therapy.

In conclusion, while mastectomy appears to provide a lower risk of recurrence in patients with intraductal carcinoma, radiation therapy can be considered as an equivalent alternative, especially for patients with smaller tumor sizes and lower nuclear grades, allowing for breast preservation and favorable cosmetic outcomes.

Antibiotic pharmacokinetics in surgery Pharmacokinetics is the study of variables that affect drug concentrations at the effector site. Understanding the pharmacokinetics of antibiotics in surgical settings is crucial for optimizing patient outcomes. This review aims to explore the factors that influence antibiotic concentrations at the site of action during surgical procedures. Various factors, including drug properties, patient characteristics, and surgical factors, can impact antibiotic pharmacokinetics. Understanding these factors allows for tailoring antibiotic dosing regimens to maximize efficacy and minimize the risk of resistance. Additionally, advances in pharmacokinetic modeling and simulation have provided valuable tools for individualized antibiotic dosing in surgical patients. Overall, optimizing antibiotic pharmacokinetics in surgery is essential for enhancing antimicrobial efficacy and reducing treatment failures and the emergence of resistant strains.

The use of molecular probes to distinguish new primary tumors from recurrent tumors in gynecologic malignancies. In gynecologic malignancies, distinguishing new primary tumors from recurrent tumors can be challenging. We aimed to evaluate the use of molecular probes in this context. We conducted a retrospective study including patients with gynecologic malignancies who underwent surgical resection of their tumors and subsequent molecular analysis. Molecular probes targeting specific genetic alterations were used to detect tumor-specific mutations. Our results showed that molecular probes were able to accurately differentiate between new primary tumors and recurrent tumors in the majority of cases. This approach demonstrated a high sensitivity and specificity in distinguishing between these two entities, which can guide treatment decisions and improve patient outcomes. Therefore, molecular probes represent a valuable tool in the management of gynecologic malignancies.

Reinforcement of incontinent stools in the treatment of encopresis. Encopresis, the involuntary passage of feces in inappropriate places, is a common problem in children. We investigated the efficacy of reinforcing incontinent stools in the treatment of encopresis. Twenty-five children diagnosed with encopresis were randomly assigned to either the intervention group or the control group. The intervention group received reinforcement of incontinent stools through a reward system, while the control group received standard care. After six weeks of treatment, the intervention group showed a significant decrease in the frequency of incontinent stools compared to the control group. These findings suggest that reinforcing incontinent stools may be an effective strategy in the treatment of encopresis. Further studies with larger sample sizes are warranted to validate these results.

Articulatory impairment associated with tardive dyskinesia. Tardive dyskinesia is a movement disorder associated with the long-term use of certain medications, such as antipsychotics. While commonly characterized by involuntary movements of the face, tongue, and limbs, articulatory impairment has been reported as a less recognized manifestation. This study aimed to investigate the prevalence and clinical characteristics of articulatory impairment in patients with tardive dyskinesia. A total of 100 patients with a confirmed diagnosis of tardive dyskinesia were included in the study. Results showed that 32% of patients presented with articulatory impairment, characterized by speech difficulties and altered vocal patterns. These findings highlight the need for increased awareness and comprehensive evaluation of articulatory impairment in patients with tardive dyskinesia.

Comparison of pulse oximeters: accuracy at low arterial pressure in volunteers. Pulse oximeters are widely used in medical practice for non-invasive measurement of oxygen saturation in arterial blood. However, their accuracy can be compromised under certain circumstances, such as low arterial pressure. In this study, we aimed to evaluate the accuracy of different pulse oximeters at low arterial pressure in healthy volunteers. A total of 50 participants were recruited and subjected to stepwise reduction of arterial pressure using a blood pressure cuff. Oxygen saturation measurements were simultaneously obtained from four pulse oximeters, and compared to invasive arterial blood gas analysis. The results showed significant differences in accuracy among the tested pulse oximeters, with some devices displaying greater deviations at low arterial pressure. These findings highlight the importance of considering the specific limitations of pulse oximeters in clinical practice, particularly in patients with low blood pressure.

Ovarian granulosa-stromal cell tumors are characterized by trisomy 12. Ovarian granulosa-stromal cell tumors (OGSCTs) are rare neoplasms that arise from the sex cord-stromal cells of the ovary. They are known to exhibit a spectrum of histological features and clinical behavior. In recent years, genetic studies have shed light on the molecular alterations involved in the pathogenesis of these tumors. One recurrent finding is the presence of trisomy 12 in a subset of OGSCTs. Trisomy 12 refers to the presence of an extra copy of chromosome 12 in the tumor cells. This chromosomal abnormality has been implicated in the overexpression of specific genes and dysregulation of signaling pathways, which may contribute to the development and progression of OGSCTs. Further research is warranted to investigate the clinical significance of trisomy 12 and its potential as a diagnostic or prognostic marker in OGSCTs.

Pharmacodynamics in cancer therapy. Pharmacodynamics, the study of the effects of drugs on the body, plays a crucial role in cancer therapy. This abstract aims to provide an overview of the pharmacodynamic principles and strategies used in cancer treatment. 

Cancer is a complex and heterogeneous disease characterized by uncontrolled cell growth and proliferation. Pharmacodynamic interventions in cancer therapy target various pathways involved in cell signaling, DNA replication, and cell cycle progression. These interventions aim to induce cell death, inhibit tumor growth, and prevent metastasis. 

Different classes of drugs, such as cytotoxic agents, hormonal therapies, immunotherapies, and targeted therapies, have been developed to selectively target cancer cells or disrupt their microenvironment. Pharmacodynamic studies in cancer therapy evaluate drug efficacy, mechanisms of action, dose-response relationships, and drug interactions. 

Understanding the pharmacodynamics of anticancer drugs is crucial for optimizing treatment regimens, minimizing toxicity, and improving patient outcomes. By tailoring treatment strategies based on individual patient characteristics, pharmacodynamics plays a vital role in personalized cancer therapy.

Delayed presentation of intrapericardial diaphragmatic hernia, an unusual cause of colon obstruction. Intrapericardial diaphragmatic hernia (IDH) is a rare form of diaphragmatic hernia, characterized by the herniation of abdominal organs into the pericardial sac. Here, we report a case of delayed presentation of IDH causing colon obstruction in a 62-year-old male patient. The patient initially presented with symptoms consistent with gastrointestinal obstruction, but the diagnosis was missed on initial evaluation. Subsequent imaging studies revealed the presence of IDH, with the colon being the herniated organ. The patient underwent surgical repair, with reduction of the hernia and resection of the ischemic colon. Postoperative recovery was uneventful, and the patient was discharged in stable condition. This case highlights the importance of considering IDH in the differential diagnosis of colon obstruction, particularly in cases with atypical presentations. Early recognition and timely intervention are crucial for optimal patient outcomes.

Polyneuropathy, ophthalmoplegia, leukoencephalopathy, and intestinal pseudo-obstruction: POLIP syndrome. POLIP syndrome, which stands for polyneuropathy, ophthalmoplegia, leukoencephalopathy, and intestinal pseudo-obstruction, is a rare neurological disorder characterized by a combination of these clinical features. We present a case report of a 42-year-old male who presented with progressive neurological symptoms including bilateral optic neuropathy, ptosis, ophthalmoplegia, sensory polyneuropathy, constipation, and chronic intestinal pseudo-obstruction. MRI examination revealed multifocal white matter hyperintensities consistent with leukoencephalopathy. The diagnosis of POLIP syndrome was made based on clinical presentation, neuroimaging findings, and exclusion of other possible causes. Genetic testing was negative for mitochondrial DNA mutations commonly associated with this syndrome. The patient was managed with supportive care and symptomatic treatment including laxatives and parenteral nutrition as needed. Despite the presence of all four diagnostic criteria, the patient experienced a slowly progressive course with limited response to treatment. POLIP syndrome is a rare and challenging disorder characterized by a combination of neurological and gastrointestinal features. Further research is needed to better understand the pathophysiology and develop effective treatment strategies for this condition.

A case of classical mycosis fungoides associated with human T-cell lymphotropic virus type I. We present a case of classical mycosis fungoides (MF) associated with human T-cell lymphotropic virus type I (HTLV-I) infection. The patient initially presented with erythematous scaly patches on the skin, which progressed to plaques and tumors. A skin biopsy revealed characteristic features of MF, and HTLV-I serology was positive. The patient was started on systemic therapy and showed a partial response. HTLV-I infection is known to be associated with adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma (ATLL), but its association with MF is rare. This case highlights the importance of considering HTLV-I infection in the differential diagnosis of cutaneous lymphomas, especially in regions where HTLV-I is endemic. Further studies are needed to explore the potential role of HTLV-I in the pathogenesis of MF and its impact on disease outcomes.

Indigenous cases of Lyme disease diagnosed in North Carolina. We present a case series of indigenous cases of Lyme disease diagnosed in North Carolina. Seven patients, aged 18 to 52 years, presented with symptoms consistent with Lyme disease, including erythema migrans rash, fever, fatigue, and joint pain. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing confirmed the presence of Borrelia burgdorferi DNA in all patients. Serologic testing revealed positive IgM and IgG antibodies against B. burgdorferi. All patients had a history of tick exposure and outdoor activities in wooded areas. Treatment with doxycycline resulted in resolution of symptoms in all cases. These cases highlight the increasing incidence of Lyme disease in areas previously considered non-endemic and emphasize the need for increased awareness and appropriate diagnostic testing in regions with emerging Lyme disease endemicity.

Photosensitive epilepsies and photoconvulsive responses in Arabs. Photosensitive epilepsies have been found to be more prevalent in the Arab population compared to other ethnic groups. This phenomenon, known as photoconvulsive response (PCR), is characterized by a seizure or epileptic activity induced by exposure to specific visual stimuli, such as flickering lights or patterns. The prevalence of PCR in Arabs has been attributed to genetic factors, as certain genetic variations have been identified in individuals with photosensitive epilepsies. Additionally, environmental factors, such as cultural practices or specific visual stimuli commonly found in Arab countries, may also contribute to the increased susceptibility to PCR. Understanding the underlying mechanisms and risk factors associated with photosensitive epilepsies in Arabs is crucial for proper diagnosis, management, and prevention of these conditions. Further research is needed to elucidate the genetic and environmental factors influencing this unique population and to develop targeted interventions for affected individuals.

Embryo reduction in multifetal pregnancies after infertility therapy: obstetrical risks and perinatal benefits are related to operative strategy.  To assess the benefits that can be expected from embryo reduction of multiple pregnancies after infertility therapy, we report 58 consecutive cases of selective termination using either a transcervical or a transabdominal approach. Embryo reduction in multifetal pregnancies after infertility therapy is commonly used to decrease obstetrical risks and improve perinatal outcomes. In this study, we analyzed 58 cases of selective termination performed using either a transcervical or a transabdominal approach. Our findings revealed that the choice of operative strategy significantly influenced both obstetrical risks and perinatal benefits. The transcervical approach was associated with a lower rate of complications, including preterm labor and preterm premature rupture of membranes, compared to the transabdominal approach. Additionally, perinatal outcomes, such as neonatal survival and birth weight, were more favorable in cases where the transcervical technique was employed. These results emphasize the importance of selecting an appropriate operative strategy to optimize outcomes in multifetal pregnancies following infertility therapy.

Management decisions in laryngeal carcinoma in situ. Laryngeal carcinoma in situ is a premalignant condition that presents a therapeutic challenge due to its potential for progression to invasive carcinoma. A total of 63 patients diagnosed with laryngeal carcinoma in situ were included in a retrospective study to determine the optimal management approach. The treatment modalities employed included endoscopic laser excision (43 cases) and radiotherapy (20 cases). The average follow-up period was 48 months. In the laser group, the overall recurrence rate was 16.3% (7 cases), with local recurrence observed in 4 cases and regional recurrence in 3 cases. In the radiotherapy group, the recurrence rate was 25% (5 cases), with local recurrence in 2 cases, regional recurrence in 1 case, and distant recurrence in 2 cases. Salvage surgery was successfully performed in all recurrent cases. Based on the study findings, a multidisciplinary approach involving endoscopic laser excision and radiotherapy is recommended for the management of laryngeal carcinoma in situ to achieve optimal outcomes and minimize the risk of progression to invasive carcinoma.

Third ventricle cavernous angioma: report of two cases. Cavernous angiomas are rare vascular malformations that can occur in various locations within the central nervous system. Reports of cavernous angiomas specifically involving the third ventricle are even more uncommon. Here, we present two cases of third ventricle cavernous angioma, both of which were incidentally found during brain imaging for unrelated reasons. The patients were asymptomatic and did not require surgical intervention. The clinical and radiological findings of these cases are described, emphasizing the importance of considering cavernous angiomas in the differential diagnosis of lesions involving the third ventricle. Additionally, we discuss the challenges in management decisions for these rare lesions and the need for long-term follow-up to monitor for potential complications.

Psychological characteristics of children with Shwachman syndrome. Shwachman syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by exocrine pancreatic insufficiency, skeletal abnormalities, and bone marrow dysfunction. This study aimed to investigate the psychological characteristics of children with Shwachman syndrome. Twenty children (aged 6-16 years) diagnosed with Shwachman syndrome were included in the study. The Wechsler Intelligence Scale for Children-Fourth Edition (WISC-IV) was used to assess their cognitive abilities, and the Child Behavior Checklist (CBCL) was used to evaluate their behavioral and emotional problems. Results showed that children with Shwachman syndrome had significantly lower mean scores on all WISC-IV indexes compared to the general population. Moreover, they exhibited a higher prevalence of externalizing and internalizing problems as assessed by the CBCL. Specifically, attention problems, aggressive behavior, and social problems were the most commonly reported behavioral difficulties. These findings highlight the need for comprehensive psychological assessment and support for children with Shwachman syndrome to optimize their overall well-being and quality of life.

Murine erythroleukemia cell line GM979 contains factors that can activate silent chromosomal human gamma-globin genes. Murine erythroleukemia cell line GM979 has been shown to contain factors that possess the ability to activate silent chromosomal human gamma-globin genes. In order to evaluate the potential therapeutic application of these factors in patients with beta-thalassemia or sickle cell disease, further investigation is necessary. The aim of this study was to determine the specific factors within GM979 cells that are responsible for the activation of gamma-globin genes and to elucidate the underlying mechanisms involved. Through a series of experiments, we identified a soluble factor secreted by GM979 cells that can induce upregulation of gamma-globin gene expression in both erythroid and non-erythroid cells. Furthermore, we found that this factor acts through the binding of specific transcription factors to the gamma-globin gene promoter region, leading to its activation. These findings provide valuable insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying gamma-globin gene regulation and offer potential therapeutic targets for the treatment of beta-hemoglobinopathies.

Access to cancer prevention, detection, and treatment. Cancer continues to be a major global health concern, with millions of individuals being diagnosed with this disease each year. Access to cancer prevention, detection, and treatment plays a crucial role in reducing cancer-related morbidity and mortality. This abstract aims to highlight the importance of ensuring equitable access to cancer services.

Limited access to cancer prevention strategies, such as vaccinations against human papillomavirus (HPV) or hepatitis B virus (HBV), can contribute to higher cancer incidence rates. Additionally, barriers to cancer screening, including lack of awareness, financial constraints, and inadequate healthcare infrastructure, hinder early detection and timely interventions. Furthermore, disparities in access to high-quality cancer treatment options, including surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy, often disproportionately affect vulnerable populations, leading to poorer outcomes.

Efforts to address these disparities must prioritize a multi-faceted approach. This includes increasing public awareness about cancer and its risk factors, implementing comprehensive screening programs, strengthening healthcare infrastructure to provide timely and accessible diagnostic and treatment services, and advocating for policy changes that promote equitable access to cancer care. These interventions can significantly contribute to reducing the burden of cancer worldwide.

Point mutation in the exoplasmic domain of the erythropoietin receptor resulting in hormone-independent activation and tumorigenicity. This study reports a point mutation in the exoplasmic domain of the erythropoietin receptor (EPOR) that leads to hormone-independent activation and tumorigenicity. The mutation was identified in a patient with polycythemia vera, a myeloproliferative disorder characterized by excessive production of red blood cells. Molecular analysis revealed a missense mutation, resulting in the substitution of a proline residue with a histidine residue at position 225 of the EPOR protein. Functional assays demonstrated that the mutant EPOR exhibited constitutive activation and promoted cell proliferation even in the absence of erythropoietin stimulation. Moreover, in vivo studies using a mouse xenograft model showed that expression of the mutant EPOR in hematopoietic stem cells resulted in the formation of erythroid tumors. These findings provide novel insights into the pathogenesis of polycythemia vera and suggest potential therapeutic targets for this disease. Further research is warranted to explore the clinical implications and therapeutic possibilities of targeting this mutant EPOR in the treatment of polycythemia vera.

How selective is selective posterior rhizotomy? Although selective posterior rhizotomy has become an increasingly utilized surgical treatment for spasticity, the procedure is unstandardized and is performed differently at various medical centers. Selective posterior rhizotomy (SPR) is a surgical procedure commonly used for the management of spasticity in patients with cerebral palsy. Although its popularity has grown, there remains a lack of standardization in the technique across different medical centers. This study aimed to evaluate the selectivity of SPR and determine the factors influencing its selectivity.

A retrospective analysis was conducted on a cohort of patients who underwent SPR for spasticity management. The degree of selectivity achieved by each surgeon was assessed by measuring the postoperative reduction in electromyographic activity of target muscles. Additionally, factors such as patient age, spasticity severity, and surgeon experience were analyzed to identify potential predictors of selectivity.

The results demonstrated significant variability in selectivity among surgeons, with a wide range of electromyographic reductions observed. Multiple linear regression analysis revealed that surgeon experience and spasticity severity were the most influential factors affecting selectivity. Patient age did not significantly impact the degree of selectivity achieved.

In conclusion, while SPR is an effective treatment modality for spasticity, the level of selectivity can vary widely among surgeons. Standardization of the technique and further research into refining the surgical approach are necessary to improve patient outcomes and ensure consistent results across medical centers.

An objective score to predict upper tract deterioration in myelodysplasia.  Bladder dysfunction in myelodysplasia may present a significant hazard to the upper tract and a threat to kidney function. This study aimed to develop an objective scoring system to predict upper tract deterioration in patients with myelodysplasia. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 102 patients with myelodysplasia who underwent urodynamic testing and renal function assessment. Multiple variables including age, gender, bladder capacity, maximum detrusor pressure, and presence of detrusor sphincter dyssynergia were analyzed to identify factors associated with upper tract deterioration. Using logistic regression analysis, a scoring system was developed. The scoring system demonstrated good discrimination and calibration, with an area under the curve of 0.87. Patients with a higher score were found to have a significantly increased risk of upper tract deterioration. This objective scoring system may aid in identifying individuals at higher risk of upper tract deterioration and guide appropriate management strategies to preserve kidney function in myelodysplasia.

Cerebrospinal fluid eicosanoid levels: endogenous PGD2 and LTC4 synthesis by antigen-presenting cells that migrate to the central nervous system. This study aimed to investigate the synthesis of endogenous prostaglandin D2 (PGD2) and leukotriene C4 (LTC4) by antigen-presenting cells (APCs) that migrate to the central nervous system (CNS), using cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) eicosanoid levels as an indicator. CSF samples were collected from patients with CNS inflammation, and the presence of PGD2 and LTC4 was assessed using enzyme immunoassay. The results showed significantly elevated levels of both PGD2 and LTC4 in CSF samples. Further analysis revealed that APCs present in CSF were responsible for the production of these eicosanoids. This suggests that APCs in the CNS play a role in the local synthesis of PGD2 and LTC4, potentially contributing to the inflammation and immune response in the central nervous system.

Primary malignant melanoma of the lower respiratory tract.  Report of a case and literature review. Primary malignant melanoma of the lower respiratory tract is an extremely rare malignancy with no clear standard treatment guidelines. This case report presents a 62-year-old male patient who was diagnosed with primary malignant melanoma of the trachea. The patient presented with progressive dyspnea and hemoptysis, and a subsequent bronchoscopic examination revealed an endobronchial mass in the trachea. Histopathological examination of the biopsy specimen confirmed the diagnosis of primary malignant melanoma. The patient underwent a multidisciplinary approach, including surgical resection, adjuvant radiation therapy, and immunotherapy. Despite the aggressive management, the patient's prognosis remains grim, with poor response to treatment and rapid disease progression. A comprehensive literature review of similar cases was conducted to explore the current understanding of this rare entity. Further research is necessary to establish standardized treatments and improve the prognosis of primary malignant melanoma of the lower respiratory tract.

Solid and cystic ultimobranchial body remnants in the thyroid. Solid and cystic ultimobranchial body remnants (S&CUBRs) are rare congenital anomalies found in the thyroid gland. We present a case of a 45-year-old female who underwent thyroidectomy for a suspicious nodule, and pathology revealed the presence of S&CUBRs within the thyroid parenchyma. Microscopic examination demonstrated both solid and cystic components, with the cystic areas containing colloid-filled spaces lined by cuboidal or columnar epithelium. Immunohistochemical staining for calcitonin, a marker of ultimobranchial cells, showed positive staining within the solid nodules and negative staining in the cystic areas. This finding suggests that the solid component represents the ultimobranchial body remnants, while the cystic areas may represent cystic degeneration or dilated follicles. Understanding the histopathological features of S&CUBRs is important in order to differentiate them from other thyroid lesions, as their recognition can help prevent unnecessary diagnostic workup and overtreatment. Further studies are needed to elucidate the pathogenesis and clinical significance of these structures in the thyroid gland.

New active analogues of vitamin D with low calcemic activity. Vitamin D derivatives have been widely used in the treatment of various diseases, such as psoriasis, osteoporosis, and certain types of cancer. However, their clinical use is limited due to their potential to cause hypercalcemia. In this study, new analogues of vitamin D with low calcemic activity were developed and evaluated. The analogues were synthesized using a modified synthetic route, and their cytotoxicity and calcemic activity were assessed in vitro and in vivo. Preliminary results showed that the new analogues exhibited significant cytotoxic effects on cancer cells while having minimal impact on calcium metabolism. These findings suggest that these new analogues have the potential to be promising candidates for further development as therapeutic agents with reduced calcemic side effects.

Meropenem pharmacokinetics and penetration into an inflammatory exudate.  The pharmacokinetics and penetration into a cantharidine-induced inflammatory exudate of meropenem was studied in six volunteers following a single 1-g intravenous dose. Blood and exudate samples were collected at multiple time points up to 12 hours post-dose. Meropenem concentrations in the plasma and exudate were determined using high-performance liquid chromatography. The pharmacokinetic parameters were calculated using noncompartmental analysis. Meropenem exhibited a rapid distribution phase with an average time to reach maximum concentration (Tmax) of 0.5 hours. The mean maximum concentration (Cmax) in plasma was 52.6 g/mL, while in exudate, it was 32.8 g/mL. The penetration ratio of meropenem into the exudate was 62.4%. The study demonstrates that meropenem has good penetration into inflammatory exudates, suggesting its potential efficacy in treating infections associated with such exudates.

Granulomatous prostatitis and poorly differentiated prostate carcinoma. Granulomatous prostatitis (GP) and poorly differentiated prostate carcinoma (PDPC) are two distinct conditions that can present with similar clinical and pathological features, making accurate diagnosis challenging. This study aims to better understand the clinical characteristics and outcomes of patients diagnosed with GP and PDPC.

A retrospective analysis was conducted on patients diagnosed with GP (n=30) and PDPC (n=25) between 2010 and 2020. Clinical and pathological data were collected and analyzed. Patients with GP had a median age of 63 years, while those with PDPC had a median age of 68 years. Both groups presented with lower urinary tract symptoms, including dysuria and urinary frequency. However, patients with PDPC were more likely to have elevated prostate-specific antigen levels and a higher Gleason score on biopsy.

Treatment outcomes varied between the two groups. Patients with GP typically responded well to medical therapy, including antibiotics and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs. In contrast, patients with PDPC often required more aggressive management, such as surgery, radiation therapy, or androgen deprivation therapy.

In conclusion, accurate diagnosis and differentiation of GP and PDPC are crucial for appropriate management and treatment selection. This study highlights the importance of considering clinical and pathological factors when evaluating patients with prostatic lesions.

Multiple gunshot wounds of the head: an anthropological view.  A decomposed body was judged at the scene to have two gunshot wounds of the thorax and three of the head. This case report presents an anthropological view of a decomposed body with multiple gunshot wounds, specifically two in the thorax and three in the head. The aim was to document and analyze the wound patterns to aid in the investigation and determination of cause of death. Detailed examination and documentation of the wounds were performed, including measurements and descriptions of entrance and exit wounds, as well as the direction of fire. The findings suggest multiple gunshots were fired at close range, causing severe injuries to the head. The information gathered from this study may contribute to forensic investigations and further understanding of gunshot wound patterns.

Epidemiology of acute respiratory infections in young children from Thailand. This study aimed to investigate the epidemiology of acute respiratory infections (ARI) in young children from Thailand. A total of 500 children aged 1 to 5 years were enrolled in the study. Nasopharyngeal swabs were collected for laboratory testing, including polymerase chain reaction (PCR) for respiratory viruses, bacterial culture, and serological analysis. 

The results showed that 62% of the children had at least one respiratory virus detected, with the most common being respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) (38%). Other viruses identified included influenza virus (12%), human rhinovirus (10%), and adenovirus (8%). Bacterial cultures were positive in 18% of the children, with Streptococcus pneumoniae being the most common (12%). 

The incidence of ARI was highest during the rainy season, with a peak in August. Children who attended daycare centers had a higher risk of ARI compared to those who stayed at home. 

Overall, ARI in young children from Thailand is predominantly viral in nature, with RSV being the most common respiratory virus detected. The findings highlight the importance of targeted interventions, such as vaccination against RSV, to reduce the burden of ARI in this population.

Arterial responses during migraine headache. Migraine headache is a common neurological disorder characterized by recurrent episodes of severe headache accompanied by various symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound. Although the etiology of migraine headache is still not fully understood, it is believed to involve the dysfunction of the cranial vasculature. 

This study aimed to investigate arterial responses during a migraine headache using a non-invasive imaging technique. Twenty-seven patients with a history of migraine headache were recruited, and their arterial responses were assessed using dynamic 3D contrast-enhanced magnetic resonance angiography. 

The results showed significant changes in the diameter of the middle cerebral artery during a migraine attack compared to the pain-free state. These changes were characterized by vasoconstriction followed by vasodilation, indicating the presence of neurovascular dysfunction during a migraine headache. 

In conclusion, this study provides evidence for abnormal arterial responses in patients with migraine headache, suggesting a potential role of neurovascular mechanisms in the pathophysiology of this debilitating condition. Further research is needed to elucidate the underlying causes and develop targeted interventions for the management of migraine headache.

Expression of P-glycoprotein in adult T-cell leukemia cells. P-glycoprotein (P-gp) is a membrane protein that plays a crucial role in multidrug resistance (MDR) in various cancers. In this study, we aimed to investigate the expression of P-gp in adult T-cell leukemia (ATL) cells. 

Using flow cytometry, we analyzed peripheral blood samples from 20 ATL patients and 10 healthy controls. Our results revealed significantly higher expression of P-gp in ATL cells compared to control samples (p<0.001). Furthermore, immunohistochemical analysis of bone marrow biopsies from ATL patients confirmed the overexpression of P-gp in leukemic cells. 

Next, we examined the correlation between P-gp expression and clinical characteristics of ATL patients. Interestingly, a positive correlation was observed between P-gp expression and advanced disease stage (p=0.002). Additionally, patients with higher P-gp expression exhibited poorer response to chemotherapy (p=0.018). 

In conclusion, our findings demonstrate the upregulation of P-gp in ATL cells, suggesting its potential role in conferring MDR and contributing to disease progression. Targeting P-gp may therefore be a promising strategy to overcome treatment resistance and improve outcomes in ATL patients. Further studies are warranted to explore the underlying mechanisms and validate these findings in larger cohorts.

Effect of indomethacin on the pathophysiology of experimental meningitis in rabbits. In this study, we investigate the effect of indomethacin on the pathophysiology of experimental meningitis in rabbits. Meningitis was induced in the animals by intracisternal injection of Streptococcus pneumoniae.
