The rabbits were then divided into two groups: one group received indomethacin treatment and the other group served as a control. We found that indomethacin significantly reduced the inflammatory response in the meninges, as seen by decreased cerebrospinal fluid levels of inflammatory markers such as interleukin-1 beta and tumor necrosis factor-alpha. Additionally, indomethacin treatment attenuated the blood-brain barrier damage and reduced the number of bacteria in the cerebrospinal fluid. These findings suggest that indomethacin may have potential therapeutic benefits in the management of bacterial meningitis.

Anti-Kveim monoclonal antibody.  New monoclonal antibody reacting to epithelioid cells in sarcoid granulomas. The study aimed to identify risk factors for the transmission of hepatitis B virus (HBV) among Gambian children aged 6 months to 5 years. Out of the 973 children examined, 33% were found to have evidence of HBV infection, with a third of these children being carriers. The study found a significant association between HBV infection and the presence of tropical ulcer scars, as well as between the presence of e antigenaemia (indicative of active viral replication) and the presence of bedbugs in the child's bed. However, no association was found between HBV infection and traditional scarring, circumcision, or injections. These findings suggest that skin disease and arthropods, specifically bedbugs, may play a crucial role in the transmission of HBV among children in West Africa. Further research on the modes of transmission and preventive measures targeting these risk factors is warranted. In addition, a new monoclonal antibody, specifically targeting epithelioid cells in sarcoid granulomas, has been developed, suggesting potential advancements in the diagnosis and treatment of sarcoidosis.

Speech, velopharyngeal function, and hearing before and after orthognathic surgery.  Articulation, voice, resonance, hearing sensitivity, and middle ear function were examined in 34 patients before and 3, 6, 9, and 12 months after orthognathic surgery. This study evaluated the impact of orthognathic surgery on speech, velopharyngeal function, and hearing in 34 patients. Preoperative and postoperative assessments were conducted at 3, 6, 9, and 12 months intervals. Measures of articulation, voice quality, resonance, hearing sensitivity, and middle ear function were examined. 

Results showed significant improvements in speech outcomes following orthognathic surgery. Articulation patterns improved in all patients, accompanied by enhanced voice quality and resonance. Velopharyngeal function also showed remarkable improvement post-surgery. Patients exhibited better control and closure of the velopharyngeal port, leading to improved speech intelligibility.

In terms of hearing, there were no significant changes in hearing sensitivity or middle ear function following surgery. This suggests that orthognathic surgery does not adversely affect auditory function.

Overall, orthognathic surgery positively impacts speech and velopharyngeal function, without detrimental effects on hearing. These findings highlight the efficacy and safety of orthognathic surgery in treating patients with craniofacial anomalies and dysfunctions.

Effect of hydrocele on testis and spermatogenesis. Hydrocele is a common condition characterized by the accumulation of fluid in the tunica vaginalis, leading to scrotal swelling. This study aimed to investigate the effect of hydrocele on testis and spermatogenesis. Testicular biopsies were obtained from 30 patients with hydrocele and compared to 30 control subjects. Histological analysis revealed no significant difference in testicular volume or Leydig cell count between the two groups. However, there was a significant decrease in spermatogonia, primary spermatocytes, and spermatids in the hydrocele group compared to controls. Furthermore, the hydrocele group exhibited higher levels of reactive oxygen species and lower expression of antioxidant enzymes, suggesting that oxidative stress may contribute to impaired spermatogenesis in hydrocele patients. These findings enhance our understanding of the impact of hydrocele on testicular function and may have implications for fertility management in affected individuals.

Lymph node metastasis from papillary-follicular thyroid carcinoma in young patients.  A total of 117 patients under 20 years of age with papillary and/or follicular thyroid cancer presented to the M. A total of 117 patients under 20 years of age with papillary and/or follicular thyroid cancer presented to the M. D. Anderson Cancer Center between 1996 and 2016. Out of these patients, 32 (27.4%) had lymph node metastasis detected at the time of initial surgery. The majority of cases were diagnosed as papillary thyroid carcinoma (78.1%), while 21.9% were diagnosed as follicular thyroid carcinoma. The median age at diagnosis was 17 years. Lymph node metastasis was more common in patients with larger tumor size and extrathyroidal extension. There was no significant difference in the rate of lymph node metastasis between patients with papillary and follicular thyroid carcinoma. This study highlights the importance of careful evaluation of lymph node involvement in young patients with papillary-follicular thyroid carcinoma in order to guide appropriate management decisions.

Urogenital dysfunction after abdominoperineal resection for carcinoma of the rectum. This retrospective study aimed to determine the prevalence and risk factors of urogenital dysfunction following abdominoperineal resection (APR) for rectal carcinoma. Medical records of 78 patients who underwent APR between 2010 and 2015 were reviewed. Urogenital dysfunction was defined as urinary incontinence or erectile dysfunction persisting for more than 6 months postoperatively. The overall prevalence of urogenital dysfunction was found to be 33%. Multivariate analysis identified male gender, age above 60 years, and tumor stage as independent risk factors for urogenital dysfunction. Postoperative complications, including anastomotic leakage and surgical site infection, were not significantly associated with urogenital dysfunction. These findings emphasize the importance of preoperative counseling and close postoperative monitoring for urogenital dysfunction in patients undergoing APR for rectal carcinoma, particularly in older male patients with advanced tumor stage.

A blood-liquid interface for prolonged extracorporeal oxygenation with excellent antithrombogenicity. Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) is a life-saving technique for patients with severe respiratory or cardiac failure. However, its efficacy is limited by the formation of blood clots within the ECMO circuit. In this study, we developed a novel blood-liquid interface for prolonged extracorporeal oxygenation with excellent antithrombogenicity. The interface consisted of a two-layered system, with the upper layer being a plasma-like solution and the lower layer being a silicone oil mixture. We evaluated the antithrombogenicity of this interface using in vitro tests and found a significantly reduced platelet adhesion and activation compared to conventional ECMO circuits. Moreover, the interface maintained a stable oxygen transfer efficiency over a prolonged period. These findings suggest that the blood-liquid interface has the potential to improve the safety and efficacy of ECMO therapy by minimizing thrombotic complications. Further studies are needed to assess its clinical feasibility.

A topographical relationship between Helicobacter pylori and gastritis: quantitative assessment of Helicobacter pylori in the gastric mucosa.  A topographical relationship between the number of Helicobacter pylori in the gastric mucosa and the histological severity of gastritis was studied in 902 pairs of biopsy specimens taken from 314 patients. Histological assessment of gastritis was performed using the Sydney system. Helicobacter pylori density was quantified by counting the number of organisms in six gastric regions. A significant correlation was observed between the number of Helicobacter pylori and the severity of gastritis (r = 0.54, p < 0.001), as well as the activity of gastritis (r = 0.43, p < 0.001). Furthermore, a significant variation in Helicobacter pylori density was observed between different gastric regions (p < 0.001). The highest density was found in the antrum, followed by the corpus and cardia. These findings provide quantitative evidence for a topographical relationship between Helicobacter pylori colonization and the severity and activity of gastritis, emphasizing the importance of regional sampling in evaluating Helicobacter pylori infection.

Evaluation of argon laser surgery in children under 13 years of age. Argon laser surgery has become a popular treatment option for various medical conditions, including the management of vascular malformations and airway stenosis. However, there is limited data regarding its safety and efficacy in the pediatric population, specifically in children under 13 years of age. 

In this retrospective study, we aimed to evaluate the outcomes and complications associated with argon laser surgery in this specific age group. A total of 45 children, aged between 6 months and 13 years, underwent argon laser surgery for various indications. We assessed the success rate of the procedure, as well as the rate of complications such as bleeding, scarring, and infection.

Preliminary analysis demonstrates a high success rate of 94% in achieving the desired treatment outcome. However, complications were encountered in 15% of the cases, including minor bleeding and transient scarring. No instances of infection were observed. 

These preliminary findings suggest that argon laser surgery is a safe and effective option for children under 13 years of age, with a high success rate and low complication rate. However, further research with a larger sample size is warranted to validate these results and establish guidelines for its use in this specific population.

Portal vein resection with a new antithrombogenic catheter. This study presents a novel technique for portal vein resection using a newly developed antithrombogenic catheter. The procedure was performed on 27 patients with portal vein thrombosis, hepatic malignancies, or other liver pathologies necessitating portal vein resection. The antithrombogenic catheter, incorporating a specialized coating to prevent thrombus formation, was successfully inserted into the portal vein during surgery. The primary outcome measures included intraoperative complications, postoperative thrombosis rate, and long-term patency of the reconstructed portal vein. Secondary outcomes included postoperative mortality, morbidity, and overall survival. Results indicate a significantly reduced incidence of thrombosis compared to traditional portal vein resection techniques, highlighting the efficacy of the antithrombogenic catheter in minimizing vascular complications. Furthermore, long-term patency rates were encouraging, demonstrating the feasibility and potential benefits of this innovative approach to portal vein resection. Further prospective studies are warranted to validate these findings and assess the long-term outcomes of patients undergoing portal vein resection with the new antithrombogenic catheter.

Pancreatic mucinous cystadenocarcinoma with pseudosarcomatous mural nodules.  A report of a case with immunohistochemical study. We present a case of pancreatic mucinous cystadenocarcinoma with pseudosarcomatous mural nodules. A 52-year-old male patient presented with abdominal pain and weight loss. Imaging studies revealed a multiloculated cystic mass in the pancreas, and the patient underwent surgical resection. Histological examination demonstrated a cystic lesion with nodular areas in the mural component. Immunohistochemical analysis revealed positive staining for cytokeratin 7 and mucin, supporting the diagnosis of mucinous cystadenocarcinoma. The nodular areas showed a spindle cell morphology with positivity for vimentin and actin, suggesting a pseudosarcomatous transformation. This case highlights the rare occurrence of pseudosarcomatous mural nodules in pancreatic mucinous cystadenocarcinoma and emphasizes the importance of immunohistochemistry in making an accurate diagnosis. Further studies are warranted to elucidate the molecular mechanisms underlying this phenomenon and its prognostic significance.

Argon green (514 nm) versus krypton red (647 nm) modified grid laser photocoagulation for diffuse diabetic macular edema. Diabetic macular edema (DME) is a leading cause of vision loss in patients with diabetes. Laser photocoagulation has been widely used as a treatment option for DME, with modified grid laser photocoagulation being one of the recommended techniques. However, the optimal wavelength for this procedure is still debated. This study aimed to compare the efficacy of argon green (514 nm) and krypton red (647 nm) modified grid laser photocoagulation in the treatment of diffuse DME.

A total of 80 eyes from 40 patients with diffuse DME were randomly assigned to receive either argon green or krypton red laser photocoagulation. Visual acuity, central macular thickness, and the presence of macular edema were evaluated at baseline and at regular follow-up visits. The results showed that both laser wavelengths led to a significant improvement in visual acuity and reduction in central macular thickness. However, the argon green laser demonstrated a higher rate of complete resolution of macular edema compared to the krypton red laser.

In conclusion, both argon green and krypton red modified grid laser photocoagulation are effective in improving visual outcomes and reducing macular thickness in patients with diffuse DME. However, the argon green laser appears to have a higher success rate in achieving complete resolution of macular edema. Further studies with larger sample sizes are warranted to confirm these findings and establish the optimal laser wavelength for the treatment of DME.

The febrile alcoholic in the emergency department. Febrile alcoholic patients frequently present to the emergency department with various complications and challenges. We conducted a retrospective analysis of febrile alcoholic patients admitted to our emergency department over a one-year period. Out of 250 patients identified, the most common presenting symptoms were fever, jaundice, and altered mental status. The most common comorbidities observed were liver cirrhosis and alcoholic hepatitis. Microbiological analysis revealed that the most frequently isolated pathogens were Escherichia coli and Streptococcus pneumoniae. Additionally, many patients had polymicrobial infections. The mortality rate among febrile alcoholic patients was found to be significantly higher compared to non-alcoholic febrile patients. Prompt diagnosis, appropriate antibiotic therapy, and supportive care are crucial in the management of febrile alcoholic patients in the emergency department to reduce morbidity and mortality.

Effect of felbamate on plasma levels of carbamazepine and its metabolites.  Felbamate (FBM) is a novel antiepileptic drug (AED) currently undergoing clinical evaluation in the United States. This study aimed to investigate the effect of felbamate (FBM) on plasma levels of carbamazepine (CBZ) and its metabolites. A total of 32 patients with epilepsy who were stabilized on CBZ monotherapy were enrolled in this study. The patients were divided into two groups, with Group A receiving FBM in addition to CBZ and Group B continuing on CBZ monotherapy. Plasma levels of CBZ and its active metabolite, carbamazepine-10,11-epoxide (CBZ-E), were measured before and after the addition of FBM in Group A and at the same time intervals in Group B. The results showed a significant increase in plasma levels of CBZ and CBZ-E in Group A after the addition of FBM. The increase in CBZ levels was attributed to the inhibitory effect of FBM on the metabolism of CBZ by hepatic enzymes. These findings suggest the need for close monitoring of CBZ levels when FBM is co-administered to ensure optimal therapeutic efficacy and avoid potential drug interactions.

Cortical tremor: a variant of cortical reflex myoclonus. Cortical tremor is a rare variant of cortical reflex myoclonus that presents with rhythmic involuntary movements affecting the extremities. We present a case of a 45-year-old male with a 2-year history of intermittent, stereotypical hand tremors. Neurological examination revealed a characteristic tremor of both hands, triggered by specific tasks such as writing and holding objects. Electromyography demonstrated cortical origin of the tremor, with no evidence of peripheral nerve involvement. MRI of the brain was unremarkable. The patient was started on low-dose clonazepam, resulting in significant improvement of tremor frequency and severity. Cortical tremor is a distinct entity within the spectrum of myoclonus disorders, characterized by its unique clinical features and response to pharmacotherapy. Recognition of this variant is crucial for appropriate diagnosis and management.

Angioedema from angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors: a cause of upper airway obstruction. Angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors (ACE inhibitors) are commonly prescribed medications for the treatment of hypertension and heart failure. While angioedema is a known adverse effect of ACE inhibitors, it is a relatively rare occurrence. This case report presents a patient who developed acute upper airway obstruction secondary to angioedema following initiation of ACE inhibitor therapy. The patient presented with sudden onset of facial and tongue swelling, along with difficulty breathing and speaking. Immediate intervention, including administration of intramuscular epinephrine and airway management, was necessary to prevent further deterioration. This case highlights the importance of recognizing angioedema as a potentially life-threatening complication of ACE inhibitors and emphasizes the need for prompt management and consideration of alternative medications in patients who develop this adverse effect.

Transbronchial biopsies in children after heart-lung transplantation.  Sixty transbronchial biopsies have been performed in eight children after heart-lung transplantation. This retrospective study aimed to evaluate the safety and diagnostic yield of transbronchial biopsies (TBB) in children who underwent heart-lung transplantation. A total of eight pediatric patients who underwent heart-lung transplantation at our institution between 2010 and 2015 were included in the study. Sixty TBB procedures were performed on these patients for surveillance of acute rejection. The TBBs were analyzed for complications, histopathological findings, and diagnostic yield. The results demonstrated that TBBs were a safe procedure in this pediatric population, with no major complications observed. Histopathological evaluation of the biopsies revealed evidence of acute cellular rejection in 15% of the cases. The diagnostic yield of TBBs was found to be relatively low in this population, with a majority of the biopsies showing no significant abnormalities. Despite the limited diagnostic efficacy, TBBs continue to be a valuable tool for surveillance of acute rejection and should be considered in the post-transplant management of pediatric heart-lung transplant recipients. Further studies with larger sample sizes are needed to confirm these findings.

Optimal interpretation of the supine exercise electrocardiogram in patients with right bundle branch block. Patients with right bundle branch block (RBBB) often present challenges in the interpretation of exercise electrocardiogram (ECG) due to the characteristic ECG changes associated with RBBB. This study aimed to determine the optimal interpretation of the supine exercise ECG in patients with RBBB. 
A retrospective analysis of 98 patients with RBBB who underwent supine exercise testing was performed. The ECG variables evaluated included ST-segment changes, T-wave abnormalities, and QRS-axis shifts during exercise. The optimal interpretation of the supine exercise ECG in patients with RBBB was determined based on the presence or absence of significant changes indicative of myocardial ischemia or other cardiac abnormalities. 
The results showed that 65% of patients with RBBB demonstrated abnormal exercise ECG findings. ST-segment changes were the most common abnormality observed, followed by T-wave abnormalities and QRS-axis shifts. 
In conclusion, patients with RBBB frequently exhibit abnormal exercise ECG findings. Careful interpretation of ST-segment changes, T-wave abnormalities, and QRS-axis shifts is crucial in distinguishing physiological changes from pathological findings in patients with RBBB during supine exercise testing.

Use of a knee-brace for control of tibial translation and rotation. This article discusses the use of a knee-brace for the control of tibial translation and rotation in patients with knee instability. The importance of proper knee stability in maintaining joint health and preventing further damage is highlighted. Different types of knee-braces, including hinged and non-hinged braces, are described along with their mechanisms of action. The potential benefits and limitations of using a knee-brace for tibial translation and rotation control are explored. Factors to consider when selecting a knee-brace, such as the patient's specific condition, activity level, and compliance, are also discussed. The article concludes with a summary of current evidence and recommendations for the use of knee-braces in the management of knee instability.

Limitation of transcatheter arterial chemoembolization using iodized oil for small hepatocellular carcinoma. Transcatheter arterial chemoembolization (TACE) using iodized oil has been widely used as a therapeutic modality for hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) patients. However, its efficacy in treating small HCC lesions remains controversial. This study aims to evaluate the limitations of TACE using iodized oil for small HCC. A systematic review of relevant literature was conducted to analyze the outcomes and complications associated with this treatment approach. It was found that TACE using iodized oil had limited efficacy in achieving complete tumor necrosis and long-term survival in patients with small HCC lesions. Furthermore, the procedure was associated with increased risks of liver dysfunction and intrahepatic recurrence. Therefore, alternative treatment strategies should be considered for small HCC lesions to optimize patient outcomes and minimize potential complications.

Left ventricular diastolic dysfunction presenting as ascites: the importance of clinically assessing central venous pressure. Ascites is a common presentation of liver cirrhosis; however, other etiologies should also be considered. We report a case of left ventricular diastolic dysfunction presenting as ascites. A 73-year-old male with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presented with abdominal distention and shortness of breath. Examination revealed tense ascites. Laboratory investigations ruled out hepatic causes of ascites. Echocardiography demonstrated left ventricular diastolic dysfunction with preserved ejection fraction. Central venous pressure measurement showed elevated pressures, further supporting the diagnosis. This case emphasizes the importance of considering cardiac etiologies in patients presenting with ascites. Clinically assessing central venous pressure can aid in the diagnosis and appropriate management of such cases. Timely recognition and treatment of cardiac causes can prevent further complications and improve patient outcomes.

Cutaneous manifestations of multiple myeloma. Multiple myeloma is a hematological malignancy characterized by the proliferation of plasma cells in the bone marrow. Cutaneous manifestations of multiple myeloma are rare but can provide important clues to the diagnosis and prognosis of the disease. In this retrospective study, we reviewed the medical records of 65 multiple myeloma patients who presented with cutaneous manifestations. The most common cutaneous findings were skin lesions (40%), followed by pruritus (26%) and hyperpigmentation (18%). The presence of skin lesions was associated with a higher disease stage and poorer overall survival. Skin biopsy revealed a variety of histopathological findings, including plasmacytoma, leukocytoclastic vasculitis, and amyloid deposition. These findings suggest that cutaneous manifestations in multiple myeloma should prompt further investigation and may have prognostic implications.

Dietary management of acute childhood diarrhea: optimal timing of feeding and appropriate use of milks and mixed diets. Acute diarrhea is a common condition in childhood and dietary management plays a crucial role in its treatment. This study aimed to determine the optimal timing of feeding and appropriate use of milks and mixed diets in children with acute diarrhea. A total of 150 children aged 6 months to 5 years with acute diarrhea were included in the study. They were divided into three groups: early feeding group, delayed feeding group, and control group. The early feeding group showed shorter duration of diarrhea compared to the delayed feeding group (p<0.05). Furthermore, the use of oral rehydration solution and milk supplementation was found to be effective in reducing the severity of dehydration and promoting growth in children with acute diarrhea. The results of this study provide valuable insights for healthcare professionals in managing acute childhood diarrhea through appropriate dietary interventions.

Autoimmune enteropathy and colitis: is there a generalised autoimmune gut disorder? Children with protracted diarrhoea, circulating enterocyte autoantibodies, and an enteropathy showing features of inappropriate HLA molecule expression on the jejunal crypt epithelium, often present with persistent blood and mucus in their stools. The presence of circulating enterocyte autoantibodies and abnormal HLA molecule expression on the jejunal crypt epithelium suggest a possible autoimmune etiology in children with protracted diarrhea, colitis, and persistent blood and mucus in the stools. This study aimed to investigate whether there is a generalized autoimmune gut disorder in these patients. Histological examination of the intestinal biopsies revealed focal villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, and increased numbers of intraepithelial lymphocytes. Immunohistochemical analysis showed increased expression of HLA-DR on the crypt epithelium. These findings support the hypothesis that autoimmune mechanisms play a role in the pathogenesis of enteropathy and colitis in these children. Further research is needed to elucidate the specific autoantigens involved and the underlying molecular mechanisms.

Renal effects of cyclosporine. Cyclosporine is a potent immunosuppressive agent used in organ transplantation to prevent rejection. However, its use is limited by its renal side effects, including renal dysfunction and nephrotoxicity. This study aimed to investigate the renal effects of cyclosporine in a rat model. Rats were treated with cyclosporine for 4 weeks, and renal function was assessed using creatinine clearance and histological examination. Cyclosporine treatment resulted in a significant decrease in creatinine clearance, indicating renal dysfunction. Histological analysis revealed signs of nephrotoxicity, including tubular dilatation, interstitial fibrosis, and inflammatory infiltrates. These findings highlight the potential renal toxicity of cyclosporine and emphasize the need for close monitoring of renal function in patients undergoing cyclosporine therapy. Further research is warranted to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and develop strategies to mitigate cyclosporine-induced renal injury.

Indications of the carbon dioxide laser in tracheobronchial pathology of the infant and young child: 14 cases.  Fourteen children aged between 6 months and 7 years (mean age = 3. The use of the carbon dioxide (CO2) laser in the management of tracheobronchial pathology in infants and young children is presented in this study. Fourteen cases, with patients ranging in age from 6 months to 7 years (mean age = 3.5 years), were included. The indications for CO2 laser treatment included foreign body removal, tracheobronchial stenosis, and granulation tissue removal. The CO2 laser provided several advantages in these cases, including precise tissue ablation, minimal thermal injury, and excellent hemostasis. All procedures were successful, with no intraoperative complications reported. Postoperative follow-up revealed satisfactory clinical outcomes, with improvements in symptoms and reduction in airway obstruction. The CO2 laser appears to be a safe and effective tool for managing tracheobronchial pathology in the pediatric population.

Ciliary motility in two patients with yellow nail syndrome and recurrent sinopulmonary infections. We report two cases of yellow nail syndrome (YNS) presenting with recurrent sinopulmonary infections and impaired ciliary motility. YNS is a rare disorder characterized by discolored, thickened, and slowed growing nails, lymphedema, and respiratory manifestations. In both cases, nasal nitric oxide (nNO) levels were decreased, suggesting impaired ciliary function. Ciliary beat frequency (CBF) measurements using high-speed digital microscopy revealed significantly reduced CBF compared to healthy controls. Electron microscopy of nasal epithelial cells demonstrated structural abnormalities, including absent or disorganized microtubules and abnormal ciliary axonemes. These findings suggest that impaired ciliary motility may be a contributing factor to the recurrent sinopulmonary infections seen in YNS. Further studies are needed to understand the underlying mechanisms and potential therapeutic interventions for this condition.

Interaction of sodium sensitivity and stress in young adults.  The interaction of sodium sensitivity and stress-induced cardiovascular reactivity was studied in white and black young adults aged 18-23 years. The study aimed to investigate the interaction between sodium sensitivity and stress-induced cardiovascular reactivity in young adults. A total of 100 participants, including 50 white and 50 black individuals aged between 18 and 23 years, were enrolled in the study. Sodium sensitivity was assessed using a standardized dietary sodium intake protocol, and cardiovascular reactivity was measured during a stress task. Results showed that both white and black individuals with high sodium sensitivity exhibited significantly higher cardiovascular reactivity during the stress task compared to those with low sodium sensitivity. Moreover, the interaction between sodium sensitivity and stress-induced cardiovascular reactivity differed between white and black participants, suggesting a potential racial disparity in this relationship. Further research is needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and clinical implications of these findings.

Familial trigeminal neuralgia and Charcot-Marie-Tooth neuropathy. Trigeminal neuralgia (TN) and Charcot-Marie-Tooth (CMT) neuropathy are distinct neurological conditions that have been rarely reported to coexist within the same family. However, this abstract presents two cases of familial trigeminal neuralgia occurring concurrently with Charcot-Marie-Tooth neuropathy in two unrelated families. The first case involved a mother and daughter, both presenting with TN and CMT type 1A. The second case involved three siblings, all displaying TN and CMT type 1A. The combination of TN and CMT in these families suggests a potential genetic link between the two conditions. Investigation into the shared genetic mechanisms, possibly involving peripheral myelin protein genes, may provide insights into the etiology and pathogenesis of both TN and CMT. Clinicians should be aware of the possibility of this unique familial association, as it may impact diagnostic and therapeutic approaches for patients presenting with trigeminal neuralgia.

Clinical significance of intratesticular arterial anatomy. The intratesticular arterial anatomy is of great clinical significance in various aspects of urology. A detailed understanding of this anatomy is crucial for the management of male infertility, testicular tumors, and testicular torsion. This study aimed to comprehensively evaluate the intratesticular arterial anatomy using a large sample size of 100 patients who underwent testicular angiography. The results demonstrated significant anatomical variations in the branching pattern of the testicular artery and its connections with the deferential artery. Additionally, a significant correlation was observed between the pattern of arterial anatomy and the clinical presentation of testicular pathology. This study provides valuable insights into the intratesticular arterial anatomy, aiding in the accurate diagnosis and management of testicular conditions. Furthermore, it highlights the importance of considering individual variations when planning surgical interventions in the testicular region.

Impact of active immunisation against enteritis necroticans in Papua New Guinea. Enteritis necroticans, caused by Clostridium perfringens, is a severe and potentially fatal infection prevalent in many developing countries, including Papua New Guinea (PNG). This study aimed to assess the impact of active immunization against enteritis necroticans in PNG. A retrospective analysis of the medical records of patients diagnosed with enteritis necroticans between 2010 and 2018 was conducted. Out of a total of 223 cases, 100 had received active immunization against C. perfringens. The results showed a significant reduction in the incidence and mortality rates in the vaccinated group compared to the non-vaccinated group. The vaccine was found to be effective in preventing severe complications and reducing the burden of enteritis necroticans in PNG. These findings underscore the importance of implementing active immunization programs in high-risk populations to combat this devastating infection.

Increased MEPP frequency as an early sign of experimental immune-mediated motoneuron disease. Immune-mediated motoneuron disease (IMMD) is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder characterized by selective loss of motoneurons. Early detection and understanding of disease progression are crucial for effective management and treatment. This study aimed to investigate the potential of miniature endplate potential (MEPP) frequency as an early biomarker for IMMD. A murine model of IMMD was used, and MEPP frequency was assessed in the diaphragm muscle. Results showed a significant increase in MEPP frequency in IMMD mice compared to controls, even before the onset of clinical symptoms. This increase in MEPP frequency correlated with the progression of motor dysfunction and the loss of motoneurons. Furthermore, treatment with a disease-modifying therapy resulted in a significant reduction in MEPP frequency and amelioration of motor deficits. These findings suggest that monitoring MEPP frequency could provide valuable insights into the early pathophysiological changes associated with IMMD and serve as a potential biomarker for disease progression and therapeutic response.

Definitive mandibular replacement using reconstruction plates.  Mandibular defects following radical cancer surgery continue to provide challenges to head and neck surgeons. In this case series, we present our experience with definitive mandibular replacement using reconstruction plates in patients who underwent radical cancer surgery resulting in mandibular defects. A total of 15 patients were included, all of whom underwent definitive mandibular reconstruction using a reconstruction plate. The reconstruction plates were placed using a modified transoral approach. The primary outcome measure was the success of mandibular replacement, assessed based on postoperative radiographic evaluation and clinical examination. Secondary outcome measures included complications, functional outcomes, and patient satisfaction. Our results showed that all patients achieved successful mandibular replacement, with good postoperative radiographic and clinical outcomes. Complications were minimal and included plate exposure in two patients and infection in one patient, all of which were successfully managed. Functional outcomes were satisfactory, with patients reporting improved speech and masticatory function. Overall, definitive mandibular replacement using reconstruction plates proved to be a viable surgical option for patients with mandibular defects following radical cancer surgery.

Auras and subclinical seizures: characteristics and prognostic significance. Auras and subclinical seizures are often observed in patients with epilepsy, but their characteristics and prognostic significance are not well understood. In this study, we aimed to investigate the characteristics of auras and subclinical seizures and their impact on seizure prognosis. We analyzed data from 200 patients with epilepsy who underwent long-term video-electroencephalography monitoring. A total of 80 patients (40%) experienced auras, with the most common symptoms being visual disturbances (48%), followed by auditory (27%) and olfactory (18%) sensations. Subclinical seizures were observed in 60 patients (30%), with the majority presenting as focal motor seizures (43%) and focal impaired awareness seizures (38%). Patients with auras were more likely to have a longer duration of epilepsy and a higher frequency of seizures compared to those without auras. Furthermore, patients with subclinical seizures had a higher risk of seizures worsening over time. These findings suggest that auras and subclinical seizures may serve as markers of disease progression and may have implications for the management and prognosis of epilepsy patients.

Auditory-evoked responses in benign intracranial hypertension syndrome. Benign intracranial hypertension syndrome (BIHS) is a condition characterized by elevated intracranial pressure without evidence of any intracranial pathology. This study aimed to investigate the auditory-evoked responses in patients with BIHS. Auditory-evoked responses were recorded using electroencephalography in 20 patients diagnosed with BIHS and compared to 20 age- and gender-matched healthy controls. The results revealed a significant delay in the latency of wave V in patients with BIHS compared to controls. Furthermore, the amplitude of wave V was significantly reduced in BIHS patients. These findings suggest that BIHS may affect the central auditory pathways, leading to delayed and attenuated auditory-evoked responses. The exact mechanisms underlying these changes remain unclear and require further investigation. Nevertheless, this study provides valuable insights into the auditory functioning in BIHS, which may contribute to the understanding and management of this condition.

Results of treatment of displaced patellar fractures by partial patellectomy. Part III. A retrospective study. A retrospective study of 50 patients with displaced patellar fractures who underwent treatment with partial patellectomy was conducted. The study aimed to evaluate the outcomes and complications associated with this surgical technique. Demographic data such as age, gender, mechanism of injury, and pre-existing comorbidities were collected. In addition, surgical details including the size and direction of the fracture, type of fixation used, and postoperative management were considered. Follow-up assessments were performed to determine functional outcomes, including range of motion, strength, and pain scores. Complications such as infection, nonunion, malunion, and patellar instability were also recorded. The results demonstrated that partial patellectomy offered satisfactory outcomes, with most patients achieving good pain relief, improved knee function, and satisfactory range of motion. The overall complication rate was low, with infection being the most common complication. Patient satisfaction with the procedure was high, highlighting the effectiveness of partial patellectomy for the treatment of displaced patellar fractures.

Prolonged confusion following convulsions due to generalized nonconvulsive status epilepticus.  Among patients with a prolonged confusional state after convulsive seizure, we diagnosed 8 cases as generalized nonconvulsive status epilepticus. Prolonged confusion after convulsive seizures can be attributed to various underlying causes, with generalized nonconvulsive status epilepticus being one of them. In our study, we identified and diagnosed 8 cases of generalized nonconvulsive status epilepticus in patients presenting with prolonged confusion following convulsions. This condition is characterized by continuous or recurrent electrographic seizure activity without the typical motor manifestations seen in convulsive seizures. The diagnosis of generalized nonconvulsive status epilepticus can be challenging as it requires both clinical suspicion and confirmation through electroencephalogram (EEG) findings. Timely recognition and treatment of this condition are crucial to prevent long-lasting neurologic deficits and to improve patient outcomes. Further research is warranted to better understand the etiology and optimal management approach for patients with prolonged confusion after convulsive seizures.

Clinical and manometric aspects of diffuse esophageal spasm in a cohort of subjects evaluated for dysphagia and/or chest pain. Diffuse esophageal spasm (DES) is a motor disorder characterized by simultaneous or uncoordinated contractions of the esophageal musculature, leading to dysphagia and/or chest pain. This study aimed to evaluate the clinical and manometric aspects of DES in a cohort of subjects presenting with these symptoms. A total of 127 individuals with dysphagia and/or chest pain were included in the analysis. The mean age of the subjects was 59.4 years, with a male predominance (63%). Dysphagia was the most common presenting symptom (78%), followed by chest pain (48%). The manometric findings revealed simultaneous contractions in the esophagus in all cases. However, no significant association was found between the severity of symptoms and manometric findings. This study highlights the importance of considering DES in the differential diagnosis of dysphagia and/or chest pain, as timely diagnosis can guide appropriate management strategies for affected individuals.

Portal vein resection with a new antithrombogenic catheter. Portal vein resection is a challenging procedure in liver surgery, often associated with a high risk of thrombosis. This study presents a new technique utilizing an antithrombogenic catheter during portal vein resection to reduce the incidence of thrombotic complications. Out of 50 patients who underwent portal vein resection, 25 received the standard technique without the antithrombogenic catheter, while the other 25 received the new technique. Patients in the new technique group had a significantly lower incidence of portal vein thrombosis compared to the standard technique group (4% vs. 20%, p<0.05). Additionally, the new technique group had a shorter duration of surgery and reduced blood loss. There were no significant differences in postoperative complications or long-term survival between the two groups. These findings suggest that the use of an antithrombogenic catheter during portal vein resection can effectively decrease the incidence of thrombotic complications without compromising patient outcomes.

T cell subsets (Tc, Th, Ts, Tsi) and IL2 receptor-bearing cells in peripheral blood of patients in the acute phase of alcoholic hepatitis. Alcoholic hepatitis is a severe liver disease characterized by inflammation and damage caused by chronic alcohol consumption. The role of T cell subsets and IL2 receptor-bearing cells in the pathogenesis of alcoholic hepatitis remains poorly understood. In this study, we aimed to investigate the distribution of T cell subsets (Tc, Th, Ts, Tsi) and IL2 receptor-bearing cells in the peripheral blood of patients in the acute phase of alcoholic hepatitis. We enrolled 40 patients with acute alcoholic hepatitis and 40 healthy controls. Flow cytometry analysis was used to determine the percentages of T cell subsets and IL2 receptor-bearing cells. Our results showed that patients with alcoholic hepatitis had significantly higher percentages of Th cells and IL2 receptor-bearing cells compared to the control group. Additionally, the percentages of Tc, Ts, and Tsi cells were significantly decreased in patients with alcoholic hepatitis. These findings suggest an imbalance in T cell subsets and increased IL2 receptor expression in the acute phase of alcoholic hepatitis, which may contribute to the pathogenesis of this disease. Further studies are needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and potential therapeutic targets.

Biology of basal cell carcinoma (Part I). Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is the most common type of skin cancer worldwide, predominantly affecting fair-skinned individuals. This review aims to provide a comprehensive understanding of the biology underlying BCC development and progression. BCC arises from the basal cells of the epidermis and is primarily driven by aberrant Sonic Hedgehog (SHH) signaling pathway activation. Dysregulation of SHH pathway components, including the Patched1 (PTCH1) receptor and the Smoothened (SMO) protein, leads to uncontrolled proliferation and survival of basal cells. Additionally, BCC is associated with alterations in other signaling pathways, such as Wnt/-catenin, Ras/mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK), and Notch. Understanding the intricate molecular mechanisms underlying BCC pathogenesis will aid in the identification of potential therapeutic targets for this common malignancy.

Ultrasonography and magnetic resonance imaging in Leigh disease. Leigh disease is a rare mitochondrial disorder characterized by progressive neurological deterioration. This study aimed to evaluate the use of ultrasonography (US) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) in the diagnosis of Leigh disease. A total of 32 patients with clinically suspected Leigh disease were included in the study. US findings showed the presence of bilateral symmetric basal ganglia lesions in 29 patients (90.6%). MRI findings revealed bilateral symmetric lesions in the basal ganglia, thalamus, and brainstem in all 32 patients. Additionally, MRI identified additional findings such as cortical lesions and cerebellar involvement in some patients. US and MRI showed high sensitivity and specificity in the diagnosis of Leigh disease, providing valuable information for early detection and management of this devastating disease.

Subtrochanteric fractures treated with interlocking nailing.  In a prospective study of 31 subtrochanteric fractures treated with Grosse-Kempf interlocking nails with a followup period of at least 1 year, there was a 87. 1% (27/31) union rate, and a union period of 4. In this prospective study, we evaluated the efficacy of Grosse-Kempf interlocking nails in the treatment of subtrochanteric fractures. A total of 31 patients with subtrochanteric fractures were included and followed up for at least 1 year. Our results demonstrate a high union rate of 87.1% (27/31) after the treatment with interlocking nails. The average union period was 4.3 months. The use of interlocking nails allows for stable fixation and facilitates early weight bearing, leading to successful fracture healing. We also observed a low rate of complication, with only 1 case of implant failure and 2 cases of postoperative infection. These findings suggest that interlocking nailing is an effective treatment option for subtrochanteric fractures, providing satisfactory union rates and favorable clinical outcomes.

Isolated calf venous thrombosis: diagnosis with compression US. Isolated calf venous thrombosis (ICVT) is a common condition that poses a diagnostic challenge due to its nonspecific symptoms. Compression ultrasound (US) has emerged as a reliable tool for the diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). This study aims to evaluate the diagnostic accuracy of compression US in the diagnosis of ICVT. A retrospective analysis of patients with suspected ICVT who underwent compression US was conducted. The sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value (PPV), negative predictive value (NPV), and accuracy of compression US were calculated. Out of 72 patients included in the study, compression US identified ICVT in 56 patients, yielding a sensitivity of 78%. The specificity, PPV, NPV, and accuracy of compression US in the diagnosis of ICVT were 91%, 89%, 81%, and 88%, respectively. Compression US is a valuable diagnostic tool with good accuracy in detecting ICVT, facilitating timely intervention and preventing complications.

Life-threatening complications during anaesthesia in a patient with a ventriculo-atrial shunt and pulmonary hypertension [published erratum appears in Anaesthesia 1991 Mar;46(3):241] A 6-year-old patient with hydrocephalus who underwent revision of a ventriculo-atrial shunt is described. The patient developed life-threatening complications during anaesthesia, including a sudden rise in pulmonary artery pressure and severe hypoxemia. This was likely due to the presence of a ventriculo-atrial shunt and pre-existing pulmonary hypertension. Immediate intervention was required to stabilize the patient's condition, including optimization of ventilation and hemodynamics. This case highlights the importance of careful monitoring and management of patients with ventriculo-atrial shunts and pulmonary hypertension during anaesthesia to prevent potentially life-threatening complications. Further research is needed to better understand the risk factors and appropriate management strategies for this patient population.

Resting metabolic rate and energy balance in amenorrheic and eumenorrheic runners. Amenorrhea, the absence of menstrual periods, is a common condition among female athletes, particularly in runners. This study aimed to investigate the relationship between resting metabolic rate (RMR) and energy balance in amenorrheic and eumenorrheic runners. RMR was measured using indirect calorimetry in 20 amenorrheic and 20 eumenorrheic runners. Energy balance was assessed by determining energy intake and expenditure through food records and activity diaries. The results showed that amenorrheic runners had significantly lower RMR compared to eumenorrheic runners, even when adjusted for fat-free mass. Additionally, energy intake was significantly lower in amenorrheic runners, while energy expenditure through exercise was similar between the two groups. Consequently, amenorrheic runners had a significantly more negative energy balance compared to their eumenorrheic counterparts. These findings suggest that the lower RMR and reduced energy intake in amenorrheic runners may contribute to the development and maintenance of their menstrual dysfunction. Further research is needed to understand the underlying mechanisms and develop appropriate interventions to support the metabolic health of amenorrheic athletes.

Periurethral colonic-type polyp simulating urethral caruncle. A 56 year old female presented with recurrent episodes of urinary retention and dysuria. On examination, a fleshy, polypoid mass was observed protruding from the urethral orifice. Initial clinical impression of a urethral caruncle was made. However, histopathological examination revealed a periurethral colonic-type polyp with intestinal metaplasia. This is an extremely rare occurrence, with only a few similar cases reported in the literature. The patient underwent surgical excision of the polyp and subsequent cystoscopy confirmed its complete removal. The differential diagnosis between urethral caruncle and colonic-type polyp can be challenging, highlighting the importance of histopathological confirmation for appropriate management and prevention of recurrence. Further studies are warranted to better understand the etiology and management of such unique cases.

Achieving pH control in the critically ill patient: the role of continuous infusion of H2-receptor antagonists. Maintaining appropriate pH levels is crucial in critically ill patients. This study examines the effectiveness of continuous infusion of H2-receptor antagonists in achieving pH control. A total of 100 critically ill patients were included in the study, with 50 receiving continuous infusion of H2-receptor antagonists and 50 receiving standard care. The patients' pH levels were closely monitored and compared between the two groups. Results showed that continuous infusion of H2-receptor antagonists significantly improved pH control compared to standard care. These findings suggest that continuous infusion of H2-receptor antagonists may be a beneficial strategy in achieving optimal pH levels in critically ill patients. Further research is needed to fully elucidate the optimal dosing and duration of therapy for this intervention.

Fatal pulmonary venoocclusive disease secondary to a generalized venulopathy: a new syndrome presenting with facial swelling and pericardial tamponade. Pulmonary venoocclusive disease (PVOD) is a rare and often fatal condition characterized by occlusion of small pulmonary veins, leading to increased pulmonary vascular resistance and ultimately right heart failure. We present a case of a 52-year-old male who presented with progressive dyspnea, facial swelling, and pericardial tamponade. Diagnostic workup revealed PVOD with diffuse venulopathy involving various organ systems, including the lungs, liver, and spleen. Despite aggressive therapy, the patient's condition rapidly deteriorated, and he succumbed to the disease. This case highlights the importance of considering PVOD in the differential diagnosis of patients with unexplained dyspnea and facilitates early recognition and management of this devastating condition. Further research is needed to better understand the underlying pathogenesis and explore potential treatment options for this newly described syndrome.

Complications in hyperthermia treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia.  Of 435 patients treated with local hyperthermia to the prostate 27 had 29 complications, for an over-all complication rate of 6. This study aimed to evaluate the complications associated with hyperthermia treatment for benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). A total of 435 patients who underwent local hyperthermia to the prostate were included in the analysis. Among them, 27 patients experienced a total of 29 complications, resulting in an overall complication rate of 6%. The most common complications observed were urinary tract infections (n=12) and urinary retention (n=8). Other complications included urethral stricture (n=3) and rectourethral fistula (n=1). The study highlights the importance of monitoring and managing potential complications in patients undergoing hyperthermia treatment for BPH. Further research is needed to optimize the treatment protocol and minimize the risk of adverse events.

Leukemias of indeterminant lineage. Leukemia of indeterminate lineage is a rare form of leukemia characterized by the inability to definitively classify the leukemia cells as either myeloid or lymphoid lineage. In this case report, we describe two patients, a 42-year-old male and a 55-year-old female, with leukemias of indeterminate lineage. Both patients presented with fatigue, fever, and anemia. Peripheral blood and bone marrow examinations revealed the presence of blast cells that displayed both myeloid and lymphoid characteristics, with no definitive lineage markers. Flow cytometry analysis and cytogenetic studies were inconclusive in determining the lineage of the leukemic cells. The clinical course of both patients was aggressive, with rapidly progressive disease and limited treatment options. Leukemias of indeterminate lineage pose significant diagnostic and therapeutic challenges due to their atypical presentation and lack of clear classification. Further research is needed to better understand the underlying biology and develop targeted therapies for this rare form of leukemia.

Thyrotoxicosis induced by topical iodine application. Thyrotoxicosis induced by topical iodine application is a rare and poorly understood phenomenon. We present a case of a 47-year-old woman who developed symptoms consistent with thyrotoxicosis following the application of iodine solution to a surgical wound. Thyroid function tests revealed suppressed thyrotropin (TSH) levels and elevated free thyroxine (FT4) and free triiodothyronine (FT3) levels. Ultrasound imaging of the thyroid gland showed increased vascularity and decreased echogenicity, consistent with thyroiditis. Thyroid autoantibodies were negative. The patient was diagnosed with iodine-induced thyrotoxicosis and successfully treated with discontinuation of iodine application and beta-blocker therapy. This case highlights the need for caution when using iodine-containing solutions topically, as they can lead to thyroid dysfunction and subsequent thyrotoxicosis.

Eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome associated with L-tryptophan ingestion. Eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome (EMS) is a rare but potentially life-threatening condition that has been associated with the ingestion of L-tryptophan, an essential amino acid commonly found in dietary supplements. This abstract presents a case report of a 42-year-old female who developed EMS after taking L-tryptophan supplements for sleep disturbances. The patient presented with myalgia, eosinophilia, and skin nodules, fulfilling the diagnostic criteria for EMS. She required hospitalization and extensive medical intervention to manage her symptoms. The association between L-tryptophan intake and EMS has been well documented, with outbreaks occurring in the late 1980s. While the exact mechanism of L-tryptophan-induced EMS remains unclear, it is believed to involve immunologic and toxicologic factors. Prompt recognition of EMS is crucial for early intervention and appropriate management. Healthcare professionals should be aware of this potential adverse reaction and advise patients on the risks associated with L-tryptophan supplementation.

Growth velocity before sudden infant death. Sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS) is a tragic and unexplained cause of death in infants under one year of age. Numerous possible risk factors have been identified, including certain growth patterns. In this study, we aimed to investigate the relationship between growth velocity and the occurrence of SIDS. We conducted a retrospective analysis of medical records from infants who had experienced SIDS and compared their growth velocity patterns to a control group of healthy infants. Our results indicate that infants who experienced SIDS had a significantly slower growth velocity during the first six months of life compared to the control group. This finding suggests that growth velocity may serve as a potential predictive marker for SIDS and highlights the importance of monitoring growth patterns in infants to identify those at higher risk. Further research is needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and develop interventions to prevent SIDS in these vulnerable individuals.

Palliation of malignant esophageal obstruction. Malignant esophageal obstruction is a common complication in advanced cancer patients, leading to poor quality of life and debilitating symptoms. Palliative treatment options include stent placement, dilatation, and laser therapy. This retrospective study aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of palliative interventions in patients with malignant esophageal obstruction. A total of 56 patients were included, and the interventions performed were stent placement (n=34), dilatation (n=18), and laser therapy (n=4). Successful relief of dysphagia was achieved in 82% of patients, with a median dysphagia score reduction of 3 points. The mean survival time after intervention was 4.9 months. Complications were observed in 14% of patients, with stent migration being the most common. In conclusion, palliative interventions for malignant esophageal obstruction provide effective relief of dysphagia and can be considered as a viable treatment option in these patients. Further studies are warranted to optimize the selection of intervention and assess long-term outcomes.

How long can a coronary reperfusion catheter be placed in acute coronary occlusion following failed transluminal coronary angioplasty? A case report. This case report describes the successful placement and extended duration of a coronary reperfusion catheter in a patient with acute coronary occlusion following failed transluminal coronary angioplasty (TCA). A 61-year-old male presented with angina and was diagnosed with a high-grade stenosis of the left anterior descending artery (LAD). TCA was attempted but was unsuccessful in achieving revascularization. Subsequently, a 6-French reperfusion catheter was advanced into the LAD, and successful revascularization was achieved. Despite initial improvement, the patient developed recurrent chest pain and electrocardiographic changes indicative of reocclusion of the LAD. Reperfusion catheter re-entry was attempted and successful, leading to sustained revascularization. The catheter was left in place for a prolonged period, with close monitoring of the patient's clinical condition. This case highlights the potential benefit of prolonged reperfusion catheter placement in the setting of acute coronary occlusion following failed TCA. Further studies are warranted to determine the optimal duration of catheter placement in such cases.

Molecular and hematologic characterization of Scottish-Irish type (epsilon gamma delta beta)zero thalassemia. Thalassemia is a genetic disorder characterized by abnormal hemoglobin production, leading to chronic anemia. Scottish-Irish type (epsilon gamma delta beta)zero thalassemia is a rare variant that has not been extensively studied. In this case study, we present the molecular and hematologic characterization of two patients with this type of thalassemia. Genetic analysis revealed a homozygous deletion of the epsilon gamma delta beta () gene cluster. Hematologic evaluation showed severe anemia and microcytosis in both patients. Additionally, Hb Bart's levels were elevated, suggesting impaired gamma chain synthesis. These findings contribute to the understanding of the pathophysiology of Scottish-Irish type ()zero thalassemia and provide important insights for future diagnostic and therapeutic strategies. Further research is needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and develop targeted treatments for this rare thalassemia variant.

Diagnostic significance of carcinoembryonic antigen in the differential diagnosis of malignant mesothelioma. Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) has been used as a tumor marker in various malignancies. However, its diagnostic significance in the differential diagnosis of malignant mesothelioma remains unclear. This study aimed to evaluate the utility of CEA in discriminating malignant mesothelioma from other malignancies involving the serosal membranes. We analyzed CEA levels in pleural effusion samples from 74 patients with malignant mesothelioma and 57 patients with other malignancies. The mean CEA level in the malignant mesothelioma group was significantly higher compared to the non-mesothelioma group (p < 0.001). Using a cutoff value of 10 ng/mL, CEA exhibited a sensitivity of 62.2% and specificity of 91.2% in distinguishing malignant mesothelioma from other malignancies. Furthermore, a CEA level >10 ng/mL was associated with significantly poorer overall survival in malignant mesothelioma patients (p = 0.015). Our findings suggest that CEA can serve as a useful adjunctive tool in the differential diagnosis of malignant mesothelioma, particularly when combined with other diagnostic modalities.

The anatomy and physiology of nerve injury. Nerve injury is a commonly encountered clinical problem with significant implications for patient morbidity and quality of life. Understanding the anatomy and physiology of nerve injury is crucial for accurate diagnosis and effective management. This review aims to provide an overview of the important aspects of nerve anatomy and physiology in relation to injury.

The anatomical structure of a nerve includes the axon, myelin sheath, and connective tissue layers. Nerves can be classified as peripheral or central, based on their location in the body. Peripheral nerves consist of motor, sensory, and autonomic fibers, while central nerves are predominantly composed of myelinated axons. 

Injury to a nerve can occur due to various causes, including trauma, compression, infection, or autoimmune disorders. The extent and severity of nerve injury can vary and may result in functional deficits ranging from mild sensory disturbances to complete loss of motor function. The process of nerve regeneration involves a complex interplay of cellular and molecular events, including Wallerian degeneration, axonal sprouting, and reinnervation.

Understanding the anatomy and physiology of nerve injury is essential for accurate diagnosis, effective management, and implementation of appropriate rehabilitation strategies. Further research is necessary to elucidate the mechanisms underlying nerve regeneration and develop novel therapeutic interventions for patients with nerve injuries.

Combined laminoplasty and posterolateral fusion for spinal canal surgery in children and adolescents. Spinal canal stenosis in children and adolescents is a rare but potentially debilitating condition that requires surgical intervention to prevent neurological deficits. Traditional surgical techniques for spinal canal decompression involve laminectomy, which can lead to instability and subsequent need for fusion. This study aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of a combined laminoplasty and posterolateral fusion technique in pediatric patients with spinal canal stenosis. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 32 patients who underwent this procedure between 2010 and 2018. The mean age at surgery was 12.6 years, and the most common etiology was congenital spinal stenosis. Postoperative neurological deficits were observed in 3 patients, while complications such as wound infection and pseudarthrosis were seen in 6 patients. The majority of patients (87.5%) demonstrated improved clinical outcomes, with no cases of worsening neurological deficits. This combined surgical technique provides a safe and effective option for spinal canal decompression in children and adolescents with spinal stenosis.

Bleeding ectatic vascular lesion involving the sigmoid colon, endoscopically indistinguishable from angiodysplasia, in an 8-yr-old boy. We present a case of an 8-year-old boy with a bleeding ectatic vascular lesion involving the sigmoid colon. The lesion appeared endoscopically indistinguishable from angiodysplasia. The patient initially presented with recurrent episodes of bright red blood per rectum and was subsequently diagnosed with this uncommon vascular anomaly. The lesion was successfully treated using endoscopic therapy, specifically argon plasma coagulation. The patient's symptoms resolved, and there were no further episodes of bleeding during the follow-up period of 12 months. This case highlights the importance of considering vascular anomalies as a potential cause of gastrointestinal bleeding in pediatric patients. It also emphasizes the efficacy of endoscopic therapy in the management of such lesions, providing a minimally invasive alternative to surgical intervention. Further studies are warranted to better understand the etiology, natural history, and optimal management strategies for bleeding ectatic vascular lesions involving the sigmoid colon in children.

Pelvic lipomatosis associated with cystitis glandularis and adenocarcinoma of the bladder. Pelvic lipomatosis is a rare condition characterized by excessive deposition of adipose tissue in the pelvic region. We report a case of pelvic lipomatosis in a 62-year-old male who presented with lower urinary tract symptoms including frequency, urgency, and dysuria. Imaging studies revealed a significant increase in pelvic fat volume, causing compression of adjacent structures. Endoscopic evaluation revealed cystitis glandularis, a known association with pelvic lipomatosis, and tissue biopsy confirmed the presence of adenocarcinoma of the bladder. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first reported case of pelvic lipomatosis associated with both cystitis glandularis and adenocarcinoma of the bladder. The patient underwent radical cystectomy with ileal conduit diversion. Postoperatively, he had resolution of urinary symptoms and is currently undergoing adjuvant chemotherapy. Further studies are needed to explore the relationship between pelvic lipomatosis, cystitis glandularis, and bladder adenocarcinoma.

Relationship of ischemic heart disease to sudden death. Ischemic heart disease (IHD) is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. Sudden death is a devastating consequence of IHD, and understanding the relationship between the two is crucial for effective prevention and management strategies. This study aimed to investigate the association between IHD and sudden death.

A systematic review of relevant literature was conducted, and data from multiple studies were analyzed. The results revealed a strong correlation between IHD and sudden death, with IHD accounting for a significant proportion of sudden deaths. Additionally, several risk factors for sudden death in patients with IHD were identified, including previous myocardial infarction, ventricular arrhythmias, and left ventricular dysfunction.

These findings highlight the importance of early detection and aggressive management of IHD to prevent sudden death. Further research is needed to identify additional risk factors and develop targeted interventions to reduce the incidence of sudden death in individuals with IHD.

Possible mechanisms of abnormal norepinephrine sensitivity and reactivity of resistance vessels and the development of hypertension in spontaneously hypertensive rats. We investigated the possible mechanisms underlying abnormal norepinephrine sensitivity and reactivity of resistance vessels in the development of hypertension in spontaneously hypertensive rats (SHR). Using in vitro studies, we found that the sensitivity of resistance vessels to norepinephrine was significantly higher in SHR compared to normotensive control rats. Furthermore, we observed an enhanced vasoconstrictor response to norepinephrine in SHR. These findings suggest that abnormal norepinephrine sensitivity and reactivity of resistance vessels may contribute to the development of hypertension in SHR. Further studies are needed to elucidate the specific mechanisms underlying this abnormality and to explore potential therapeutic targets for hypertension treatment.

Psychological stress and the fibrositis/fibromyalgia syndrome. Fibrositis and fibromyalgia syndrome are chronic pain conditions characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain, fatigue, and psychological distress. This study investigated the relationship between psychological stress and the severity of symptoms in fibrositis/fibromyalgia patients. A total of 75 patients diagnosed with fibrositis/fibromyalgia were divided into two groups based on their perceived stress levels. The participants completed self-report measures of stress, pain severity, and psychological distress. The results indicated a significant positive correlation between perceived stress and pain severity (r = 0.45, p < 0.001), as well as psychological distress (r = 0.32, p = 0.004). Furthermore, multiple regression analysis revealed that perceived stress significantly predicted pain severity ( = 0.43, p = 0.001) and psychological distress ( = 0.28, p = 0.009). These findings suggest that psychological stress plays a crucial role in the symptomatology of fibrositis/fibromyalgia patients, highlighting the importance of addressing stress management techniques in their treatment.

Recurrent lateral rectus palsy in childhood. Recurrent lateral rectus palsy is a rare condition characterized by repeated episodes of paralysis of the lateral rectus muscle, resulting in limited or absent outward eye movement. This condition usually presents in childhood and can have a significant impact on visual function and quality of life. The etiology of recurrent lateral rectus palsy is not well understood, but it is thought to be related to dysfunction of the cranial nerves or their associated nuclei. Diagnosis is based on clinical features and neuroimaging findings. Treatment options include patching, corrective lenses, vision therapy, and surgical intervention in severe cases. Further research is needed to better understand the underlying causes and optimal management of this condition.

Deep femoral to anterior tibial bypass after failed femoropopliteal reconstructions. Deep femoral to anterior tibial bypass is a surgical procedure performed when previous femoropopliteal reconstructions have failed. This study aims to evaluate the outcomes of this bypass procedure and identify potential risk factors associated with graft failure in these cases. A retrospective analysis was conducted on a cohort of patients who underwent deep femoral to anterior tibial bypass after failed femoropopliteal reconstructions. The primary endpoint was graft patency rate, while secondary endpoints included limb salvage rate and overall survival. The results showed a satisfactory graft patency rate of 80% at one year, with limb salvage and overall survival rates of 90% and 85%, respectively. Risk factors for graft failure included age, diabetes, and smoking. In conclusion, deep femoral to anterior tibial bypass provides a viable option for patients with failed femoropopliteal reconstructions, with acceptable outcomes and low morbidity. Further studies are warranted to validate these findings.

Hazards of internal fixation in the treatment of slipped capital femoral epiphysis. Slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) is a condition commonly seen in adolescents and poses a challenge for orthopedic surgeons. Internal fixation with screws is a widely accepted treatment option for stabilizing the femoral head. However, this technique carries certain hazards that must be considered. In this study, we retrospectively analyzed 52 patients with SCFE who underwent internal fixation with screws. Complications such as avascular necrosis, screw migration, and infection were observed in 14 patients (27%). Among these, avascular necrosis was the most common complication, occurring in 10 patients (19%). Additionally, four patients (8%) required revision surgery due to screw migration. These findings highlight the potential risks associated with internal fixation in the treatment of SCFE, emphasizing the need for careful patient selection, meticulous surgical technique, and postoperative monitoring. Surgeons should be aware of these hazards and consider alternative treatment options in patients at higher risk.

Leukocyte alkaline phosphatase score in patients with cerebrovascular disease and in patients with primary and metastatic brain tumors. The leukocyte alkaline phosphatase (LAP) score is a valuable diagnostic tool in differentiating between various diseases. In this study, we assessed the LAP score in patients with cerebrovascular disease (CVD) and those with primary and metastatic brain tumors. A total of 87 patients were included, with 30 diagnosed with CVD and 57 with brain tumors. The LAP score was significantly lower in patients with CVD compared to those with brain tumors (p<0.001). Among the brain tumor patients, the LAP score was further analyzed based on primary or metastatic tumors. The LAP score was significantly higher in patients with primary tumors compared to those with metastatic tumors (p<0.05). These findings suggest that the LAP score can aid in distinguishing between CVD and brain tumors, as well as between primary and metastatic brain tumors, thus aiding in appropriate diagnosis and treatment decisions.

Monocortical miniplate fixation of mandibular angle fractures.  Noncompression monocortical miniplate fixation of mandibular fractures has become a reliable method of providing rigid fixation and eliminating the need for intermaxillary fixation. This retrospective study aimed to evaluate the outcomes of monocortical miniplate fixation in the management of mandibular angle fractures. A total of 50 patients with mandibular angle fractures were included and treated with monocortical miniplate fixation. Follow-up examinations were conducted at regular intervals for a mean duration of 9 months to assess functional and radiographic outcomes. The results showed excellent stability and occlusal function postoperatively. Furthermore, early restoration of mandibular mobility and decreased pain was observed. Additionally, there were no cases of plate or screw failure, infection, or malocclusion. Monocortical miniplate fixation of mandibular angle fractures is a reliable technique that offers stable fixation, improved patient comfort, and decreased morbidity compared to traditional techniques involving intermaxillary fixation.

Helicobacter pylori infection: a simplified diagnostic approach.  We evaluated the diagnostic accuracy of endoscopic finding of nodular antritis and rapid urease test (RUT) in order to simplify the approach to the diagnosis of Helicobacter pylori (H.  pylori) infection. A total of 185 patients presenting with dyspeptic symptoms were included in this study. Endoscopic findings of nodular antritis were correlated with the results of the RUT for H. pylori. The sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value (PPV), negative predictive value (NPV), and accuracy of nodular antritis for the diagnosis of H. pylori infection were calculated. The prevalence of H. pylori infection in the study population was 60.5%. The presence of nodular antritis was found to have a sensitivity of 70.2%, specificity of 89.6%, PPV of 88.1%, NPV of 73.1%, and accuracy of 77.3% for the diagnosis of H. pylori infection. The combination of nodular antritis and a positive RUT result increased the accuracy to 89.2%. This simplified diagnostic approach utilizing endoscopic findings of nodular antritis and RUT shows promise for accurately diagnosing H. pylori infection.

Transient neuromuscular impairment resulting from prolonged inhalation of halothane and enflurane. This study aimed to evaluate the transient neuromuscular impairment caused by prolonged inhalation of halothane and enflurane in a patient population. Muscle strength and coordination tests were performed on 40 patients before and after undergoing surgery under general anesthesia with either halothane or enflurane. The results showed a significant decrease in muscle strength and coordination after anesthesia administration with both halothane and enflurane. The impairment was more pronounced in the enflurane group compared to the halothane group. These findings suggest that prolonged inhalation of halothane and enflurane can lead to transient neuromuscular dysfunction.
