The window operation is a safe and effective treatment option for Bartholin gland cysts and abscesses, offering better outcomes and patient satisfaction compared to traditional methods.

Hemibody irradiation in advanced prostatic carcinoma. The efficacy and safety of hemibody irradiation (HBI) were evaluated in patients with advanced prostatic carcinoma. Forty-two patients with metastatic prostate cancer were treated with HBI, delivering a radiation dose of 20 Gy to one-half of the body. The primary endpoints were pain relief, tumor response, and overall survival. Pain relief was achieved in 76% of patients, with a mean duration of 4.6 months. Tumor response was observed in 31% of patients, including partial response in 19% and stable disease in 12%. The median overall survival was 10.2 months. The most common side effects were mild fatigue and transient hematological toxicity. No significant long-term toxicities were encountered. HBI provided effective pain relief and demonstrated antitumor activity in patients with advanced prostatic carcinoma. Further studies are warranted to optimize the dose and fractionation schedule of HBI and investigate its potential in combination with other treatment modalities for prostate cancer.

The early diagnosis and treatment of developmental patella infera syndrome.  Developmental patella infera and associated arthrofibrosis after knee surgery require prompt recognition and treatment. Developmental patella infera syndrome (DPIS) is a rare condition characterized by abnormal patella development and subsequent patellar height reduction. It can lead to significant functional impairment and arthritis if left untreated. This study aims to highlight the importance of early diagnosis and treatment of DPIS.

We conducted a retrospective analysis of 30 patients diagnosed with DPIS and associated arthrofibrosis following knee surgery. Patients presenting with anterior knee pain, limited range of motion, and functional limitations were evaluated clinically and radiographically. The diagnosis was confirmed using imaging modalities such as X-rays and magnetic resonance imaging.

Early recognition of DPIS allowed for prompt intervention and better outcomes. Treatment strategies included patellar realignment procedures, arthroscopic debridement, and physical therapy. Patients who received timely treatment showed significant improvement in pain, range of motion, and overall function.

The findings of this study highlight the importance of early diagnosis and appropriate management of DPIS. Prompt recognition and intervention can prevent long-term complications such as chronic pain and functional limitations. Further research is warranted to optimize treatment strategies and improve outcomes for patients with DPIS and associated arthrofibrosis.

Neuropsychological profile linked to low dopamine: in Alzheimer's disease, major depression, and Parkinson's disease. This study aimed to investigate the neuropsychological profile associated with low dopamine levels in three neurodegenerative diseases: Alzheimer's disease, major depression, and Parkinson's disease. A total of 150 participants were included in the study, with 50 individuals diagnosed with each of the three disorders. Dopamine levels were measured using positron emission tomography (PET) scans. Neuropsychological assessments were conducted to evaluate cognitive functions, including memory, attention, and executive functioning.

Results showed a significant correlation between low dopamine levels and cognitive impairments in all three diseases. Individuals with low dopamine had worse performance in memory tasks, attentional control, and executive functions compared to those with normal dopamine levels. The findings suggest that dopamine plays a crucial role in cognitive functioning and that targeting dopamine pathways may be a potential therapeutic approach for cognitive symptoms in these neurodegenerative diseases. Further research is warranted to explore the underlying mechanisms and develop targeted interventions.

Impact of day care on dementia patients--costs, well-being and relatives' views. Day care programs for individuals with dementia have been shown to provide many benefits, including reducing caregiver burden and improving the well-being of patients. However, the impact of day care on costs and the perspectives of relatives remains relatively unexplored. This study aimed to address these gaps in the literature. A mixed methods approach was utilized, including quantitative analysis of cost data and qualitative interviews with relatives of dementia patients attending day care. Preliminary findings suggest that day care programs can lead to significant cost savings, as they reduce the need for full-time residential care. Moreover, relatives reported positive perceptions of the impact of day care on their loved ones' well-being, emphasizing increased social interaction and engagement. These findings highlight the importance of day care programs in the overall management of dementia and underscore the need for further research in this area.

Adult phosphorylase b kinase deficiency.  Phosphorylase b kinase deficiency affecting muscle has been observed infrequently in children with weakness and hepatomegaly, and in 2 adults with cramps on exertion. Phosphorylase b kinase deficiency is a rare genetic disorder that affects the muscle and liver metabolism. Most commonly observed in children, it is characterized by muscle weakness and hepatomegaly. Here, we present two cases of adult patients with symptoms of cramps on exertion that were later diagnosed with adult phosphorylase b kinase deficiency. Significant muscle weakness was not a prominent feature in these cases. Both patients underwent extensive diagnostic workup, including genetic testing, which confirmed the deficiency of phosphorylase b kinase activity. Interestingly, hepatomegaly was also noted in these patients, although it was not a predominant symptom. This report highlights the importance of considering phosphorylase b kinase deficiency as a possible diagnosis in adult patients presenting with unexplained cramps on exertion, even in the absence of significant muscle weakness. A thorough diagnostic evaluation, including genetic testing, is crucial for the accurate diagnosis and appropriate management of this disorder.

Femoropopliteal angioplasty.  Factors influencing long-term success.  Prospective data was recorded on 217 percutaneous transluminal angioplasty (PTA) procedures performed in the superficial femoral and popliteal arteries over an 8-year period. The success of femoropopliteal angioplasty (PTA) and the factors influencing long-term outcomes were investigated in a study of 217 procedures performed on the superficial femoral and popliteal arteries. Prospective data was collected over an 8-year period. The primary patency rates at 1, 3, and 5 years were 57%, 35%, and 24%, respectively. The secondary patency rates at the same time intervals were 64%, 53%, and 45%, respectively. Factors associated with a higher risk of restenosis included shorter lesion length, moderate-severe calcification, and the presence of diabetes. The use of stents had a positive impact on long-term patency rates. In-stent restenosis occurred in 22% of cases. Reintervention rates were 25% at 1 year, 39% at 3 years, and 52% at 5 years. The findings highlight the need for careful patient selection and the consideration of adjunctive therapies to improve the long-term success of femoropopliteal angioplasty.

Isolated ventral pancreatitis in a patient with pancreas divisum. Pancreas divisum is a congenital anatomical variant of the pancreas that occurs when the dorsal and ventral pancreatic ducts fail to fuse during development. This condition is usually asymptomatic, but can be associated with recurrent pancreatitis in some cases. Isolated ventral pancreatitis, where only the ventral duct is affected, is a rare presentation of pancreas divisum. We present a case of a patient with isolated ventral pancreatitis, who presented with abdominal pain and elevated serum amylase levels. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography confirmed the diagnosis of pancreas divisum with stenosis of the ventral duct. This case highlights the need for further awareness and understanding of the clinical implications of pancreas divisum, particularly its association with isolated ventral pancreatitis.

The UCLA-University of Utah epidemiologic survey of autism: the etiologic role of rare diseases. The UCLA-University of Utah epidemiologic survey of autism aimed to determine the etiologic role of rare diseases in autism. A comprehensive analysis of medical records of 153 autistic children and their families was conducted. Findings revealed that 4.6% of the children had a rare disease, which was significantly higher compared to the general population. These rare diseases included genetic syndromes, metabolic disorders, and structural brain abnormalities. Among the children with rare diseases, 80.6% had an identified genetic cause. Additionally, 52.9% of cases with rare diseases were associated with more severe autistic symptoms. This study highlights the importance of considering rare diseases in the etiology of autism and provides insights for future research and clinical management.

Mechanism of intermittent preexcitation in the Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome. Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome is a cardiac condition characterized by the presence of an additional electrical pathway called an accessory pathway, which causes intermittent preexcitation of the ventricles. This study aimed to investigate the mechanism underlying intermittent preexcitation in WPW syndrome. 

Electrocardiograms (ECGs) of 75 patients with WPW syndrome were analyzed. The presence of intermittent preexcitation was confirmed in 48 patients. During sinus rhythm, intermittent preexcitation was observed as episodes of a short PR interval, slurred upstroke of the QRS complex (delta wave), and widened QRS complex. The accessory pathway demonstrated intermittent conduction, resulting in a variable degree of preexcitation. 

Further electrophysiological studies were performed in a subset of patients to evaluate the electrophysiological properties of the accessory pathway during intermittent preexcitation. These studies revealed varying rates of anterograde conduction through the accessory pathway during episodes of intermittent preexcitation. In some cases, anterograde conduction was completely blocked during intermittent preexcitation, resulting in complete normalization of the QRS complex. 

In conclusion, the mechanism of intermittent preexcitation in WPW syndrome involves varying rates of anterograde conduction through the accessory pathway. The findings suggest that intermittent preexcitation is related to the dynamic behavior of the accessory pathway, emphasizing the importance of careful evaluation and management of patients with WPW syndrome.

Multimodality cisplatin treatment in nonresectable alpha-fetoprotein-positive hepatoma.  Twenty-eight patients with alpha-fetoprotein-positive (AFP+) nonresectable hepatoma have been enrolled in a new multimodality Phase I, II program. The treatment consisted of cisplatin given in combination with other modalities, including surgery, radiation therapy, and chemotherapy. The primary objective of the study was to evaluate the safety and efficacy of this multimodality approach in patients with AFP+ nonresectable hepatoma. 

Of the 28 patients enrolled, the majority had advanced stage disease and were not fit for surgical resection. Cisplatin was administered as a chemotherapy agent, with a starting dose of 75 mg/m2. The dose was escalated in subsequent cycles based on individual patient tolerance and response. Other treatment modalities, such as radiation therapy and surgery, were tailored to the specific needs of each patient.

Preliminary results showed promising response rates, with a significant reduction in tumor size and stabilization of disease in a substantial number of patients. Adverse events were manageable, with the most common being hematological toxicity and renal impairment. Overall, the multimodality cisplatin treatment showed potential as a therapeutic option for AFP+ nonresectable hepatoma, warranting further investigation in larger clinical trials.

Prevention and changing demographics. Prevention is a key aspect in addressing the changing demographics of disease burden, especially in the context of an aging population. This study aims to assess the effectiveness of implementing a prophylactic regimen for uric acid stones using alternate day doses of alkaline potassium salts. Uric acid stone formation is typically prevented by an increase in urinary pH postprandially, a process that is compromised in patients with such calculi.

The proposed regimen involves the administration of a single dose of alkaline potassium salt every other day, thereby simulating the physiological mechanism seen in individuals with normal postprandial alkaline tide. Patient self-monitoring is an integral part of this regimen, ensuring that urinary pH levels increase to above 6.8 within 1 1/2 to 2 hours after medication intake.

In a cohort of 17 patients, including 7 with recurrent gravel/colic syndrome and 10 with prior stones, this prophylactic approach effectively eliminated calculus formation over an average follow-up period of 2 1/2 years. Notably, this alternate day regimen demonstrated better tolerance and compliance compared to multiple daily doses.

While these preliminary findings are promising, further studies are warranted to establish the efficacy and safety of this regimen before it can be recommended as the standard therapy for uric acid stone prophylaxis. Addressing preventive measures in the face of changing demographics is essential in mitigating disease burden and improving patient outcomes.

Sclerotherapy for esophageal varices.  Endoscopic injection sclerotherapy (EIS) frequently is used for patients with esophageal varices, both for controlling acute hemorrhage and for prophylaxis. The effectiveness and safety of endoscopic injection sclerotherapy (EIS) in the management of esophageal varices were evaluated. A total of 78 patients with esophageal varices were included in the study. Acute hemorrhage was successfully controlled in 94% of cases, with a rebleeding rate of only 8%. Prophylactic EIS significantly reduced the incidence of variceal hemorrhage, with only 4% of patients experiencing bleeding during the follow-up period. Complications such as esophageal ulceration, strictures, and perforation were rare, occurring in less than 5% of patients. Overall, EIS was found to be a safe and effective treatment option for esophageal varices, both in terms of acute hemorrhage control and prophylaxis. Further studies are needed to compare the efficacy of EIS with other treatment modalities such as endoscopic variceal ligation and transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt.

Relative effects of brain and non-brain injuries on neuropsychological and psychosocial outcome. This study aimed to investigate the relative effects of brain and non-brain injuries on neuropsychological and psychosocial outcomes. Participants included individuals who had experienced traumatic brain injury (TBI), non-brain injuries, or both. Neuropsychological measures were administered to assess cognitive functioning, while psychosocial outcomes were evaluated using self-report measures of mood, anxiety, and quality of life. Results indicated that individuals with TBI exhibited significant deficits in cognitive functioning compared to those with non-brain injuries. Furthermore, individuals with comorbid brain and non-brain injuries displayed the most severe cognitive impairments. In terms of psychosocial outcomes, participants with TBI reported higher levels of mood disturbances and lower quality of life compared to those with non-brain injuries. These findings highlight the substantial impact of brain injuries on both cognitive and psychosocial functioning. Understanding these differential effects can aid in developing targeted interventions and support strategies for individuals with brain injuries, ultimately improving their overall outcome and quality of life.

Endoscopic retrograde brush cytology. Endoscopic retrograde brush cytology is a technique used to obtain cytological samples from suspicious lesions in the biliary and pancreatic ducts. In this study, we evaluated the diagnostic accuracy and feasibility of endoscopic retrograde brush cytology in the detection of malignancies in these ducts. A total of 150 patients with suspected biliary or pancreatic malignancies underwent endoscopic retrograde brush cytology. The procedure was successfully performed in all cases, with no major complications reported. The cytological samples obtained were examined by experienced cytopathologists, and the results were compared with histopathological findings or clinical follow-up. The sensitivity, specificity, and accuracy of endoscopic retrograde brush cytology in detecting malignancies were 82%, 95%, and 90%, respectively. These findings demonstrate that endoscopic retrograde brush cytology is a safe and effective method for diagnosing biliary and pancreatic malignancies, providing valuable information for appropriate management and treatment decisions.

The role of the iliolumbar ligament in the lumbosacral junction.  The biomechanical function of the iliolumbar ligament in the human lumbosacral junction was investigated by analyzing the three-dimensional movements of the whole lumbar and lumbo-sacral-ilium specimens. The iliolumbar ligament is an essential structure in the lumbosacral junction, providing stability and support to the region. To understand its biomechanical function, we analyzed the three-dimensional movements of lumbar and lumbosacral-ilium specimens. 

Our findings revealed that the iliolumbar ligament plays a crucial role in maintaining the integrity and stability of the lumbosacral junction. It restricts excessive anterior translation, lateral flexion, and rotation in the lumbar spine. 

Furthermore, the ligament acts as a tension band, assisting in load-bearing and distributing forces evenly across the lumbosacral junction. It also contributes to the maintenance of the lumbar lordosis and pelvic alignment.

Understanding the biomechanical properties of the iliolumbar ligament is vital in comprehending the pathophysiology of various conditions affecting the lumbosacral region. This knowledge can aid in developing targeted treatment strategies for patients with lumbosacral instability or pathology involving the iliolumbar ligament.

Epidemiology of acute respiratory tract infections among young children in Kenya.  The epidemiology of acute respiratory tract infection (ARI) was investigated in a rural community 80 km north of Nairobi, Kenya. A cross-sectional study was conducted to determine the epidemiology of acute respiratory tract infections (ARI) among young children in a rural community in Kenya. A total of 500 children under the age of 5 years were enrolled in the study. Information on demographics, environmental factors, and ARI symptoms was collected through household interviews. Nasal swabs were collected from each child and analyzed for respiratory pathogens using molecular techniques.

The results showed that the overall prevalence of ARI in the study population was 45%. The most common respiratory pathogens detected were respiratory syncytial virus (RSV), influenza virus, and parainfluenza virus. Risk factors associated with ARI included younger age, male gender, overcrowding, and exposure to indoor air pollution.

Furthermore, the study identified a seasonal variation in ARI, with a higher prevalence during the dry season. The findings highlight the importance of implementing preventive measures, such as vaccination and improved indoor air quality, to reduce the burden of ARI among young children in rural areas of Kenya.

Gastrointestinal intraluminal pH in normal subjects and those with colorectal adenoma or carcinoma. Gastrointestinal intraluminal pH plays a crucial role in various physiological processes and has been implicated in the development and progression of colorectal adenoma and carcinoma. This study aimed to investigate the differences in intraluminal pH between normal subjects and those with colorectal adenoma or carcinoma. A total of 100 participants were included in this cross-sectional study, categorized into three groups: normal subjects, colorectal adenoma, and colorectal carcinoma. Gastrointestinal pH was measured using a wireless pH monitoring system. The results revealed a significant decrease in intraluminal pH in both colorectal adenoma and carcinoma groups compared to normal subjects. Furthermore, there was a positive correlation between intraluminal pH and tumor size in the carcinoma group. These findings suggest that alterations in gastrointestinal intraluminal pH may contribute to the development and progression of colorectal adenoma and carcinoma, providing potential targets for early detection and intervention.

Congenital cyst of common bile duct: an unusual cause of obstructive jaundice. Obstructive jaundice is a common presentation in clinical practice, often caused by gallstones or malignant tumors. However, less common causes must also be considered to ensure appropriate diagnosis and management. Here, we present a case of obstructive jaundice caused by a congenital cyst in the common bile duct, a rare etiology accounting for less than 1% of all biliary tract anomalies. The patient, a 45-year-old male, presented with symptoms of jaundice and abdominal pain. Imaging studies revealed a cystic lesion in the common bile duct, confirmed by endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography. The patient subsequently underwent surgical excision of the cyst, resulting in resolution of symptoms. This case highlights the importance of considering uncommon causes of obstructive jaundice in clinical practice to ensure early diagnosis and appropriate management.

Mycobacterium chelonei keratopathy with visual rehabilitation by a triple procedure. Mycobacterium chelonei keratopathy is a rare ocular infection leading to significant visual impairment. We present a case of a 44-year-old male who developed Mycobacterium chelonei keratopathy following a traumatic corneal laceration. Despite medical treatment with topical and systemic antibiotics, the infection persisted and resulted in extensive corneal scarring. The patient underwent a triple procedure consisting of penetrating keratoplasty, cataract extraction, and intraocular lens implantation. Visual acuity significantly improved postoperatively, and the patient achieved functional visual rehabilitation. This case highlights the importance of early recognition and timely management of Mycobacterium chelonei keratopathy to prevent irreversible visual impairment.

Radiology for cochlear implants. Cochlear implants have revolutionized the treatment of severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss. However, the radiological assessment of cochlear implant recipients remains a critical component in determining candidacy, surgical planning, and postoperative evaluation. This review aims to provide an overview of the radiological imaging techniques used in assessing cochlear implant patients. Computed tomography (CT) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) are the two main modalities employed in this population. CT is particularly useful in visualizing the temporal bone anatomy and assessing electrode array position within the cochlea. MRI, on the other hand, provides detailed soft tissue contrast and is valuable in evaluating the neural elements, such as the cochlear nerve, brainstem, and central auditory pathways. Additionally, MRI can aid in the identification of any abnormalities or pathology that may preclude implantation or affect implant outcomes. Understanding the strengths and limitations of these imaging techniques is vital for otolaryngologists, radiologists, and other healthcare professionals involved in the management of cochlear implant patients. Further advancements in imaging technology may continue to enhance our ability to accurately assess cochlear implant recipients and optimize overall patient outcomes.

Approach to the patient with genital ulcer disease. Genital ulcer disease (GUD) presents a diagnostic challenge to healthcare providers due to the wide range of possible etiologies. In this review article, the authors discuss the approach to patients presenting with GUD, focusing on the differential diagnosis, proper workup, and appropriate management strategies. The most common causes of GUD include sexually transmitted infections (STIs) such as herpes simplex virus (HSV), syphilis, chancroid, and genital herpes; non-STI causes such as traumatic ulcers and Behcet's disease; and rare conditions such as granuloma inguinale and lymphogranuloma venereum. A thorough history, physical examination, and laboratory investigations are key components of the diagnostic workup. The authors emphasize the importance of obtaining serologic tests for syphilis, polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing for HSV, and dark field microscopy or direct fluorescent antibody testing for Treponema pallidum. Treatment of GUD varies depending on the underlying etiology and may include antimicrobial therapy, antiviral therapy, or immunosuppressive agents. Early and accurate diagnosis is crucial to prevent the spread of STIs and to ensure appropriate management of non-infectious causes of GUD.

Coracoclavicular screw fixation for unstable fractures of the distal clavicle. Coracoclavicular (CC) screw fixation is a widely used technique for treating unstable fractures of the distal clavicle. This study aimed to evaluate the clinical outcomes and complications associated with CC screw fixation in patients with distal clavicle fractures. A systematic review and meta-analysis of published literature were performed. The results showed that CC screw fixation had a high overall rate of union (95.7%) and a low rate of complications, such as hardware failure (3.1%) and infection (1.7%). Furthermore, CC screw fixation resulted in satisfactory functional outcomes and a high patient satisfaction rate. In conclusion, CC screw fixation is an effective and safe treatment option for unstable fractures of the distal clavicle.

Chordoma: a 20-year clinicopathologic review of the experience at Groote Schuur Hospital, Cape Town.  Eighteen chordomas (11 females and 7 males) were seen over a 20-year period; 61% of the tumors occurred in the sphenoid region. This study presents a 20-year clinicopathologic review of chordomas at Groote Schuur Hospital in Cape Town. A total of 18 chordomas were identified, with 11 females and 7 males affected. The majority of tumors (61%) were located in the sphenoid region. The mean age at presentation was 49 years, ranging from 33 to 67 years. The most common clinical presentation was headache (61%) followed by visual disturbances (33%). Radiologically, these tumors were typically large, infiltrative lesions with erosion into adjacent bone and soft tissue. Histologically, all cases exhibited characteristic chordoma features such as physaliphorous cells and myxoid stroma. Surgical resection was the mainstay of treatment, often combined with adjuvant radiotherapy. Despite treatment, chordomas have a high potential for recurrence, requiring close clinical follow-up. This study highlights the clinicopathological features of chordomas and emphasizes the importance of early diagnosis and comprehensive treatment strategies.

Nasopalatine duct cyst: an analysis of 334 cases.  The nasopalatine duct cyst (NPDC) is the most common cyst of nonodontogenic origin in the maxilla. We retrospectively analyzed 334 cases of nasopalatine duct cyst (NPDC) to characterize its clinical and radiographic features. The mean age of the patients was 45 years, with a slight male predominance (52.4%). The most common symptom was a painless swelling in the anterior maxilla (76.3%), followed by nasal obstruction (17.4%) and pain (9.0%). On radiographic examination, the majority of NPDCs appeared as well-defined radiolucent lesions (87.1%), with 10.2% showing mixed radiolucent-radiopaque features and 2.7% exhibiting radiopaque characteristics. The sizes ranged from 3 to 20 mm in the greatest dimension, with a mean size of 10.2 mm. Histopathological analysis confirmed the diagnosis of NPDC in all cases, with characteristic epithelial lining and connective tissue wall. Our findings provide a comprehensive overview of NPDC, aiding in its recognition and management.

Factors associated with binocular single vision in microtropia/monofixation syndrome.  We reviewed the charts of 398 patients with microtropia/monofixation syndrome to determine what factors influence the level of binocularity attained. The charts of 398 patients with microtropia/monofixation syndrome were reviewed to investigate factors associated with binocular single vision. Age at diagnosis, magnitude of microtropia, presence of eccentric fixation, and amblyopia severity were analyzed. Binocular single vision was achieved in 266 patients (67%) and was significantly associated with younger age at diagnosis and smaller magnitudes of microtropia. Presence of eccentric fixation and amblyopia severity did not significantly influence the level of binocularity attained. These findings suggest that early diagnosis and smaller microtropia may be important prognostic factors for binocular single vision in microtropia/monofixation syndrome. Further studies are needed to fully understand the underlying mechanisms and optimize treatment strategies.

Short-term radiotherapy as palliative treatment in patients with transitional cell bladder cancer. This study aimed to assess the efficacy of short-term radiotherapy as a palliative treatment in patients with transitional cell bladder cancer. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 75 patients diagnosed with advanced stage transitional cell bladder cancer who received short-term radiotherapy as palliative treatment between 2010 and 2015. The primary endpoint was the overall response rate, while secondary endpoints included progression-free survival, overall survival, and treatment-related toxicities. The overall response rate was 68%, with 42 patients achieving a partial response and 8 patients achieving a complete response. The median progression-free survival and overall survival were 8 months and 14 months, respectively. Treatment-related toxicities were mild, with only 12% of patients experiencing grade 3 or 4 toxicities. These findings suggest that short-term radiotherapy could be an effective and well-tolerated palliative treatment option for patients with advanced stage transitional cell bladder cancer. Further prospective studies are warranted to confirm these results and optimize treatment strategies.

Immunohistochemical study of erythropoietin in cerebellar hemangioblastomas associated with secondary polycythemia.  Although cerebellar hemangioblastomas are known to be associated with secondary polycythemia, the cellular derivation of erythropoietin (EPO) in hemangioblastomas still remains obscure. In this immunohistochemical study, we investigated the presence and cellular localization of erythropoietin in cerebellar hemangioblastomas associated with secondary polycythemia. The study included five cases of cerebellar hemangioblastomas, all of which exhibited increased erythropoietin expression. Immunohistochemical staining revealed that erythropoietin was primarily localized to the cytoplasm of tumor cells with variable reactivity in blood vessels. Interestingly, erythropoietin expression was more pronounced in areas of increased vascularity within the tumor. These findings suggest that cerebellar hemangioblastomas can produce erythropoietin, which may contribute to the development of secondary polycythemia in these patients. The cellular source of erythropoietin in hemangioblastomas is likely the tumor cells themselves, rather than the surrounding vasculature. Further investigation is needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and potential therapeutic implications of erythropoietin production in cerebellar hemangioblastomas.

Right-to-left shunting through a patent foramen ovale caused by pulmonary hypertension associated with rheumatoid arthritis and Sjogren's syndrome: a case report. This case report describes a rare medical presentation of right-to-left shunting through a patent foramen ovale (PFO) in a patient with both pulmonary hypertension associated with rheumatoid arthritis and Sjogren's syndrome. The patient presented with exertional dyspnea, cyanosis, and digital clubbing. Echocardiography revealed a PFO with evidence of right heart strain. Pulmonary function tests showed severe obstructive and restrictive lung disease. The diagnosis of pulmonary hypertension was confirmed by right heart catheterization. The patient underwent surgical closure of the PFO, leading to significant improvement in clinical symptoms and oxygen saturation levels. This case highlights the importance of considering PFO as a possible cause of hypoxemia in patients with pulmonary hypertension associated with autoimmune diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis and Sjogren's syndrome.

Predicting treatment outcome in nocturnal enuresis. Nocturnal enuresis is a common childhood disorder characterized by involuntary nighttime bedwetting beyond the age of 5 years. Various treatment options have been utilized, including behavioral and pharmacological interventions, with varying degrees of success. However, predicting treatment outcome in individual patients remains a challenge. This review aims to summarize the current literature on factors associated with treatment response in nocturnal enuresis.
Multiple factors have been proposed as potential predictors of treatment outcome. Demographic factors such as age, gender, and family history of enuresis have shown inconsistent associations with treatment response. Comorbid conditions, such as constipation and sleep disorders, have also been explored as potential predictors but have yielded conflicting results. Additionally, the severity and frequency of bedwetting episodes at baseline have been shown to correlate with treatment response in some studies.
Psychosocial factors, such as the child's motivation and parental involvement in treatment, have been identified as important predictors of success. Furthermore, the presence of functional bladder capacity and the ability to awaken in response to a full bladder have been suggested as indicators of treatment efficacy.
In conclusion, while several potential predictors of treatment outcome in nocturnal enuresis have been identified, further research is needed to establish their validity and utility in clinical practice. A better understanding of these predictors may allow for personalized treatment approaches and improve treatment success rates in this common childhood disorder.

Cauda equina syndrome after continuous spinal anesthesia. Cauda equina syndrome (CES) is a rare but debilitating complication of spinal anesthesia. We present a case series of CES following continuous spinal anesthesia and analyze the presenting symptoms, diagnostic findings, management, and outcomes. A total of 10 patients developed CES after undergoing continuous spinal anesthesia for various surgical procedures. The mean age of the patients was 56 years, and there was no gender predilection. The most common presenting symptom was severe back pain, followed by urinary and bowel dysfunction. Magnetic resonance imaging confirmed the diagnosis of CES in all cases, revealing compression of the cauda equina roots. Surgical decompression was performed in all patients, resulting in partial or complete resolution of symptoms. However, long-term outcomes were variable, with some patients experiencing residual neurological deficits. Our findings highlight the importance of prompt recognition and timely intervention in patients developing CES after continuous spinal anesthesia to improve outcomes and prevent long-term complications. Further research is needed to identify risk factors and develop strategies for prevention of this devastating complication.

Chondrosarcoma of bone in children.  Chondrosarcoma of bone rarely occurs in children. Chondrosarcoma of bone is a rare malignant tumor that primarily occurs in adults. However, it is extremely uncommon in children, making up less than 5% of all pediatric bone tumors. This study aimed to analyze the clinical characteristics, treatment approaches, and outcomes of chondrosarcoma in children.

A retrospective analysis was conducted on pediatric patients diagnosed with chondrosarcoma of bone between 2000 and 2020. Demographic data, clinical features, imaging findings, histopathological findings, treatment modalities, and survival outcomes were collected and analyzed.

A total of 25 patients (mean age: 12.7 years) were included in the study. The most common site of involvement was the long bones, followed by the pelvis and ribs. The majority of patients presented with pain and swelling at the affected site. Radiographic evaluation revealed lytic lesions with areas of calcifications. Histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of chondrosarcoma in all cases.

Multimodal treatment approaches were employed, including surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy. Limb salvage surgery was attempted in the majority of cases, while amputation was required in a few. The overall 5-year survival rate was 75%.

In conclusion, chondrosarcoma of bone is an extremely rare malignancy in children. Prompt diagnosis, multidisciplinary treatment, and long-term follow-up are crucial for achieving favorable outcomes in these patients. Further research is warranted to optimize treatment strategies and improve survival in this population.

Glucagonoma syndrome is an underdiagnosed clinical entity. Glucagonoma syndrome is a rare and underdiagnosed clinical entity characterized by the presence of a glucagon-secreting tumor, most commonly located in the pancreas. This syndrome presents with a variety of clinical manifestations, including necrolytic migratory erythema, weight loss, diabetes mellitus, anemia, and gastrointestinal symptoms. Diagnosis can be challenging, as symptoms may be nonspecific and mimic other conditions. Biochemical testing is crucial in establishing the diagnosis, with elevated serum levels of glucagon being a key finding. Imaging studies, such as computed tomography and magnetic resonance imaging, are useful in localizing the tumor. Surgical resection of the tumor is the treatment of choice, with curative intent. Long-term follow-up is necessary due to the potential for recurrence and metastasis. This abstract highlights the need for increased awareness and recognition of glucagonoma syndrome to optimize patient outcomes.

Hepatic giant cavernous hemangioma with microangiopathic hemolytic anemia and consumption coagulopathy. Hepatic giant cavernous hemangioma is a common benign liver tumor that can present with various clinical manifestations. We report a case of a 37-year-old female who presented with abdominal pain, jaundice, and hemoglobinuria. Laboratory investigations revealed microangiopathic hemolytic anemia and consumption coagulopathy, suggesting an underlying coagulopathy associated with hepatic giant cavernous hemangioma. Imaging studies confirmed the presence of a large hepatic cavernous hemangioma. The patient received supportive care including blood transfusions and anticoagulant therapy. Despite aggressive management, the patient's condition continued to deteriorate. Eventually, a decision was made to perform a surgical resection of the tumor, resulting in a significant improvement in the patient's clinical condition. This case highlights the association between hepatic giant cavernous hemangioma and microangiopathic hemolytic anemia with consumption coagulopathy, as well as the potential benefit of surgical intervention in selected cases. Further research is needed to better understand the pathophysiology and optimal management strategies for this rare presentation.

Diagnosis of oral hairy leukoplakia by ultrastructural examination of exfoliative cytologic specimens.  Lingual exfoliative cytologic specimens (scrapings) were obtained from 18 patients positive for human immunodeficiency virus with clinical oral hairy leukoplakia. Ultrastructural examination of exfoliative cytologic specimens was performed to diagnose oral hairy leukoplakia (OHL) in 18 patients positive for human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) with clinical manifestations of OHL. The oral scrapings were collected from the lingual surface of the patients and were processed for transmission electron microscopy. The examination revealed characteristic morphological features of OHL, including hypertrophic and elongated epithelial cells with prominent nuclear chromatin irregularities and abundant viral particles within the nucleus. These findings confirmed the presence of Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) in all 18 patients, substantiating the role of EBV in the etiology of OHL. The ultrastructural examination of exfoliative cytologic specimens represents a valuable tool for diagnosing OHL, especially in HIV-positive individuals, allowing for prompt identification and appropriate management of this oral manifestation of HIV infection.

Urinary tract re-functionalization after long-term diversion.  A 20-year experience with 177 patients. Urinary tract re-functionalization after long-term diversion is a critical aspect in the care of patients who have undergone urinary diversion procedures. In this study, we present a comprehensive analysis of 177 patients who underwent long-term urinary diversion and subsequently underwent re-functionalization procedures over a 20-year period. Our results demonstrate a high success rate of 92.6% in achieving satisfactory bladder function, with 10.2% of patients requiring revision surgeries due to complications. Furthermore, we observed a significant improvement in quality of life measures and overall patient satisfaction following re-functionalization. These findings highlight the importance of urinary tract re-functionalization as an effective and feasible strategy for patients with long-term urinary diversion, emphasizing the need for continued research and advancements in this field.

Muscle relaxation rates in individuals susceptible to malignant hyperthermia. Malignant hyperthermia (MH) is a potentially life-threatening condition characterized by hypermetabolism and skeletal muscle rigidity triggered by certain volatile anesthetics and depolarizing muscle relaxants. In this study, we aimed to investigate the muscle relaxation rates in individuals susceptible to MH.

A total of 25 MH-susceptible individuals and 25 non-susceptible controls were included in the study. Muscle relaxation rates were measured using a standardized protocol involving administration of succinylcholine and subsequent monitoring of the time taken for muscle relaxation to occur. 

Our results showed a significantly slower muscle relaxation rate in individuals susceptible to MH compared to controls (p<0.001). The mean time for muscle relaxation in the MH-susceptible group was 38 seconds compared to 15 seconds in the control group. 

These findings highlight the importance of monitoring muscle relaxation rates in individuals at risk for MH during anesthesia administration. Early recognition of MH susceptibility can help guide anesthesia management and prevent complications associated with this condition. Further research is warranted to elucidate the underlying mechanisms contributing to the slower muscle relaxation rates observed in MH-susceptible individuals.

Increased serum beta 2-microglobulin concentrations in hyperthyroid states.  Serum beta 2-microglobulin concentrations were determined in 21 untreated hyperthyroid patients (12 with Graves' disease, and nine with toxic nodular adenoma) and in 20 healthy controls. The present study aimed to investigate serum beta 2-microglobulin concentrations in hyperthyroid states. A total of 21 untreated hyperthyroid patients, including 12 with Graves' disease and nine with toxic nodular adenoma, were compared to 20 healthy controls. Serum beta 2-microglobulin concentrations were measured in all participants. The results showed that hyperthyroid patients had significantly higher serum beta 2-microglobulin levels compared to healthy controls (p < 0.001). Furthermore, within the hyperthyroid group, patients with Graves' disease exhibited higher beta 2-microglobulin levels compared to those with toxic nodular adenoma (p = 0.032). These findings suggest that elevated serum beta 2-microglobulin concentrations may be associated with hyperthyroid states, particularly in patients with Graves' disease. Further studies are warranted to explore the potential clinical implications of this biomarker in hyperthyroidism.

Esophageal motility, heartburn, and gastroesophageal reflux: variations in clinical presentation of esophageal dysphagia. Esophageal dysphagia is a common symptom of various esophageal disorders and can present with different clinical manifestations. This study aimed to investigate the variations in clinical presentation of esophageal dysphagia related to esophageal motility, heartburn, and gastroesophageal reflux (GER).

A total of 100 patients with esophageal dysphagia were enrolled in the study. Patients underwent esophageal motility testing, pH monitoring, and upper endoscopy. Clinical characteristics, including dysphagia severity, presence of heartburn, and GER symptoms, were assessed.

Results showed that 40% of patients had abnormal esophageal motility, with ineffective esophageal motility being the most common finding. Heartburn was reported by 60% of patients, with 30% having erosive esophagitis on endoscopy. GER symptoms were present in 75% of patients, and abnormal acid exposure was observed in 55% of patients.

Significant variations were observed in the clinical presentation of esophageal dysphagia related to esophageal motility, heartburn, and GER. These findings suggest that a comprehensive evaluation including esophageal motility testing and reflux monitoring is essential for accurate diagnosis and management of patients with esophageal dysphagia. Further studies are warranted to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and optimize treatment strategies for different subgroups of patients.

Pseudotumor of the craniocervical junction during long-term hemodialysis. Pseudotumor of the craniocervical junction is a rare complication seen in patients undergoing long-term hemodialysis. We present a case of a 56-year-old male with end-stage renal disease who developed a pseudotumor at the craniocervical junction after 13 years of hemodialysis treatment. The patient presented with severe occipital headache, neck pain, and progressive neurological deficits. Magnetic resonance imaging revealed a large mass compressing the brainstem and spinal cord. Surgical intervention was performed to decompress the neural structures and remove the tumor. Histopathological examination confirmed the presence of a pseudotumor, characterized by fibrous tissue proliferation with chronic inflammation and hemosiderin deposits. This case highlights the importance of considering pseudotumor as a possible differential diagnosis in patients on long-term hemodialysis who present with symptoms suggestive of craniocervical junction compression. Early diagnosis and intervention are crucial for preventing further neurological deterioration and improving patient outcomes. Further studies are needed to better understand the pathogenesis and optimal management of this rare complication.

Fungal brain abscesses (aspergillosis/mucormycosis) in two immunosuppressed patients. We report two cases of fungal brain abscesses in immunosuppressed patients, one due to aspergillosis and the other due to mucormycosis. Both patients presented with nonspecific symptoms such as headache, fever, and altered mental status. Radiological imaging revealed multiple intracranial lesions consistent with abscesses. Surgical intervention was performed in both cases to drain the abscesses and obtain samples for microbiological analysis. The cultures confirmed the presence of Aspergillus fumigatus and Mucor spp. respectively. Both patients received antifungal therapy with amphotericin B and underwent aggressive management of their underlying immunosuppression. Despite intensive treatment, both patients had a protracted course with persistent neurological deficits. Fungal brain abscesses, although rare, should be considered in immunosuppressed individuals presenting with intracranial lesions. Early diagnosis, appropriate surgical intervention, and targeted antifungal therapy are crucial in improving outcomes for these patients.

Rigid fixation of internal orbital fractures.  When large portions of the internal orbit are destroyed (two to four walls), standard bone-grafting techniques for immediate and late orbital reconstruction may not yield predictable eye position. In these cases, rigid fixation of internal orbital fractures is a viable alternative for achieving stable and accurate eye position. This article reviews the use of rigid fixation, specifically titanium miniplates and screws, in the management of internal orbital fractures. A retrospective analysis of 25 patients who underwent rigid fixation for internal orbital fractures is presented. The results show that rigid fixation allowed for precise restoration of orbital volume and shape, resulting in improved postoperative eye position and ocular function. The complications associated with rigid fixation are minimal, and overall patient satisfaction is high. Rigid fixation provides a reliable and effective method for addressing complex internal orbital fractures, offering better outcomes compared to conventional bone-grafting techniques.

Oral labetalol in hypertensive urgencies. Hypertensive urgencies are common in clinical practice, requiring prompt blood pressure control to prevent end-organ damage. Labetalol, a non-selective beta-blocker with alpha1-antagonist activity, has been widely used in the management of hypertensive crises. This review aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of oral labetalol in the treatment of hypertensive urgencies. Multiple databases were searched for relevant studies, which were then assessed for methodological quality. The findings indicate that oral labetalol effectively reduces blood pressure in patients with hypertensive urgencies, with a rapid onset of action and a favorable side effect profile. However, caution is advised in patients with underlying cardiac or respiratory conditions. Further research is needed to determine optimal dosing regimens and long-term outcomes of oral labetalol in this clinical setting.

Lack of association between keratoconus, mitral valve prolapse, and joint hypermobility. Keratoconus, mitral valve prolapse (MVP), and joint hypermobility are three conditions that have been reported to occur together in some cases. However, the exact relationship between these conditions remains unclear. In this retrospective study, we aim to investigate the association between keratoconus, MVP, and joint hypermobility.

We reviewed the medical records of 120 patients diagnosed with keratoconus between 2010 and 2018. The presence of MVP and joint hypermobility was assessed through echocardiography and Beighton hypermobility score, respectively. Demographic and clinical data were collected, including age, sex, and family history of keratoconus, MVP, or joint hypermobility.

Our results showed no significant association between keratoconus, MVP, and joint hypermobility. Among the 120 patients included in the study, only 12 had concomitant MVP, and only 8 had joint hypermobility. Furthermore, there was no family history of these conditions in any of the patients.

In conclusion, our findings suggest that there is no significant association between keratoconus, MVP, and joint hypermobility. Further studies with larger sample sizes and more comprehensive assessments are needed to confirm these results.

A rapid, effective technique for retrograde crossing of valvular aortic stenosis using standard coronary catheters Retrograde crossing of valvular aortic stenosis can be challenging even to experienced angiographers. This study aimed to evaluate the feasibility and efficacy of a rapid and effective technique for retrograde crossing of valvular aortic stenosis using standard coronary catheters. A total of 25 patients with severe valvular aortic stenosis were included in the study. The retrograde crossing technique involved the use of standard coronary catheters with different shapes and sizes to navigate through the narrowing of the aortic valve. The success rate of retrograde crossing was assessed, and any complications or adverse events were documented. The results showed a high success rate of retrograde crossing using this technique, with 96% of patients successfully crossed. No major complications or adverse events were reported. This technique provides a safe and feasible alternative for retrograde crossing of valvular aortic stenosis and may improve the success rate of aortic valve interventions. Further studies are warranted to validate these findings in a larger patient population.

Prochlorperazine and transdermal scopolamine added to a metoclopramide antiemetic regimen.  A controlled comparison. OBJECTIVE: The objective of this study was to compare the efficacy of adding prochlorperazine and transdermal scopolamine to a metoclopramide antiemetic regimen in preventing postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV). DESIGN: This study utilized a controlled comparison design. SETTING: The study was conducted in a surgical center. PARTICIPANTS: Adult patients scheduled for elective surgery under general anesthesia were included in the study. INTERVENTIONS: The participants were randomly assigned to receive either a metoclopramide only antiemetic regimen or a combination of metoclopramide, prochlorperazine, and transdermal scopolamine. MEASUREMENTS AND MAIN RESULTS: The incidence of PONV was significantly lower in the group receiving the combination antiemetic regimen compared to the metoclopramide only group. Additionally, the combination regimen resulted in better control of PONV symptoms and reduced the need for rescue antiemetic medication. CONCLUSION: Adding prochlorperazine and transdermal scopolamine to a metoclopramide antiemetic regimen is an effective strategy for preventing PONV in patients undergoing elective surgery under general anesthesia.

Homeobox gene expression plus autocrine growth factor production elicits myeloid leukemia.  In the murine myelomonocytic leukemia WEHI-3B, proviral insertions have induced expression of the Hox-2. This study investigated the role of homeobox gene expression and autocrine growth factor production in the development of myeloid leukemia. The murine myelomonocytic leukemia cell line, WEHI-3B, was used as a model. The results show that proviral insertions induced the expression of the Hox-2 homeobox genes in WEHI-3B cells. Furthermore, these cells also exhibited autocrine growth factor production. Specifically, granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor (GM-CSF) was found to be secreted by the WEHI-3B cells and acted as an autocrine growth factor. This autocrine loop of homeobox gene expression and GM-CSF production contributed to the development of myeloid leukemia in this cell line. These findings provide insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying the pathogenesis of myeloid leukemia and may have implications for the development of targeted therapies.

Repetitive intraoperative mapping and cryotherapy improve the results of endocardial resection for ventricular tachycardia. The objective of this study was to evaluate the efficacy of repetitive intraoperative mapping and cryotherapy in improving the results of endocardial resection for ventricular tachycardia. A total of 50 patients underwent endocardial resection for drug-refractory ventricular tachycardia. Mapping was performed using a repeated cycle of endocardial activation mapping followed by cryotherapy ablation. Follow-up assessments were conducted at 1, 3, 6, and 12 months postoperatively. The results showed a significant reduction in ventricular tachycardia episodes and improvement in left ventricular ejection fraction in the majority of patients. Complications were minimal, with no major adverse events reported. This study highlights the potential benefits of repetitive intraoperative mapping and cryotherapy in enhancing the success rate of endocardial resection for ventricular tachycardia.

Vascular entrapment of intra-aortic balloon after short-term balloon counterpulsation. Intra-aortic balloon counterpulsation (IABP) is a commonly used mechanical circulatory support device in patients with cardiac dysfunction. However, there have been rare reports of complications associated with the use of IABP, including vascular entrapment of the balloon. We present a case of a 65-year-old male who developed vascular entrapment of the IABP balloon after a short-term duration of counterpulsation. The patient underwent emergent surgical intervention to remove the entrapped balloon, and despite successful removal, he developed ischemic complications in the affected limb. This case highlights the importance of careful monitoring and prompt recognition of potential complications associated with IABP, as prompt intervention can significantly impact patient outcomes. Further studies are warranted to examine the risk factors and optimal management strategies for vascular entrapment in patients undergoing IABP therapy.

Pancreatic ascites presenting in infancy, with review of the literature. Pancreatic ascites is a rare condition characterized by the accumulation of pancreatic fluid in the peritoneal cavity. It typically presents in adults and is associated with underlying pancreatic pathology such as pancreatitis or trauma. Here, we report a case of pancreatic ascites presenting in infancy, which is extremely rare with only a few cases reported in the literature. A 6-month-old male infant presented with abdominal distention and respiratory distress. Imaging and laboratory investigations revealed a diagnosis of pancreatic ascites. Surgical exploration confirmed a pancreatic duct disruption as the underlying cause. The patient underwent pancreaticojejunostomy with resolution of symptoms and good postoperative outcomes. This case highlights the importance of considering pancreatic ascites as a differential diagnosis in infants presenting with abdominal distention, as early identification and prompt surgical intervention can lead to successful management. A review of the literature on pediatric cases of pancreatic ascites is also presented.

Localization of calcitonin gene-related peptide in human esophageal Langerhans cells. Langerhans cells (LCs) are antigen-presenting cells located in the epidermis and mucosal surfaces, playing a crucial role in immune responses and inflammation. Calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) is a neuropeptide involved in neurogenic inflammation and pain signaling. The presence and functional significance of CGRP in LCs remain unclear. In this study, we investigated the localization of CGRP in human esophageal LCs. Immunohistochemical analysis revealed a significant co-localization of CGRP and LC marker CD1a in the esophageal mucosa of patients with gastroesophageal reflux disease. Further double immunofluorescence staining confirmed the presence of CGRP in LCs. In addition, the expression of CGRP-R, the receptor for CGRP, was detected in LCs. These findings suggest that CGRP may be involved in the regulation of LC functions in the esophagus, potentially modulating immune responses and inflammation. Further studies are warranted to elucidate the role of CGRP in LC biology and its implications in esophageal diseases.

Death and functional outcome after spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage. Intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) is a devastating form of stroke with high morbidity and mortality rates. However, there is limited data on the long-term functional outcomes and factors associated with death following spontaneous ICH. In this retrospective study, we evaluated 150 patients with spontaneous ICH to assess their functional outcomes and survival rates. We found that the majority of patients (62%) experienced poor functional outcome, defined as a Modified Rankin Scale (mRS) score of 4-6, indicating severe disability or death, at one-year follow-up. Older age, higher baseline National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) score, larger hematoma volume, presence of intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH), and elevated systolic blood pressure at admission were independently associated with poor functional outcome. Additionally, older age, higher baseline NIHSS score, presence of IVH, and larger hematoma volume were identified as independent predictors of increased mortality. These findings highlight the need for early identification and aggressive management of these high-risk factors in order to improve outcomes and reduce mortality rates in patients with spontaneous ICH.

Hypercalcemia with excess serum 1,25 dihydroxyvitamin D in lymphomatoid granulomatosis/angiocentric lymphoma. Lymphomatoid granulomatosis/angiocentric lymphoma is a rare and aggressive form of lymphoma. In this case report, we present a patient who presented with hypercalcemia and excess serum levels of 1,25 dihydroxyvitamin D. Laboratory investigations revealed elevated serum calcium (13.8 mg/dL) and markedly increased serum 1,25 dihydroxyvitamin D levels (207 pg/mL), along with evidence of renal impairment. Imaging studies demonstrated bilateral pulmonary nodules, consistent with lymphomatoid granulomatosis/angiocentric lymphoma. The patient underwent a lung biopsy, which confirmed the diagnosis. Treatment with systemic chemotherapy and corticosteroids led to normalization of serum calcium and decreased levels of 1,25 dihydroxyvitamin D. Hypercalcemia with excess serum 1,25 dihydroxyvitamin D in lymphomatoid granulomatosis/angiocentric lymphoma is a rare phenomenon and warrants further investigation.

Meningeal involvement in Bence Jones multiple myeloma. Meningeal involvement in Bence Jones multiple myeloma is an uncommon but severe complication of this hematologic malignancy. It presents as leptomeningeal infiltration of plasma cells, leading to a variety of neurological symptoms, including headache, cranial nerve palsies, and motor and sensory deficits. Diagnosis requires a high index of suspicion and is often confirmed through cerebrospinal fluid analysis and imaging studies. Treatment options include intrathecal chemotherapy, systemic chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and stem cell transplantation. However, the prognosis remains poor, with a median survival of less than one year. Further research is needed to improve the understanding and management of meningeal involvement in Bence Jones multiple myeloma and to develop novel therapeutic approaches to improve survival outcomes.

Spinal cord decompression via a modified costotransversectomy approach combined with posterior instrumentation for management of metastatic neoplasms of the thoracic spine. Metastatic neoplasms of the thoracic spine are a common source of morbidity and mortality in patients with cancer. Surgical interventions, such as spinal cord decompression, combined with posterior instrumentation, have been utilized to achieve pain relief and improve neurological function. In this retrospective study, we evaluated the outcomes of 27 patients who underwent spinal cord decompression via a modified costotransversectomy approach, followed by posterior instrumentation for the management of metastatic neoplasms of the thoracic spine. The mean age of the patients was 58 years, and the most common primary tumor was lung cancer. Surgical intervention resulted in significant improvements in pain scores and neurological status. Postoperative complications, including wound infections and instrumentation failure, were observed in a small number of patients. Overall, spinal cord decompression via a modified costotransversectomy approach, combined with posterior instrumentation, appears to be a safe and effective treatment option for patients with metastatic neoplasms of the thoracic spine.

Vertical partial laryngectomy: a critical analysis of local recurrence. Vertical partial laryngectomy (VPL) is a surgical procedure commonly performed for the treatment of laryngeal cancer. While it has shown promising results in terms of local control of the disease, the occurrence of local recurrence remains a significant concern. This study aims to critically analyze the incidence and factors associated with local recurrence following VPL. 

A comprehensive search of electronic databases was conducted to identify studies reporting on local recurrence after VPL. After applying inclusion and exclusion criteria, a total of 15 studies were included for analysis. The overall incidence of local recurrence was found to be 18.6%, with a wide variation across studies. 

Several factors were identified as potential predictors of local recurrence, including advanced tumor stage, positive surgical margins, and perineural invasion. However, the strength of these associations varied among the studies. 

Furthermore, analysis of the type of VPL procedure performed revealed that supraglottic laryngectomy had a higher incidence of local recurrence compared to other techniques. 

In conclusion, local recurrence following VPL remains a significant concern. Further studies are needed to better understand the risk factors and develop strategies to minimize this complication.

Growth abnormalities in children with juvenile rheumatoid arthritis. Juvenile rheumatoid arthritis (JRA) is a chronic autoimmune disease that commonly affects children. This study aimed to investigate the prevalence of growth abnormalities in children with JRA and to identify potential risk factors associated with growth retardation. A total of 85 patients diagnosed with JRA were included in the study. Anthropometric measurements including height, weight, and body mass index were recorded and compared to age-matched reference values. Additionally, disease characteristics and treatment modalities were analyzed for their potential effects on growth parameters. Results showed that growth abnormalities were present in 42% of children with JRA, with the majority experiencing growth retardation. Disease duration, active joint involvement, and higher disease severity scores were associated with a higher risk of growth abnormalities. These findings highlight the importance of monitoring growth parameters in children with JRA and implementing appropriate interventions to mitigate growth retardation.

Complications of nasotracheal intubation in neonates, infants and children: a review of 4 years' experience in a children's hospital.  A computerized database was set up to study the incidence and outcome of complications of nasotracheal intubation in a paediatric hospital. A retrospective review was conducted over a four-year period to assess the complications of nasotracheal intubation in neonates, infants, and children at a children's hospital. A computerized database was utilized to collect data on the incidence and outcome of these complications. A total of 326 patients were included in the study. The most common complications encountered were epistaxis (n=45), subglottic stenosis (n=8), and laryngeal edema (n=6). Other less frequent complications included nasal trauma, infection, and vocal cord injury. The overall incidence of complications was found to be 18.4%. Despite the relatively high incidence of complications, the majority of cases resolved with appropriate management. Further studies are needed to identify risk factors and develop strategies to minimize complications associated with nasotracheal intubation in this population.

Fusiform dilatations of the carotid artery following radical surgery of childhood craniopharyngiomas. Fusiform dilatations of the carotid artery are a potential complication following radical surgery of childhood craniopharyngiomas. This study aimed to evaluate the incidence, clinical characteristics, and management strategies of this vascular complication. A retrospective analysis was conducted on patients who underwent radical surgery for childhood craniopharyngiomas at a single institution over a 10-year period. Of the 45 patients included in the study, 7 (15.6%) developed fusiform dilatations of the carotid artery. The mean age at diagnosis was 8.4 years, and all patients had undergone gross total resection of the tumor. The dilatations were identified on postoperative imaging studies, and none of the patients exhibited clinical symptoms. Close surveillance with periodic imaging follow-ups was implemented for all affected patients. No intervention was required during the follow-up period, ranging from 6 months to 8 years. In conclusion, fusiform dilatations of the carotid artery can occur following radical surgery for childhood craniopharyngioma, but they generally remain asymptomatic and do not require intervention.

Cholesterol cysts of the temporal bone: diagnosis and treatment.  Cholesterol cyst (or granuloma) of the temporal bone, a recognized clinical entity distinct from cholesteatoma, is more common than previously thought. Cholesterol cysts (or granulomas) of the temporal bone are increasingly being recognized as a distinct clinical entity, separate from cholesteatoma. This study aims to explore the diagnosis and treatment approaches for cholesterol cysts in the temporal bone. A retrospective analysis of patients with cholesterol cysts presenting at our institution was conducted, and demographic data, presenting symptoms, radiographic findings, histopathological characteristics, and treatment outcomes were assessed.

Results showed that cholesterol cysts in the temporal bone are more common than previously thought, with a higher prevalence in males. The most common presenting symptom was hearing loss, followed by tinnitus and vertigo. Radiographically, cholesterol cysts appeared as well-demarcated expansile lesions with low attenuation values on computed tomography scans. Histopathological evaluation exhibited cholesterol crystals surrounded by giant cell reactions.

Surgical management, including cystectomy with simultaneous mastoid obliteration, was found to be the optimal treatment strategy for these cysts, resulting in improved hearing outcomes and lower recurrence rates. In conclusion, cholesterol cysts of the temporal bone should be considered in the differential diagnosis of temporal bone lesions, and surgical intervention is recommended for their successful management.

Acute porphyria presenting with hyperamylasemia. We present a case series of four patients who presented with acute porphyria and hyperamylasemia, highlighting the importance of considering this rare condition in the differential diagnosis of patients with elevated serum amylase levels. All patients had abdominal pain, neurological symptoms, and elevated serum amylase levels, which initially led to a misdiagnosis of acute pancreatitis. However, further investigation revealed significantly elevated urinary porphyrin levels and characteristic findings on genetic testing, confirming the diagnosis of acute porphyria. Prompt initiation of appropriate treatment with hemin resulted in resolution of symptoms and normalization of serum amylase levels. Early recognition of this atypical presentation is crucial to avoid unnecessary interventions and to ensure appropriate management of acute porphyria. Clinicians should have a high index of suspicion for acute porphyria in patients presenting with hyperamylasemia and abdominal pain.

Delayed hearing loss after neurovascular decompression. Neurovascular decompression (NVD) is a surgical procedure commonly performed to alleviate symptoms of various neurovascular compression syndromes. Although successful in relieving symptoms such as trigeminal neuralgia or hemifacial spasm, delayed complications can occur postoperatively. This case report presents a rare occurrence of delayed hearing loss, three years after NVD for trigeminal neuralgia. The patient, a 56-year-old female, experienced bilateral sensorineural hearing loss that manifested gradually over a span of six months. Audiometric testing revealed severe hearing loss in both ears, predominantly affecting the high-frequency range. Magnetic resonance imaging demonstrated no new vascular compression or other pathological findings. This case emphasizes the importance of long-term follow-up and consideration of delayed complications in patients who have undergone NVD, particularly those experiencing auditory symptoms. Further research is warranted to better understand the underlying mechanisms and potential preventive strategies for delayed hearing loss after NVD.

Long term follow-up of descending thoracic aorto-iliac/femoral bypass.  A prospective study of 26 patients undergoing descending thoracic aorto-iliac/femoral (DTAI/F) bypass was conducted over a 13-year period with an average follow up of 53 months. Results showed that the majority of patients (92.3%) maintained patent bypass grafts, with only two instances of thrombosis and one instance of graft occlusion requiring revascularization. The overall 5-year primary patency rate was 86.2%, while the 10-year primary patency rate was 69.2%. Secondary patency rates at 5 and 10 years were 92.3% and 84.6%, respectively. Additionally, limb salvage rates were high, with only one patient requiring major amputation during the follow-up period. Complications such as graft infection, anastomotic pseudoaneurysm, and graft stenosis were observed in a small number of cases. This study suggests that DTAI/F bypass is a durable and effective treatment option for patients with occlusive disease in the descending thoracic aorta and iliac/femoral arteries, with good long-term outcomes.

Comparative clinical pharmacology of calcium channel blockers. Calcium channel blockers (CCBs) are widely used in the management of cardiovascular diseases. However, there are multiple subclasses of CCBs with varying pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic properties. This review aimed to compare the clinical pharmacology of different CCBs to guide prescribing decisions. Several factors were assessed, including onset and duration of action, extent of protein binding, metabolism pathway, half-life, and potential drug interactions. A comprehensive literature search was conducted to identify relevant studies comparing CCB subclasses. Overall, the findings suggest that each subclass of CCBs has unique characteristics that may influence their clinical utility. Understanding these differences is essential for optimizing therapy and minimizing adverse effects. Further research is warranted to expand our knowledge of the comparative clinical pharmacology of CCBs and their specific indications.

Intercostal arteriovenous fistula due to pleural biopsy A 32 year old woman had a pleural biopsy for a left pleural effusion, which showed caseating granuloma typical of tuberculosis. After the pleural biopsy, the patient developed an intercostal arteriovenous fistula, which is a rare complication. This was confirmed by imaging studies, which demonstrated an abnormal communication between the intercostal artery and vein. The patient presented with symptoms of dyspnea and hemoptysis. She underwent embolization of the fistula, which successfully resolved her symptoms. The case highlights the importance of considering intercostal arteriovenous fistula as a potential complication of pleural biopsy, especially in patients with findings suggestive of tuberculosis. Prompt recognition and management of this complication are crucial to prevent potentially serious consequences such as recurrent bleeding or further damage to the surrounding structures.

Ultrasonographic detection of the second-trimester fetus with trisomy 18 and trisomy 21. We present two cases of prenatal diagnosis of trisomy 18 and trisomy 21 using ultrasonography in the second trimester of pregnancy. In both cases, routine prenatal screening identified increased nuchal translucency and fetal anomalies on ultrasonographic examination. Amniocentesis confirmed the presence of trisomy 18 and trisomy 21, respectively. Trisomy 18, also known as Edwards syndrome, is characterized by severe developmental abnormalities and a high mortality rate. Trisomy 21, or Down syndrome, is associated with intellectual disability and multiple physical features. Ultrasonographic findings in both cases included structural abnormalities such as cardiac defects, brain anomalies, and limb abnormalities. Genetic counseling was provided to the families, addressing the clinical implications and management options available for the diagnosed conditions. These cases highlight the utility of ultrasonography as a valuable tool in the early detection and prenatal diagnosis of trisomy 18 and trisomy 21, allowing for informed decision-making and appropriate management of affected pregnancies.

Idiopathic sclerosing peritonitis in a man. Idiopathic sclerosing peritonitis (ISP) is a rare and poorly understood condition characterized by fibrosis and inflammation of the peritoneum. This abstract presents a case of ISP in a 52-year-old man who presented with abdominal pain, distension, and weight loss. Computed tomography scan revealed thickening and enhancement of the peritoneum. Surgical exploration showed diffuse fibrosis and adhesions involving the peritoneum. Histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of ISP. The patient was treated with immunosuppressive therapy, including corticosteroids and azathioprine, which resulted in improved symptoms and radiologic findings. ISP is a challenging diagnosis due to its rarity and nonspecific clinical presentation. Further research is needed to better understand the etiology, pathogenesis, and optimal management of this condition.

Malignant potential of juvenile polyposis coli. Juvenile polyposis coli is a rare syndrome characterized by the development of multiple juvenile polyps in the gastrointestinal tract. While these polyps are typically benign, there have been reports of malignant transformation occurring in a subset of patients. In this study, we aimed to evaluate the malignant potential of juvenile polyposis coli by analyzing the clinical and pathological features of patients with this condition. Our results showed that a significant proportion of patients with juvenile polyposis coli developed adenocarcinoma within the polyps, with a higher incidence in older patients and those with a family history of colorectal cancer. These findings highlight the importance of close surveillance and timely intervention in patients with juvenile polyposis coli to detect and manage any potential malignancy.

Dental enamel defects in first-degree relatives of coeliac disease patients. Coeliac disease is an autoimmune disorder that is associated with various extra-intestinal manifestations, including dental enamel defects.
