A total of 20 rats were divided into two groups: a control group and a distracted group exposed to auditory and visual distractions during a motor task. Distraction was found to significantly affect the integrity of the spinal cord as measured by evoked potentials, with the distracted group showing delayed and reduced amplitudes compared to the control group. Additionally, the distracted group exhibited signs of spinal cord ischemia and decreased clinical performance. These findings highlight the detrimental effects of distraction on spinal cord function and emphasize the need to minimize distractions in clinical settings to ensure optimal neurological outcomes.

The internal oblique-iliac crest free flap in composite defects of the oral cavity involving bone, skin, and mucosa. Composite defects of the oral cavity involving bone, skin, and mucosa present a significant challenge in reconstruction. This study aimed to evaluate the use of the internal oblique-iliac crest free flap in these cases. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 24 patients who underwent reconstruction with this flap following tumor resection. The overall success rate of flap survival was 91.7%. The flap provided excellent aesthetic and functional outcomes, allowing for proper restoration of oral competence and speech. Complications were minimal, with only one case of partial flap loss. The internal oblique-iliac crest free flap is a valuable option for composite defect reconstruction in the oral cavity.

Acute sensorineural deafness in Lassa fever A prospective audiometric evaluation of 69 hospitalized febrile patients in Sierra Leone, West Africa, revealed a sensorineural hearing deficit (SNHD) in 14 (29%) of 49 confirmed cases of Lassa fever and in 0 of 20 febrile controls. A prospective audiometric evaluation was conducted on 69 hospitalized febrile patients in Sierra Leone, West Africa, to assess the occurrence of acute sensorineural deafness (SNHD) in cases of Lassa fever. Out of the 49 confirmed cases of Lassa fever, 14 (29%) were found to have SNHD, while none of the 20 febrile controls showed any hearing deficit. This study demonstrates a significant association between Lassa fever and SNHD, highlighting the importance of prompt recognition and management of this complication. Further investigation is required to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and potential therapeutic interventions for preventing or treating SNHD in Lassa fever patients. Early identification and treatment of SNHD may contribute to better patient outcomes and reduce the burden of this debilitating condition.

Experience with photocoagulation in Behcet's disease. The efficacy of photocoagulation as a treatment for retinal complications in patients with Behcet's disease was investigated in a retrospective medical record review. A total of 32 eyes of 18 patients with ocular manifestations of Behcet's disease were included in the study. Photocoagulation was performed in 23 eyes, while the remaining 9 eyes served as controls. Among the eyes treated with photocoagulation, visual acuity improved or remained stable in 15 eyes (65.2%). In contrast, visual acuity worsened in 6 eyes (66.7%) in the control group. The most common complications observed were macular edema and vitreous hemorrhage. Photocoagulation demonstrated effectiveness in improving or stabilizing visual acuity in patients with Behcet's disease, highlighting its potential as a valuable treatment option for retinal complications in this patient population.

A double-masked evaluation of lignocaine-prilocaine cream (EMLA) used to alleviate the pain of retrobulbar injection A randomised, placebo controlled, double-masked study was undertaken in 115 patients undergoing cataract surgery to assess the efficacy of the anaesthetic cream EMLA (eutetic mixture of local anaesthetic, lignocaine-prilocaine) in alleviating the pain of retrobulbar injection. The patients were randomly assigned to receive either EMLA cream or a placebo cream applied to the injection site prior to the retrobulbar injection. Pain scores were assessed using a visual analog scale immediately after the injection. The mean pain score in the EMLA group was significantly lower compared to the placebo group (p<0.05). Additionally, the EMLA group reported a higher satisfaction rate with the pain relief provided. The use of EMLA cream appears to be effective in reducing the pain associated with retrobulbar injection during cataract surgery.

Deterioration following delay in performing femoral angioplasty.  It is not uncommon for a delay to occur between assessment arteriography and angioplasty attempt. Femoral angioplasty is a commonly performed procedure for the treatment of arterial blockages in the lower extremities. However, delays in performing this procedure can lead to deterioration of the patient's condition. In this study, we investigated the impact of delayed femoral angioplasty on patient outcomes. We found that a delay between assessment arteriography and the actual angioplasty attempt was associated with a higher risk of deterioration in patients with arterial blockages. Factors such as increased pain, impaired mobility, and progression of the underlying arterial disease were observed in patients who experienced a delay. These findings highlight the importance of timely intervention to optimize patient outcomes in femoral angioplasty procedures. Further studies are needed to identify strategies for minimizing delays and improving patient care in this context.

Brain magnetic resonance imaging and neuropsychologic evaluation of patients with idiopathic dilated cardiomyopathy.  We compared brain magnetic resonance imaging and neuropsychologic performance in 20 neurologically asymptomatic patients suffering from idiopathic dilated cardiomyopathy (mean age 41 [range 18-49] years) and 20 age-matched controls (mean age 38 [range 28-49] years).  Patients exhibited a significantly higher rate of cerebral infarcts (20% versus 0%, p less than 0. In this study, we examined the brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) findings and neuropsychologic performance of patients with idiopathic dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM). A total of 20 neurologically asymptomatic patients with DCM, aged between 18 and 49 years, were compared to 20 age-matched controls. The patients with DCM exhibited a significantly higher rate of cerebral infarcts compared to the control group (20% versus 0%, p < 0.001). Furthermore, the patients with DCM had lower scores on neuropsychologic evaluation, particularly in domains related to executive function and memory. Our findings suggest that patients with idiopathic DCM may be at increased risk for cerebral infarcts and cognitive impairment, warranting further investigation and early intervention strategies.

Parietal cell vagotomy and dilatation for peptic duodenal stricture.  Gastric outlet obstruction due to peptic duodenal stricture (pyloric stenosis) was treated with parietal cell vagotomy and dilatation of the stricture in 32 patients.  Follow-up is in the range of 5 years in 37. The combination of parietal cell vagotomy and dilatation of peptic duodenal strictures was performed on 32 patients with gastric outlet obstruction. Follow-up was conducted for a period of 5 years with a total of 37 patients. The procedure involved vagotomy to reduce gastric acid secretion and dilation of the stricture to alleviate the obstruction. The success rate of the procedure was evaluated based on the resolution of symptoms and improvement in gastric emptying. Overall, the combination approach proved to be effective in relieving the gastric outlet obstruction caused by peptic duodenal strictures.

Trends in conserving treatment of invasive carcinoma of the breast in females. This study aimed to determine the trends in conserving treatment of invasive carcinoma of the breast in females over a specific time period. The medical records of 500 female patients diagnosed with invasive breast carcinoma between 2000 and 2010 were retrospectively reviewed. The data extracted included patient demographics, tumor characteristics, and treatment modalities received. The results demonstrated a significant increase in the utilization of conserving treatment, such as breast-conserving surgery (BCS) followed by radiation therapy (RT), throughout the study period. The proportion of patients undergoing BCS with RT increased from 45% in 2000 to 65% in 2010. This trend was observed across different age groups, stages of disease, and hormone receptor statuses. The findings suggest a shift towards more conservative approaches in the treatment of invasive breast carcinoma in females, highlighting the importance of multidisciplinary decision-making and patient-centered care in achieving optimal outcomes for these patients.

The effect of omental pedicle graft transfer on spinal microcirculation and laminectomy membrane formation.  The properties of the omentum and its effect on spinal neurologic disease was investigated. The omentum has long been recognized for its unique properties including abundant blood supply, immunomodulatory effects, and angiogenic capacity. This study aimed to investigate the effect of omental pedicle graft transfer on spinal microcirculation and laminectomy membrane formation in a rat model. Twenty-four rats underwent laminectomy at the L4-L5 level, followed by omental pedicle graft transfer in half of the animals. Microscopic evaluation of the laminectomy site revealed significantly improved microcirculation and reduced formation of laminectomy membrane in the omental graft group compared to the control group. These findings suggest that omental pedicle graft transfer may be a promising therapeutic strategy for spinal neurologic disease.

Successful liver transplantation in a patient with a thrombosed portomesenteric system after multiple failed shunts. The authors present a case of successful liver transplantation in a patient with portal hypertension due to a thrombosed portomesenteric system after multiple failed shunts. The patient was a 46-year-old man with a history of alcoholic cirrhosis and portal vein thrombosis. Despite multiple attempts at shunt procedures, the patient continued to experience recurrent variceal bleeding. Liver transplantation was deemed necessary due to worsening liver function and recurrent episodes of hepatic encephalopathy. The surgical procedure involved resection of the thrombosed portomesenteric system and anastomosis of the donor liver to the recipient's hepatic artery, portal vein, and bile duct. The patient had an uneventful postoperative course and remains free of variceal bleeding and hepatic encephalopathy at the 6-month follow-up visit. This case highlights the successful management of portal hypertension and thrombosed portomesenteric system through liver transplantation in a challenging patient population.

Late relapse with nodular lymphoma after treatment for diffuse non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. Late relapse after treatment for diffuse non-Hodgkin's lymphoma (DLBCL) is a well-recognized entity. However, the occurrence of nodular lymphoma (NL) as a late relapse following DLBCL treatment is relatively rare. We report a case study of a patient who initially presented with DLBCL and achieved complete remission following multi-agent chemotherapy and radiation therapy. Eight years later, the patient developed NL in a different anatomic location. A comprehensive review of the literature revealed only a few cases of NL as a late relapse after DLBCL treatment. The pathogenesis and optimal management of such cases remain poorly understood. Further studies are warranted to better understand the factors contributing to this unique pattern of relapse and to guide treatment decisions.

The freckle sign--an endoscopic feature of the cecum. The "freckle sign" is a newly identified endoscopic feature of the cecum. It refers to small, brownish spots that can be seen on the surface of the cecal mucosa during endoscopy. This sign is thought to be associated with inflammation and may serve as a potential marker for certain gastrointestinal conditions. A retrospective analysis of 150 endoscopy procedures was conducted to evaluate the prevalence and significance of the freckle sign. Results showed that the freckle sign was present in 30% of cases, with a higher prevalence in patients with inflammatory bowel disease and colorectal cancer. Further studies are needed to determine the exact etiology and clinical implications of the freckle sign, but it has the potential to aid in the diagnosis and management of gastrointestinal disorders.

Lipolytic factors associated with murine and human cancer cachexia. Cachexia is a common and debilitating syndrome often seen in cancer patients, characterized by weight loss, muscle wasting, and metabolic abnormalities. Lipolytic factors, responsible for the breakdown of fat stores, have been implicated in the development of cancer cachexia. In this study, we investigated the association between lipolytic factors and cancer cachexia in both murine and human models.

In a murine model of cancer cachexia, we analyzed the expression of lipolytic factors in adipose tissue during tumor progression. We found that levels of lipolytic factors, such as adipose triglyceride lipase (ATGL) and hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL), were significantly increased in cachectic mice compared to controls. Furthermore, inhibition of ATGL and HSL attenuated weight loss and muscle wasting in cachectic mice.

In human cancer patients, we measured circulating levels of lipolytic factors and correlated them with clinical parameters of cachexia. We observed elevated levels of ATGL and HSL in cachectic patients compared to non-cachectic individuals. Moreover, higher levels of these lipolytic factors were associated with greater weight loss and muscle wasting in cancer patients.

Our findings suggest that lipolytic factors play a critical role in the development of cancer cachexia. Targeting these factors may represent a potential therapeutic strategy for managing cachexia and improving patient outcomes. Further research is warranted to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and develop targeted interventions for this devastating syndrome.

Molteno implants and operating microscope-induced retinal phototoxicity. This study aimed to investigate the potential retinal phototoxicity induced by Molteno implants surgery under the operating microscope. A total of 45 eyes of 45 patients who underwent Molteno implants surgery were included in the study. All patients were evaluated for retinal changes before and after surgery, including visual acuity, macular thickness, and retinal sensitivity. The study found that 13 eyes (28.9%) developed retinal phototoxicity after surgery, evidenced by decreased visual acuity, increased macular thickness, and decreased retinal sensitivity. The severity of retinal changes was positively correlated with both the duration of surgery and the intensity of light exposure. The use of protective measures, such as intraocular filters and low-intensity light sources, may reduce the risk of retinal phototoxicity during Molteno implants surgery. Further investigation is needed to develop guidelines for minimizing this potential complication.

Otitis media in day-care children. This study examines the incidence and risk factors for otitis media in day-care children. A total of 500 children aged 6 months to 5 years attending day-care centers were followed for a period of 1 year. The incidence of otitis media was determined through regular otoscopic examinations and parental reports of symptoms. Analysis of risk factors included age, sex, attendance at day-care center, presence of siblings, breastfeeding history, and exposure to passive smoking.

The overall incidence of otitis media in the study population was 45%, with a higher prevalence in children aged less than 2 years (60%). Attendance at day-care centers was found to be a significant risk factor, with children spending more hours in day-care exhibiting a higher incidence of otitis media. Presence of siblings and exposure to passive smoking also significantly increased the risk.

These findings suggest that day-care attendance, presence of siblings, and exposure to passive smoking are important risk factors for otitis media in young children. Early identification and intervention strategies targeting these factors may help reduce the burden of otitis media in day-care settings.

Micromotion of cemented and uncemented femoral components. Micromotion of femoral components in total hip arthroplasty is a common concern that may lead to implant loosening and failure. This study aimed to compare the micromotion of cemented and uncemented femoral components in a cohort of patients undergoing total hip arthroplasty. A total of 50 patients were included in the study, with 25 receiving a cemented femoral component and 25 receiving an uncemented femoral component. Micromotion of the femoral component was measured using radiostereometric analysis at various time points postoperatively. The results showed significantly higher micromotion in the uncemented group compared to the cemented group at all time points. This finding suggests that cemented femoral components provide more stability and reduce micromotion in total hip arthroplasty. Further research is needed to investigate the long-term clinical implications of these findings.

Posterior transfer of the adductors in children who have cerebral palsy.  A long-term study. Cerebral palsy (CP) is a neurological disorder characterized by abnormal muscle tone, posture, and movement. The adductor muscles of the hip are commonly affected, leading to scissoring gait and difficulty with ambulation. Surgical intervention, such as posterior transfer of the adductors, may be considered to improve functional outcomes in these patients. This long-term study aimed to evaluate the outcomes of posterior adductor transfer in children with CP. A total of 50 patients who underwent the procedure were followed for an average of 10 years. The study assessed changes in gait, muscle tone, and range of motion postoperatively. Overall, the results demonstrated significant improvements in gait pattern, reduction in muscle tone, and increased range of motion in the hip joint. These findings suggest that posterior adductor transfer is an effective surgical intervention for children with CP, providing long-term functional benefits. Further research is needed to explore additional factors influencing outcomes and refine surgical techniques.

Amebic meningoencephalitis in a patient with AIDS caused by a newly recognized opportunistic pathogen.  Leptomyxid ameba. We present a case report of amebic meningoencephalitis in a patient with acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS) caused by a newly recognized opportunistic pathogen, Leptomyxid ameba. The patient, a 45-year-old male with a history of intravenous drug use and unprotected sexual activity, presented with symptoms of headache, confusion, and seizures. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis revealed an elevated white blood cell count and protein level, and magnetic resonance imaging showed multiple enhancing lesions in the brain. A cerebrospinal fluid culture grew an organism identified as Leptomyxid ameba, a rare and poorly understood pathogen. The patient was started on antimicrobial therapy including amphotericin B, but unfortunately, his condition rapidly deteriorated and he succumbed to the disease within a week of presentation. This case highlights the importance of considering opportunistic infections in patients with AIDS who present with neurological symptoms, especially when conventional pathogens are not identified. Further research is needed to better understand the epidemiology, pathogenesis, and treatment options for Leptomyxid ameba infections.

Multiple noncontiguous spine fractures.  The data from a prospective study of 508 spine injuries were reviewed to determine the incidence of multiple noncontiguous spine fractures. This study aimed to determine the incidence of multiple noncontiguous spine fractures in a prospective cohort of 508 patients with spine injuries. Patient demographics, mechanism of injury, clinical presentation, imaging findings, and treatment outcomes were analyzed. Of the 508 patients included in the study, 28 (5.5%) were found to have multiple noncontiguous spine fractures. The most common mechanism of injury was motor vehicle accidents (46%), followed by falls (25%) and sports-related injuries (18%). Patients with multiple noncontiguous fractures had a higher injury severity score and longer hospital stays compared to those with a single fracture. This study highlights the importance of recognizing and appropriately managing multiple noncontiguous spine fractures to optimize patient outcomes.

Sequential esophageal motility studies after endoscopic injection sclerotherapy: a prospective investigation.  To assess prospectively the effects of endoscopic intravariceal sclerosis (EIS) on esophageal function, we performed esophageal manometry on 13 cirrhotic patients before EIS, 24 h after the second session and 4 wk after the fourth session. The aim of this study was to evaluate the impact of endoscopic intravariceal sclerosis (EIS) on esophageal motility through sequential esophageal motility studies. Thirteen cirrhotic patients were included in this prospective investigation. Esophageal manometry was performed prior to EIS, 24 hours after the second session, and 4 weeks after the fourth session. The study revealed that EIS had a significant effect on esophageal function. There was a noticeable decrease in esophageal peristalsis and lower esophageal sphincter tone after EIS administration. These changes were observed immediately after the second session and persisted even after 4 weeks. These findings suggest that EIS can impact esophageal motility, potentially leading to functional impairments. Further research should be conducted to evaluate the long-term effects of EIS on esophageal function and to identify appropriate management strategies for such complications.

Risk of cancer death in first-degree relatives of patients with hereditary non-polyposis cancer syndrome (Lynch type II): a study of 130 kindreds in the United Kingdom. This study aimed to determine the risk of cancer death in first-degree relatives of patients diagnosed with hereditary non-polyposis cancer syndrome (HNPCC) type II, also known as Lynch syndrome. A total of 130 kindreds from the United Kingdom were included in the study. Information regarding family history and cancer deaths was collected through interviews and medical records. The results showed that first-degree relatives of HNPCC type II patients had a significantly higher risk of cancer-related death compared to the general population. The risk was highest for colorectal cancer, with an age-standardized mortality ratio of 4.53 (95% confidence interval, 3.42-5.96). The risk was also elevated for several other cancer types, including endometrial, ovarian, and gastric cancers. These findings emphasize the importance of surveillance and preventive strategies for individuals with a family history of HNPCC type II.

Managing geriatric arrhythmias, II: Drug selection and use [published erratum appears in Geriatrics 1991 Jun;46(6):100] Age-related impairments in antiarrhythmic drug distribution, metabolism, and excretion may result in accumulation of these potent drugs, increasing the risk of adverse drug reactions and drug interactions in the elderly. This article focuses on the management of arrhythmias in the geriatric population, specifically discussing drug selection and use. Age-related changes in the body can affect the distribution, metabolism, and excretion of antiarrhythmic drugs, leading to potential drug accumulation and an increased risk of adverse reactions and drug interactions in older individuals. The article highlights the importance of considering these factors when prescribing antiarrhythmic medications to geriatric patients and provides recommendations for appropriate drug selection and dosing in this population. The goal is to optimize treatment outcomes while minimizing the potential for harm in this vulnerable patient group.

Hashimoto's encephalopathy: a steroid-responsive disorder associated with high anti-thyroid antibody titers--report of 5 cases. Hashimoto's encephalopathy (HE) is a rare neurologic disorder characterized by symptoms such as seizures, cognitive impairment, and behavioral changes. Although it primarily affects individuals with Hashimoto's thyroiditis, a thyroid autoimmune disease, the pathophysiology of HE remains unclear. This study reports on five cases of HE, all of which had high anti-thyroid antibody titers. All patients presented with various neurologic symptoms, including seizures, psychosis, and cognitive decline. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) showed abnormalities in two patients, including subcortical white matter changes and hippocampal atrophy. Treatment with corticosteroids resulted in significant clinical improvement in all cases. The positive response to steroids, along with the high anti-thyroid antibody titers, supports the autoimmune nature of HE. This report emphasizes the importance of recognizing HE as a potential etiology for neurologic symptoms in patients with Hashimoto's thyroiditis and highlights the efficacy of corticosteroid therapy in managing this condition.

Cholecystokinin enhanced hepatobiliary scanning with ejection fraction calculation as an indicator of disease of the gallbladder. Cholecystokinin enhanced hepatobiliary scanning with ejection fraction calculation has been widely used as a diagnostic tool for diseases of the gallbladder. This study aimed to evaluate the feasibility and accuracy of this technique in the detection of gallbladder diseases. A total of 100 patients with suspected gallbladder diseases underwent cholecystokinin enhanced hepatobiliary scanning with ejection fraction calculation. The results were compared with the gold standard diagnostic methods such as ultrasound and histopathological examination. The sensitivity and specificity of the cholecystokinin enhanced hepatobiliary scanning with ejection fraction calculation were found to be 90% and 85%, respectively. These findings support the use of this technique as an effective tool for the diagnosis of gallbladder diseases, providing valuable information for the selection of appropriate treatment strategies.

A cellist with arm pain: thermal asymmetry in scalenus anticus syndrome.  We report on a cellist with pain and coldness of the upper extremity. This case report discusses a unique presentation of scalenus anticus syndrome (SAS) in a cellist presenting with arm pain and coldness. The patient was a 28-year-old female who complained of worsening pain and cold sensation in her left arm while playing the cello. Physical examination revealed a thermal asymmetry with a notable decrease in temperature on the affected side. Diagnostic workup included electromyography, which showed abnormal electrophysiological findings consistent with neurogenic changes. A computed tomography (CT) scan of the thoracic outlet was performed, which revealed an abnormal insertion of the scalenus anticus muscle causing compression of the brachial plexus. The patient was subsequently treated with physical therapy and underwent surgical decompression of the thoracic outlet with excellent outcome. This case highlights the importance of considering SAS as a cause of upper extremity pain and thermal asymmetry, especially in musicians who frequently engage in repetitive upper limb activities.

Massive allografts in salvage revisions of failed total knee arthroplasties.  Ten patients with failed total knee arthroplasties and severe bone loss were treated with massive whole distal femur and proximal tibial allografts in combination with prosthetic implants. Massive bone loss is a challenging issue in revision total knee arthroplasty (TKA) and can compromise the stability and longevity of prosthetic implants. To address this problem, we present a case series of ten patients who underwent salvage revisions of failed TKA using massive allografts combined with prosthetic implants. The allografts consisted of whole distal femur and proximal tibia, addressing both bone loss and structural defects. All patients were followed up for at least two years, and clinical, radiographic, and functional outcomes were evaluated. Our results demonstrate that the use of massive allografts in combination with prosthetic implants can provide satisfactory stability and functional outcomes in patients with severe bone loss. Further studies are warranted to establish the long-term efficacy and safety of this procedure.

Controlled trial of antimycobacterial therapy in Crohn's disease.  Clofazimine versus placebo. Crohn's disease is a chronic inflammatory bowel disease characterized by transmural inflammation of the gastrointestinal tract. Recent studies have suggested a potential association between Mycobacterium avium subspecies paratuberculosis (MAP) and Crohn's disease. This controlled trial aimed to evaluate the efficacy of antimycobacterial therapy in the management of Crohn's disease.

A total of 80 patients with active Crohn's disease were randomly assigned to receive either clofazimine, an antimycobacterial agent, or placebo for a duration of 12 weeks. The primary endpoint was the clinical response, defined as a reduction in Crohn's Disease Activity Index (CDAI) score of 70 points or remission, at week 12.

The results showed that patients receiving clofazimine had a significantly higher clinical response rate compared to those receiving placebo (62.5% vs. 32.5%, p=0.029). Moreover, the proportion of patients achieving remission was also higher in the clofazimine group (37.5% vs. 17.5%, p=0.046).

In conclusion, this controlled trial provides evidence for the efficacy of antimycobacterial therapy, specifically clofazimine, in the management of active Crohn's disease. Further research is needed to elucidate the exact mechanism of action and long-term effects of antimycobacterial therapy in this patient population.

Blue breath holding is benign. Blue breath holding is a benign phenomenon commonly observed in young children. It is characterized by a sudden, involuntary breath holding episode that is often preceded by a minor emotional or physical stimuli, such as frustration, pain, or startle. During these episodes, the child's face turns blue or pale, they lose consciousness, and may experience muscle stiffness or jerking. However, the child spontaneously recovers within a minute without any long-term sequelae. The underlying mechanism of blue breath holding involves an involuntary reflexive apnea followed by a Valsalva maneuver. Although frightening for parents and caregivers, blue breath holding is generally harmless and does not require specific intervention or treatment. Education and reassurance are essential in managing and alleviating parental anxiety associated with this phenomenon.

Left ventricular diastolic dysfunction presenting as ascites: the importance of clinically assessing central venous pressure. Diastolic dysfunction of the left ventricle is a common finding in patients with heart failure. However, the presentation of ascites as the initial manifestation of diastolic dysfunction is not well documented in the literature. We present a case of a 62-year-old female who presented with progressive abdominal distension and dyspnea on exertion. Physical examination revealed ascites, but no other signs of heart failure. Further evaluation, including echocardiography, demonstrated preserved systolic function but severe diastolic dysfunction. The measurement of central venous pressure, which was markedly elevated, was crucial in making the diagnosis. This case highlights the importance of considering diastolic dysfunction as a potential cause of ascites and the utility of clinically assessing central venous pressure in these patients.

Excitatory amino acids in the developing brain: ontogeny, plasticity, and excitotoxicity. Excitatory amino acids play a crucial role in the developing brain, influencing neurodevelopment, plasticity, and excitotoxicity. This article provides an overview of the ontogeny of excitatory amino acids, focusing on the changes that occur during different stages of brain development. Glutamate is the primary excitatory neurotransmitter in the central nervous system, and its receptors undergo significant developmental changes, leading to dynamic alterations in synaptic plasticity and neuronal excitability. However, excessive activation of excitatory amino acid receptors can lead to excitotoxicity, a pathological process associated with various neurological disorders. This article explores the mechanisms underlying excitotoxicity and its implications in neurodevelopmental disorders. Understanding the intricate balance of excitatory amino acid signaling during brain development is essential for identifying potential therapeutic targets to mitigate the detrimental effects of excitotoxicity.

Fresnel prisms improve visual perception in stroke patients with homonymous hemianopia or unilateral visual neglect. Homonymous hemianopia and unilateral visual neglect are common visual deficits seen in stroke patients. These deficits can significantly impact visual perception and daily functioning. This study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Fresnel prisms in improving visual perception in stroke patients with these visual deficits. 

A total of 30 stroke patients with either homonymous hemianopia or unilateral visual neglect were included in the study. Each patient received a pair of Fresnel prisms, which were attached to their eyeglasses. Visual perception was assessed using standardized visual perception tests before and after wearing the prisms for a period of one month. 

The results demonstrated a significant improvement in visual perception in both groups of patients after wearing the prisms. Specifically, patients with homonymous hemianopia showed improvement in visual field awareness, while patients with unilateral visual neglect showed improvement in attention and awareness towards the neglected side. 

These findings suggest that Fresnel prisms can be an effective intervention in improving visual perception in stroke patients with homonymous hemianopia or unilateral visual neglect. Further studies are warranted to determine the long-term effects and optimal duration of prism use in these patients.

Adjunctive use of beta-adrenergic blockers, calcium antagonists and other therapies in coronary thrombolysis. In the setting of coronary thrombolysis, adjunctive therapies such as beta-adrenergic blockers and calcium antagonists have been explored to enhance the efficacy and safety of the treatment. This review aimed to evaluate the evidence on the use of these therapies as part of the management strategy. Several randomized controlled trials and meta-analyses were included in the analysis. The findings showed that the adjunctive use of beta-antagonists and calcium antagonists in combination with thrombolysis led to improved outcomes, including reduced mortality and decreased incidence of reinfarction. However, caution should be exercised as these therapies may also be associated with adverse effects such as hypotension and bradycardia. Further studies are warranted to better understand the optimal timing, dosing, and patient selection for adjunctive therapies in coronary thrombolysis.

Relationship among level of distraction, evoked potentials, spinal cord ischemia and integrity, and clinical status in animals. This study aimed to investigate the relationship among the level of distraction, evoked potentials, spinal cord ischemia and integrity, and clinical status in animals. A total of 40 animals were used in this experiment and were divided into four groups based on the level of distraction: no distraction (control), low distraction, moderate distraction, and high distraction. Evoked potentials, including somatosensory evoked potentials (SSEPs) and motor evoked potentials (MEPs), were recorded before and after spinal cord distraction. Spinal cord ischemia and integrity were assessed using histopathological analysis and immunohistochemistry staining. Clinical status was evaluated using a neurological scoring system. The results showed a significant correlation between the level of distraction and changes in evoked potentials, spinal cord ischemia, and clinical status. These findings suggest that the level of distraction plays a crucial role in spinal cord function and integrity, highlighting the importance of minimizing distraction during spinal surgeries to prevent postoperative neurological complications.

Perianal appearances associated with constipation.  The perianal appearances were studied prospectively of 136 constipated children (mean age 3. The perianal appearances of 136 constipated children (mean age 3.8 years) were studied prospectively to investigate their association with constipation. The majority of children (85%) presented with perianal findings, such as perianal erythema (67%), maceration (41%), and fissures (24%). These findings were significantly more prevalent in children with chronic constipation compared to those with intermittent constipation. Furthermore, the severity of perianal erythema and maceration was found to be positively correlated with the duration and severity of constipation. There was also a positive association between the presence of fissures and the frequency of constipation episodes per week. These findings suggest that perianal appearances, specifically perianal erythema, maceration, and fissures, are common in constipated children and may serve as indicators of the severity and chronicity of constipation. Therefore, the identification and management of these perianal findings should be an integral part of the evaluation and treatment of children with constipation.

Fluorometric determination of pseudocholinesterase activity in postmortem blood samples.  A fluorometric assay using 3-(p-hydroxyphenyl) propionic acid (HPPA) was conducted to determine the activity of pseudocholinesterase (ChE) [Enzyme Commission (EC) No. Pseudocholinesterase activity in postmortem blood samples can provide important information in forensic investigations. In this study, a fluorometric assay using 3-(p-hydroxyphenyl) propionic acid (HPPA) was utilized to determine pseudocholinesterase activity in postmortem blood samples. Pseudocholinesterase (ChE) is an enzyme that hydrolyzes choline esters and plays a significant role in the metabolism of certain drugs and toxins. The assay method presented in this study demonstrated good sensitivity and reliability in detecting pseudocholinesterase activity in postmortem blood samples. The results obtained can aid in determining the cause of death and evaluating the effects of specific drugs or poisons. The potential applications of this assay in forensic science and toxicology are discussed.

Intravenous but not intracolonic epidermal growth factor maintains colonocyte proliferation in defunctioned rat colorectum. To investigate the effect of intravenous (IV) and intracolonic (IC) epidermal growth factor (EGF) on colonocyte proliferation in the defunctioned rat colorectum, a study was conducted on 20 male rats. The rats were divided into four groups: control, IV EGF, IC EGF, and IC phosphate-buffered saline (PBS). The rats in the IV EGF and IC EGF groups received 50 g/kg of EGF while the control and IC PBS groups received equivalent volumes of PBS. After 14 days, colon tissue biopsy specimens were obtained and analyzed for proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA) and Ki-67 expression. The results showed that IV EGF significantly increased PCNA and Ki-67 expression, indicating increased colonocyte proliferation, compared to the control and IC PBS groups. However, IC EGF did not show a significant effect on colonocyte proliferation. Therefore, it was concluded that IV, but not IC, administration of EGF maintains colonocyte proliferation in the defunctioned rat colorectum.

Endoscopic ventricular fenestration using a "saline torch".  The fiberoptic endoscope has never gained popularity among neurosurgeons although it is ideally suited for navigating within the cerebral ventricles. Endoscopic ventricular fenestration is a procedure that is commonly performed in cases of hydrocephalus. However, the use of a fiberoptic endoscope for this purpose has met with limited acceptance among neurosurgeons. This study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and feasibility of endoscopic ventricular fenestration using a novel technique called the "saline torch". 

A total of 30 patients with hydrocephalus were included in this study. The procedure was performed under general anesthesia using a fiberoptic endoscope equipped with the saline torch. The saline torch consisted of a saline-filled catheter with an attached light source. The endoscope was inserted into the cerebral ventricles through a burr hole, and the saline torch was used to create a fenestration in the ventricular wall.

The results showed that endoscopic ventricular fenestration using the saline torch was successful in all cases. The procedure was associated with minimal intraoperative bleeding and no major complications were reported. Postoperative imaging confirmed the patency of the fenestration and demonstrated a significant reduction in ventricular size.

In conclusion, endoscopic ventricular fenestration using the saline torch is a safe and effective technique for the treatment of hydrocephalus. Further studies are warranted to evaluate its long-term outcomes and compare it to conventional surgical methods.

Wound infection following early repeat sternotomy for postoperative bleeding. This abstract presents a case of wound infection following early repeat sternotomy for postoperative bleeding. The patient underwent cardiac surgery and developed postoperative bleeding requiring a repeat sternotomy within 48 hours. The patient initially had an uneventful recovery but subsequently developed a wound infection at the incision site, manifesting as erythema, swelling, and purulent discharge. The wound cultures grew Staphylococcus aureus, indicating a healthcare-associated infection. Treatment involved surgical debridement, empiric antibiotic therapy, and wound care. Risk factors for infection in this case included the repeat sternotomy, prolonged operative time, the close proximity of the initial incision to the sternum, potential contamination during surgery, and the presence of a foreign body (surgical hardware). Early identification and management of surgical site infections are crucial to prevent complications such as mediastinitis and sepsis.

Relaxation training in school classes does not reduce headache complaints. The effectiveness of relaxation training in reducing headache complaints among school-aged children was investigated. A total of 200 students from two elementary schools were randomly assigned to either a relaxation training group or a control group. The relaxation training group received 12 weeks of relaxation exercises during school hours, while the control group continued their regular classes. Headache complaints were assessed using a self-report questionnaire at baseline and post-intervention. Results showed no significant difference in headache complaints between the relaxation training group and the control group at post-intervention. These findings suggest that relaxation training implemented in school settings may not be an effective strategy for reducing headache complaints among children.

Complications of general anesthesia for Nd:YAG laser resection of endobronchial tumors.  We studied the incidence and mechanisms of cardiovascular complications and postoperative respiratory insufficiency associated with GA and Nd:YAG laser endobronchial tumor resection. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 150 patients who underwent Nd:YAG laser resection of endobronchial tumors under general anesthesia (GA). The incidence and mechanisms of cardiovascular complications and postoperative respiratory insufficiency were evaluated. Cardiovascular complications, including arrhythmias and hypotension, were observed in 12% of patients and were predominantly attributed to the release of catecholamines following laser activation. Postoperative respiratory insufficiency occurred in 10% of patients and was attributed to airway obstruction due to edema and mucus plugging. Patients with preexisting cardiovascular and respiratory diseases were at higher risk for these complications. Strategies to minimize these complications included careful patient selection, optimization of preoperative cardiovascular and respiratory status, and close monitoring during and after the procedure. It is important for the anesthesia team to be aware of these potential complications and take appropriate measures to reduce their incidence and severity.

Natural history and cardiac manifestations of homozygous familial hypercholesterolaemia.  Forty-nine patients with homozygous familial hypercholesterolaemia (diagnosed on the basis of family history, xanthomatosis, total serum cholesterol and low-density lipoprotein receptor status) were studied over a period of 13 years, and underwent cardiovascular assessment. This study aimed to investigate the natural history and cardiac manifestations of homozygous familial hypercholesterolaemia (FH). A total of 49 patients with confirmed homozygous FH were followed for a period of 13 years. The patients were assessed for cardiovascular outcomes, including myocardial infarction, angina, and coronary artery bypass grafting. The study found that homozygous FH patients had a significantly increased risk of developing cardiovascular disease compared to the general population. The cumulative incidence of cardiovascular events was found to be 62% in males and 51% in females during the follow-up period. The majority of cardiovascular events occurred before the age of 40. These findings emphasize the need for early and aggressive management of homozygous FH to prevent or delay the onset of cardiovascular complications.

Radiation necrosis of the optic chiasm, optic tract, hypothalamus, and upper pons after radiotherapy for pituitary adenoma, detected by gadolinium-enhanced, T1-weighted magnetic resonance imaging: case report. We report a case of a 51-year-old male patient who presented with progressive vision loss following radiotherapy for pituitary adenoma. Gadolinium-enhanced, T1-weighted magnetic resonance imaging revealed significant radiation necrosis affecting the optic chiasm, optic tract, hypothalamus, and upper pons. The patient experienced visual field deficits, hormonal imbalances, and hypothalamic dysfunction. The clinical presentation, radiological findings, and histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of radiation necrosis. Treatment options for radiation necrosis were discussed, including corticosteroids and hyperbaric oxygen therapy. The patient showed partial improvement with corticosteroid treatment. This case highlights the potential complications associated with radiotherapy for pituitary adenoma and emphasizes the importance of long-term follow-up and monitoring for early detection of radiation necrosis.

Pancreatic ascites: treatment by continuous somatostatin infusion. Pancreatic ascites is a rare complication of pancreatitis characterized by the accumulation of fluid in the peritoneal cavity. Current treatment options are limited and often ineffective, leading to high morbidity and mortality rates. In this study, we evaluated the efficacy of continuous somatostatin infusion as a treatment for pancreatic ascites. 

Ten patients with pancreatic ascites refractory to conventional therapy were included in this retrospective analysis. Continuous infusion of somatostatin was initiated at a rate of 250 g/hour and adjusted based on clinical response. 

All patients showed a significant reduction in ascitic fluid volume within 48 hours of somatostatin infusion initiation. Complete resolution of pancreatic ascites was achieved in 70% of patients within 7 days of treatment. No major adverse events were reported during the treatment period.

These findings suggest that continuous somatostatin infusion is a safe and effective treatment option for pancreatic ascites refractory to conventional therapy. Further prospective studies are warranted to confirm these results and optimize the dosing regimen.

Management of posterior urethral strictures secondary to pelvic fractures in children.  Bulboprostatic anastomotic urethroplasty was performed in 20 children with posterior urethral strictures secondary to bony pelvic fractures. The age of the children ranged from 3 to 13 years. All patients presented with urinary symptoms and were evaluated with urethrography, cystoscopy, and retrograde urethrography. Bulboprostatic anastomotic urethroplasty was performed to reconstruct the posterior urethra. Sixteen patients had successful outcomes, with no recurrence of strictures or urinary symptoms during a follow-up period ranging from 6 to 36 months. Four patients had recurrent strictures and required additional procedures, including direct visual internal urethrotomy or dilation. Bulboprostatic anastomotic urethroplasty appears to be a reliable and effective treatment option for managing posterior urethral strictures secondary to pelvic fractures in children, leading to a high rate of success and minimal complications.

Acupuncture and chronic pain: a criteria-based meta-analysis. Acupuncture is commonly used as an adjunct therapy for chronic pain management, but its effectiveness remains controversial. We conducted a criteria-based meta-analysis to evaluate the efficacy of acupuncture in treating chronic pain. A comprehensive search of databases yielded 12 randomized controlled trials that met inclusion criteria. The primary outcomes measured were pain intensity and quality of life. Secondary outcomes included various pain-related measures such as sleep quality and functional status. The overall meta-analysis demonstrated a significant reduction in pain intensity in patients receiving acupuncture compared to controls (p<0.01). Quality of life and other pain-related outcomes also showed significant improvement with acupuncture treatment. These results support the use of acupuncture as an effective therapy for chronic pain, but further high-quality studies are needed to confirm these findings and explore potential mechanisms of action.

Carcinoma of the pancreas: a retrospective review.  Eighty-five patients with adenocarcinoma of the pancreas were reviewed in order to evaluate the efficacy of our methods of diagnosis and treatment. A retrospective review of eighty-five patients diagnosed with adenocarcinoma of the pancreas was conducted to assess the effectiveness of our diagnostic and treatment approaches. The study included patients ranging in age from 40 to 80 years, with a mean age of 65 years. The majority of patients presented with nonspecific symptoms such as abdominal pain, weight loss, and jaundice. Advanced imaging techniques including computed tomography (CT) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) were used for diagnosis, complemented by biopsy confirmation in most cases. A multidisciplinary approach involving surgical resection, chemotherapy, and/or radiation therapy was employed in the treatment of these patients. The overall survival rate at 1-year follow-up was 25%, with a median survival time of 10 months. These findings emphasize the challenges associated with the diagnosis and management of pancreatic adenocarcinoma, highlighting the need for early detection strategies and novel therapeutic interventions.

Acute respiratory tract infection in children in Idikan Community, Ibadan, Nigeria: severity, risk factors, and frequency of occurrence.  A longitudinal, community-based study of the epidemiology of acute respiratory tract infection (ARI) in children less than 5 years old was carried out in a community of low socioeconomic level in Ibadan, Nigeria. This study aimed to determine the severity, risk factors, and frequency of occurrence of acute respiratory tract infection (ARI) in children less than 5 years old in the Idikan Community of Ibadan, Nigeria. A longitudinal, community-based approach was employed to assess the epidemiology of ARI in this low socioeconomic level community. Data was collected over a period of time to evaluate the severity of ARI, identify potential risk factors, and determine the frequency of ARI occurrence in the study population. The results of this study will provide valuable insights into the burden of ARI in this community and inform strategies for prevention and management.

Achieving pH control in the critically ill patient: the role of continuous infusion of H2-receptor antagonists. Acid-base disturbances are common in critically ill patients and can lead to significant morbidity and mortality. Achieving pH control is essential for optimal patient outcomes. H2-receptor antagonists, such as ranitidine or famotidine, have been used for the treatment of gastric hyperacidity in the critically ill. This review aimed to evaluate the role of continuous infusion of H2-receptor antagonists in achieving pH control in critically ill patients. Existing literature suggests that continuous infusion of these agents can effectively reduce gastric acid secretion and maintain optimal pH levels. However, further research is needed to establish the ideal dosing strategies and potential side effects of this approach.

Obstructing carcinoma of the cecum. Obstructing carcinoma of the cecum refers to a malignancy that causes obstruction in the cecum, the first part of the large intestine. This condition often presents with abdominal pain, bloating, and changes in bowel habits. It requires prompt medical intervention as it can lead to bowel perforation or severe complications if left untreated. Diagnosis is usually made through imaging studies such as computed tomography (CT) scans or colonoscopy, followed by confirmatory biopsy. Treatment options include surgical resection of the tumor, which can be curative in early-stage disease, or palliative measures for advanced cases. Adjuvant chemotherapy may also be considered to reduce the risk of recurrence. Overall, the prognosis for obstructing carcinoma of the cecum varies depending on the stage and individual patient factors.

Unusually late onset of cerebrospinal fluid rhinorrhea after head trauma. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) rhinorrhea is a rare complication following head trauma, typically occurring within the first few days. We present a case of an unusually late onset of CSF rhinorrhea, which manifested six months after the initial injury. A 34-year-old male sustained a head injury during a motor vehicle accident and subsequently developed persistent clear nasal discharge. Imaging studies confirmed the presence of a frontal skull base defect and CSF leak. Endoscopic repair of the defect was performed, resulting in resolution of the rhinorrhea. This case serves as a reminder that CSF rhinorrhea should be considered in the differential diagnosis of persistent clear nasal discharge, even if it occurs several months after the initial head trauma.

Monomorphic adenomas of the major salivary glands: clinicopathological study of 44 cases. We conducted a clinicopathological study of 44 cases of monomorphic adenomas of the major salivary glands. Patients presented with various clinical symptoms, including painless swelling, facial nerve palsy, and mucous discharge. Histological examination revealed distinct cellular patterns, with tubular, trabecular, and solid growth patterns being the most common. Immunohistochemical staining showed positivity for cytokeratin and S100 protein. Surgical excision was the primary treatment modality, with recurrence occurring in 23.5% of cases. Malignant transformation was observed in 4.5% of cases, primarily in older patients. Our study highlights the importance of accurate diagnosis and appropriate management of monomorphic adenomas to minimize recurrence and prevent malignant transformation.

Questionable role of CNS radioprophylaxis in the therapeutic management of childhood rhabdomyosarcoma with meningeal extension. Meningeal extension in rhabdomyosarcoma is a rare occurrence and its optimal management remains unclear. This study aims to investigate the therapeutic role of central nervous system (CNS) radioprophylaxis in childhood rhabdomyosarcoma with meningeal extension. A retrospective review was conducted on pediatric patients diagnosed with rhabdomyosarcoma and meningeal extension between 2000 and 2018. A total of 32 patients met the inclusion criteria. Patients were divided into two groups: those who received CNS radioprophylaxis (n=18) and those who did not (n=14). The median follow-up period was 3.5 years. The addition of CNS radioprophylaxis did not show a significant improvement in overall survival (OS) (p=0.658) or event-free survival (EFS) (p=0.918). Furthermore, no significant difference was observed in the incidence of leptomeningeal relapse between the two groups (p=0.246). These findings suggest a questionable role of CNS radioprophylaxis in the therapeutic management of childhood rhabdomyosarcoma with meningeal extension. Further prospective studies are warranted to clarify the optimal treatment approach for these patients.

Role of ultrasound guided fine needle aspiration biopsy in the diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma. This retrospective study aimed to evaluate the role of ultrasound-guided fine needle aspiration biopsy (FNAB) in the diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). The study included 75 patients with suspected HCC based on imaging findings. FNAB was performed following a standardized protocol, and the cytological samples were analyzed for the presence of malignant cells. The results were compared with the final histopathological diagnosis obtained through surgical resection or liver transplantation. FNAB showed a sensitivity of 86.7% and a specificity of 97.1% in diagnosing HCC. The positive predictive value and negative predictive value were 95.7% and 92.3%, respectively. These findings suggest that ultrasound-guided FNAB is a reliable and accurate diagnostic tool for HCC, providing valuable information for treatment planning.

Hyperglycemia presenting with occipital seizures.  Seizures are common in hyperglycemia and are often the first manifestation, particularly in nonketotic hyperglycemia (NKH). This case report presents a rare manifestation of hyperglycemia in the form of occipital seizures. A 42-year-old male with a history of uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus presented with sudden-onset visual disturbances and bilateral occipital seizures. Laboratory findings revealed significantly elevated blood glucose levels, confirming the diagnosis of hyperglycemia. The patient was initially managed with intravenous fluids and insulin therapy, resulting in rapid normalization of blood glucose levels and resolution of the seizures. Neuroimaging studies were unremarkable, ruling out structural causes. This case highlights the importance of considering hyperglycemia as a potential cause of seizures, especially occipital seizures, in patients with known diabetes or risk factors for hyperglycemia. Prompt recognition and treatment of hyperglycemia are crucial in preventing further neurological complications and improving patient outcomes. Further research is needed to elucidate the underlying pathophysiology and optimal management strategies for this rare presentation of hyperglycemia.

Propranolol and the morning increase in sudden cardiac death: (the beta-blocker heart attack trial experience).  To provide insight into the protective effect of propranolol on mortality after myocardial infarction observed in the beta-Blocker Heart Attack Trial, the time of occurrence of sudden cardiac death was examined in this population. The beta-Blocker Heart Attack Trial demonstrated a reduced mortality rate in patients who received propranolol after a myocardial infarction. To further understand the mechanism behind this protective effect, the timing of sudden cardiac death was analyzed in this patient population. A morning increase in sudden cardiac death was observed, with the incidence peaking between 6 am and noon. Propranolol treatment significantly reduced the occurrence of sudden cardiac death during this time period. This suggests that propranolol may have a beneficial effect on preventing morning surge-related sudden cardiac death post-myocardial infarction. Further research is needed to fully understand the underlying mechanisms and to optimize treatment strategies for these high-risk periods.

Labetalol and MRI as initial medical and diagnostic modalities in a marfanoid patient with expanding ascending aortic aneurysm. Marfan syndrome is a hereditary connective tissue disorder associated with the development of aortic aneurysms. Prompt diagnosis and appropriate medical management are crucial in preventing aortic dissection and rupture. This case report describes the use of labetalol and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) as initial medical and diagnostic modalities in a marfanoid patient presenting with an expanding ascending aortic aneurysm. Labetalol, a non-selective beta-blocker with alpha-blocking properties, was chosen as the initial medical therapy based on its ability to reduce hemodynamic stress on the aortic wall. MRI was utilized to assess the size and characteristics of the aneurysm before considering surgical intervention. Serial imaging demonstrated stabilization of the aneurysm size over a 12-month period, suggesting successful medical management. This case highlights the potential role of labetalol and MRI in the early management of ascending aortic aneurysms in patients with Marfan syndrome or related connective tissue disorders. Further research is warranted to determine the efficacy and safety of this approach.

Oral diseases in older adults [clinical conference] In the case presented, a 65-year-old man with multiple dental, medical, and social problems benefited from interdisciplinary assessment and treatment. This clinical conference report presents a case of a 65-year-old man with multiple dental, medical, and social problems, highlighting the importance of interdisciplinary assessment and treatment in managing oral diseases in older adults. The patient presented with numerous dental concerns, including periodontal disease, edentulism, and dental caries, as well as comorbid medical conditions and psychosocial challenges. Interdisciplinary collaboration involving dental professionals, general physicians, social workers, and psychologists facilitated a comprehensive assessment of the patient's oral health needs and appropriate treatment planning. This approach ensured the provision of personalized dental care and preventive measures tailored to the patient's overall health status, including the management of systemic diseases such as diabetes and cardiovascular conditions. The case underscores the necessity of a holistic and patient-centered approach to oral care in older adults, aiming to improve their quality of life and overall health outcomes.

Spontaneous perinephric hemorrhage: imaging and management. Spontaneous perinephric hemorrhage is a rare condition that can have potentially life-threatening consequences. Prompt diagnosis and effective management are crucial in order to prevent further complications and improve patient outcomes. This abstract aims to review the imaging modalities and management strategies for spontaneous perinephric hemorrhage.

Various imaging techniques such as ultrasound, computed tomography (CT), and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) play a pivotal role in the diagnosis of spontaneous perinephric hemorrhage. Ultrasound is often the initial imaging modality of choice due to its accessibility and ability to detect free fluid in the perinephric space. CT scan provides more detailed information about the extent and location of the hemorrhage, aiding in surgical planning. MRI, although less commonly used, can provide valuable information regarding the presence of active bleeding and help identify underlying causes.

Management options for spontaneous perinephric hemorrhage range from conservative approaches such as observation and bed rest to more invasive interventions such as embolization or surgical exploration. Factors such as the severity of bleeding, stability of the patient, and underlying etiology should be considered when determining the optimal management strategy.

In conclusion, spontaneous perinephric hemorrhage requires prompt and accurate diagnosis using imaging modalities. Appropriate management strategies should be tailored to individual patients based on the extent of the hemorrhage and underlying etiology.

Fast short-tau inversion-recovery MR imaging. Fast short-tau inversion-recovery (STIR) MR imaging has emerged as a valuable tool in the evaluation of various musculoskeletal conditions. This imaging technique combines the advantages of both conventional T1- and T2-weighted imaging, allowing for improved visualization of edema, fluid collections, and inflammatory processes. With its short inversion time and rapid imaging time, fast STIR imaging enables efficient assessment of pathology while minimizing motion artifacts. It has been particularly useful in the assessment of bone marrow edema, infectious processes, stress fractures, and soft tissue abnormalities such as muscle and tendon injuries. In addition, fast STIR imaging has shown promising results in the evaluation of joint diseases such as arthritis and synovitis. Overall, fast STIR MR imaging provides a valuable noninvasive modality for the evaluation of musculoskeletal pathology.

Treatment of duodenitis with cimetidine: a clinical, endoscopic, and histologic study.  We studied the effectiveness of cimetidine in the treatment of endoscopically diagnosed duodenitis. In this study, we aimed to assess the efficacy of cimetidine in the treatment of duodenitis as diagnosed by endoscopy. A total of 60 patients with endoscopically confirmed duodenitis were included in the study. They were randomly assigned to two groups: group A received cimetidine treatment (800 mg/day) for a duration of 6 weeks, while group B received a placebo. Endoscopic evaluation and histological assessment were performed at baseline and at the end of the treatment period. The results showed that patients in group A exhibited significant improvement in both endoscopic findings and histologic features compared to those in group B. Specifically, group A had a higher rate of complete resolution of duodenitis (65% vs. 30% in group B) and a significant reduction in the severity of inflammation and erosion compared to group B. These findings suggest that cimetidine is an effective treatment option for duodenitis, leading to improvement in both endoscopic and histologic features.

Cutaneous angiolipoleiomyoma.  We describe eight cases of cutaneous angiolipoleiomyoma, a rare tumor previously reported only once under the term cutaneous angiomyolipoma. Cutaneous angiolipoleiomyoma is a rare tumor that has been minimally reported in the literature. In this case series, we present eight cases of cutaneous angiolipoleiomyoma, previously referred to as cutaneous angiomyolipoma. The patients ranged in age from 26 to 65 years, with an equal distribution between males and females. The tumors were located in various sites, including the trunk, upper extremity, and lower extremity. Histopathological examination revealed a triphasic composition of smooth muscle cells, adipocytes, and blood vessels. No signs of malignancy were observed in any of the cases. Surgical excision was the primary treatment modality, and no recurrences were documented during the follow-up period. We advocate for increased recognition and reporting of cutaneous angiolipoleiomyoma to contribute to the understanding of its clinical presentation, management, and long-term outcomes.

Topical treatment of necrotic foot ulcers in diabetic patients: a comparative trial of DuoDerm and MeZinc. Necrotic foot ulcers are a common complication in diabetic patients, requiring specialized treatment to promote wound healing and prevent infection. This comparative trial aimed to evaluate the efficacy of two topical treatments, DuoDerm and MeZinc, in the management of necrotic foot ulcers. A total of 50 diabetic patients with necrotic foot ulcers were randomly assigned to receive either DuoDerm or MeZinc. The primary outcome measures included wound healing rate, reduction in ulcer size, and time to complete healing. Secondary outcomes assessed were pain reduction, infection control, and patient satisfaction. The results of this trial will provide valuable insights for clinicians regarding the optimal topical treatment for necrotic foot ulcers in diabetic patients.

Sumatriptan in acute migraine: pharmacology and review of world experience. Sumatriptan is a selective 5-hydroxytryptamine1 receptor agonist that has been widely used for the treatment of acute migraine attacks. It acts by reducing the neurogenic inflammation associated with migraine and by constricting dilated cranial blood vessels. This paper reviews the pharmacology and world experience of sumatriptan in the management of acute migraines. Multiple clinical trials have demonstrated its efficacy in relieving migraine symptoms, including headache pain, photophobia, phonophobia, and nausea. Adverse effects are generally mild and transient, with the most common being injection site reactions. Overall, sumatriptan is considered a safe and effective treatment option for acute migraines, providing rapid relief and improving patient quality of life.

Newer antihypertensive agents. With the continuous development of therapeutic options for hypertension management, newer antihypertensive agents have emerged as potential alternatives or adjuncts to traditional therapies. These agents, which include angiotensin receptor blockers, calcium channel blockers, direct renin inhibitors, and others, offer unique mechanisms of action and improved efficacy in reducing blood pressure. Additionally, they may possess additional beneficial effects, such as a more favorable side effect profile or the ability to target specific patient populations. This review aims to provide an overview of the latest developments in the field of newer antihypertensive agents, including their pharmacology, clinical efficacy, and safety profiles. Continued research and clinical trials are needed to further establish their place in hypertension management.

A cohort study of fat intake and risk of breast cancer. The association between dietary fat intake and the risk of breast cancer has been widely studied, but the results have been inconsistent. To further explore this relationship, we conducted a cohort study among a large sample of women. A total of [number] participants were recruited and followed up for [number] years. Dietary fat intake was assessed using validated food frequency questionnaires. Incident cases of breast cancer were identified through linkage with cancer registries. Cox proportional hazards models were used to estimate hazard ratios (HRs) and 95% confidence intervals (CIs) adjusting for potential confounding factors. The results showed that high intake of total fat, saturated fat, and trans fat were significantly associated with an increased risk of breast cancer. In contrast, higher intake of polyunsaturated fat and monounsaturated fat was associated with a decreased risk. These findings suggest that modifying fat intake, particularly reducing saturated and trans fat consumption, could be a potential strategy for reducing the risk of breast cancer.

Treatment of leptomeningeal carcinomatosis with continuous intraventricular infusion of recombinant interleukin-2.  A 42-year-old man developed leptomeningeal carcinomatosis 6 years after treatment of a malignant melanoma. Leptomeningeal carcinomatosis is a rare complication of malignant melanoma with limited treatment options. We present a case of a 42-year-old man who developed leptomeningeal carcinomatosis 6 years after initial treatment of his primary malignancy. Due to the aggressive nature of his disease and limited response to standard therapies, the patient was treated with continuous intraventricular infusion of recombinant interleukin-2 (IL-2). This treatment approach resulted in a significant improvement in his clinical symptoms, including headache and cognitive impairment. Additionally, imaging studies demonstrated a reduction in leptomeningeal tumor deposits. The intraventricular infusion of IL-2 offers a promising therapeutic option for patients with leptomeningeal carcinomatosis, providing symptom relief and potentially improving overall survival. Further studies are warranted to investigate the efficacy and safety of this treatment modality.

Squamous cell carcinoma antigen (TA-4) in penile carcinoma. Penile carcinoma is a rare malignancy with a diverse histologic spectrum, and its diagnosis often relies on clinical and pathological evaluation. Squamous cell carcinoma antigen (TA-4) has emerged as a potential biomarker for penile carcinoma due to its specific expression in squamous epithelium and its association with tumor invasion and metastasis. This study aimed to evaluate the diagnostic and prognostic value of TA-4 in penile carcinoma. A total of 78 patients with penile carcinoma were enrolled, and TA-4 expression was assessed by immunohistochemistry. The results showed that TA-4 expression was significantly higher in penile carcinoma tissues compared to adjacent normal tissues. Furthermore, TA-4 expression was positively correlated with tumor stage, lymph node metastasis, and poor prognosis. These findings suggest that TA-4 may serve as a potential diagnostic and prognostic marker for penile carcinoma, providing valuable information for treatment decisions and patient management. Further studies are warranted to validate the clinical utility of TA-4 in larger cohorts and to explore its underlying molecular mechanisms in penile carcinoma.

Photochemotherapy improves chronic cutaneous graft-versus-host disease.  We have used oral psoralen photochemotherapy (PUVA) to treat four patients with chronic graft-versus-host disease of the skin, oral mucosa, and liver, who had responded only partially to long-term immunosuppressive therapy (prednisolone, cyclosporine, azathioprine). PUVA therapy was performed on four patients with chronic cutaneous graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) that had previously shown limited response to conventional immunosuppressive treatments. The patients had manifestations of GVHD in the skin, oral mucosa, and liver. Oral psoralen photochemotherapy (PUVA) was administered, which involves the combination of oral psoralen and UVA therapy. The treatment resulted in significant improvements in the symptoms of GVHD, particularly in the skin and oral mucosa. The patients experienced a reduction in the severity of skin lesions and improvement in oral ulcerations. This suggests that PUVA therapy may be an effective option in managing chronic cutaneous GVHD not responsive to conventional treatment approaches.

Clinical diagnosis of Binswanger's disease. Binswanger's disease is a rare form of vascular dementia characterized by subcortical white matter lesions and cognitive decline. This abstract aims to emphasize the importance of early and accurate clinical diagnosis in managing this condition. Clinical presentation typically includes progressive cognitive impairment, gait abnormalities, mood disturbances, and urinary incontinence. Neuroimaging findings reveal prominent bilateral white matter hyperintensities on T2-weighted magnetic resonance imaging scans. Differential diagnoses such as Alzheimer's disease, multiple sclerosis, and normal pressure hydrocephalus should be considered and excluded. Special attention should be given to patients with a history of hypertension, cerebrovascular disease, and cardiovascular risk factors. Treatment mainly focuses on managing vascular risk factors and symptomatic treatment of cognitive decline. Multidisciplinary care involving neurologists, psychiatrists, and rehabilitation specialists is pivotal to optimize patient outcomes. Despite the challenges in diagnosing and managing Binswanger's disease, clinicians should remain vigilant and proactive in order to provide appropriate care to affected individuals.

Recurrent pigmented melanocytic nevus. The recurrence of pigmented melanocytic nevus is a rare phenomenon that has been poorly studied. Here, we present a case report of a 32-year-old patient who developed a recurrent pigmented melanocytic nevus on the back, which had previously been excised and histologically confirmed as a benign lesion. The reoccurrence of the nevus occurred six years after the initial excision. Histological examination of the recurrent nevus showed similar features to the original lesion, including the presence of melanocytes within the basal layer of the epidermis and the dermal melanophages. Further investigation revealed no mutations in the BRAF or NRAS genes, which are commonly associated with melanoma development. This case highlights the need for further research into the mechanisms underlying the recurrence of pigmented melanocytic nevi and suggests that close monitoring is essential even after complete excision of these lesions.

Work and power in gait of stroke patients. Stroke patients often exhibit abnormal gait patterns due to motor impairments. The aim of this study was to investigate the relationship between work and power in the gait of stroke patients. Seventeen stroke patients and seventeen healthy controls participated in the study. Kinematic and kinetic data were collected during treadmill walking using a motion capture system and force plates. The work done by muscles and the power generated at different joints were calculated using inverse dynamics analysis. Results showed that stroke patients had significantly lower work and power generation at the affected lower limb joints compared to the healthy controls. Specifically, work and power deficits were observed at the ankle, knee, and hip joints. Additionally, stroke patients exhibited altered distribution of work and power between the affected and unaffected limbs, with increased reliance on the unaffected limb. These findings contribute to a better understanding of gait abnormalities in stroke patients and may guide the development of targeted rehabilitation interventions.

Simplified hepatic resection with the use of prolonged vascular inflow occlusion. Hepatic resection is a common procedure for the treatment of liver tumors. However, the traditional method, which involves total vascular occlusion during the resection, can lead to significant ischemia-reperfusion injury and increase the risk of postoperative complications. This study evaluates the feasibility and safety of a simplified technique using prolonged vascular inflow occlusion during hepatic resection. The results demonstrate that this method effectively reduces intraoperative blood loss and operative time. Additionally, there is a significant decrease in postoperative complications, such as liver dysfunction and bile leakage.
