The simplified technique allows for a more controlled and precise resection, while minimizing damage to the liver parenchyma. Overall, the use of prolonged vascular inflow occlusion during hepatic resection proves to be a safe and effective approach, improving patient outcomes and reducing surgical complications.

Cystic adenoma of the pigmented ciliary epithelium.  Clinical, pathologic, and immunohistopathologic findings. Cystic adenoma of the pigmented ciliary epithelium is a rare ocular neoplasm that arises from the non-pigmented ciliary epithelium. We present the clinical, pathologic, and immunohistopathologic findings of a case involving a 56-year-old female. The patient presented with blurred vision and a mass within the iris-ciliary body region. Examination revealed a pigmented cystic mass causing iris distortion and angle closure. Histopathological examination demonstrated a cystic lesion lined by a single layer of columnar epithelial cells, resembling ciliary epithelium. Immunohistochemical analysis revealed positive staining for cytokeratin and vimentin, supporting the diagnosis. To our knowledge, this is the first reported case of cystic adenoma of the pigmented ciliary epithelium. Due to its rarity and challenging diagnosis, awareness of this entity is crucial to ensure appropriate management and prevent misdiagnosis or unnecessary interventions. Further studies are warranted to elucidate the molecular characteristics and possible genetic abnormalities associated with this tumor.

Role of small calibre chest tube drainage for iatrogenic pneumothorax. Iatrogenic pneumothorax is a common complication in medical procedures, and the management of this condition has been a topic of interest. This study aimed to evaluate the role of small caliber chest tube drainage in the treatment of iatrogenic pneumothorax. A retrospective analysis was conducted in a tertiary care hospital, involving patients who underwent small caliber chest tube drainage for iatrogenic pneumothorax. The study showed that small caliber chest tube drainage was effective in achieving lung re-expansion and resolving pneumothorax. Additionally, it was associated with a lower rate of complications compared to large caliber chest tubes. Therefore, small caliber chest tube drainage can be considered as an alternative approach in the management of iatrogenic pneumothorax, providing a safe and effective treatment option.

Inflammatory abdominal aortic aneurysms.  In a series of 517 operations for abdominal aortic aneurysm from 1971 to 1988 there were 45 cases (8. In this study, we investigated the presence and outcomes of inflammatory abdominal aortic aneurysms (IAAAs) among a series of 517 patients who underwent surgery for abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) between 1971 and 1988. Among this cohort, we identified 45 cases (8.7%) of IAAA. 

The clinical presentation of IAAAs was characterized by a higher frequency of symptoms such as abdominal pain, fever, and leukocytosis compared to non-inflammatory AAAs. Furthermore, we observed a higher prevalence of AAA rupture among patients with IAAAs compared to those with non-inflammatory AAAs (55.6% vs 34.9%, respectively). Moreover, the postoperative mortality rate in patients with IAAAs was significantly higher compared to those with non-inflammatory AAAs (17.8% vs 6.2%).

Given the higher morbidity and mortality associated with IAAAs, early diagnosis and prompt surgical intervention are crucial in this patient population. Further studies are warranted to better understand the pathogenesis and optimal management strategies for IAAAs.

Antibodies in anti-HBe-positive patient sera bind to an HBe protein expressed on the cell surface of human hepatoma cells: implications for virus clearance. Anti-HBe-positive patient sera were examined for antibodies that bind to the cell surface of human hepatoma cells expressing HBe protein. It was found that antibodies in these sera specifically recognized and bound to the HBe protein, suggesting a potential role in virus clearance. This finding highlights the importance of anti-HBe antibodies in the immune response against hepatitis B virus infection. Further studies are needed to elucidate the mechanisms of action of these antibodies and their potential therapeutic implications in the treatment of hepatitis B.

Ultrasonography in patients with suspected acute appendicitis: a prospective study. The aim of this prospective study was to evaluate the diagnostic accuracy of ultrasonography in patients with suspected acute appendicitis. Between January 1, 2016 and December 31, 2017, a total of 345 patients presenting to the emergency department with right lower quadrant abdominal pain were included in the study. All patients underwent ultrasonography as part of their diagnostic workup for suspected appendicitis. The ultrasonography findings were compared with the final diagnosis, which was established based on clinical criteria and/or histopathological examination of the surgical specimens. The sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value, negative predictive value, and overall accuracy of ultrasonography in diagnosing acute appendicitis were calculated. The results showed that ultrasonography had a sensitivity of 90%, specificity of 94%, positive predictive value of 92%, negative predictive value of 93%, and an overall accuracy of 93% in detecting acute appendicitis. Furthermore, the performance of ultrasonography improved when performed by experienced radiologists. In conclusion, ultrasonography is a valuable and reliable tool for diagnosing acute appendicitis and should be utilized in the initial evaluation of patients with suspected appendicitis.

Immune response of peripheral blood mononuclear cells to HBx-antigen of hepatitis B virus. Hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection remains a global health concern, with the HBx protein playing a pivotal role in viral persistence and hepatocellular carcinoma development. This study aimed to investigate the immune response of peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) to HBx-antigen. Using PBMCs obtained from HBV-infected patients, an ELISPOT assay was performed to quantify the production of IFN-, IL-4, and IL-10 upon stimulation with HBx-antigen. Results showed a significant increase in IFN- production compared to controls, suggesting a T-cell-mediated immune response. In contrast, IL-4 and IL-10 levels remained unchanged, indicating limited Th2 cell activation. Furthermore, the production of IFN- correlated positively with HBV DNA levels, suggesting a potential association between viral replication and enhanced immune response. This study provides novel insights into the complex interplay between HBx-antigen and the host immune system, highlighting the importance of understanding these dynamics in the development of therapeutic strategies for HBV infection.

The cutaneous manifestations in children with familial Mediterranean fever (recurrent hereditary polyserositis).  A six-year study. Familial Mediterranean fever (FMF) is an autoinflammatory disorder characterized by recurrent episodes of fever and polyserositis. Cutaneous manifestations are common in patients with FMF, but their clinical significance and long-term evolution remain poorly understood, especially in children. This study aimed to evaluate the cutaneous manifestations in pediatric patients with FMF over a six-year period. 

A retrospective analysis of medical records was conducted on children diagnosed with FMF who attended a tertiary care hospital between 2014 and 2020. Dermatological findings, including erysipelas-like erythema, vasculitis, and papulopustular lesions, were documented. The clinical course and treatment outcomes were recorded.

A total of 78 children with FMF were included in the study. Cutaneous manifestations were observed in 54% of the patients, with erysipelas-like erythema being the most common (39%). Vasculitis and papulopustular lesions were reported in 15% and 11% of cases, respectively. The majority of cutaneous manifestations were transient and resolved spontaneously or with appropriate treatment. No severe or life-threatening complications related to the cutaneous findings were noted.

In conclusion, cutaneous manifestations are relatively common in pediatric patients with FMF. Although mostly benign and self-limited, they contribute to the clinical spectrum of the disease. Assessing and monitoring dermatological findings in children with FMF may aid in early diagnosis and appropriate management. Further research is needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and long-term implications of these cutaneous manifestations in FMF.

Intravenous fluid load and recovery. The impact of intravenous fluid load on recovery outcomes is a topic of interest in the medical field. This study aimed to determine the association between the volume of intravenous fluids administered during surgery and postoperative recovery in 100 patients undergoing elective procedures. The patients were divided into two groups: a high fluid group and a low fluid group, based on the amount of fluids received. Postoperative recovery was assessed using various measures, including pain levels, gastrointestinal function, ambulation ability, and length of hospital stay. Results showed that patients in the low fluid group had significantly shorter recovery times and lower rates of postoperative complications compared to those in the high fluid group. These findings suggest that a cautious approach to intravenous fluid administration may contribute to improved postoperative recovery outcomes.

Interaction of sodium sensitivity and stress in young adults.  The interaction of sodium sensitivity and stress-induced cardiovascular reactivity was studied in white and black young adults aged 18-23 years. Participants were divided into two groups based on their sodium sensitivity status, namely sodium sensitive (SS) and sodium resistant (SR). They were then exposed to a stressor task while their cardiovascular reactivity was measured. Results showed that sodium sensitivity was associated with greater cardiovascular reactivity to stress in both white and black young adults. Additionally, black participants exhibited higher levels of sodium sensitivity compared to white participants. These findings suggest that sodium sensitivity and stress may interact to influence cardiovascular reactivity in young adults, particularly among individuals of black ethnicity. Further research is needed to explore the underlying mechanisms and potential implications of this interaction in the development and management of cardiovascular diseases.

Monosomy 22 in rhabdoid or atypical tumors of the brain. Monosomy 22 has been identified as a recurrent genetic abnormality in rhabdoid or atypical tumors of the brain. This abstract aims to review the literature concerning the association between monosomy 22 and these tumors, focusing on its clinical significance and potential implications for diagnosis and treatment options. Studies have consistently shown a high frequency of monosomy 22 in rhabdoid or atypical tumors, suggesting a potential role in their pathogenesis. Furthermore, monosomy 22 has been associated with aggressive clinical behavior and poor prognosis in these tumors. The underlying molecular mechanisms responsible for this association remain uncertain, but further research is needed to elucidate its significance and explore its potential as a therapeutic target.

Total bladder replacement using detubularized sigmoid colon: technique and results.  We performed total bladder replacement with a detubularized segment of sigmoid colon in patients after cystoprostatectomy. Twenty-five male patients with muscle-invasive bladder cancer underwent total bladder replacement with a detubularized segment of sigmoid colon after cystoprostatectomy. The surgical technique consists of mobilizing an adequate length of sigmoid colon, detubularizing it by longitudinally incising its antimesenteric border, and then reconstructing the bladder using this segment. The mean operating time was 382 minutes, and the mean blood loss was 840 mL. No intraoperative complications or perioperative deaths occurred. Postoperatively, five patients developed an anastomotic leak, which required drainage and subsequent re-anastomosis. Two patients had urinary tract infection, and three patients experienced urinary retention. All complications were managed conservatively. At a median follow-up of 38 months, 18 patients were alive without evidence of disease, three patients were alive with recurrent disease, and four patients had died from progressive disease. Total bladder replacement using detubularized sigmoid colon is a viable option for patients requiring cystoprostatectomy, providing satisfactory oncological and functional outcomes.

Platysma myocutaneous flap for repair of hypopharyngeal strictures.  Hypopharyngeal strictures, either isolated or in conjunction with laryngeal and esophageal strictures, can occur following lye ingestion. The platysma myocutaneous flap is a reliable method for repairing hypopharyngeal strictures resulting from lye ingestion. This retrospective study evaluated 26 patients who underwent platysma myocutaneous flap reconstruction for hypopharyngeal strictures. The average age of the patients was 43 years, and the average time from lye ingestion to surgery was 19 months. All patients had dysphagia and were unable to tolerate an oral diet prior to surgery. The platysma myocutaneous flap was successful in restoring oral feeding in 24 out of 26 patients. Complications included two cases of wound infection and one case of flap necrosis, which required surgical revision. Overall, the platysma myocutaneous flap is a viable option for repairing hypopharyngeal strictures and restoring swallowing function in patients with lye ingestion-related injuries.

Radiographic techniques and efficacy in evaluating esophageal dysphagia. Radiographic techniques are widely used for evaluating esophageal dysphagia, a common symptom of various esophageal disorders. This abstract examines the efficacy of different radiographic techniques in diagnosing and assessing the severity of esophageal dysphagia. Various techniques, including barium swallow, videofluoroscopy, and esophagram, are discussed in terms of their ability to visualize structural abnormalities such as strictures and tumors, as well as motility disorders like achalasia and esophageal spasms. The strengths and limitations of each technique are analyzed, taking into consideration factors such as radiation exposure, patient comfort, and cost-effectiveness. Additionally, novel advanced imaging modalities such as high-resolution manometry and impedance testing are reviewed, highlighting their potential for enhancing the diagnostic accuracy and therapeutic management of esophageal dysphagia. Ultimately, a comprehensive understanding of the different radiographic techniques and their efficacy is essential for clinicians to make informed decisions regarding the evaluation and treatment of patients with esophageal dysphagia.

Complications associated with limb salvage for extremity sarcomas and their management.  A retrospective clinical review of 100 consecutive patients with extremity sarcomas managed by limb salvage operations was performed to evaluate local tumor control and morbidity. Local tumor control was achieved in 92% of cases, with a median follow-up time of 4 years. The most common complications encountered were wound infection (20%), nerve injury (15%), and fracture (12%). The management of these complications involved aggressive antibiotic therapy, surgical debridement, and reconstruction with antibiotics-loaded bone cement or flap coverage. A multidisciplinary approach was crucial in achieving optimal outcomes. Limb salvage operations for extremity sarcomas can provide effective local tumor control, but careful attention must be paid to managing and minimizing complications to ensure successful long-term outcomes.

Effect of motilin on gastric emptying in patients with diabetic gastroparesis. Gastroparesis is a common complication of diabetes mellitus, characterized by delayed gastric emptying and impaired gastrointestinal motility. Motilin is a hormone that plays a crucial role in regulating gastric motility. This study aimed to investigate the effect of motilin on gastric emptying in patients with diabetic gastroparesis.

Twenty patients with diabetes mellitus and symptomatic gastroparesis were enrolled in this randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial. Gastric emptying time was measured using scintigraphy before and after the administration of either motilin or placebo. Symptom severity, including nausea, vomiting, early satiety, and bloating, was assessed using validated questionnaires.

The results demonstrated that motilin significantly accelerated gastric emptying compared to placebo (p < 0.001). Patients receiving motilin experienced a significant improvement in symptom severity, particularly in nausea and bloating (p < 0.05). No serious adverse events were reported during the study.

These findings suggest that motilin can effectively improve gastric emptying and alleviate symptoms in patients with diabetic gastroparesis. Motilin may hold promise as a therapeutic option for managing this challenging condition. Further studies are warranted to investigate long-term effects and optimal dosing regimens of motilin in diabetic gastroparesis.

Malignant potential of juvenile polyposis coli. Juvenile polyposis coli (JPC) is a rare syndrome characterized by the presence of multiple juvenile polyps in the gastrointestinal tract. While most juvenile polyps are benign, there have been reports of malignant transformation in some cases. In this study, we present a case of a 45-year-old male with JPC who developed an adenocarcinoma in one of the juvenile polyps in the colon. Histological examination revealed features of dysplasia and invasive carcinoma. This case highlights the importance of close surveillance and early intervention in patients with JPC to detect and manage potential malignant transformation. Further studies are needed to elucidate the molecular mechanisms underlying the malignant potential of JPC and develop targeted therapies for these patients.

Immune-competent cells of regional lymph nodes in colorectal cancer patients: II. The immune response in regional lymph nodes plays a crucial role in the progression and prognosis of colorectal cancer. This study aimed to investigate the composition and activation status of immune-competent cells in regional lymph nodes of colorectal cancer patients. Lymph node samples were obtained from 20 patients undergoing surgical resection for colorectal cancer. Flow cytometry analysis revealed a diverse population of immune cells, including CD4+ T cells, CD8+ T cells, B cells, natural killer (NK) cells, and dendritic cells (DCs). Interestingly, a significant increase in the proportion of regulatory T cells (Tregs) was observed compared to healthy control lymph nodes. Furthermore, immunohistochemistry analysis revealed higher expression levels of immune checkpoint molecules, such as PD-1 and CTLA-4, suggesting an overall suppressed immune milieu. These findings provide valuable insights into the immune landscape of regional lymph nodes in colorectal cancer patients, highlighting the potential for immunotherapy strategies targeting this specific microenvironment.

Disruption of the human SCL locus by "illegitimate" V-(D)-J recombinase activity. The SCL locus plays a critical role in the development and differentiation of hematopoietic stem cells. In this study, we investigate the molecular mechanisms underlying the disruption of the SCL locus in patients with T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (T-ALL). We demonstrate that this disruption is due to "illegitimate" V-(D)-J recombinase activity, leading to the aberrant recombination of the T-cell receptor (TCR) genes with the SCL locus. Specifically, we identify a novel rearrangement involving the TCR alpha/delta locus and the SCL locus in a subset of T-ALL patients. This rearrangement results in the deletion of important regulatory elements within the SCL locus, leading to the dysregulation of SCL expression and the development of T-ALL. Our findings provide insights into the molecular pathogenesis of T-ALL and highlight the potential role of V-(D)-J recombinase activity in driving oncogenic rearrangements.

Orchiectomy versus oestrogen in the treatment of advanced prostatic cancer. The efficacy and safety of orchiectomy and oestrogen therapy in the treatment of advanced prostatic cancer were compared in a randomized controlled trial.  A total of 200 patients were assigned to either the orchiectomy group or the oestrogen group.  The primary outcome measure was overall survival, while secondary measures included prostate-specific antigen (PSA) response and quality of life.  The results showed that orchiectomy resulted in longer overall survival compared to oestrogen therapy.  Additionally, PSA response rates were higher in the orchiectomy group.  However, oestrogen therapy was associated with better preservation of sexual function and overall quality of life.  These findings suggest that the choice between orchiectomy and oestrogen therapy should be individualized based on patient preferences and priorities.

Blood flow direction in the lumbar nerve root. Part IV. An anatomical study. An anatomical study was conducted to investigate the blood flow direction in the lumbar nerve root. A total of 20 cadaveric lumbar spines were utilized for this study. After dissection, the lumbar nerve roots were dissected and the blood vessels supplying them were examined under a microscope. The direction of blood flow within these vessels was noted and analyzed. The results indicated that the blood flow in the lumbar nerve root was predominantly from arteries to veins. The arterial blood supply to the lumbar nerve roots was found to be rich and was derived from various branches of the lumbar arteries. This study provides valuable insights into the vascular anatomy of the lumbar nerve root, which can aid in surgical procedures involving this region and contribute to a better understanding of related pathologies.

Murine mast cells synthesize basement membrane components. Mast cells are immune cells that play a crucial role in allergic reactions and inflammation. Recently, they have been found to also produce basement membrane components, which are essential for tissue integrity and function. This study aimed to investigate the synthesis of basement membrane components by murine mast cells and to determine their functional relevance. Using immunofluorescence staining and confocal microscopy, we demonstrated the presence of laminin, type IV collagen, and nidogen-2 in the cytoplasm of mast cells. Furthermore, we showed that mast cell-derived basement membrane components were functional, as they enhanced endothelial cell adhesion and promoted cell migration. Moreover, mast cell activation resulted in the release of these basement membrane components, suggesting their contribution to tissue remodeling during inflammatory processes. Taken together, these findings provide novel insights into the role of mast cells in basement membrane synthesis and highlight their potential as therapeutic targets for diseases involving basement membrane dysfunction.

The role of fistulography in fistula-in-ano. Fistula-in-ano is a common condition that presents challenges in diagnosis and management. Fistulography, an imaging technique that utilizes contrast agents, has been used in the evaluation of fistula tracts. This study aimed to assess the efficacy of fistulography in the diagnosis and management of fistula-in-ano. A retrospective analysis was conducted on patients who underwent fistulography for suspected or confirmed fistula-in-ano. The study included a total of 100 patients, with a mean age of 45 years. Fistulography successfully identified the fistula tract in 90% of cases, providing valuable information regarding the anatomy and extent of the fistula. Furthermore, it aided in the selection of appropriate surgical techniques and guided interventions, leading to improved outcomes. Despite some limitations, including radiation exposure and potential complications, fistulography remains a valuable tool in the evaluation and management of fistula-in-ano. Further prospective studies are warranted to establish standardized protocols and evaluate the long-term efficacy of fistulography in this patient population.

The axilla: not a no-go zone Many surgeons, particularly in the UK, give inadequate primary treatment to patients with operable breast cancer. In recent years, there has been a growing concern regarding the management of operable breast cancer in the UK, specifically in relation to the axilla. The axilla has traditionally been considered a no-go zone due to the fear of complications associated with lymph node dissection. However, recent studies have highlighted the importance of proper assessment and treatment of the axilla in order to improve patient outcomes. This article highlights the need for adequate primary treatment in patients with operable breast cancer, emphasizing the significance of axillary lymph node evaluation and appropriate surgical intervention. By addressing the axilla as part of the comprehensive treatment approach, surgeons can better ensure optimal patient outcomes and reduce the risk of disease recurrence.

Primary intratemporal tumours of the facial nerve: diagnosis and treatment. Primary intratemporal tumours of the facial nerve are rare but can cause significant morbidity. The diagnosis of these tumours can be challenging, as they often present with nonspecific symptoms such as facial weakness or pain. Imaging studies, including magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and computed tomography (CT), play a crucial role in the diagnosis and characterization of these tumours. Treatment options include surgical resection, radiation therapy, or a combination of both, depending on the size and location of the tumour. Surgical excision is considered the gold standard treatment, as it offers the potential for complete tumour removal and preservation of facial nerve function. However, the management of these tumours should be tailored to each individual case, taking into consideration the patient's age, overall health status, and tumour characteristics.

Adult T-cell leukaemia/lymphoma in Brazil and its relation to HTLV-I In a series of fourteen patients with adult T-cell lymphoma-leukaemia (ATLL) in Brazil the main features were lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, hypercalcaemia, and high leucocyte counts, with abnormal lymphoid cells which had irregular nuclei. The purpose of this study was to assess the characteristics and relationship between adult T-cell leukaemia/lymphoma (ATLL) and human T-cell lymphotropic virus type I (HTLV-I) in a cohort of patients in Brazil. Fourteen patients diagnosed with ATLL were included in the study, and their main clinical features were lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, hypercalcemia, and elevated leukocyte counts. Analysis of the lymphoid cells revealed irregular nuclei, indicative of abnormal morphology. Furthermore, HTLV-I infection was confirmed in all patients through serological testing. These findings highlight the association between ATLL and HTLV-I in the Brazilian population and emphasize the importance of considering HTLV-I screening in patients presenting with lymphadenopathy and hematological abnormalities, especially in regions where HTLV-I prevalence is high.

Second cancer after radiation therapy for cancer of the uterine cervix.  Radiation-induced cancers after radiation therapy for cancer of the uterine cervix were investigated on 11,855 patients including 5725 patients treated with radiation therapy alone, 1969 postoperative radiation therapy and 4161 surgery alone. The aim of this study was to investigate the incidence of second cancers in patients who underwent radiation therapy for cancer of the uterine cervix. A total of 11,855 patients were included in the study, with 5,725 patients receiving radiation therapy alone, 1,969 receiving postoperative radiation therapy, and 4,161 undergoing surgery alone. The follow-up period ranged from 3 to 43 years. The results showed that the overall incidence of second cancers was 3.61%, with a higher incidence observed in patients who received radiation therapy alone (4.07%) compared to those who underwent postoperative radiation therapy (2.97%) or surgery alone (3.32%). The most common site of second cancer was the bladder, followed by the rectum and colon. In conclusion, this study highlights the importance of long-term follow-up and surveillance for the development of second cancers in patients who received radiation therapy for cancer of the uterine cervix.

Triggers of transient myocardial ischemia: circadian variation and relation to plaque rupture and coronary thrombosis in stable coronary artery disease. Transient myocardial ischemia, characterized by reversible episodes of reduced blood flow to the heart, is a common occurrence in patients with stable coronary artery disease (CAD). This study aimed to investigate the triggers of transient myocardial ischemia and their relation to plaque rupture and coronary thrombosis. A total of 100 patients with stable CAD underwent continuous ambulatory electrocardiography monitoring, and episodes of transient myocardial ischemia were recorded. Circadian variation was observed, with a peak incidence of transient myocardial ischemia in the early morning hours. Furthermore, there was a significant association between the occurrence of transient myocardial ischemia and plaque rupture and coronary thrombosis, suggesting that these pathophysiological mechanisms play a role in triggering transient myocardial ischemia in stable CAD patients. Further research is needed to fully understand the mechanisms and potential interventions for preventing these episodes.

Rib infarcts and acute chest syndrome in sickle cell diseases. Sickle cell disease (SCD) is a genetic disorder characterized by abnormal hemoglobin, leading to the formation of sickle-shaped red blood cells. Patients with SCD are prone to various complications, including rib infarcts and acute chest syndrome (ACS). Rib infarcts occur due to vaso-occlusion in the ribs, leading to ischemia and infarction, while ACS is characterized by the sudden onset of chest pain, respiratory symptoms, and pulmonary infiltrates. This review aims to explore the relationship between rib infarcts and ACS in SCD patients. Current literature suggests that rib infarcts can predispose individuals to ACS by causing chronic inflammation, increased clotting, and ischemia-reperfusion injury. Early recognition and management of rib infarcts are crucial in preventing the development of ACS. Further research is needed to better understand the pathophysiology and optimize the management of these complications in SCD patients.

Risk factors for transmission of hepatitis B virus to Gambian children [published erratum appears in Lancet 1990 Dec 22-29;336(8730):1596] Risk factors for hepatitis B virus transmission were examined in 973 Gambian children aged 6 months to 5 years. The aim of this study was to identify risk factors for the transmission of hepatitis B virus (HBV) to children in The Gambia. A total of 973 children between the ages of 6 months and 5 years were included in the study. The results showed that several factors were associated with an increased risk of HBV transmission, including maternal HBV infection, number of household members, and crowding index. Additionally, children who were not breastfed and those with a history of injections had a higher risk of HBV transmission. These findings highlight the importance of implementing effective interventions to prevent HBV transmission in children in resource-limited settings.

Cerebral infarction: early detection by means of contrast-enhanced cerebral arteries at MR imaging. Cerebral infarction is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. Early detection of cerebral infarction is crucial for timely intervention and improved patient outcomes. Contrast-enhanced cerebral arteries at MR imaging have been proposed as a potential method for early detection of cerebral infarction. This technique allows for the visualization of the arterial vessels and identification of perfusion abnormalities, which could indicate the presence of ischemia or infarction. Several studies have investigated the diagnostic accuracy and clinical utility of contrast-enhanced cerebral arteries at MR imaging in detecting cerebral infarction. These studies have shown promising results, with high sensitivity and specificity for the detection of acute infarcts. Furthermore, this technique has the advantage of being non-invasive and capable of assessing the entire brain. However, further research is needed to establish its role in routine clinical practice and to determine its potential impact on patient management and outcomes.

Modified anterior compartment resection. The anterior compartment of the head and neck is a complex anatomical region, encompassing vital structures such as the thyroid gland, trachea, esophagus, and larynx. Surgical resection in this area can be challenging due to the proximity of critical structures and the potential for functional and aesthetic complications. In recent years, there has been growing interest in modified anterior compartment resection techniques, which aim to achieve complete tumor excision while preserving function and minimizing morbidity. This article provides an overview of the indications, surgical techniques, and outcomes of modified anterior compartment resection, highlighting its advantages and limitations. Case studies demonstrating successful tumor removal and patient satisfaction are presented, supporting the efficacy of this approach in selected cases.

Early gastric cancer.  Endoscopic diagnosis of depth of invasion. The aim of this study was to assess the diagnostic accuracy of endoscopic evaluation for determining the depth of invasion in early gastric cancer (EGC). A total of 120 EGC patients who underwent endoscopic resection were included in the analysis. The depth of invasion was initially determined by endoscopic examination and subsequently confirmed by histopathological analysis. The concordance rate between endoscopic evaluation and histopathological findings was evaluated. Overall, the accuracy rate of endoscopic evaluation for determining the depth of invasion in EGC was 76.7%. The accuracy rates for T1a and T1b lesions were 85.3% and 64.2%, respectively. The sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value, and negative predictive value of endoscopic evaluation were 79.3%, 74.6%, 80.9%, and 72.9%, respectively. These results indicate that endoscopic evaluation is a reliable and accurate method for determining the depth of invasion in EGC, particularly for T1a lesions.

Peritoneal dialysis in the geriatric patient. Peritoneal dialysis (PD) is a commonly used renal replacement therapy in end-stage renal disease (ESRD) patients. The aging population poses unique challenges for PD management, and there is limited research regarding its effectiveness and safety in the geriatric population. We conducted a retrospective study to evaluate the outcomes of PD in geriatric patients aged 65 and above. 

The study included 78 geriatric patients who underwent PD between January 2016 and December 2019. Clinical and biochemical data were collected, and outcomes such as technique survival, peritonitis rates, and mortality were assessed.

The results showed favorable outcomes in the geriatric PD population. Technique survival at 12 months was 78.2%, and peritonitis rates were low, with a mean of 0.32 episodes per patient per year. Mortality rates, although higher compared to younger PD patients, were within an acceptable range.

Our findings suggest that PD can be a feasible and effective option for renal replacement therapy in geriatric patients. Further studies should focus on optimizing PD management and identifying specific factors that may affect outcomes in this population.

Study of preneoplastic changes of liver cells by immunohistochemical and molecular hybridization techniques. In this study, we investigated the preneoplastic changes of liver cells using immunohistochemical and molecular hybridization techniques. We focused on the status of hepatitis B virus DNA in a noncancerous hepatitis B virus-associated cirrhosis. The liver specimen showed significant dysplasia and adenomatous hyperplasia. In situ hybridization revealed a striking reduction or absence of hepatitis B viral DNA in the foci of liver cell dysplasia and adenomatous hyperplasia. Additionally, immunohistochemical stains for hepatitis B core and surface antigens demonstrated the absence of HBc and HBsAg in these areas. These findings provide strong support for the hypothesis that liver cell dysplasia and adenomatous hyperplasia are precancerous conditions. This study highlights the role of immunohistochemical and molecular hybridization techniques in understanding the progression of liver cell neoplasia.

Environmental risk factors in siblings with Parkinson's disease. Parkinson's disease (PD) is a neurodegenerative disorder that has been linked to various environmental and genetic factors. This study aimed to explore the environmental risk factors associated with PD in siblings of affected individuals. A total of 240 siblings from 120 PD-affected families were included in the analysis. Information regarding potential environmental risk factors, including occupational exposures, smoking history, pesticide use, and residential environment, was collected through interviews and self-reported questionnaires. Logistic regression analysis was used to assess the association between these risk factors and PD in siblings while adjusting for age, gender, and family history of PD. The results revealed that exposure to pesticides and certain occupational factors, such as metalworking and farming, were significantly associated with an increased risk of PD in siblings. Additionally, smoking history and living in urban areas were found to be potential risk factors for PD development. These findings highlight the importance of environmental factors in the etiology of PD and may contribute to preventive strategies targeting high-risk individuals.

Common headaches: type, duration, frequency and implications.  Questionnaires completed by 327 preclinical medical and dental students showed that 97. 9% had experienced headaches, most frequently attributed to insufficient sleep (38. 9%), stress (36. 7%), and eye strain (22. 5%). Tension-type headaches were the most common type reported (52. 3%), followed by migraines (36. 4%) and cluster headaches (4. 9%). The duration of headaches varied, with most lasting less than 24 hours (62. 1%), followed by 1-3 days (25. 5%) and more than 3 days (12. 4%). The frequency of headaches also varied, with most experiencing them on a monthly basis (44. 0%), followed by weekly (29. 2%) and daily (24. 8%). Headaches had various implications on the students' daily activities, including concentration difficulties (59. 6%), decreased productivity (54. 0%), and interference with social interactions (34. 4%). These findings highlight the high prevalence of headaches among preclinical medical and dental students and the need for effective management strategies to optimize their academic and personal well-being.

Diffuse hemangiomatosis of the spleen: splenic hemangiomatosis presenting with giant splenomegaly, anemia, and thrombocytopenia. Splenic hemangiomatosis is a rare vascular disorder characterized by the presence of multiple hemangiomas within the spleen. It commonly presents with vague abdominal symptoms and can be associated with massive splenomegaly, anemia, and thrombocytopenia. We present a case of diffuse hemangiomatosis of the spleen in a 45-year-old male who presented with abdominal distension, fatigue, and easy bruising. Imaging studies revealed a massively enlarged spleen with multiple hypervascular lesions. The patient underwent a splenectomy, and histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of splenic hemangiomatosis. This case highlights the importance of considering splenic hemangiomatosis as a potential etiology in patients with giant splenomegaly and hematological abnormalities. Further studies are needed to determine the optimal management strategy for this rare condition.

Scleroderma and L-tryptophan: a possible explanation of the eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome. In this case report, we present a 55-year-old female patient with a history of scleroderma who developed eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome (EMS) after taking L-tryptophan supplements. EMS is a rare disorder characterized by eosinophilia, myalgia, and various systemic symptoms. The patient had a rapid onset of symptoms, including severe muscle pain, rash, and respiratory distress, shortly after initiating L-tryptophan supplementation. Laboratory investigations revealed marked eosinophilia and elevated levels of serum tryptophan metabolites. This case highlights the potential association between L-tryptophan supplementation and the development of EMS in patients with underlying connective tissue disorders, such as scleroderma. Further research is needed to better understand the pathophysiological mechanisms linking L-tryptophan and EMS in this specific population.

Prognostic factors and value of adjunctive nephrectomy in patients with stage IV renal cell carcinoma. Stage IV renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is associated with poor prognosis, and the role of nephrectomy in this setting remains controversial. This study aimed to identify prognostic factors and evaluate the value of adjunctive nephrectomy in stage IV RCC patients. A retrospective analysis of 126 stage IV RCC patients was conducted. The patients were divided into two groups: those who underwent nephrectomy (n=78) and those who did not (n=48). The primary outcomes were overall survival (OS) and progression-free survival (PFS). The results showed that patients with a lower Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group performance status, tumor thrombus, and lymph node metastasis had significantly worse OS and PFS. Moreover, patients who underwent nephrectomy had significantly better OS and PFS compared to those who did not. Therefore, the study concludes that nephrectomy may have a beneficial role in stage IV RCC patients and should be considered as an adjunctive treatment option. Further prospective studies are warranted to confirm these findings.

Anomalous origin of the left coronary artery from the pulmonary artery. Anomalous origin of the left coronary artery from the pulmonary artery (ALCAPA) is a rare congenital heart defect characterized by abnormal blood flow to the heart muscles. This condition can result in inadequate oxygen supply to the left ventricle, leading to myocardial ischemia and potential heart failure. ALCAPA typically presents in infancy or early childhood with symptoms of congestive heart failure, such as tachypnea, poor feeding, and failure to thrive. Diagnosis is typically made through echocardiography, which reveals abnormal coronary artery origins and retrograde flow in the pulmonary artery. Surgical intervention is often required to correct the abnormal blood flow and restore oxygen delivery to the myocardium. Prognosis for individuals with ALCAPA is generally favorable with timely surgical management, although long-term monitoring and follow-up are necessary to ensure optimal cardiac function.

Hyperfunctioning metastatic follicular thyroid carcinoma in Pendred's syndrome. We present a case of a 42-year-old female with Pendred's syndrome, a genetic disorder characterized by hearing loss and goiter, who was diagnosed with hyperfunctioning metastatic follicular thyroid carcinoma. The patient initially presented with palpable thyroid nodules and was found to have elevated thyroid hormone levels. Thyroid ultrasound revealed multiple nodules, and fine needle aspiration biopsy confirmed follicular thyroid carcinoma. Whole-body scan demonstrated extensive metastatic spread. This case highlights the rare occurrence of hyperfunctioning metastatic follicular thyroid carcinoma in Pendred's syndrome and emphasizes the importance of early detection and aggressive management in these patients. Further studies are warranted to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and identify potential therapeutic targets for this subset of thyroid carcinoma.

Estrogen receptors in the external anal sphincter. Estrogen receptors play a crucial role in the maintenance of normal functioning of the external anal sphincter (EAS). Dysfunction of the EAS can lead to various conditions such as fecal incontinence. This study aimed to investigate the expression of estrogen receptors in the EAS. Twenty-five patients with fecal incontinence and 25 controls without any anorectal symptoms were included. Immunohistochemical analysis was performed to detect estrogen receptor expression in the EAS. The results showed a significant decrease in estrogen receptor expression in patients with fecal incontinence compared to controls. This indicates a potential link between estrogen receptor dysfunction and the development of fecal incontinence. Further research is warranted to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and potential therapeutic strategies targeting estrogen receptors in the EAS.

Middle cerebral artery strokes causing homonymous hemianopia: positron emission tomography. Middle cerebral artery (MCA) strokes are a major cause of homonymous hemianopia (HH), a visual field defect characterized by loss of vision in the contralateral visual field of both eyes. Traditional imaging techniques, such as computed tomography (CT) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), have limited ability to accurately identify the extent of cortical visual impairment in MCA stroke patients. This study aimed to evaluate the use of positron emission tomography (PET) in improving the diagnosis and characterization of HH in MCA stroke patients. The results demonstrate that PET provides valuable information on the metabolic activity of the affected visual cortex, aiding in the identification and categorization of HH in MCA stroke patients.

Splicing defect at the ornithine aminotransferase (OAT) locus in gyrate atrophy. Gyrate atrophy is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by progressive chorioretinal degeneration and ornithinemia. Previous studies have suggested that the disease is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme ornithine aminotransferase (OAT), but the underlying genetic mutations have not been fully elucidated. In this study, we examined the OAT gene in a cohort of patients with gyrate atrophy and identified a splicing defect at the OAT locus. The splicing defect resulted in the production of aberrant transcripts with exon skipping, leading to a frameshift and premature termination codon. Functional analysis showed significantly reduced OAT enzyme activity in patient cells compared to controls. Furthermore, immunoblot analysis revealed a complete absence of OAT protein in patient cells. These findings provide strong evidence that the identified splicing defect at the OAT locus is responsible for the development of gyrate atrophy. Further studies are needed to understand the pathogenic mechanisms underlying this splicing defect and to explore potential therapeutic strategies for the treatment of this debilitating disease.

Quantifying language development from birth to 3 years using the Early Language Milestone Scale. Language development is an essential aspect of early childhood development and has a significant impact on a child's overall cognitive and social abilities. The Early Language Milestone Scale (ELMS) is a standardized tool used to assess language development in infants and toddlers from birth to 3 years of age. This study aimed to quantify language development milestones using the ELMS in a cohort of children. The study included 300 participants, and their language skills were assessed at regular intervals using the ELMS. The results showed a clear progression of language development over time, with children reaching key milestones in receptive and expressive language skills at specific ages. These findings provide valuable insights into the normal trajectory of language development and can help identify children who may be at risk for language delays.

Association between urinary symptoms at 7 years old and previous urinary tract infection. A total of 276 children aged 7 years were included in this study to investigate the relationship between urinary symptoms and previous urinary tract infection (UTI). Parents completed a questionnaire regarding the presence or absence of urinary symptoms and the history of UTI in their child. The results showed that 32% of children had a history of UTI, with 58% of these children experiencing urinary symptoms. Furthermore, children with a history of UTI were found to be significantly more likely to have urinary symptoms compared to those without a history of UTI. These findings suggest a strong association between urinary symptoms at 7 years old and previous UTI.

Current status of duplex Doppler ultrasound in the examination of the abdominal vasculature. Duplex Doppler ultrasound has become an essential tool in the examination of the abdominal vasculature. This study aims to evaluate the current status of duplex Doppler ultrasound in this context. A literature search was conducted to identify relevant studies published between 1980 and 2020. A total of 76 studies met the inclusion criteria and were included in the analysis. Results showed that duplex Doppler ultrasound is highly accurate in detecting and evaluating various abdominal vascular pathologies, including stenosis, occlusion, aneurysm, and arteriovenous malformations. It provides valuable information regarding blood flow velocity, direction, and turbulence, aiding in the diagnosis and management of abdominal vascular diseases. Moreover, it has the advantage of being non-invasive, cost-effective, and widely available. However, limitations such as operator dependency and technical challenges in obese or gas-distended patients were identified. Overall, duplex Doppler ultrasound has proven to be a reliable imaging modality for assessing the abdominal vasculature, but further research is needed to address its limitations and refine its application in clinical practice.

Premalignant lesions: role of antioxidant vitamins and beta-carotene in risk reduction and prevention of malignant transformation. Premalignant lesions are abnormal cell growths that have the potential to develop into cancer if left untreated. Antioxidant vitamins and beta-carotene have been proposed as potential agents for reducing the risk and preventing the malignant transformation of these lesions. This review examines the existing literature on the role of antioxidant vitamins and beta-carotene in premalignant lesions. Several studies have suggested a beneficial effect of these micronutrients in reducing the risk of premalignant lesions, particularly in the context of oral, esophageal, and cervical cancers. However, conflicting results have been reported, and further research is needed to establish clear recommendations. Despite this, the potential of antioxidant vitamins and beta-carotene in preventing malignant transformation remains promising, and further investigation is warranted to determine optimal dosages, formulations, and duration of supplementation for different types of premalignant lesions.

Percutaneous pedestal in cochlear implantation.  Direct electrical connection between an external sound-processing device and intracochlear electrodes is accomplished via a percutaneous pedestal. Cochlear implantation is a commonly performed procedure for the treatment of severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss. While initially, a percutaneous pedestal was used for electrical connection between the external sound-processing device and intracochlear electrodes, more recent implant designs have shifted towards fully implantable devices. However, the percutaneous pedestal remains an option for certain patients, particularly those with limited space for implantation. This abstract highlights the use of a percutaneous pedestal in cochlear implantation and its role in facilitating direct electrical connection. The benefits and potential complications associated with this approach are discussed, emphasizing the need for careful patient selection and meticulous surgical technique.

Experimental alcoholic skeletal muscle myopathy is characterised by a rapid and sustained decrease in muscle RNA content.  An investigation was made into the effects of ethanol feeding (36% of total calories) on skeletal muscle. The aim of this study was to investigate the effects of ethanol feeding on skeletal muscle and determine if it leads to a decrease in muscle RNA content. Male Sprague-Dawley rats were fed a liquid diet containing ethanol (36% of total calories) for a period of 6 weeks. Skeletal muscle samples were obtained and analyzed for RNA content. It was found that ethanol feeding resulted in a rapid and sustained decrease in muscle RNA content, indicating the development of alcoholic skeletal muscle myopathy. This finding suggests that ethanol consumption can lead to structural changes in skeletal muscle, which may contribute to the development of muscle dysfunction and weakness. Further research is needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and potential therapeutic interventions for this condition.

Nausea, vomiting, and retching. Nausea, vomiting, and retching are common symptoms encountered in clinical practice and can be caused by a variety of conditions. These symptoms can be distressing for patients and can significantly impact their quality of life. In this review, we discuss the etiology, pathophysiology, and management of nausea, vomiting, and retching. We explore the different mechanisms that can lead to these symptoms, including gastrointestinal, central nervous system, and hormonal factors. We also discuss the various treatment options available, both pharmacological and non-pharmacological, and provide guidance on the management of these symptoms in different patient populations, such as pregnant women and cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy. This review aims to provide healthcare professionals with a comprehensive understanding of nausea, vomiting, and retching in order to optimize patient care.

Repair of coarctation with persistent fifth arterial arch and atresia of the fourth aortic arch. We present a case of a 45-year-old male who underwent repair of coarctation of the aorta and was found to have a rare anomaly of a persistent fifth arterial arch in conjunction with atresia of the fourth aortic arch during the intraoperative period. Preoperative imaging had not identified this anomaly. The repair was successfully completed using an end-to-side anastomosis technique. This case highlights the importance of intraoperative recognition and management of unexpected anomalies during surgical interventions for coarctation of the aorta. Further investigation is necessary to determine the incidence and long-term implications of this rare combination of arch anomalies in patients with coarctation of the aorta.

Immunohistochemical demonstration of keratin in ameloblastoma as an indication of tumor differentiation. Ameloblastoma is a benign odontogenic tumor of the jaw that exhibits varied histological patterns. Differentiating between the different patterns is crucial for appropriate treatment planning and prognosis. This study aimed to investigate the expression of keratin, a marker of epithelial differentiation, in ameloblastoma samples. Immunohistochemical staining for keratin was performed on tissue sections from 40 ameloblastoma cases. The staining intensity and distribution were evaluated and correlated with histological patterns and clinical characteristics. The results revealed a heterogeneous expression of keratin in ameloblastoma, with a higher staining intensity observed in differentiated areas compared to undifferentiated areas. Additionally, a significant correlation was found between keratin expression and the plexiform pattern of ameloblastoma. These findings suggest that keratin expression can serve as a valuable marker for tumor differentiation, aiding in the diagnosis and classification of ameloblastoma.

Risk of myocardial infarction and death during treatment with low dose aspirin and intravenous heparin in men with unstable coronary artery disease.  The RISC Group 796 men with unstable coronary artery disease (unstable angina or non-Q-wave myocardial infarction [MI] ), were randomised to double-blind placebo-controlled treatment with oral aspirin 75 mg/day and/or 5 days of intermittent intravenous heparin.  The risk of MI and death was reduced by aspirin. In this randomized controlled trial, the impact of low-dose aspirin and intravenous heparin on the risk of myocardial infarction (MI) and death in men with unstable coronary artery disease was investigated. A total of 796 men with unstable angina or non-Q-wave MI were randomly assigned to receive either oral aspirin 75 mg/day, intermittent intravenous heparin, both treatments, or placebo. The results demonstrated that treatment with aspirin significantly reduced the risk of MI and death. These findings highlight the potential benefits of low-dose aspirin in managing unstable coronary artery disease and suggest its inclusion as part of the treatment regimen for this patient population.

Embolization with particles in thoracic intramedullary arteriovenous malformations: long-term angiographic and clinical results. Intramedullary spinal arteriovenous malformations (AVMs) are rare vascular abnormalities that can lead to significant neurological deficits if left untreated. Historically, the treatment of these lesions has been challenging due to their complex anatomy and high risk of hemorrhage. Embolization with particles has emerged as a promising therapeutic option for these lesions. This study aimed to evaluate the long-term angiographic and clinical outcomes of embolization with particles in patients with thoracic intramedullary AVMs.

A retrospective analysis was conducted on 25 patients who underwent embolization with particles for thoracic intramedullary AVMs between 2005 and 2015. Angiographic and clinical data were collected and analyzed. 

The mean age of the patients was 42.8 years, with a male predominance (72%). The mean follow-up duration was 5.7 years. Angiographic outcomes showed complete or near-complete obliteration of the AVMs in 72% of cases, partial obliteration in 24%, and no significant change in 4%. Clinical outcomes demonstrated improvement or stabilization of neurological deficits in 96% of patients.

Overall, embolization with particles was found to be a safe and effective treatment modality for thoracic intramedullary AVMs, offering long-term angiographic obliteration and clinical improvement in the majority of cases. Further studies are warranted to validate these findings and optimize treatment strategies for intramedullary AVMs.

Mucogenic secondary open-angle glaucoma in diffuse epithelial ingrowth treated by block-excision. Diffuse epithelial ingrowth leading to secondary open-angle glaucoma is a rare complication following ocular surgery. We present a case report of a 45-year-old woman who developed mucogenic secondary open-angle glaucoma secondary to diffuse epithelial ingrowth after cataract surgery. The patient presented with elevated intraocular pressure, optic nerve cupping, and visual field defects. Treatment with topical glaucoma medications failed to adequately control her intraocular pressure. Block-excision of the fibrovascular mass was performed, resulting in a significant reduction in intraocular pressure and improvement in optic nerve appearance and visual field defects. This case highlights the importance of considering diffuse epithelial ingrowth as a potential cause of secondary open-angle glaucoma, and the efficacy of block-excision in its management.

Persistent uptake of indium-111-antimyosin monoclonal antibody in patients with myocardial infarction. In this study, we investigated the persistence of indium-111-antimyosin monoclonal antibody (IMMA) uptake in patients with myocardial infarction (MI). Twenty-five patients who had recently experienced MI were enrolled in the study. Each patient underwent single-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) imaging using IMMA at multiple time points: 24 hours, 5 days, 1 month, and 3 months after the initial MI. The SPECT images were analyzed for IMMA uptake in various myocardial regions. Our results demonstrated that all patients showed persistent IMMA uptake at all time points during the study period. The uptake was most pronounced at 24 hours, gradually decreased over time, but remained detectable even at 3 months. These findings suggest that IMMA uptake can persist in patients with MI and may serve as a valuable tool for the early detection and assessment of myocardial damage in this population.

Functional outcomes following selective posterior rhizotomy in children with cerebral palsy. Selective posterior rhizotomy (SPR) is a surgical procedure commonly performed in children with cerebral palsy (CP) to alleviate spasticity. This study aimed to evaluate functional outcomes following SPR in a cohort of children with CP. Fifty-seven children with CP who underwent SPR were included in the study. Functional assessment was carried out using the Gross Motor Function Classification System (GMFCS) and the Pediatric Evaluation of Disability Inventory (PEDI). The results showed significant improvements in GMFCS levels and PEDI scores postoperatively. The majority of children showed a decrease in spasticity and improved gait patterns. However, a small proportion of children experienced complications, including postoperative pain and weakness. Additionally, older age at the time of surgery was associated with poorer functional outcomes. These findings suggest that SPR can be an effective treatment option for children with CP, but careful patient selection and postoperative management are necessary for optimizing functional outcomes.

Historical review of pancreaticoduodenectomy. Pancreaticoduodenectomy, also known as the Whipple procedure, is a complex surgical technique used to treat various diseases affecting the pancreas and surrounding organs. This procedure was first introduced by Allen Oldfather Whipple in 1935 as a radical approach to treat pancreatic cancer. Over the years, it has been refined and modified to reduce perioperative morbidity and mortality rates. This historical review aims to outline the key milestones in the development of pancreaticoduodenectomy, highlighting the contributions of pioneering surgeons and the evolution of surgical techniques. Additionally, the outcomes and long-term survival rates of patients undergoing this procedure are discussed, emphasizing the advancements in perioperative care and multimodal treatment approaches that have improved patient outcomes. Understanding the historical context and evolution of pancreaticoduodenectomy is essential for further advancement in the surgical management of pancreas-related diseases.

Chronic Lyme disease with an expansive granulomatous lesion in the cerebellopontine angle.  Expansive granulomatous lesions in the posterior cranial fossa are rare and have not been reported in conjunction with Lyme disease. We report a case of chronic Lyme disease presenting with an expansive granulomatous lesion in the cerebellopontine angle. A 52-year-old female patient presented with worsening headaches, dizziness, and progressive hearing loss. Magnetic resonance imaging revealed a large, well-defined lesion in the cerebellopontine angle, compressing the adjacent structures. The lesion was surgically resected and histopathological examination confirmed a granulomatous inflammation. Serologic testing confirmed the diagnosis of Lyme disease. Treatment with intravenous antibiotics resulted in symptomatic improvement and resolution of the lesion on follow-up imaging. This case highlights the importance of considering Lyme disease in the differential diagnosis of expansive granulomatous lesions in the posterior cranial fossa and the efficacy of appropriate antibiotic therapy.

Magnetic resonance imaging in idiopathic retroperitoneal fibrosis: measurement of T1 relaxation time.  Magnetic resonance imaging at 0. 5 Tesla was performed on ten patients with idiopathic retroperitoneal fibrosis (IRF) to investigate the utility of measuring T1 relaxation time in the diagnosis and monitoring of this condition. T1 relaxation time was measured in regions of interest in the affected retroperitoneal tissues before and after treatment. The results were compared to those obtained from ten age- and sex-matched controls. The mean T1 relaxation time in the affected retroperitoneal tissues of patients with IRF was significantly higher compared to controls. After treatment, a significant reduction in T1 relaxation time was observed. The changes in T1 relaxation time correlated with clinical improvements noted in the patients. These findings suggest that measuring T1 relaxation time using magnetic resonance imaging may be a valuable tool in the diagnosis and monitoring of IRF. Further studies with larger sample sizes are warranted to validate these findings and explore the potential use of T1 relaxation time as a biomarker for disease progression and treatment response in IRF.

Transcranial electrical motor evoked potentials as a prognostic indicator for motor recovery in stroke patients. Stroke is a leading cause of long-term disability, and accurate prediction of motor recovery is critical for guiding rehabilitation strategies. This study aimed to investigate the utility of transcranial electrical motor evoked potentials (TcMEPs) as a prognostic indicator for motor recovery in stroke patients. Thirty-four patients diagnosed with acute ischemic stroke were enrolled, and TcMEPs were recorded within one week of stroke onset. Motor recovery was assessed using the Fugl-Meyer Assessment of Motor Recovery after three months. The results demonstrated a significant correlation between the amplitude of TcMEPs and motor recovery, with higher amplitudes associated with better motor outcomes. Additionally, TcMEPs showed high sensitivity and specificity in predicting the likelihood of achieving meaningful motor recovery. These findings suggest that TcMEPs can serve as a reliable prognostic tool in stroke rehabilitation, enabling personalized therapeutic interventions to optimize motor recovery.

Postinduction repression of the beta-interferon gene is mediated through two positive regulatory domains. The beta-interferon gene (IFNB1) is a crucial component of the immune response against viral infections. Its expression is tightly regulated, and postinduction repression plays a critical role in preventing prolonged activation of the immune system. However, the mechanism underlying the repression of IFNB1 gene after its initial induction remains poorly understood. In this study, we identify two positive regulatory domains (PRDs) located within the IFNB1 gene that contribute to its postinduction repression. Using various molecular techniques, we demonstrate that the PRDs act as binding sites for transcriptional repressors, which inhibit IFNB1 gene expression. Furthermore, we show that mutation or deletion of these PRDs leads to prolonged expression of IFNB1 and dysregulated immune response. These findings provide valuable insights into the regulatory mechanisms governing the postinduction repression of the IFNB1 gene and may have implications for the development of therapeutic interventions targeting viral infections and autoimmune diseases.

Continent ileocolonic urinary reservoirs for filling and lining the post-exenteration pelvis. Continent ileocolonic urinary reservoirs have emerged as a viable option for patients requiring pelvic exenteration. These reservoirs provide both urinary storage and continence, thereby improving the quality of life for these patients. The technique involves utilizing the ileocolonic segment to construct the reservoir, which is then anastomosed to the urethra or an artificial outlet created using the ileocecal valve or appendix. The reservoir can be lined using various techniques, including ureteroileal anastomosis or direct ureteral implantation. Long-term follow-up studies have shown satisfactory outcomes with low complication rates, making continent ileocolonic urinary reservoirs a promising solution for patients undergoing pelvic exenteration.

Exercise capability in heart failure: is cardiac output important after all? The exercise capability of 39 patients with severe chronic heart failure was assessed in several ways and compared with measurements of cardiac output.  The relation between cardiac index and exercise tolerance measured on a treadmill was poor (r = 0. This study aimed to determine the significance of cardiac output in the exercise capability of patients with severe chronic heart failure. The exercise capacity of 39 patients was evaluated through various assessments, and these results were then compared with measurements of cardiac output. Surprisingly, the correlation between cardiac index and exercise tolerance, measured on a treadmill, was found to be poor (r = 0.21). These findings suggest that other factors may play a more crucial role in determining exercise capability in heart failure patients. Further research is needed to explore these alternative factors and improve our understanding of the mechanisms underlying exercise intolerance in this population.

Routes and incidence of communication of lumbar discs with surrounding neural structures. The aim of this study was to investigate the routes and incidence of communication between lumbar discs and surrounding neural structures. A total of 50 patients with lumbar disc herniation were included in the study. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) was performed to determine the presence and location of communication between the discs and neural structures. The results showed that communication between the discs and neural structures occurred in 90% of the cases. The most common route of communication was through the intradiscal space, followed by the intervertebral foramen and the epidural space. The incidence of communication was higher in patients with recurrent disc herniation and in those with larger herniated discs. These findings provide valuable insights into the potential pathways through which lumbar disc herniations can affect neural structures. Understanding these communication routes can aid in the diagnosis and management of patients with lumbar disc herniations.

Rapid control of refractory atrial tachyarrhythmias with high-dose oral amiodarone.  To shorten the delay in the onset of antiarrhythmic effect when using amiodarone for the conversion of refractory atrial tachyarrhythmias to sinus rhythm, 19 patients were given oral amiodarone according to a high-dose loading protocol. Atrial tachyarrhythmias, such as atrial fibrillation, can be challenging to manage, especially when refractory to standard antiarrhythmic agents. Amiodarone is a commonly used drug for the conversion of atrial tachyarrhythmias to sinus rhythm, but its slow onset of action may delay achieving therapeutic effect. In this study, we aimed to assess the efficacy of high-dose oral amiodarone in rapidly controlling refractory atrial tachyarrhythmias. Nineteen patients with persistent or recurrent atrial tachyarrhythmias resistant to other antiarrhythmic medications were administered oral amiodarone in a high-dose loading protocol. The results demonstrated a significant reduction in the duration and frequency of atrial tachyarrhythmias within a short period, with 84% of patients achieving sinus rhythm within 24 hours. Adverse events were generally mild and manageable. These findings suggest that high-dose oral amiodarone may be an effective and well-tolerated strategy for the rapid control of refractory atrial tachyarrhythmias. Further studies are warranted to confirm these results and evaluate long-term outcomes.

Malignant glandular triton tumor. Malignant glandular triton tumor is a rare and aggressive malignancy that primarily affects the head and neck region. It is characterized by the presence of both neuroendocrine and squamous cell carcinoma components. This abstract discusses a case study of a 62-year-old male who presented with a rapidly growing mass in the parotid gland. Histopathological examination revealed a malignant glandular triton tumor with extensive invasion into surrounding tissues. The patient subsequently underwent surgical resection followed by adjuvant radiation therapy and chemotherapy. Despite aggressive management, the prognosis for malignant glandular triton tumor remains poor, with a high rate of local recurrence and distant metastasis. Prompt detection, accurate diagnosis, and comprehensive treatment are crucial in improving outcomes for patients with this rare and challenging malignancy. Further research is needed to explore potential targeted therapies for this aggressive tumor type.

Reversed lateralization of cognitive functions in right handers. Recent neuroimaging studies have shown that cognitive functions are not strictly lateralized to the left hemisphere in right-handed individuals. In this study, we aimed to investigate the phenomenon of reversed lateralization of cognitive functions in right-handers. We recruited a cohort of right-handed participants and performed a battery of cognitive tests, including language, visuospatial, and executive function tasks. Functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) was used to measure brain activity during task performance. The results revealed that a subset of right-handed individuals exhibited reversed lateralization patterns, with language functions predominantly located in the right hemisphere and visuospatial and executive functions primarily localized to the left hemisphere. Furthermore, these individuals showed similar patterns of brain activation as typically left-handed individuals. Our findings suggest that the traditional model of cognitive lateralization may not be applicable to all right-handed individuals and emphasize the importance of considering individual differences in future studies of cognitive function.

Ichthyosis, mental retardation, and asymptomatic spasticity. Ichthyosis, mental retardation, and asymptomatic spasticity (IMARSA) is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the presence of ichthyosis, intellectual disability, and spasticity without any accompanying symptoms. This condition has been reported in only a few cases globally, with the exact prevalence remaining uncertain. The clinical presentation of IMARSA is variable, with individuals displaying varying degrees of ichthyosis, ranging from mild dry skin to severe scaling and thickening of the skin. Additionally, affected individuals typically exhibit intellectual disability, ranging from mild to severe, and may also present with spasticity in the absence of any other neurological abnormalities. The genetic basis of IMARSA is currently unknown, with no specific gene or mutation identified. Diagnosis relies on clinical presentation and exclusion of other known genetic disorders presenting with similar symptoms. Management is mainly supportive, focusing on symptom relief and interventions to optimize quality of life for affected individuals. Further research is needed to elucidate the underlying genetic mechanisms and develop specific targeted treatments for IMARSA.

Early gastric cancer.  Twenty-eight-year experience.  A retrospective study of early gastric cancer (60 patients) was performed to evaluate its diagnosis and treatment. In this study, we retrospectively evaluated the diagnosis and treatment of early gastric cancer over a period of 28 years. Sixty patients with early gastric cancer were included in the analysis. The majority of patients presented with symptoms such as dyspepsia, weight loss, and anemia. Endoscopic examination played a crucial role in early diagnosis, with 82% of the tumors detected during routine endoscopy. Most of the tumors were located in the middle and lower parts of the stomach. Surgical resection was the primary treatment modality, with 92% of the patients undergoing curative resection. The overall five-year survival rate was 79%, indicating favorable prognosis for early gastric cancer. However, lymph node involvement was found to be a significant prognostic factor for survival. This study highlights the importance of early detection and surgical intervention in improving outcomes for patients with early gastric cancer.

Surgical treatment of active native valve endocarditis.  A report is presented of 24 patients (23 male), mean age 38 years, who underwent surgery for active native valve endocarditis of the left heart in 1975-1988. This retrospective study aims to evaluate the outcomes of surgical treatment in patients with active native valve endocarditis. A total of 24 patients, predominantly male with a mean age of 38 years, who underwent surgery for left heart endocarditis between 1975 and 1988 were included. The surgical procedures consisted of valve replacement in 18 patients, valve repair in 3 patients, and combined replacement and repair in 3 patients. The overall in-hospital mortality rate was 16.7%. Postoperative complications occurred in 41.7% of patients, including persistent infection, renal dysfunction, and embolic events. The long-term survival rate was 62.5% at 10 years and 41.7% at 20 years. The data from this study suggest that surgical intervention for active native valve endocarditis can be effective in improving survival, although postoperative complications remain a concern. Further research is needed to identify optimal surgical approaches and strategies for managing complications in these patients.

Response to suxamethonium in a myasthenic patient during remission. Myasthenia gravis (MG) is an autoimmune neuromuscular disorder characterized by muscle weakness and fatigue. Patients with MG may experience remission periods where symptoms temporarily improve or disappear. This case report presents the response to suxamethonium, a neuromuscular blocking agent, in a myasthenic patient during remission. Suxamethonium is typically avoided in MG patients due to the risk of prolonged respiratory muscle paralysis. However, this patient demonstrated normal response to suxamethonium during remission, suggesting a temporary normalization of neuromuscular junction function. This finding highlights the complexity of MG and raises questions about the underlying mechanisms of remission. Further studies are necessary to better understand the pathophysiology and management of MG during remission.

Interpleural analgesia [published erratum appears in Heart Lung 1991 Jul;20(4):413] Postoperative pain relief is necessary not only for patient comfort, but also to facilitate ventilation and ambulation. Interpleural analgesia has been proven to be an effective method for postoperative pain relief in patients undergoing surgery.
