Interphase cytogenetic analysis has emerged as an essential tool in the diagnosis and study of neoplastic disorders. This technique involves the investigation of chromosomal abnormalities and their impact on cellular behavior and disease development. By analyzing interphase nuclei, interphase cytogenetics allows for the detection of numerical and structural chromosomal aberrations that may not be visible in traditional cytogenetic analyses.

In the context of neoplastic disorders, interphase cytogenetic analysis provides valuable information for accurate diagnosis, prognosis, and treatment planning. It has proven particularly useful in identifying specific genetic alterations associated with hematologic malignancies, solid tumors, and genetic syndromes. With the advent of fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) and other molecular techniques, interphase cytogenetics has become highly sensitive and specific in detecting chromosomal rearrangements, gene amplifications, and deletions.

Furthermore, interphase cytogenetic analysis has contributed to a better understanding of the underlying mechanisms and pathways involved in neoplastic transformation. By elucidating the genetic alterations associated with tumor initiation and progression, this technique has facilitated the development of targeted therapies and personalized medicine approaches.

Overall, interphase cytogenetic analysis plays a crucial role in the comprehensive assessment of neoplastic disorders, improving diagnostic accuracy, prognostication, and therapeutic decision-making. Its continued advancements are anticipated to further enhance our understanding of cancer biology and enhance patient outcomes.

Potential role of beta-carotene in prevention of oral cancer. Oral cancer is a significant global health problem, with high mortality rates and limited treatment options. Various chemopreventive strategies have been investigated to reduce the incidence and progression of oral cancer, including the use of dietary compounds such as beta-carotene. Beta-carotene, a precursor of vitamin A, exhibits powerful antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties, which have been shown to inhibit carcinogenesis and suppress tumor growth in preclinical models. Epidemiological studies have reported mixed results regarding the association between beta-carotene intake and oral cancer risk, with some suggesting a protective effect and others indicating no significant association. This discrepancy may be due to variations in study design, population characteristics, and genetic factors. Nevertheless, preclinical and clinical evidence supports the potential role of beta-carotene in oral cancer prevention by modulating key molecular pathways involved in tumor initiation and progression. Further studies are necessary to investigate the optimal dosage, duration, and population subgroups that may benefit the most from beta-carotene intervention for oral cancer prevention.

Unusual aspects of aortovenous fistulas associated with ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysms. Aortovenous fistulas (AVFs) associated with ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysms (RAAAs) are rare but potentially life-threatening complications. Most reported cases describe AVFs between the aorta and the inferior vena cava (IVC) or iliac veins. Here, we present two cases of AVFs associated with RAAAs that had atypical characteristics. The first case involved an AVF between the aorta and the right common iliac artery, with subsequent dilation of the right iliac vein. The second case featured an AVF between the aorta and the left internal iliac vein. In both cases, the patients presented with symptoms of hypovolemia and hemodynamic instability. Radiographic imaging revealed disrupted abdominal aortic aneurysms and contrast extravasation into adjacent veins. Emergency surgical intervention was performed to repair the aneurysms and ligate the AVFs. Both patients experienced successful recoveries without any postoperative complications. These cases highlight the diverse presentations and management considerations of AVFs associated with RAAAs.

General assay for phosphoproteins in cerebrospinal fluid: a candidate marker for paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration. Paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration (PCD) is a rare neurological disorder associated with various types of cancers. The diagnosis of PCD can be challenging and often requires the identification of specific biomarkers. This study aimed to develop a general assay for phosphoproteins in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) as a potential marker for PCD. CSF samples were collected from PCD patients and controls, and phosphoproteins were enriched and analyzed using mass spectrometry. A panel of phosphoproteins was identified, showing differential expression between PCD patients and controls. Further validation studies confirmed the diagnostic accuracy of selected phosphoproteins in distinguishing PCD patients from controls. These findings suggest that phosphoproteins in CSF could serve as promising biomarkers for PCD. The developed assay may be a valuable tool for early diagnosis and monitoring of PCD, leading to improved patient outcomes. Further studies are warranted to validate these findings in larger cohorts and different cancer types associated with PCD.

Ulnar nerve decompression with medial epicondylectomy for neuropathy at the elbow.  Ulnar nerve decompression with medial epicondylectomy was performed in 66 elbows between 1966 and 1986 for compressive ulnar neuropathy at the elbow. This study aimed to evaluate the outcomes of ulnar nerve decompression with medial epicondylectomy for neuropathy at the elbow. A total of 66 elbows that underwent the procedure between 1966 and 1986 were included in the analysis. The mean age of the patients was 51 years, and the mean follow-up period was 7 years. The most common presenting symptom was numbness and tingling in the ulnar distribution. Seventy-eight percent of the patients reported improvement in symptoms postoperatively, while 16% reported no change and 6% reported worsening of symptoms. The mean grip strength improved from 45% preoperatively to 71% postoperatively. Overall, ulnar nerve decompression with medial epicondylectomy showed favorable outcomes in relieving symptoms and improving grip strength in patients with compressive ulnar neuropathy at the elbow.

Management of renovascular disease. Renovascular disease, also known as renal artery stenosis, is a condition characterized by the narrowing of the renal arteries, leading to impaired blood flow to the kidneys. This can result in hypertension and renal dysfunction. The management of renovascular disease aims to restore renal blood flow and control blood pressure, thereby preventing further kidney damage. 

Treatment options include medical therapy, percutaneous transluminal renal angioplasty (PTRA), and surgical revascularization. Medical therapy involves the use of antihypertensive medications to control blood pressure and manage associated conditions such as diabetes and high cholesterol. PTRA is a minimally invasive procedure that involves the inflation of a small balloon within the narrowed artery, expanding the lumen and improving blood flow. In cases where PTRA is not feasible or unsuccessful, surgical revascularization may be considered. This involves bypassing the blocked or narrowed artery with a graft to restore normal blood flow to the kidneys.

The choice of treatment depends on various factors including the severity of the disease, presence of comorbidities, and patient preference. Close monitoring and regular follow-up are crucial to assess treatment efficacy and optimize long-term renal function.

Skin exudate levels of interleukin 6, interleukin 1 and other cytokines in mycosis fungoides. Mycosis fungoides (MF) is the most common type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma, characterized by the infiltration of malignant T-cells into the skin. The role of cytokines in the pathogenesis of MF remains unclear. In this study, we aimed to investigate the levels of interleukin 6 (IL-6), interleukin 1 (IL-1) and other cytokines in skin exudates of patients with MF. 
Skin exudate samples were collected from 30 patients with MF and 30 healthy controls. The levels of IL-6, IL-1, and other cytokines were measured using enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay. Our results showed that the levels of IL-6 and IL-1 were significantly higher in the skin exudates of MF patients compared to healthy controls (p<0.001). Furthermore, the levels of other cytokines, including tumor necrosis factor-alpha and interferon-gamma, were also elevated in MF patients. 
These findings suggest that cytokines, especially IL-6 and IL-1, may play a role in the pathogenesis of MF. Further studies are needed to elucidate the mechanisms by which these cytokines contribute to the development and progression of MF, and to explore their potential as therapeutic targets.

Is liver transplantation justified for the treatment of hepatic malignancies? Twenty-eight patients received orthotopic liver transplants for malignant disease between February 1, 1984, and December 31, 1989.  Preoperative diagnoses included hepatocellular carcinoma (n = 16), cholangiocarcinoma (n = 3), other primary hepatic tumors (n = 6), and metastatic diseases to the liver (n = 3). Overall survival at 1, 3, and 5 years were 70%, 59%, and 51%, respectively. The recurrence-free survival rates at the same intervals were 62%, 51%, and 44%. Hepatocellular carcinoma patients had the best outcomes, with a 5-year survival rate of 62%. Cholangiocarcinoma patients had the lowest survival rates, with a 5-year survival rate of 28%. Although liver transplantation for hepatic malignancies can provide significant survival benefits in select patients, careful patient selection is crucial. Future studies should focus on refining selection criteria and improving long-term outcomes to determine the role of liver transplantation in hepatic malignancies.

Microstaging of squamous cell carcinomas. Microstaging is a critical component in the management of squamous cell carcinomas (SCCs). It provides detailed information about the depth of invasion, tumor thickness, and involvement of adjacent structures, which are crucial for appropriate treatment planning and prognosis determination. This retrospective study aimed to evaluate the utility of microstaging in a cohort of 100 patients with SCCs.

The results showed that microstaging significantly correlated with the risk of lymph node metastasis (p < 0.001) and disease progression (p = 0.003). Patients with deeper invasion and thicker tumors had a higher likelihood of lymph node involvement and poorer prognosis. Additionally, the involvement of adjacent structures was associated with a significantly higher risk of local recurrence (p = 0.012).

Furthermore, microstaging was found to be a valuable tool in guiding treatment decisions. Patients with early-stage disease (microstaging T1) had excellent outcomes with surgery alone, while those with more advanced disease (microstaging T2-T4) benefited from multimodal approaches, including surgery, radiation therapy, and chemotherapy.

In conclusion, microstaging provides crucial information for risk stratification, treatment planning, and prognostication in SCCs. Its incorporation into routine clinical practice is recommended to optimize patient management and improve outcomes.

An autosomal recessive gene that delays expression of lupus in BXSB mice. The BXSB mouse strain is a well-known model for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). However, a subline of BXSB mice has been identified that shows a significant delay in the onset and severity of lupus-like disease. In this study, the authors investigate the genetic basis of this delayed lupus phenotype in the BXSB mice. Using a combination of linkage analysis, genome-wide association study, and candidate gene approaches, they identify a novel autosomal recessive gene that is responsible for the delayed expression of lupus. This gene appears to modulate the immune response and promote immune tolerance, resulting in a milder lupus phenotype. Further understanding of this gene and its mechanism of action may provide insights into potential therapeutic strategies for delayed onset and progression of lupus in humans.

Intracatheter streptokinase for recurrent peritonitis in CAPD. Recurrent peritonitis is a common complication in patients undergoing continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis (CAPD). Intracatheter streptokinase has been used as a treatment option for this condition, but its efficacy and safety have not been extensively studied. This study aimed to evaluate the outcomes of patients with recurrent peritonitis who received intracatheter streptokinase. A total of 50 patients with CAPD and recurrent peritonitis were included in the study. The patients were treated with intracatheter streptokinase and were monitored for complications and treatment outcomes. The results showed that intracatheter streptokinase was effective in resolving peritonitis episodes, with a success rate of 80%. There were no major complications associated with the use of intracatheter streptokinase. The study suggests that intracatheter streptokinase can be considered as a safe and effective treatment option for patients with recurrent peritonitis in CAPD. Further research is needed to assess the long-term outcomes and optimal dosing regimens of intracatheter streptokinase in this patient population.

Isolated ventral pancreatitis in a patient with pancreas divisum. Pancreas divisum is a congenital anomaly that occurs when the dorsal and ventral pancreatic ducts fail to fuse, resulting in impaired pancreatic drainage. Although it is a relatively common finding, it is usually asymptomatic. We present the case of a 45-year-old male who presented with severe abdominal pain and was found to have isolated ventral pancreatitis in the setting of pancreas divisum. This is a rare presentation, as most cases of pancreatitis in pancreas divisum involve both the dorsal and ventral pancreas. The patient underwent endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) with stent placement to relieve obstruction of the ventral pancreatic duct. He had a successful recovery with resolution of symptoms. This case highlights the importance of considering isolated ventral pancreatitis as a potential etiology in patients with pancreas divisum presenting with acute pancreatitis-like symptoms. Proper diagnosis and targeted management can lead to favorable outcomes in these patients.

Kenneth McKenzie, Harvey Cushing, and the early neurosurgical treatment of spasmodic torticollis.  In 1923, Dr. Spasmodic torticollis, also known as cervical dystonia, is a movement disorder characterized by involuntary contractions of the neck muscles, resulting in abnormal head positioning. This medical abstract focuses on the early neurosurgical treatment of spasmodic torticollis by Dr. Kenneth McKenzie and Harvey Cushing in 1923. The abstract highlights their pioneering work in treating this condition through the surgical division of the accessory nerve, which was found to be the pathogenic factor in spasmodic torticollis. The abstract emphasizes the importance of their contributions in advancing the understanding and treatment of this debilitating movement disorder, paving the way for future neurosurgical interventions in the field.

Defective dystrophin in Duchenne and Becker dystrophy myotubes in cell culture. Duchenne and Becker muscular dystrophies (DMD and BMD) are progressive muscle-wasting disorders caused by defective dystrophin protein. In this study, myotubes derived from DMD and BMD patient cells were cultured to investigate the dystrophin expression and functionality. Immunocytochemical analysis showed a complete absence of dystrophin in DMD myotubes, whereas BMD myotubes displayed a reduced and abnormal dystrophin distribution. Additionally, western blotting confirmed the absence or presence of truncated dystrophin isoforms in DMD and BMD myotubes, respectively. Functional assessment revealed reduced sarcolemmal integrity and increased susceptibility to mechanical stress in both DMD and BMD myotubes, as evidenced by increased cell membrane permeability and decreased resistance to hypotonic shock. Furthermore, immunofluorescence staining for the dystrophin-associated protein complex components showed disrupted localization and reduced expression levels in DMD and BMD myotubes compared to controls. These findings provide insights into the pathogenesis of DMD and BMD and highlight the potential of using myotubes as a model system for studying disease mechanisms and evaluating therapeutic interventions.

Transesophageal echocardiography in the diagnosis of ostial left coronary artery stenosis. The aim of this study was to evaluate the efficacy of transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) in diagnosing ostial left coronary artery stenosis (OLCAS). A retrospective analysis was conducted on 50 patients who underwent TEE for suspected coronary artery disease. TEE findings were compared to coronary angiography, the gold standard for diagnosing OLCAS. Results showed that TEE had a sensitivity of 92% and a specificity of 98% in detecting OLCAS. Additionally, it had a positive predictive value of 88% and a negative predictive value of 99%. The most common TEE findings associated with OLCAS were focal luminal narrowing, plaque formation, and irregularly shaped ostium. TEE also demonstrated excellent visualization of the proximal course of the left coronary artery. Overall, TEE was found to be a highly accurate and non-invasive imaging modality for diagnosing OLCAS, providing important information for appropriate management and treatment of patients with this condition.

Long-term effects of delapril on renal function and urinary excretion of kallikrein, prostaglandin E2, and thromboxane B2 in hypertensive patients.  The effects of delapril, an angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor, on renal function and the renin-angiotensin and kallikrein-prostaglandin systems were investigated in 10 hypertensive patients who were treated for between 4 months and 1 year. Delapril, an angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor, is commonly used to treat hypertension. However, its effects on renal function and the renin-angiotensin and kallikrein-prostaglandin systems have not been extensively studied. In this research, renal function and the urinary excretion of kallikrein, prostaglandin E2, and thromboxane B2 were measured in 10 hypertensive patients who had been treated with delapril for a duration of 4 months to 1 year. The results showed that delapril had a positive effect on renal function, resulting in improved renal parameters. Additionally, the drug was found to increase urinary excretion of kallikrein and prostaglandin E2, while suppressing thromboxane B2 levels. This suggests that delapril might have renoprotective and anti-inflammatory effects in hypertensive patients.

Management of hypertension by reduction in sympathetic activity. Hypertension, a major global health problem, is often associated with an overactive sympathetic nervous system. Current treatment strategies for hypertension primarily target the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system or calcium channels, but emerging evidence suggests that reducing sympathetic activity may be a promising alternative approach. This abstract reviews the potential management of hypertension through sympathetic activity reduction. Various interventions aimed at modulating sympathetic activity, such as lifestyle modifications, exercise, dietary changes, and pharmacological options including beta blockers and centrally acting agents, are discussed. The impact of sympathetic activity reduction on blood pressure control and its potential effects on cardiovascular outcomes are examined. The abstract highlights the need for further research to establish the efficacy and safety of these interventions and to determine their optimal utilization in the management of hypertension. Future directions and potential advancements in this field are also proposed.

Surgery for acute and chronic cholecystitis.  Cholecystostomy and cholecystectomy remain appropriate and effective therapy for acute and chronic cholecystitis. Cholecystostomy and cholecystectomy are widely accepted as the primary surgical interventions for acute and chronic cholecystitis. This study aims to evaluate the efficacy and appropriateness of these procedures in the treatment of these conditions. A retrospective analysis of patients who underwent cholecystostomy or cholecystectomy for acute or chronic cholecystitis was conducted. The results showed that both procedures effectively resolved symptoms and improved patient outcomes. Cholecystostomy was found to be particularly beneficial for patients with severe comorbidities or high surgical risk. Cholecystectomy, on the other hand, offered a more definitive treatment option with lower rates of recurrence. Overall, both procedures were deemed appropriate and effective in the management of acute and chronic cholecystitis.

Bleeding gastroesophageal varices: gastric vein embolization after partial portal decompression. Gastroesophageal varices are a common complication of portal hypertension and can lead to life-threatening bleeding. Gastric vein embolization after partial portal decompression has been proposed as a treatment option for this condition. We present a case study of a patient with bleeding gastroesophageal varices who underwent this procedure. The patient had a history of alcoholic cirrhosis and presented with massive upper gastrointestinal bleeding. After initial stabilization, a partial portal decompression procedure was performed to decrease portal hypertension. Subsequently, gastric vein embolization was performed to further reduce the risk of variceal bleeding. This involved the selective embolization of the left gastric vein and its tributaries using coils and sclerosing agents. The procedure was successful in achieving hemostasis and the patient had no further episodes of bleeding during follow-up. Our case highlights the potential efficacy of gastric vein embolization after partial portal decompression in the management of bleeding gastroesophageal varices. Further research is needed to evaluate the long-term outcomes and safety of this treatment approach.

Delayed onset of cardiac arrhythmias from sustained-release verapamil. Verapamil is a calcium channel blocker commonly used to treat cardiac arrhythmias. This case report describes a patient who experienced delayed onset of cardiac arrhythmias after taking sustained-release verapamil. The patient presented with palpitations and chest discomfort several hours after ingesting the medication. Electrocardiogram monitoring revealed episodes of atrial fibrillation, which required treatment with electrical cardioversion. The delay in the onset of cardiac arrhythmias suggests a potential role of sustained-release verapamil in promoting arrhythmogenicity. It is important for clinicians to be aware of this adverse effect and to monitor patients closely after initiating verapamil therapy. Further studies are warranted to investigate the underlying mechanisms and determine the incidence of delayed onset cardiac arrhythmias associated with sustained-release verapamil.

Polyglucosan body disease.  Adult polyglucosan disease has been described in 15 cases. Polyglucosan body disease is a rare metabolic disorder characterized by the accumulation of insoluble glycogen-like material in various tissues, including the central and peripheral nervous systems. This abstract presents a case series of 15 adults with polyglucosan disease. The average age of onset was 42 years (range, 30-71 years), and the most common initial symptom was progressive gait disturbance. Other neurological features included cognitive impairment, bladder dysfunction, and peripheral neuropathy. Muscle biopsy showed characteristic polyglucosan bodies in all cases. Genetic analysis revealed mutations in the glycogen branching enzyme gene in five cases. Treatment options are limited, with individualized symptom management being the mainstay. Early recognition of this disease is crucial to optimize patient care and provide appropriate genetic counseling. Further studies are needed to better understand the pathogenesis and develop targeted therapies for this rare disorder.

Plasma cell granuloma of the nasal cavity treated by radiation therapy. Plasma cell granuloma is a rare benign lesion that can occur in various anatomical locations. This case report presents a rare manifestation of plasma cell granuloma in the nasal cavity and describes its successful treatment with radiation therapy. A 46-year-old male presented with nasal obstruction and epistaxis. Nasal endoscopy revealed a mass in the left nasal cavity. Biopsy confirmed a diagnosis of plasma cell granuloma. Due to the inaccessible location and the potential for incomplete surgical resection, the patient was treated with radiation therapy. A total dose of 45 Gy in 25 fractions was delivered over a period of 5 weeks. Follow-up examinations showed complete resolution of the mass and significant improvement in symptoms. No acute or late toxicities were observed. This case highlights the efficacy of radiation therapy as a treatment modality for nasal plasma cell granuloma, particularly in cases where surgical resection may be challenging. Further studies are warranted to validate these findings and establish appropriate treatment guidelines.

The recalcitrant perineal wound after rectal extirpation.  Applications of muscle flap closure. Rectal extirpation is a common surgical procedure performed for various conditions, with wound healing being a critical aspect of postoperative care. However, some patients may experience persistent perineal wounds that are difficult to heal, posing a significant challenge to healthcare providers. This study aimed to investigate the efficacy of muscle flap closure in managing recalcitrant perineal wounds following rectal extirpation.

A retrospective analysis was conducted on 32 patients who had undergone rectal extirpation and subsequently developed non-healing perineal wounds. These patients were treated with muscle flap closure, either through transposition or rotation techniques. 

Results showed that muscle flap closure effectively facilitated wound healing in all patients, with complete wound closure achieved within an average of 8 weeks. Furthermore, there were no major postoperative complications observed, highlighting the safety and feasibility of this technique.

In conclusion, muscle flap closure proves to be a valuable option in the management of recalcitrant perineal wounds after rectal extirpation, offering promising outcomes and improved quality of life for patients. Further prospective studies are warranted to validate these findings and evaluate long-term outcomes.

Surgical correction of hydrothorax from diaphragmatic eventration in children on peritoneal dialysis.  Continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis (CAPD) is frequently used in the pediatric age group for reversible and end-stage renal failure. Diaphragmatic eventration, a condition characterized by abnormal elevation and thinning of the diaphragm, can lead to the development of hydrothorax in children undergoing peritoneal dialysis. This study aimed to investigate the outcomes of surgical correction of hydrothorax in these patients. A total of 12 children who underwent surgical correction for hydrothorax associated with diaphragmatic eventration during peritoneal dialysis were included in the study. The surgical procedure involved plication of the diaphragm to restore its normal position and reinforcement with a prosthetic material. All patients successfully underwent surgery without any major complications. Postoperatively, hydrothorax resolved in all cases, and there were no recurrences during the follow-up period. In conclusion, surgical correction of hydrothorax in children on peritoneal dialysis with diaphragmatic eventration is a safe and effective procedure with favorable outcomes.

Progressive coma after the transsphenoidal decompression of a pituitary adenoma with marked suprasellar extension: report of two cases. We report the cases of two patients who developed progressive coma after transsphenoidal decompression surgery for pituitary adenomas with marked suprasellar extension. Both patients initially presented with symptoms of pituitary dysfunction and underwent surgical intervention. However, postoperatively, they experienced a rapid deterioration in consciousness, eventually leading to coma. Imaging studies revealed significant expansion of the suprasellar component of the tumor, causing compression of the optic chiasm and hypothalamus. Despite aggressive medical management and interventions, both patients succumbed to their condition. This highlights the potential complications associated with transsphenoidal decompression in cases of pituitary adenomas with extensive suprasellar involvement. Surgeons should exercise caution and consider alternative treatment strategies in such cases to minimize the risk of postoperative coma and its associated morbidity and mortality. Further research is needed to better understand the underlying mechanisms and risk factors for this devastating complication.

Cytologic features of poorly differentiated 'insular' carcinoma of the thyroid, as revealed by fine-needle aspiration biopsy. Poorly differentiated 'insular' carcinoma of the thyroid (PDICT) is a rare subtype of thyroid carcinoma characterized by aggressive behavior and poor prognosis. Fine-needle aspiration biopsy (FNAB) is a minimally invasive diagnostic tool routinely used to evaluate thyroid nodules. However, little is known about the cytologic features of PDICT on FNAB, and this knowledge gap hinders accurate pre-operative diagnosis. In this study, we aim to describe the cytologic features of PDICT on FNAB and evaluate their diagnostic utility. A retrospective analysis was performed on FNAB specimens from 25 patients with surgically confirmed PDICT. Cytologic features including cellularity, tumor cell clusters, nuclear morphology, chromatin pattern, and presence of necrosis were assessed. Our results demonstrate that PDICT on FNAB is characterized by high cellularity, small cohesive clusters of tumor cells, marked nuclear pleomorphism, coarse chromatin pattern, and frequent presence of necrosis. These findings can aid in the pre-operative diagnosis of PDICT, thus providing valuable information for treatment planning and prognostic assessment. Further studies with larger sample sizes are warranted to validate these findings and improve the diagnostic accuracy of FNAB for PDICT.

Differences between florid osseous dysplasia and chronic diffuse sclerosing osteomyelitis.  Florid osseous dysplasia (FOD) is confused in the literature with chronic diffuse sclerosing osteomyelitis. Florid osseous dysplasia (FOD) and chronic diffuse sclerosing osteomyelitis (CDSO) are both rare entities presenting as radiopaque lesions in the jaws. FOD is characterized by multiple bilateral radiopaque masses that involve the mandible and maxilla, while CDSO is a chronic inflammatory condition typically affecting the mandible. Despite their similar radiographic appearance, these conditions have distinct clinical and histopathological features. FOD is typically asymptomatic, while CDSO is associated with pain, swelling, and fistula formation. Histologically, FOD is characterized by fibrous tissue with osseous metaplasia and dystrophic calcifications, whereas CDSO shows chronic inflammation with fibrosis and osteomyelitis. A thorough clinical examination, radiographic assessment, and histopathological evaluation are necessary for accurate diagnosis and appropriate management of these conditions.

Supported employment: an alternative model for vocational rehabilitation of persons with severe neurologic, psychiatric, or physical disability. Supported employment is a promising approach for vocational rehabilitation of individuals with severe neurologic, psychiatric, or physical disabilities. This model emphasizes competitive employment in integrated community settings and provides individualized support to maximize the individual's success in the workplace. The goal of supported employment is to enhance the person's quality of life and promote their full participation in society. This abstract reviews the current literature on supported employment and its effectiveness in improving employment outcomes for individuals with severe disabilities. Several studies have shown that individuals who receive supported employment services are more likely to obtain and maintain competitive employment compared to those who receive traditional vocational rehabilitation services. Furthermore, individuals in supported employment also report higher job satisfaction and overall life satisfaction. These findings highlight the importance of integrating supported employment into the rehabilitation process for individuals with severe disabilities.

A diagnostic expert system for colonic lesions. Colonic lesions pose a significant challenge in terms of accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment. A diagnostic expert system holds promise in providing reliable and efficient solutions in this domain. This study aimed to develop and evaluate a diagnostic expert system for colonic lesions based on clinical data and imaging findings. A total of 150 patients with suspected colonic lesions were included in the study. The expert system incorporated a knowledge base, an inference engine, and a user interface for data input and output. The diagnostic accuracy of the expert system was assessed by comparing its outcomes with those of experienced gastroenterologists. The expert system demonstrated a high diagnostic accuracy, with an overall sensitivity of 90% and specificity of 85%. The system also exhibited good reliability and user-friendliness. Therefore, the diagnostic expert system holds great potential in enhancing the accuracy and efficiency of colonic lesion diagnosis.

Pharmacologic stress imaging. Pharmacologic stress imaging is a diagnostic technique used in the evaluation of cardiac function and perfusion. This imaging modality is particularly useful in patients who are unable to undergo exercise stress testing. Pharmacologic stress is induced by the administration of pharmacologic agents that mimic the effects of exercise on the cardiovascular system. This results in an increase in myocardial oxygen demand and allows for the detection of ischemic regions in the heart. Various pharmacologic agents can be used, including adenosine, dipyridamole, and dobutamine. Imaging is performed using techniques such as single-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) or positron emission tomography (PET), which allow for the visualization and quantification of myocardial blood flow and function. The findings on pharmacologic stress imaging can help guide management decisions in patients with known or suspected coronary artery disease. Additionally, this technique has demonstrated prognostic value in determining the risk of future cardiac events.

A histopathologic study of spinal cord ischemia using an isohistogenic rat upper-half-body transplantation model. Spinal cord ischemia remains a challenge in clinical practice, and studies investigating its pathogenesis are limited. In this study, we developed a novel isohistogenic rat upper-half-body transplantation model to examine the histopathological changes associated with spinal cord ischemia. Sixteen male Sprague-Dawley rats were included in the study, with eight rats serving as donors and eight rats as recipients. After transplantation, the animals were sacrificed at different time points, and spinal cord tissue samples were collected for histopathological analysis. The results revealed prominent histopathological changes, including neuronal degeneration, vacuolization, and edema in the ischemic spinal cord. Additionally, neuronal loss and glial cell activation were observed in the gray matter of the affected spinal cord segments. This is the first study to establish an isohistogenic rat upper-half-body transplantation model for investigating spinal cord ischemia, providing valuable insights into its pathogenesis and potential therapeutic strategies.

The incidence of deep vein thrombosis after cementless and cemented knee replacement. The incidence of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) after total knee arthroplasty (TKA) varies depending on the type of fixation method used. This study aimed to compare the incidence of DVT after cementless and cemented knee replacement surgeries. A total of 200 patients who underwent TKA were included in the study. Fifty percent of the patients received cementless implants while the other fifty percent received cemented implants. Doppler ultrasound was performed on all patients within 24 hours postoperatively to screen for DVT. The incidence of DVT was found to be 10% in the cementless group and 20% in the cemented group. There was a statistically significant difference in the incidence of DVT between the two groups (p < 0.05), with the cementless group having a lower risk of DVT. These findings suggest that the use of cementless fixation in TKA may decrease the incidence of DVT compared to cemented fixation. Further studies with larger sample sizes are warranted to confirm these results.

Reduction in bleeding after heart-lung transplantation.  The importance of posterior mediastinal hemostasis. Bleeding is a common complication after heart-lung transplantation, often leading to increased morbidity and mortality rates. In this study, the authors aimed to investigate the impact of posterior mediastinal hemostasis on reducing bleeding in heart-lung transplant recipients. The study included 60 patients who underwent heart-lung transplantation and were divided into two groups based on the surgical technique employed for posterior mediastinal hemostasis.

Group A underwent conventional hemostasis techniques, while Group B received additional efforts to achieve meticulous posterior mediastinal hemostasis. The primary outcome measure was postoperative bleeding volume assessed over the first 48 hours.

The results showed that patients in Group B had a significantly lower mean postoperative bleeding volume compared to those in Group A (p<0.001). Furthermore, patients in Group B had a reduced need for blood transfusions and experienced shorter intensive care unit and hospital stays.

These findings highlight the importance of meticulous posterior mediastinal hemostasis in heart-lung transplant recipients, as it significantly reduces bleeding, decreases the need for blood transfusions, and improves patient outcomes.

Neuroendocrine carcinoma of the ampulla of vater. Neuroendocrine carcinoma of the ampulla of Vater is a rare malignant tumor arising in the ampulla, with a poor prognosis. This study aims to analyze the clinical characteristics and management outcomes of patients with neuroendocrine carcinoma of the ampulla of Vater. A retrospective analysis was conducted on patients diagnosed with neuroendocrine carcinoma between 2005 and 2015. The study cohort included 36 patients, with a mean age of 62 years. The majority presented with abdominal pain and jaundice. Surgical resection was the mainstay of treatment, with adjuvant chemotherapy administered in certain cases. The overall survival rate at 5 years was 34.6%, highlighting the aggressive nature of this tumor and the need for further research to improve outcomes.

Co-trimoxazole for childhood febrile illness in malaria-endemic regions. Febrile illness is a common presentation in children living in malaria-endemic regions. Co-trimoxazole, a combination of sulfamethoxazole and trimethoprim, is commonly used for the treatment of various infections. This study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of co-trimoxazole in childhood febrile illness in malaria-endemic regions. A randomized controlled trial was conducted, involving children aged 6 months to 12 years presenting with fever. The study found that co-trimoxazole significantly reduced the duration of fever and improved clinical outcomes compared to placebo. Additionally, co-trimoxazole demonstrated efficacy against common bacterial pathogens and had a preventive effect against malaria. These findings support the use of co-trimoxazole as a first-line treatment option for febrile illness in malaria-endemic regions, highlighting its potential to reduce morbidity and mortality in this population.

Immunohistochemical investigations of estrogen receptors in normal and neoplastic squamous epithelium of the vulva. Estrogen receptors (ER) play a crucial role in the regulation of cellular processes in various tissues, including the vulva. However, limited data are available regarding ER expression in vulvar squamous epithelium, particularly in neoplastic lesions. We investigated ER expression using immunohistochemistry in normal and neoplastic squamous epithelium of the vulva. A total of 30 vulvar tissue samples, including 10 normal vulvar epithelium, 10 vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN), and 10 invasive squamous cell carcinoma (SCC), were analyzed. ER expression was observed in the nuclei of epithelial cells in all normal vulvar epithelial samples. However, a significant decrease in ER expression was observed in both VIN and SCC samples compared to normal epithelium. Our findings suggest a potential role of estrogen signaling in the pathogenesis of vulvar neoplasia and highlight the need for further investigation to better understand the molecular mechanisms underlying this association.

Spinal accessory nerve palsy: an unusual complication of coronary artery bypass The neurologic complications of coronary artery bypass surgery have been well documented, with a reported incidence of 61% in one large study.  Most injuries to the peripheral nervous system involve the brachial plexus. Here, we present a case report of an unusual complication following coronary artery bypass surgery, involving the spinal accessory nerve. A 64-year-old male developed bilateral shoulder weakness and pain shortly after surgery. Clinical examination and electromyography confirmed the diagnosis of spinal accessory nerve palsy. Conservative management was initiated, including physical therapy and analgesics. Over a course of several months, the patient showed gradual improvement in strength and symptom resolution. To our knowledge, this is the first reported case of spinal accessory nerve palsy following coronary artery bypass surgery. Surgeons should be aware of this potential complication and consider it in the differential diagnosis of postoperative shoulder pain and weakness.

Preferential mitogenic activity for myoblast-like cells can be extracted from uterine leiomyoma tissues. Uterine leiomyoma, also known as fibroids, is a common benign tumor of the uterus. In this study, we investigated the presence of mitogenic activity in uterine leiomyoma tissues and its potential effects on myoblast-like cells. Tissue extracts obtained from leiomyoma specimens were tested for their ability to induce cell proliferation in vitro. Our results showed that these extracts exhibited preferential mitogenic activity for myoblast-like cells compared to normal uterine smooth muscle cells. Furthermore, we observed an increased expression of growth factors such as insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1) and fibroblast growth factor 2 (FGF-2) in the leiomyoma tissues. These findings suggest that uterine leiomyoma tissues possess mitogenic factors that may contribute to the growth and development of these tumors. Further studies are warranted to elucidate the specific mechanisms underlying this preferential mitogenic activity and its implications in leiomyoma pathogenesis.

Levels of mRNA for a putative kainate receptor are affected by seizures. Seizures have been shown to alter the expression of various genes and their corresponding proteins in the brain. One such gene is the putative kainate receptor gene, which is believed to play a role in excitatory neurotransmission. In this study, levels of mRNA coding for the putative kainate receptor were examined in an animal model of seizures. Rats were subjected to induced seizures, and brain tissue samples were collected at various time points following the seizure event. Analysis revealed a significant increase in mRNA levels for the putative kainate receptor in the hippocampus and cortex of seizure-exposed animals compared to controls. These findings suggest that seizures can modulate the expression of the putative kainate receptor, potentially contributing to the pathophysiology of epilepsy and offering a potential target for therapeutic intervention. Further studies are needed to elucidate the functional implications of these changes and explore the therapeutic potential of targeting the putative kainate receptor in the treatment of seizures.

Evaluating oxygen delivery and oxygen utilization with mixed venous oxygen saturation monitoring: a case study approach. This case study aimed to evaluate the usefulness of monitoring mixed venous oxygen saturation (SvO2) in assessing oxygen delivery and utilization in critically ill patients. Ten patients admitted to the intensive care unit were included in this study. SvO2 was continuously monitored using a pulmonary artery catheter, and additional hemodynamic parameters were recorded. The results showed that SvO2 was significantly decreased in patients with impaired oxygen delivery, as indicated by low cardiac output or decreased hemoglobin levels. Furthermore, patients with septic shock exhibited a persistent decrease in SvO2, suggesting impaired oxygen utilization. In contrast, patients with normal cardiac function or those who responded well to treatment showed stable or improved SvO2 levels. These findings suggest that SvO2 monitoring can provide valuable information about oxygen delivery and utilization in critically ill patients, allowing for timely interventions to optimize oxygenation and improve patient outcomes. Further studies are warranted to confirm these findings and establish the clinical utility of SvO2 monitoring.

Association of Escherichia coli HEp-2 adherence patterns with type and duration of diarrhoea. In this study, we investigated the association between Escherichia coli (E. coli) adherence patterns on HEp-2 cells and the type and duration of diarrhoea in patients. Stool samples were collected from 150 patients with acute gastroenteritis. E. coli strains were isolated and subjected to HEp-2 adherence assay. Adherence patterns were classified as localized, aggregative, diffuse, or non-adherent. The type and duration of diarrhoea were recorded for each patient. We found that patients with localized adherence pattern had a higher incidence of watery diarrhoea compared to other adherence patterns (p<0.05). Similarly, patients with aggregative adherence pattern had a longer duration of diarrhoea compared to other patterns (p<0.05). No significant association was observed between diffuse or non-adherent patterns and diarrhoea type or duration. Our findings suggest that E. coli adherence patterns on HEp-2 cells may be associated with the clinical presentation and duration of diarrhoea, providing valuable insights for understanding the pathogenesis of E. coli-induced gastroenteritis.

The Van Nes tibial rotationplasty. The Van Nes tibial rotationplasty is a surgical procedure used in the management of patients with malignant bone tumors around the knee joint. This technique involves removal of the distal portion of the tibia and rotation of the residual foot 180 degrees, which is then fixed to the proximal tibia. The procedure aims to provide functional and cosmetic advantages over conventional amputation or limb-sparing surgeries. This abstract reviews the indications, surgical technique, outcomes, and complications associated with the Van Nes tibial rotationplasty. Current evidence suggests that this procedure can achieve satisfactory functional outcomes, with improved joint stability, walking ability, and overall quality of life. However, careful patient selection and post-operative rehabilitation are crucial factors for optimal outcomes. Further long-term studies are warranted to establish the efficacy and durability of this procedure.

Acute oculogyric crisis after administration of prochlorperazine. Acute oculogyric crisis (AOC) is a rare extrapyramidal side effect associated with the use of certain medications, including neuroleptics such as prochlorperazine. This case report presents a patient who developed AOC shortly after receiving prochlorperazine for nausea and vomiting. The patient experienced sudden and involuntary upward deviation of the eyes, along with torticollis and dystonic movements of the neck. Immediate cessation of prochlorperazine led to gradual resolution of symptoms. Although AOC is known to occur with other neuroleptic agents, this case adds to the literature by highlighting prochlorperazine as another potential culprit. Healthcare professionals should be aware of this potential adverse reaction when prescribing prochlorperazine, especially in patients at risk for extrapyramidal symptoms.

Choroid plexus tumors in the breast cancer-sarcoma syndrome. Breast cancer-sarcoma syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the development of both breast cancer and sarcoma. Choroid plexus tumors are typically central nervous system neoplasms and their association with breast cancer-sarcoma syndrome is exceedingly rare. Here, we present a case of a 48-year-old female with a known diagnosis of breast cancer-sarcoma syndrome, who developed a choroid plexus tumor. The patient underwent surgical resection of the tumor, and histopathological analysis confirmed the presence of a choroid plexus carcinoma. Genetic testing revealed a mutation in the TP53 gene, consistent with the underlying breast cancer-sarcoma syndrome. This case highlights the importance of considering choroid plexus tumors in the differential diagnosis of patients with breast cancer-sarcoma syndrome, and the potential for genetic predisposition in the development of rare neoplasms. Further studies are needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms of tumor development in breast cancer-sarcoma syndrome.

Simultaneous superior oblique sheathectomy and inferior oblique tuck in congenital Brown's syndrome. A case report. Congenital Brown's syndrome is a rare ocular motility disorder characterized by limited elevation in adduction and a mechanical restriction of the superior oblique tendon. Surgical management, aimed at improving vertical eye movements, is often necessary to alleviate the associated diplopia and anomalous head posture. We present a case of a 13-year-old male patient with congenital Brown's syndrome, and describe a novel surgical approach involving simultaneous superior oblique sheathectomy and inferior oblique tuck. The patient underwent the procedure under general anesthesia, with a conjunctival incision made in the superonasal quadrant. The superior oblique sheath was dissected and released from its attachments, allowing for free movement of the tendon. Subsequently, the inferior oblique muscle was tacked to the periosteum of the inferonasal orbital rim. Postoperatively, the patient demonstrated improved vertical eye movements and resolution of diplopia. This case highlights the potential benefits of combining superior oblique sheathectomy and inferior oblique tuck in the management of congenital Brown's syndrome, providing a comprehensive surgical solution to this complex condition. Further studies are warranted to evaluate the long-term outcomes and potential complications of this combined approach.

Oral contraceptives, lipoproteins, and atherosclerosis. Oral contraceptives have been widely used by women as a reliable method of birth control. However, there have been concerns regarding the potential association between oral contraceptive use and the development of atherosclerosis.

This review aims to summarize the available evidence and evaluate the relationship between oral contraceptives, lipoproteins, and atherosclerosis. Several studies have reported an increase in total cholesterol and triglyceride levels among oral contraceptive users, particularly among those using higher doses of estrogen. Furthermore, alterations in lipoprotein metabolism, such as increased levels of low-density lipoprotein cholesterol and decreased levels of high-density lipoprotein cholesterol, have been observed in users of oral contraceptives.

The impact of these lipid changes on the development of atherosclerosis is still controversial. Some studies have linked oral contraceptive use to an increased risk of cardiovascular events, whereas others have found no significant association.

Further research is required to better understand the mechanisms behind these lipid alterations and to determine the overall cardiovascular risk associated with oral contraceptive use. In the meantime, clinicians should carefully consider the potential cardiovascular effects when prescribing oral contraceptives, particularly among women with underlying cardiovascular risk factors.

Clinical observation on the association of gallstones and colorectal cancer.  A possible association between gallstones, colorectal cancer, and gastric cancer was investigated. A total of 500 patients diagnosed with colorectal or gastric cancer were enrolled for this clinical observation study. Among them, 200 patients had gallstones detected during routine preoperative imaging or surgery. The presence of gallstones was significantly associated with an increased occurrence of colorectal cancer, with 58% of patients with colorectal cancer having concurrent gallstones. In contrast, only 22% of gastric cancer patients had gallstones. Furthermore, patients with both colorectal cancer and gallstones were more likely to present with advanced stage disease compared to those without gallstones. This association remained significant after adjusting for potential confounding factors such as age, sex, and BMI. These findings suggest a possible link between gallstones and colorectal cancer development, indicating that gallstones may serve as a risk factor or contributor to the pathogenesis of colorectal cancer. Further research is warranted to elucidate the underlying mechanisms of this association.

Warner-Lambert/Parke-Davis Award lecture. The Warner-Lambert/Parke-Davis Award lecture focused on the research and policy directions in the field of medicine. The lecture highlighted the controversy surrounding the relation between dietary intake of sodium chloride and blood pressure levels. The critical questions that need to be addressed include identifying a susceptible subgroup at risk of elevated blood pressure due to sodium chloride consumption, determining the size of this subgroup, and devising methods to identify it. Clinical trials are proposed to examine the long-term effects of reducing sodium chloride intake on blood pressure. The lecture emphasized the linear relationship between blood pressure levels and the risk of diseases such as stroke and coronary heart disease. Notably, even a minor change in blood pressure within the normal range can have a significant impact on disease occurrence.

Celiac disease, brain atrophy, and dementia. Celiac disease is an autoimmune disorder triggered by the ingestion of gluten in genetically predisposed individuals. In addition to gastrointestinal symptoms, it has been associated with various extraintestinal manifestations, including neurological complications. Among these, brain atrophy and dementia have gained attention in recent years. This review aims to explore the current evidence regarding the relationship between celiac disease, brain atrophy, and dementia. Several studies have reported an increased prevalence of brain atrophy and dementia in individuals with celiac disease. However, the underlying mechanisms linking celiac disease to these neurological manifestations remain unclear. Further research is needed to elucidate the pathophysiology and establish appropriate management strategies for these patients.

Toward a rational therapeutic strategy for arachnoiditis. Arachnoiditis is a debilitating condition characterized by inflammation of the arachnoid membrane surrounding the spinal cord. Despite its significant impact on patients' quality of life, there is currently no consensus on optimal treatment strategies for arachnoiditis. This review aims to provide a comprehensive overview of the existing literature on arachnoiditis treatment and propose a rational therapeutic strategy for this condition.

A thorough literature search was conducted to identify relevant studies on arachnoiditis treatment. The results suggest that a multidisciplinary approach, involving pharmacological, interventional, and rehabilitative therapies, holds promise in managing arachnoiditis symptoms effectively. While no single treatment option has demonstrated definitive efficacy, there is evidence supporting the use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, opioids, corticosteroids, and physical therapy as part of a multimodal treatment approach.

Based on the available evidence, we propose a rational therapeutic strategy for arachnoiditis that considers individual patient characteristics, symptom severity, and treatment response. This strategy emphasizes the importance of a personalized approach, targeting both pain relief and functional improvement, while minimizing the risk of adverse effects. Further research is warranted to validate the proposed therapeutic strategy and explore innovative treatment modalities for arachnoiditis.

Increasing the cancer screening of the medically underserved in south Florida. This study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a targeted intervention to increase cancer screening rates among the medically underserved population in south Florida. A community-based approach was employed whereby trained community health workers conducted educational sessions and provided resources to promote cancer screening. The intervention targeted individuals who were uninsured, had limited access to healthcare facilities, or belonged to minority or low-income communities. Pre-and post-intervention data were collected to assess changes in screening rates and knowledge about cancer prevention and early detection. Results showed a significant increase in cancer screening rates among the target population, with a particular emphasis on breast, cervical, and colorectal cancer screenings. Additionally, participants demonstrated improved understanding of the importance of regular screenings and how to access appropriate healthcare services. These findings highlight the effectiveness of community-based interventions in addressing healthcare disparities and increasing cancer screening rates among the medically underserved population. Further research is warranted to evaluate the long-term impact of such interventions and determine strategies for sustainable implementation.

Use of intravenous stilbestrol diphosphate in patients with prostatic carcinoma refractory to conventional hormonal manipulation. Intravenous stilbestrol diphosphate (STDP) is investigated as a potential treatment for patients with prostatic carcinoma who are refractory to conventional hormonal manipulation. A total of 20 patients were included in this study, all of whom had already received primary hormonal therapy. The patients received STDP intravenously at a dose of 15 mg every 3 weeks. The efficacy of STDP in terms of tumor response and survival rate was evaluated. Results showed that STDP had a favorable tumor response rate, with 80% of patients showing either partial response or stable disease. Furthermore, the survival rate at 1 year was 70%. These findings suggest that STDP may be a promising option for patients with prostatic carcinoma who have failed conventional hormonal therapy.

Outcome of cataract surgery in central India: a longitudinal follow-up study. The aim of this study was to assess the outcomes of cataract surgery in central India over a longitudinal follow-up period. A total of 250 patients who underwent cataract surgery were included in the study. The mean age of the patients was 62 years, with a range of 45-78 years. The majority of patients (76%) had bilateral cataracts. Visual acuity was measured using the Snellen chart preoperatively and at regular intervals postoperatively. The mean follow-up period was 5 years. Postoperative visual acuity improved significantly in all patients. At 1 year postoperatively, 84% of patients had a visual acuity of 6/12 or better. However, a gradual decline in visual acuity was observed over the follow-up period, with only 60% of patients maintaining a visual acuity of 6/12 or better at 5 years. The main causes of decreased visual acuity were posterior capsular opacification and age-related macular degeneration. In conclusion, cataract surgery in central India provides significant improvement in visual acuity, with good outcomes observed up to 1 year postoperatively. However, long-term follow-up is necessary to monitor for potential complications and the need for further interventions.

Computed tomography staging of the paranasal sinuses in chronic hyperplastic rhinosinusitis. Chronic hyperplastic rhinosinusitis (CHRS) is a common chronic inflammatory disease of the paranasal sinuses. The purpose of this study was to evaluate the utility of computed tomography (CT) staging in assessing the severity and extent of disease in CHRS patients. A retrospective analysis of CT scans from 78 patients with CHRS was performed. The Lund-Mackay CT staging system was used to categorize disease severity based on the presence and extent of opacification in each sinus. The results showed that CT staging correlated well with both clinical symptoms and endoscopic findings. Higher CT stage was associated with more severe symptoms and greater surgical intervention. The maxillary sinuses were the most commonly involved sinuses, followed by the ethmoid sinuses. The frontal and sphenoid sinuses were less frequently affected. CT staging proved to be an effective tool for objectively evaluating the extent of disease in CHRS, aiding in the planning of treatment and predicting surgical outcomes.

Depression after acute myocardial infarction.  The role of primary care physicians in rehabilitation. Depression is a common psychiatric disorder among patients who have experienced acute myocardial infarction (AMI). The significance of primary care physicians (PCPs) in the management and rehabilitation of depressed AMI patients is crucial, yet often overlooked. This study aimed to assess the role of PCPs in the identification, treatment, and overall management of depression in AMI patients. A comprehensive literature review was conducted, revealing that PCPs play a vital role in screening for depression, initiating appropriate interventions, coordinating care with mental health professionals, and providing ongoing support to optimize the patient's physical and psychological well-being. The study emphasizes the need for increased collaboration between PCPs and mental health specialists to ensure comprehensive care for depressed AMI patients.

Dietary predictors of symptom-associated gallstones in middle-aged women.  In 1980, 88,837 women aged 34-59 y completed a semiquantitative food frequency questionnaire and were followed for 4 y. Gallstones are a common gastrointestinal disorder, and dietary factors play a crucial role in their development. This study aimed to investigate the dietary predictors of symptom-associated gallstones in middle-aged women. A total of 88,837 women aged 34-59 years completed a semiquantitative food frequency questionnaire in 1980 and were followed up for 4 years. During the follow-up period, symptomatic gallstones were reported by 1,345 participants. The dietary analysis revealed several significant predictors of gallstone symptoms. Higher intake of refined carbohydrates, saturated fats, and cholesterol was positively associated with an increased risk of symptomatic gallstones. Conversely, higher intake of dietary fiber, polyunsaturated fats, and calcium was inversely associated with the risk. Additionally, regular consumption of coffee and moderate alcohol intake showed a protective effect. These findings suggest that modifying dietary habits, including reducing refined carbohydrate and saturated fat intake and increasing dietary fiber and calcium intake, may help in the prevention of symptom-associated gallstones in middle-aged women.

Ureteral obstruction and ureteral fistulas after aortofemoral or aortoiliac bypass surgery. Ureteral disorders following aortofemoral or aortoiliac bypass surgery are rare but significant complications that can lead to long-term morbidity. In this retrospective study, we investigated the occurrence and management of ureteral obstruction and ureteral fistulas in patients who underwent these bypass procedures. Out of 210 patients, 10 (4.8%) developed ureteral disorders, with 7 cases of ureteral obstruction and 3 cases of ureteral fistulas. The mean time to diagnosis post-surgery was 6 months. Symptoms included flank pain, urinary tract infections, and hematuria. Diagnosis was confirmed through imaging studies and ureteroscopy. Management involved endoscopic or surgical intervention, including stenting, re-implantation, and bypass revision. Five patients required nephrostomy tube placement. Despite appropriate management, complications persisted in 3 cases, necessitating nephrectomy in 2 patients. Our findings underscore the importance of early recognition and intervention of ureteral disorders following aortofemoral or aortoiliac bypass surgery in order to optimize patient outcomes and reduce long-term morbidity. Further studies are needed to identify risk factors and develop preventive strategies for these rare complications.

Patient-controlled analgesia in children.  We report our experience in introducing patient-controlled analgesia at the Royal Hospital for Sick Children, Glasgow.  Twenty-five children used the technique after orthopaedic or general surgery using the Graseby system. Patient-controlled analgesia (PCA) has been widely used in adult populations to provide effective pain management. However, its application in children has been limited due to concerns about safety and efficacy. In this study, we aimed to evaluate the implementation and outcomes of PCA in children at the Royal Hospital for Sick Children in Glasgow. 

A total of 25 children, who underwent orthopaedic or general surgery, were included in the study and utilized the Graseby PCA system for pain management. The system allowed the children to self-administer analgesic medication within predetermined safety limits, providing them with increased control over their pain relief. 

Preliminary results showed that PCA was well-tolerated and effective in managing postoperative pain in children. Pain scores were significantly reduced, and the need for rescue analgesia was minimal. Furthermore, the incidence of opioid-related adverse events was low, indicating the safety of the PCA approach in children. These findings suggest that PCA can be a valuable tool in pediatric pain management, providing tailored analgesia while minimizing the side effects associated with traditional analgesic approaches. Further research is warranted to optimize the technique and evaluate long-term outcomes.

Occurrence of beta-hexachlorocyclohexane in breast cancer patients.  The residues of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon (PAH) and neutral organochlorine compounds in breast fat of 44 breast cancer patients and 33 women free of cancer were determined. This study aims to investigate the occurrence of beta-hexachlorocyclohexane (beta-HCH) in breast cancer patients. The breast fat samples of 44 breast cancer patients and 33 cancer-free women were analyzed for residues of beta-HCH, polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon (PAH), and neutral organochlorine compounds. The results revealed that beta-HCH was significantly higher in breast cancer patients compared to cancer-free women. Additionally, a positive correlation was observed between beta-HCH levels and the presence of PAH and neutral organochlorine compounds. These findings suggest a potential association between beta-HCH exposure and breast cancer development, emphasizing the need for further research on environmental factors contributing to breast cancer risk.

Increased cholecystectomy rates in Saudi Arabia Gallstones have become increasingly prevalent in Saudi Arabia, where cholecystectomy is now one of the commonest major abdominal operations. This study aimed to investigate the trends and factors contributing to the increased cholecystectomy rates in Saudi Arabia. A retrospective analysis of hospital records from multiple tertiary care centers in Saudi Arabia was conducted. The study included patients who underwent cholecystectomy between 2010 and 2018. The results showed a significant increase in the number of cholecystectomy procedures performed during the study period. Several factors were identified as potential contributors to this trend, including the increasing prevalence of gallstones, changes in lifestyle and dietary habits, and improved access to healthcare services. Further research is needed to explore the underlying causes and develop strategies for prevention and management of gallstones in Saudi Arabia.

Chronic pain in primary care.  Identification and management of psychosocial factors. Chronic pain is a prevalent condition that often presents in primary care settings. While there is extensive research on the physiological and biomechanical aspects of pain, the role of psychosocial factors in chronic pain management remains underexplored. This review aims to identify and discuss the psychosocial factors that contribute to the experience and perpetuation of chronic pain. 
Various psychosocial factors, such as depression, anxiety, catastrophizing, and social support, have been found to play a significant role in the development and maintenance of chronic pain. It is crucial for primary care providers to recognize and address these factors as part of a comprehensive and multidisciplinary approach to pain management. The implementation of evidence-based interventions, such as cognitive-behavioral therapy, mindfulness-based stress reduction, and psychosocial education, can effectively target and modify these factors, leading to improved pain outcomes and enhanced quality of life for patients with chronic pain. Primary care providers should prioritize the identification and management of psychosocial factors in the care of patients with chronic pain to optimize treatment outcomes.

Transoesophageal echocardiogram may fail to diagnose perioperative myocardial infarction.  We report a case in which a 55-yr-old man undergoing aortocoronary bypass was monitored with electrocardiogram and transoesophageal echocardiogram. Transoesophageal echocardiography (TOE) is a commonly used imaging modality for the detection of perioperative myocardial infarction (MI). However, there are occasional instances where TOE may fail to diagnose this serious complication. In this case report, we present the experience of a 55-year-old male patient who underwent aortocoronary bypass surgery and was monitored with both electrocardiogram (ECG) and TOE. Despite continuous monitoring during the procedure, TOE failed to detect a perioperative MI, while ECG showed significant changes indicative of myocardial ischemia. This highlights the limitations of TOE in detecting myocardial infarction and emphasizes the importance of combining multiple modalities, such as ECG, troponin levels, and clinical assessment, for accurate diagnosis. Further research is warranted to explore alternative or adjunctive imaging techniques that can improve the sensitivity and specificity of perioperative MI detection. Healthcare providers should be aware of the limitations of TOE in order to ensure timely diagnosis and appropriate management of this potentially life-threatening condition.

Delayed pharyngoesophageal perforation: a complication of anterior spine surgery.  Stabilization of the cervical spine is often accomplished via an anterior cervical approach. Pharyngoesophageal perforation is a rare but severe complication that can occur following anterior spine surgery. We present a case of delayed pharyngoesophageal perforation following anterior cervical spine surgery. The patient initially presented with symptoms of dysphagia and odynophagia, which progressively worsened over several days. Further investigation confirmed the presence of a perforation in the pharyngoesophageal wall. Immediate surgical intervention was performed, including debridement of necrotic tissue and primary repair of the perforation. Postoperative management involved the administration of broad-spectrum antibiotics and enteral nutrition through a nasogastric tube. The patient experienced a gradual improvement in symptoms and was eventually discharged in stable condition. This case illustrates the importance of recognizing the potential complications associated with anterior spine surgery and the need for prompt diagnosis and management of pharyngoesophageal perforation to prevent further complications.

A new method for mapping hepatic subsegment: counterstaining identification technique. Accurate delineation of the hepatic subsegment is crucial for various procedures such as hepatic resection and tumor ablation. Currently, available mapping techniques like indocyanine green fluorescence imaging or preoperative imaging are limited by their complexity or lack of real-time visualization. This study presents a new method for mapping hepatic subsegment using a counterstaining identification technique. The technique involves the intraoperative injection of a counterstaining agent, followed by fluorescence imaging, which enables clear visualization of the hepatic subsegments. The study evaluated the efficacy and accuracy of this technique in 30 patients undergoing hepatic resection and compared the results with the conventional imaging technique. The counterstaining identification technique demonstrated high accuracy in identifying hepatic subsegments and showed superior results compared to the conventional imaging technique. This novel technique could enhance surgical precision and improve outcomes in hepatic procedures.

Effects of nimodipine on cerebral blood flow and neuropsychological outcome after cardiac surgery. This study aimed to investigate the effects of nimodipine on cerebral blood flow and neuropsychological outcome in patients undergoing cardiac surgery. A total of 100 patients were randomly assigned to receive either nimodipine or placebo. Transcranial Doppler ultrasonography was performed to measure middle cerebral artery mean flow velocity (MCAv) before and after surgery. Neuropsychological tests were conducted preoperatively and at 4 weeks postoperatively. The results showed that nimodipine administration significantly increased MCAv compared to placebo, indicating improved cerebral blood flow. Additionally, patients in the nimodipine group demonstrated better outcomes on neuropsychological tests compared to the placebo group, suggesting neuroprotective effects. These findings suggest that nimodipine may have a beneficial effect on cerebral blood flow and improve neuropsychological outcomes in patients undergoing cardiac surgery. Further studies are warranted to explore the potential clinical implications of nimodipine in this patient population.

Physiologic and pathologic alterations associated with ultrasonically generated shock waves. Ultrasonically generated shock waves (SWs) have been widely used in various medical procedures, including lithotripsy and tissue regeneration. However, their effects on biological tissues are not fully understood. In this study, we investigated the physiologic and pathologic alterations induced by SWs in an animal model. We found that SW exposure resulted in tissue damage characterized by cell death, vascular disruption, and inflammation. Furthermore, SWs triggered the release of various pro-inflammatory and pro-fibrotic cytokines. These findings indicate that SWs can induce both acute and chronic tissue injury, which may have implications for the safety and efficacy of SW-based treatments. Further research is needed to understand the underlying mechanisms and develop strategies to minimize the adverse effects of SW exposure.

Efficacy and complications of radiotherapy of anterior visual pathway tumors. Radiotherapy is a commonly employed treatment for anterior visual pathway tumors, although its efficacy and potential complications are not well understood. In a retrospective analysis, we evaluated the outcomes of radiotherapy in 36 patients with anterior visual pathway tumors, including optic nerve glioma, craniopharyngioma, and others. The overall response rate was 72%, with complete response observed in 39% of patients. However, treatment-related complications were documented in 47% of cases, including radiation retinopathy, optic neuropathy, and visual field defects. Factors associated with a higher risk of complications included higher radiation dose, larger tumor size, and younger age at the time of treatment. These findings highlight the need for careful consideration of the potential risks and benefits of radiotherapy in patients with anterior visual pathway tumors.

Mechanical measures in the prophylaxis of postoperative thromboembolism in total knee arthroplasty. Postoperative thromboembolism is a potentially life-threatening complication in patients undergoing total knee arthroplasty (TKA). Mechanical measures, such as compression stockings and intermittent pneumatic compression devices, have been widely used as prophylaxis to prevent this complication. This review aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of mechanical measures in the prophylaxis of postoperative thromboembolism in TKA. A comprehensive search of electronic databases was performed, and studies that assessed the use of mechanical measures in TKA patients were included. The results showed that mechanical measures were effective in reducing the incidence of postoperative thromboembolism. However, the optimal duration and timing of mechanical prophylaxis remain unclear. Further well-designed studies are needed to establish guidelines for the use of mechanical measures in this setting.

Cardiomyopathy associated with the smoking of crystal methamphetamine. Cardiomyopathy is a well-established consequence of chronic substance abuse, particularly related to alcohol and cocaine use. However, the association between the smoking of crystal methamphetamine and cardiomyopathy has received limited attention in the medical literature. This study aims to explore this relationship and assess the prevalence and clinical characteristics of cardiomyopathy in individuals who smoke crystal methamphetamine. A retrospective analysis of medical records and cardiac imaging data from a cohort of crystal methamphetamine users presenting to a tertiary care center will be conducted. The findings will be compared with a control group of individuals who do not use this drug.
