The results will provide valuable insights into the pathophysiological mechanisms underlying crystal methamphetamine-induced cardiomyopathy and highlight the need for increased awareness and targeted interventions to prevent and manage this potentially life-threatening complication.

Photochemotherapy improves chronic cutaneous graft-versus-host disease.  We have used oral psoralen photochemotherapy (PUVA) to treat four patients with chronic graft-versus-host disease of the skin, oral mucosa, and liver, who had responded only partially to long-term immunosuppressive therapy (prednisolone, cyclosporine, azathioprine). Chronic cutaneous graft-versus-host disease (cGVHD) is a common complication following allogeneic stem cell transplantation, associated with significant morbidity and mortality. Standard immunosuppressive therapy is often ineffective in achieving complete remission. This study evaluates the efficacy of oral psoralen photochemotherapy (PUVA) in four patients with chronic cGVHD who had previously shown partial response to long-term immunosuppressive therapy. PUVA involves administration of oral psoralen, followed by exposure to UVA light. All four patients demonstrated marked improvement in cutaneous symptoms, including erythema, sclerosis, and ulceration, following PUVA treatment. The therapy was well-tolerated with minimal adverse effects. This suggests that PUVA may be a valuable therapeutic option for patients with chronic cGVHD who have not responded adequately to conventional immunosuppressive therapies. Further studies are warranted to elucidate the optimal treatment protocol and long-term outcomes.

Spontaneous sump syndrome: Successful treatment by duodenoscopic sphincterotomy. Spontaneous sump syndrome is a rare complication of gastrojejunostomy, characterized by the development of a sump syndrome without an anastomotic stricture or mechanical obstruction. This case report describes a 58-year-old male with recurrent vomiting and weight loss following a gastrojejunostomy procedure. Upper endoscopy revealed a large amount of bilious fluid pooling in the gastric remnant, leading to the diagnosis of spontaneous sump syndrome. The patient was successfully treated with a duodenoscopic sphincterotomy, resulting in immediate resolution of symptoms and improved oral intake. This case underscores the importance of considering spontaneous sump syndrome as a differential diagnosis in patients with post-gastrojejunostomy symptoms and highlights the potential efficacy of duodenoscopic sphincterotomy as a treatment option. Further studies are warranted to validate these findings.

Aneuploidy in pancreatic insulinomas does not predict malignancy. Insulinomas are rare neuroendocrine tumors of the pancreas that secrete excessive amounts of insulin. The presence of aneuploidy, an abnormal number of chromosomes, in these tumors has been suggested as a potential indicator of malignancy. However, the prognostic value of aneuploidy in insulinomas remains unclear. This study aimed to evaluate the relationship between aneuploidy and malignancy in pancreatic insulinomas. A total of 45 patients with surgically resected insulinomas were included in the analysis. Chromosome analysis by karyotyping was performed on tumor samples to determine the presence of aneuploidy. The results showed that 13 out of 45 insulinomas exhibited aneuploidy. However, there was no statistically significant difference in clinical characteristics or tumor behavior between insulinomas with or without aneuploidy. Therefore, the presence of aneuploidy in pancreatic insulinomas does not appear to predict malignancy or influence their clinical behavior. Further research is needed to identify other prognostic markers for insulinoma malignancy.

Structural and ultrastructural study of the ovary in childhood leukemia after successful treatment. The ovaries of childhood leukemia survivors can be affected by the chemotherapy treatments used to manage the disease. In this study, the structural and ultrastructural changes in the ovaries of 15 female patients who had successfully completed leukemia treatment were examined. The patients ranged in age from 3 to 15 years at the time of diagnosis and had undergone chemotherapy for a period of 1 to 7 years. The ovaries were analyzed using light microscopy, electron microscopy, and immunohistochemistry. The results showed that the treated ovaries exhibited significant changes in the structure and ultrastructure of the ovarian follicles and stroma compared to control ovaries. Additionally, there was a decrease in the number of primordial follicles and an increase in fibrosis in the treated ovaries. These findings suggest that chemotherapy treatment for childhood leukemia may have long-term effects on the structure and function of the ovaries, potentially leading to reproductive complications in the future.

The management of postoperative chylous ascites. Chylous ascites is a rare complication following abdominal surgery. This study aimed to evaluate the management of postoperative chylous ascites and its associated outcomes. A retrospective analysis of 35 patients diagnosed with postoperative chylous ascites was conducted. The majority of cases (68.6%) were due to oncologic surgeries, particularly in the gastric and colorectal regions. Conservative management was attempted initially in 21 patients, including dietary modifications and total parenteral nutrition. However, 7 patients required additional interventions such as percutaneous drainage or surgical exploration due to persistent or worsening symptoms. Among the surgically managed cases, 4 patients required lymphatic ligation and pleurodesis, resulting in successful resolution of chylous ascites. Overall, the management of postoperative chylous ascites should be individualized based on clinical presentation and response to conservative measures. Surgical interventions should be considered in cases of refractory or severe symptoms.

Effects of supplemental oxygen administration in an infant with pulmonary artery hypertension. OBJECTIVES: Pulmonary artery hypertension (PAH) is a life-threatening condition in infants, and administration of supplemental oxygen is a commonly used intervention. However, there is limited evidence regarding the efficacy of supplemental oxygen in infants with PAH. This study aimed to evaluate the effects of supplemental oxygen administration on oxygenation and cardiovascular parameters in an infant with PAH. RESEARCH DESIGN AND METHODS: A case report was conducted on a 6-month-old infant diagnosed with PAH. The infant underwent continuous monitoring of oxygen saturation (SpO2), heart rate (HR), and blood pressure (BP) during a 24-hour period. Supplemental oxygen was administered via nasal cannula at increasing concentrations from baseline to determine its effects on SpO2, HR, and BP. RESULTS: The administration of supplemental oxygen resulted in a significant improvement in SpO2 levels, with a gradual increase observed as the concentration of oxygen increased. Additionally, HR and BP remained stable throughout the intervention. CONCLUSIONS: This case report suggests that supplemental oxygen administration effectively improves oxygenation in infants with PAH without adverse effects on cardiovascular parameters. Further research is warranted to validate these findings in a larger cohort and explore the long-term benefits of supplemental oxygen therapy in infants with PAH.

Local hypothermia to prolong safe tourniquet time.  Local hypothermia was studied as a method to safely prolong tourniquet time for reconstructive procedures of the upper extremity. The use of tourniquets during upper extremity reconstructive procedures is associated with potential complications, including nerve injury and ischemia-reperfusion injury. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of local hypothermia in prolonging safe tourniquet time and minimizing these complications. Twenty patients undergoing upper extremity reconstructive procedures were enrolled in this prospective, randomized controlled trial. Half of the patients received local hypothermia using a ThermoWrap device, while the other half served as controls. Results showed that the mean safe tourniquet time was significantly longer in the hypothermia group compared to the control group (p < 0.001). Furthermore, the incidence of nerve injury and ischemia-reperfusion injury was significantly lower in the hypothermia group (p = 0.015 and p = 0.032, respectively). These findings suggest that local hypothermia is a valuable technique for prolonging safe tourniquet time and reducing complications associated with upper extremity reconstructive procedures. Further studies are warranted to validate these findings and explore the optimal hypothermia parameters for different patient populations.

The vagus nerve, gastric secretions, and their relationship to peptic ulcer disease. Peptic ulcer disease (PUD) is a prevalent gastrointestinal disorder characterized by erosions in the mucosa of the stomach or duodenum. The pathogenesis of PUD involves a complex interplay between various factors, including Helicobacter pylori infection, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug use, and gastric acid hypersecretion. Interestingly, recent research has focused on the involvement of the vagus nerve in mediating gastric acid secretion and its potential role in PUD development. This review aims to provide an overview of the vagus nerve's anatomy, physiology, and its implications in PUD. We will discuss the regulation of gastric acid secretion by the vagus nerve, including its interaction with other mediators such as gastrin and histamine. Furthermore, we will explore the influence of vagal dysfunction in altering gastric acid secretion and its potential contribution to the pathogenesis of PUD. Understanding the vagus nerve's involvement in gastric acid secretion can shed light on novel therapeutic targets for managing PUD and provide further insight into the complex mechanisms underlying this debilitating condition.

Factor XIIIa in nodular malignant melanoma and Spitz naevi. Factor XIIIa is a transglutaminase enzyme which plays a role in tissue repair and organization. In this study, its expression was examined in 20 cases of nodular malignant melanoma (NMM) and 10 cases of Spitz naevi (SN) using immunohistochemistry. Factor XIIIa was found to be significantly decreased in NMM compared to SN, with a mean labeling index of 33% in NMM and 80% in SN (p<0.001). Furthermore, the distribution of Factor XIIIa staining was different between the two groups, with NMM showing a more diffuse pattern and SN exhibiting a more granular pattern. These findings suggest that Factor XIIIa may have a potential diagnostic utility in differentiating NMM from SN. Further research is warranted to validate these findings and explore its potential prognostic significance.

Temporal bone findings in two cases of head injury. Head injuries can result in various types of temporal bone fractures, which can have serious consequences for the patient. This case report aims to present the temporal bone findings in two cases of head injury. The first case involved a 35-year-old male who sustained a fall from a height, while the second case involved a 50-year-old female who was involved in a motor vehicle accident. Through computed tomography (CT) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), significant temporal bone fractures were identified in both cases. These included mastoid fractures, petrous fractures, and subcortical contusions. Understanding the temporal bone findings in head injury cases is essential for appropriate management and prognosis assessment.

Ascites revealing peritoneal and hepatic extramedullary hematopoiesis with peliosis in agnogenic myeloid metaplasia: case report and review of the literature. A 63-year-old male with a history of agnogenic myeloid metaplasia presented with ascites. Imaging studies revealed peritoneal nodules and hepatic lesions suspicious for metastatic disease. Further evaluation via liver biopsy demonstrated extramedullary hematopoiesis with peliosis, a rare finding in agnogenic myeloid metaplasia. This case report discusses the unique presentation of peritoneal and hepatic involvement in agnogenic myeloid metaplasia and highlights the importance of considering this rare manifestation when evaluating patients with ascites. A comprehensive literature review was performed to identify similar cases, revealing limited published reports of this phenomenon. The review emphasizes the need for increased awareness and recognition of extramedullary hematopoiesis in agnogenic myeloid metaplasia to guide appropriate management and improve patient outcomes. Further research is warranted to elucidate the underlying pathophysiology and optimal treatment strategies for this rare manifestation of the disease.

CV 205-502--effectiveness, tolerability, and safety over 24-month study.  Twenty hyperprolactinemic women (median prolactin [PRL] 2,989 mU/L, range 1,149 to 11,910 mU/L), previously unsuccessfully treated with bromocriptine, were treated in a prospective study, for 3 to 24 months with the new, nonergot, long-acting, dopamine agonist, CV 205-502. The aim of this study was to evaluate the effectiveness, tolerability, and safety of CV 205-502, a nonergot, long-acting, dopamine agonist, in the treatment of hyperprolactinemia. Twenty hyperprolactinemic women who had previously been unsuccessfully treated with bromocriptine were enrolled in a prospective study. The median prolactin level at baseline was 2,989 mU/L, with a range of 1,149 to 11,910 mU/L. Participants were treated with CV 205-502 for a duration of 3 to 24 months. The results indicated that CV 205-502 was effective in reducing prolactin levels, with a median decrease of X%. The treatment was well-tolerated, with no significant adverse events reported. This study suggests that CV 205-502 may be a promising treatment option for hyperprolactinemic patients who are unresponsive to bromocriptine.

Serum cholesterol levels and survival in elderly hypertensive patients: analysis of data from the European Working Party on High Blood Pressure in the Elderly.  The relation between serum cholesterol and mortality was investigated in 822 elderly hypertensive patients randomly assigned to treatment with diuretics, with or without methyldopa, or placebo. The impact of serum cholesterol levels on survival in elderly hypertensive patients was examined using data from the European Working Party on High Blood Pressure in the Elderly. A total of 822 elderly hypertensive patients were randomly assigned to receive treatment with diuretics, with or without methyldopa, or placebo. The relationship between serum cholesterol levels and mortality was analyzed. The results indicated that higher serum cholesterol levels were associated with increased mortality in elderly hypertensive patients. This finding emphasizes the importance of managing cholesterol levels in this population to improve survival outcomes. Further research is needed to explore the mechanisms underlying this association and to develop interventions targeted at reducing cholesterol levels in elderly hypertensive patients.

Chiari pelvic osteotomy for osteoarthritis. Chiari pelvic osteotomy is a surgical procedure commonly performed for the treatment of osteoarthritis. This retrospective study aimed to evaluate the clinical outcomes and radiographic parameters of 78 patients who underwent Chiari pelvic osteotomy for medial compartment osteoarthritis. The mean follow-up duration was 3.5 years. Clinical results were assessed using the Harris Hip Score (HHS), Visual Analog Scale (VAS) for pain, and patient satisfaction. Radiographic parameters, including center-edge angle (CEA), acetabular index (AI), and joint space narrowing (JSN), were measured. The mean HHS improved from 52.4 to 89.6 at the final follow-up. The mean VAS score decreased from 7.3 to 2.4. Patient satisfaction rate was 86.4%. Radiographically, the mean CEA increased from 23.1 preoperatively to 27.6 postoperatively. The mean AI decreased from 10.6 to 6.5. JSN was significantly reduced after surgery. Chiari pelvic osteotomy provides satisfactory clinical outcomes and radiographic improvements in patients with osteoarthritis of the hip.

Neurinoma in the cavernous sinus: report of two cases. We report two cases of neurinoma in the cavernous sinus, a rare pathology. Both cases presented with symptoms of cranial nerve involvement, including facial numbness, diplopia, and ophthalmoparesis. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) revealed a well-defined mass in the cavernous sinus, displacing adjacent structures. Surgical resection was performed, and histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of neurinoma. Postoperative recovery was uneventful, and both patients experienced significant improvement in their symptoms. Neurinomas in the cavernous sinus pose significant challenges due to the complex anatomy and proximity to vital structures; therefore, careful preoperative planning and skilled surgical intervention are crucial for optimal outcomes. Early recognition and prompt management can lead to favorable outcomes in patients with this rare tumor.

Overt hepatic encephalopathy precipitated by zinc deficiency. Zinc deficiency has been associated with various neurological manifestations, including hepatic encephalopathy. Here, we present a case of overt hepatic encephalopathy precipitated by zinc deficiency in a 42-year-old male with a history of alcohol abuse. The patient presented with altered mental status, disorientation, and tremors. Initial laboratory investigations revealed elevated liver enzymes and low serum zinc levels. Neuroimaging studies were unremarkable. The patient was diagnosed with alcoholic liver disease and zinc deficiency-induced hepatic encephalopathy. He was started on zinc supplementation along with management of his alcohol dependence. Gradually, his mental status improved, and he was discharged with a recommendation for regular follow-up and abstinence from alcohol. This case highlights the importance of considering zinc deficiency as a potential cause of hepatic encephalopathy, especially in patients with a history of alcohol abuse or malnutrition. Prompt recognition and management of zinc deficiency can lead to significant clinical improvement and prevent further neurological deterioration.

Standards for analysis of ventricular late potentials using high-resolution or signal-averaged electrocardiography: a statement by a task force committee of the European Society of Cardiology, the American Heart Association, and the American College of Cardiology. This statement provides guidelines for the analysis of ventricular late potentials using high-resolution or signal-averaged electrocardiography (ECG). Late potentials are low-amplitude signals occurring in the terminal QRS complex, which are thought to be markers of ventricular tachyarrhythmias and sudden cardiac death. The task force committee, consisting of representatives from the European Society of Cardiology, the American Heart Association, and the American College of Cardiology, reviewed the existing literature on late potentials and developed these standards for analysis. The statement covers topics such as ECG recording and filtering techniques, criteria for detection and quantification of late potentials, and the clinical relevance of late potentials in various cardiac conditions. These guidelines aim to provide a standardized approach for the assessment of ventricular late potentials and help improve the clinical management of patients at risk for arrhythmias and sudden cardiac death.

Angiocentric lymphoma with histologic features of neoplastic angioendotheliomatosis presenting with predominant respiratory and hematologic manifestations. Angiocentric lymphoma is a rare form of non-Hodgkin lymphoma characterized by infiltration of atypical lymphoid cells into the walls of vessels. We report a case of angiocentric lymphoma presenting with predominant respiratory and hematologic manifestations. A 45-year-old male presented with a three-month history of progressive dyspnea, cough, and weight loss. Physical examination revealed tachypnea, bilateral crackles on lung auscultation, and splenomegaly. Laboratory investigations showed leukocytosis with anemia and thrombocytopenia. Computed tomography scan of the chest revealed diffuse interstitial lung infiltrates. A transbronchial lung biopsy demonstrated angiocentric infiltration of atypical lymphoid cells with cytoplasmic clearing, consistent with neoplastic angioendotheliomatosis. Systemic chemotherapy was initiated, leading to a partial response. This case highlights the diverse clinical manifestations of angiocentric lymphoma and the importance of considering this entity in the differential diagnosis of respiratory and hematologic abnormalities. Further studies are needed to better understand the pathogenesis and optimal management of this rare lymphoma subtype.

A successful treatment of an intrarenal arteriovenous fistula by percutaneous embolization. Intrarenal arteriovenous fistula (AVF) is a rare condition characterized by an abnormal connection between the renal artery and vein within the kidney. Traditionally, surgical repair has been the mainstay of treatment for AVF. However, with the advancements in interventional radiology techniques, percutaneous embolization has emerged as a minimally invasive alternative. We present a case of a 45-year-old female with an incidental finding of an intrarenal AVF on routine imaging. The patient was symptomatic with hematuria and hypertension. After thorough evaluation, percutaneous embolization was performed using a combination of coils and glue to occlude the abnormal communication. Follow-up imaging at 3 months confirmed complete closure of the AVF with resolution of symptoms. Percutaneous embolization provides a safe and effective treatment option for intrarenal AVF, avoiding the need for open surgery and its associated morbidity. Further studies are warranted to evaluate long-term outcomes and complications associated with this technique.

Lack of late skin necrosis in man after high-dose irradiation using small field sizes: experiences of grid therapy. Grid therapy is a technique used in radiation therapy to treat large, complex tumors. This study aimed to investigate the occurrence of late skin necrosis in patients who underwent high-dose irradiation using small field sizes with grid therapy. A retrospective analysis of patient records was conducted, and the results showed no cases of late skin necrosis in the treated population. This suggests that grid therapy may be effective in minimizing the risk of skin necrosis, even when delivering high doses of radiation. Further research is needed to evaluate the long-term outcomes and potential complications associated with this treatment modality.

Deteriorating ischemic stroke: risk factors and prognosis.  To determine a risk profile of deterioration in cerebral infarction of less than 8 hours' duration, we studied prospectively a series of clinical and radiologic data in 98 patients. This study aimed to determine the risk factors and prognosis of deterioration in patients with cerebral infarction of less than 8 hours' duration. A total of 98 patients were prospectively studied, and their clinical and radiologic data were analyzed. The results revealed that several risk factors were associated with deterioration, including older age, elevated systolic blood pressure, larger infarct size, and involvement of multiple vascular territories. Additionally, patients with deteriorating ischemic stroke had a significantly worse prognosis, with higher rates of disability and mortality compared to those without deterioration. These findings underscore the importance of early detection and intervention in patients with cerebral infarction to prevent deterioration and improve outcomes.

Peroneal nerve palsy after total knee arthroplasty.  The prognosis for peroneal palsy after total knee arthroplasty (TKA) is poorly defined. Peroneal nerve palsy is a known complication of total knee arthroplasty (TKA) and can result in significant disability and functional impairment. However, the prognosis for this complication remains unclear. This study aims to evaluate the long-term outcomes and prognosis of peroneal palsy following TKA. A retrospective analysis of patients who developed peroneal palsy after TKA was conducted, and their clinical presentation, surgical details, and post-operative outcomes were assessed. The mean follow-up duration was 2 years. The results showed that 70% of the patients experienced complete recovery of peroneal nerve function, while the remaining 30% had residual weakness or functional limitations. Various factors such as patient age, pre-existing nerve pathology, and intraoperative complications were found to influence the prognosis. This study underscores the importance of early recognition and prompt management of peroneal nerve palsy after TKA to optimize the chances of a favorable outcome. Further research is needed to better understand the mechanisms and predictors of recovery in this population.

Unknown primary squamous cell carcinoma metastatic to the neck. Unknown primary squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) metastatic to the neck is a challenging clinical scenario. This retrospective study aimed to evaluate the outcomes of patients with unknown primary SCC metastatic to the neck who underwent comprehensive diagnostic workup and treatment at our institution. A total of 56 patients were identified. The majority of patients were male (78.6%) with a mean age of 61.4 years. The most common presenting symptom was a neck mass (84.8%). Diagnostic workup included physical examination, imaging studies, and histopathological evaluation. Treatment consisted of surgery, radiation therapy, or a combination of both. The overall survival rate at 5 years was 54.7%. Factors associated with poorer prognosis included advanced age, larger tumor size, lymph node involvement, and extracapsular spread. Further research is needed to identify optimal treatment strategies for this challenging patient population.

Tissue changes around loose prostheses. Loose prostheses, whether joint replacements or other implantable devices, can lead to significant tissue changes in the surrounding area. These changes include necrosis, fibrosis, inflammation, and bone resorption. The extent and severity of these changes may depend on various factors, including the type and location of the prosthesis, the duration of implantation, and the individual patient's immune response.

Necrosis of the surrounding soft tissues can occur due to compromised blood supply caused by mechanical pressure or infection. Fibrosis, characterized by the excessive deposition of collagen fibers, can lead to tissue contracture and loss of function. Inflammation is a common response to the presence of a foreign body, and it can further contribute to tissue damage. Bone resorption is another important consequence of loose prostheses, often resulting from the migration or instability of the implant.

Understanding these tissue changes is crucial for diagnosing and managing complications associated with loose prostheses. Early detection and prompt intervention, such as revision surgery or antimicrobial therapy, may be necessary to prevent further deterioration and improve patient outcomes. Additionally, advancements in biomaterials and surgical techniques may help reduce the incidence of prosthesis loosening and associated tissue changes in the future.

Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia complicating multiple myeloma. Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia (PCP) is a life-threatening opportunistic infection commonly seen in immunocompromised individuals, including those with multiple myeloma (MM). This study aimed to investigate the prevalence and clinical outcome of PCP in patients with MM. A retrospective analysis of medical records of 134 MM patients was conducted. Among them, 12 patients (8.9%) developed PCP, with a median time to diagnosis of 8 weeks from MM diagnosis. The majority of PCP cases presented with respiratory symptoms, and diagnosis was confirmed through bronchoalveolar lavage in all cases. Despite the use of appropriate treatment, the mortality rate was high at 41.7%. Risk factors associated with PCP development included advanced disease stage, prolonged use of immunosuppressive therapy, and low absolute lymphocyte count. These findings highlight the importance of PCP prophylaxis and early detection in MM patients to minimize the morbidity and mortality associated with this infection.

Movement disorders--limb movement and the basal ganglia. The aim of this study was to investigate the relationship between limb movement and the basal ganglia in movement disorders. A total of 100 patients with movement disorders were included in this study. Detailed clinical evaluations, including medical history, physical and neurological examinations, and neuroimaging studies, were performed. The patients were divided into two groups: those with abnormal limb movements (n=50) and those without abnormal limb movements (n=50). The results showed that all patients with abnormal limb movements had abnormalities in the basal ganglia on neuroimaging studies. In contrast, only 20% of patients without abnormal limb movements had basal ganglia abnormalities. Furthermore, there was a significant correlation between the severity of limb movement abnormalities and the extent of basal ganglia involvement. These findings suggest that the basal ganglia play a crucial role in the generation of abnormal limb movements in movement disorders. Further research is needed to elucidate the specific mechanisms underlying this relationship and to develop targeted therapeutic interventions for patients with movement disorders.

Prospective study of a prosthetic H-graft portacaval shunt.  This study was undertaken to prospectively evaluate the 8-mm Gore-Tex interposition H-graft portacaval shunt. The study included 20 patients with cirrhosis and refractory variceal bleeding who underwent the prosthetic H-graft portacaval shunt procedure. The primary outcome measures were technical success, shunt patency, and postoperative complications. Secondary outcome measures included variceal rebleeding and overall survival. The technical success rate of the H-graft portacaval shunt procedure was 95%, with successful establishment of the shunt in 19 out of 20 patients. The shunt patency rate at 1-year follow-up was 85%, with only 3 cases of shunt occlusion. Postoperative complications included hepatic encephalopathy in 4 patients, ascites in 2 patients, and wound infection in 1 patient. Variceal rebleeding occurred in 2 patients, both of whom underwent successful salvage procedures. Overall survival at 1-year follow-up was 80%. In conclusion, the prosthetic H-graft portacaval shunt is a safe and effective treatment option for patients with cirrhosis and refractory variceal bleeding. Further studies with larger sample sizes and longer follow-up periods are warranted to validate these findings.

Florid refractory schizophrenias that turn out to be treatable variants of HLA-associated narcolepsy. We present two cases of refractory schizophrenias that were ultimately diagnosed as treatable variants of HLA-associated narcolepsy. Both patients initially presented with severe psychosis and treatment-resistant schizophrenia symptoms. However, further evaluation revealed abnormal sleep patterns and excessive daytime sleepiness, prompting a suspicion for an underlying sleep disorder. Subsequent genetic testing confirmed the presence of HLA-DQB1*06:02, a known risk allele for narcolepsy. Treatment with narcolepsy-specific medications, such as stimulants and selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, resulted in significant improvement in psychosis and sleep disturbances in both cases. These cases highlight the importance of considering narcolepsy as a potential differential diagnosis in refractory cases of schizophrenia and the potential for targeted treatment to improve outcomes. Further research is warranted to explore the neurobiological mechanisms underlying this association.

Small bowel enteroscopy: an early experience in gastrointestinal bleeding of unknown origin.  Peroral small intestinal enteroscopy was performed in 35 consecutive patients with gastrointestinal bleeding of unknown origin by using a prototypic Sonde-type enteroscope. The aim of this study was to evaluate the utility of peroral small bowel enteroscopy in patients presenting with gastrointestinal bleeding of unknown origin. A total of 35 consecutive patients underwent the procedure using a prototypic Sonde-type enteroscope. The mean age of the patients was 55 years, with a slight male predominance (57%). The enteroscopy revealed a definite source of bleeding in 23 patients (66%). Among these, vascular lesions were the most common findings (57%), followed by ulcers (22%) and tumors (13%). In the remaining 12 patients (34%), no definite source of bleeding was identified. The overall diagnostic yield of peroral small bowel enteroscopy in this cohort was 66%. Complications were minimal and included one case of self-limited bleeding. In conclusion, peroral small bowel enteroscopy appears to be a valuable tool in the evaluation of gastrointestinal bleeding of unknown origin, providing a high diagnostic yield and minimal complications.

Parathyroid hormone-like peptide in normal and neoplastic mesothelial cells. The role of parathyroid hormone-like peptide (PTHrP) in normal and neoplastic mesothelial cells was investigated. PTHrP has been implicated in various physiological and pathological processes, including cell proliferation, differentiation, and tumor growth. Immunohistochemical analysis revealed the expression of PTHrP in both normal and neoplastic mesothelial cells. Furthermore, PTHrP mRNA was detected in both cell types using reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR). In vitro experiments demonstrated that PTHrP treatment stimulated proliferation and migration of mesothelial cells. Additionally, inhibition of PTHrP signaling using a neutralizing antibody reduced cell proliferation and migration. These findings suggest that PTHrP plays a role in the pathogenesis of mesothelial cell proliferation and may serve as a potential therapeutic target for mesothelioma.

Acute pulmonary oedema on the Ruwenzori mountain range. This case report describes the development of acute pulmonary edema in a 30-year-old male climber during an expedition on the Ruwenzori mountain range. The patient had a history of mild asthma but was otherwise fit and healthy. He experienced sudden onset shortness of breath, cough, and frothy pinkish sputum, progressing to respiratory distress and cyanosis. High-altitude pulmonary edema was suspected, and the patient was immediately evacuated to a lower altitude and administered supplemental oxygen. He responded well to treatment and gradually improved over the next few days. This case highlights the importance of recognizing and promptly treating high-altitude pulmonary edema in mountaineers, as it can lead to severe respiratory compromise and even death if not managed appropriately.

The modified superior based pharyngeal flap. The modified superior-based pharyngeal flap has emerged as a surgical technique for the management of velopharyngeal insufficiency (VPI) following cleft palate repair. This retrospective study reports the outcomes of 18 patients who underwent the procedure between 2010 and 2019. Preoperative assessment included clinical evaluation, nasoendoscopy, speech assessment, and imaging studies. The surgical technique involved raising a superiorly based pharyngeal flap and anchoring it to the posterior pharyngeal wall. Postoperative evaluation was performed at regular intervals and included speech assessment, nasoendoscopy, and imaging studies. Results showed satisfactory outcomes in terms of VPI correction, with improvement in speech intelligibility and resonance. Complications were minimal, with velopharyngeal insufficiency recurrence observed in only 1 patient. The modified superior-based pharyngeal flap is a reliable technique for the management of VPI, providing favorable outcomes and low complication rates.

Duplex Doppler examination of a perinephric abscess in a renal transplant. We present a case of a perinephric abscess in a renal transplant recipient diagnosed by duplex Doppler examination. A 47-year-old male presented with fever and flank pain three weeks after receiving a renal transplant. Physical examination revealed tenderness over the transplant site. Laboratory tests showed an elevated white blood cell count and C-reactive protein level. Duplex Doppler examination was performed to evaluate renal perfusion and revealed a hypoechoic collection adjacent to the renal allograft with increased vascularity. The abscess was confirmed by computed tomography-guided aspiration and culture. The patient was treated with appropriate antibiotics and underwent percutaneous drainage. Duplex Doppler examination proved to be a valuable non-invasive tool in the diagnosis and management of perinephric abscess in this renal transplant recipient.

Obstructive sleep apnea presenting with nocturnal angina, heart failure, and near-miss sudden death. Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is a common disorder characterized by recurrent partial or complete obstruction of the upper airway during sleep. This case report presents a unique presentation of OSA with symptoms of nocturnal angina, heart failure, and near-miss sudden death. A 56-year-old male with a history of hypertension and smoking presented with complaints of chest pain and dyspnea that occurred exclusively during sleep. Cardiac evaluation revealed normal coronary arteries and left ventricular dysfunction consistent with heart failure. Polysomnography confirmed a diagnosis of severe OSA with an apnea-hypopnea index of 55 events per hour. The patient was prescribed continuous positive airway pressure therapy, which resulted in resolution of symptoms and improvement in cardiac function. This case highlights the importance of considering OSA in patients presenting with atypical angina and heart failure symptoms, especially during sleep, to prevent potentially fatal complications. Early recognition, diagnosis, and treatment of OSA are essential in improving patient outcomes.

A prospective evaluation of the AO/ASIF universal femoral nail in the treatment of traumatic and reconstructive problems of the femur. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of the AO/ASIF universal femoral nail in the management of traumatic and reconstructive problems of the femur. A total of 50 patients with fractures or non-unions of the femur were included in the study. Clinical and radiological assessments were conducted pre- and postoperatively to evaluate the functional outcomes and bone healing. The results showed that the AO/ASIF universal femoral nail provided excellent stability and allowed for early mobilization in both traumatic and reconstructive cases. The overall union rate was 92%, with no major complications observed. This study suggests that the AO/ASIF universal femoral nail is a reliable and effective surgical option for the treatment of femoral fractures and non-unions.

N-[18F]fluoroacetyl-D-glucosamine: a potential agent for cancer diagnosis Positron labeled substrates such as sugars, amino acids, and nucleosides have been investigated for the in-vivo evaluation of biochemical processes in cancerous tissue.  Hexosamines are obligatory structural components of many biologically important macromolecules, including membrane glycoproteins and mucopolysaccharide. N-[18F]fluoroacetyl-D-glucosamine (FDGlcN) is a novel positron-labeled substrate that holds promise for cancer diagnosis. This study aimed to evaluate the potential of FDGlcN as an imaging agent for detecting cancerous tissue. The study involved synthesizing FDGlcN and performing in vitro and in vivo experiments to assess its ability to assess biochemical processes in cancerous tissue. The results showed that FDGlcN was successfully synthesized and exhibited high uptake in cancer cell lines compared to normal cells. Additionally, in vivo experiments demonstrated that FDGlcN selectively accumulated in tumor tissues, making it a potential candidate for cancer diagnosis. Further investigations are warranted to validate its clinical utility.

src expression in small-cell lung carcinoma and other neuroendocrine malignancies. The src gene is known to be involved in various biological processes, including cell growth, differentiation, and apoptosis. Its overexpression has been observed in numerous types of cancer, including small-cell lung carcinoma (SCLC) and other neuroendocrine malignancies. In this study, we aimed to investigate the expression pattern of src in SCLC and its association with clinicopathological features. Immunohistochemical analysis revealed that src expression was significantly higher in SCLC tissues compared to adjacent normal lung tissues. Furthermore, high src expression was correlated with advanced tumor stage and poor overall survival. These findings suggest that src could serve as a potential prognostic marker and therapeutic target in SCLC and other neuroendocrine malignancies. Further studies are warranted to elucidate the underlying molecular mechanism of src in these cancers.

Isolated lipase and colipase deficiency in two brothers. We present a case report of two brothers with isolated lipase and colipase deficiency. Lipase is an enzyme that plays a crucial role in the digestion and absorption of dietary fats, while colipase is a cofactor that enhances the activity of lipase. The patients presented with symptoms of malabsorption, including greasy stools, failure to thrive, and vitamin deficiencies. Laboratory investigations revealed low lipase and colipase levels. Genetic testing confirmed the presence of a homozygous mutation in the lipase gene. Treatment with pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy resulted in significant improvement in symptoms and nutritional status. This case highlights the importance of considering isolated lipase and colipase deficiency in the differential diagnosis of malabsorption.

Carpal tunnel syndrome: correlations between pressure measurement and intraoperative electrophysiological nerve study. Carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS) is a common condition characterized by compression of the median nerve in the carpal tunnel of the wrist. The diagnosis of CTS is primarily based on clinical symptoms and findings, but objective measurements such as pressure measurement and electrophysiological nerve study can provide additional information. This study aims to correlate the findings of pressure measurement and intraoperative electrophysiological nerve study in patients with CTS.

A total of 50 patients diagnosed with CTS were included in the study. Pressure measurement was performed using a specific device, while intraoperative electrophysiological nerve study was conducted during carpal tunnel release surgery. The results showed a significant correlation between the pressure measurement and electrophysiological nerve study findings. Higher pressure measurements were associated with more severe nerve conduction abnormalities.

These findings suggest that pressure measurement can serve as a valuable tool for assessing the severity of CTS and predicting the extent of nerve damage. Combining pressure measurement with electrophysiological nerve study can provide a comprehensive evaluation of CTS, aiding in surgical decision-making and postoperative management. Further studies are needed to validate these correlations and determine their clinical implications.

Transtelephonic defibrillation.  STUDY OBJECTIVES: This study was undertaken to assess the safety and reliability of a device for transtelephonic defibrillation. Transtelephonic defibrillation is a potential alternative method for delivering defibrillation therapy remotely via telephone communication. The objective of this study was to evaluate the safety and reliability of a device designed for transtelephonic defibrillation. A total of 50 patients with a history of cardiovascular disease and an indication for implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) placement were enrolled in the study. The transtelephonic defibrillation device was successfully implanted in all patients, and no major complications related to the device or the procedure were observed during the follow-up period. The device demonstrated high reliability, with successful transmission of defibrillation therapy in all cases where it was triggered. Additionally, patients reported a high level of satisfaction with the device and expressed confidence in its ability to deliver life-saving therapy remotely. Based on these findings, transtelephonic defibrillation may be considered a safe and reliable alternative for delivering defibrillation therapy in selected patients. Further research is warranted to evaluate its long-term efficacy and cost-effectiveness.

Diffuse hemangiomatosis of the spleen: splenic hemangiomatosis presenting with giant splenomegaly, anemia, and thrombocytopenia. Part III. A case report.  We present a case of diffuse hemangiomatosis of the spleen in a 45-year-old male who presented with giant splenomegaly, anemia, and thrombocytopenia. Radiological evaluation revealed multiple hypervascular lesions involving the entire spleen. The patient underwent a splenectomy due to the progressive worsening of his symptoms. Histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of hemangiomatosis, with numerous thick-walled blood vessels infiltrating the splenic parenchyma. The patient's postoperative course was uneventful, and his symptoms resolved with supportive management. This case highlights the rarity of diffuse hemangiomatosis of the spleen and the need to consider it as a differential diagnosis in patients presenting with splenomegaly and hematological abnormalities.

Characterization of the in vitro maturation of monocytes and the susceptibility to HIV infection. The in vitro maturation of monocytes and its relationship to susceptibility to HIV infection were investigated in this study. Monocytes were isolated from healthy donors and cultured in the presence of various maturation factors. The expression of cell surface markers and the production of cytokines were analyzed to assess the maturation status of the monocytes. Additionally, the susceptibility of the matured monocytes to HIV infection was determined by measuring viral replication and infectivity. The results revealed that the maturation of monocytes was associated with increased expression of CD14 and CD11c, as well as enhanced production of pro-inflammatory cytokines. Furthermore, matured monocytes displayed higher levels of HIV replication and infectivity compared to immature monocytes. These findings provide valuable insights into the relationship between monocyte maturation and HIV infection, highlighting the potential role of monocyte maturation as a target for therapeutic interventions.

Increasing asthma prevalence in a rural New Zealand adolescent population: 1975-89.  A survey of asthma symptoms and spirometry in 435 adolescent schoolchildren was undertaken in 1989 in a rural, largely Maori population.  The survey questionnaires were identical to those used in a 1975 survey at the same school. The aim of this study was to investigate the changes in asthma prevalence among rural New Zealand adolescents from 1975 to 1989. A total of 435 adolescent schoolchildren, predominantly Maori, were surveyed in 1989 using the same questionnaires and spirometry techniques as a previous survey conducted in 1975 at the same school. The results showed a significant increase in asthma prevalence, with 26% of adolescents reporting asthma symptoms in 1989 compared to only 8% in 1975. This increase was observed in both genders and across all age groups. The findings highlight the need for further research to identify the factors contributing to the rising asthma prevalence in this rural population.

Brain magnetic resonance imaging and neuropsychologic evaluation of patients with idiopathic dilated cardiomyopathy.  We compared brain magnetic resonance imaging and neuropsychologic performance in 20 neurologically asymptomatic patients suffering from idiopathic dilated cardiomyopathy (mean age 41 [range 18-49] years) and 20 age-matched controls (mean age 38 [range 28-49] years).  Patients exhibited a significantly higher rate of cerebral infarcts (20% versus 0%, p less than 0. This study aimed to investigate brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) findings and neuropsychologic performance in patients with idiopathic dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM). A total of 20 neurologically asymptomatic DCM patients and 20 age-matched controls were included. The results showed that DCM patients had a significantly higher incidence of cerebral infarcts compared to controls (20% versus 0%, p<0.05). Additionally, DCM patients demonstrated poorer performance on neuropsychologic evaluations, particularly in cognitive domains such as attention, memory, and executive function. These findings suggest that DCM may be associated with an increased risk of cerebral infarcts and cognitive impairment, highlighting the importance of neurologic assessment in DCM patients. Further research is needed to better understand the underlying mechanisms and potential therapeutic implications.

Unusual lymphoproliferative oropharyngeal lesions in heart and heart-lung transplant recipients.  Three unusual cases of oropharyngeal lympho-proliferative lesions were seen in recipients of heart and heart-lung transplants. These lesions, characterized by lymphoid nodules, were seen in the tonsils, pharynx, and base of tongue. Two patients presented with symptoms of sore throat and dysphagia, while one was asymptomatic. Histopathological examination revealed a polyclonal proliferation of B-cells with varying degrees of plasmacytoid differentiation. Immunohistochemical staining confirmed the B-cell nature with expression of CD20, CD79a, and PAX5. Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection was detected in all three cases by in situ hybridization for EBV-encoded RNA. The patients were managed with reduction of immunosuppression, local radiation therapy, or surgical excision. These cases highlight the importance of considering lymphoproliferative disorders in the oropharynx of transplant recipients and the association with EBV infection. Further studies are needed to elucidate the pathogenesis and optimal management of these lesions.

Permanent external striated sphincter stents in patients with spinal injuries. Spinal injuries often result in the loss of normal bowel control, leading to fecal incontinence. The use of external striated sphincter stents has been proposed as a potential treatment option for these patients. This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of permanent external striated sphincter stents in patients with spinal injuries. A total of 22 patients with spinal injuries and fecal incontinence were included in the study. Placement of the stents was successful in all patients, with no intraoperative complications. The stents effectively restored continence in 18 patients, resulting in improved quality of life and reduced need for bowel management interventions. However, four patients experienced complications including stent dislodgement and mucosal erosion. Despite these complications, permanent external striated sphincter stents show promise as a treatment option for patients with spinal injuries and fecal incontinence. Further long-term studies are warranted to assess their durability and potential for complications.

Hyponatraemia in patients with cirrhosis. Hyponatraemia, the condition of low sodium levels in the blood, is a common complication observed in patients with cirrhosis. This medical abstract aims to review the causes, consequences, and management of hyponatraemia in this patient population. The main etiology of hyponatraemia in cirrhosis is believed to be the impaired renal water excretion due to the presence of vasopressin, a hormone that regulates water balance. This hormone is upregulated in cirrhosis, leading to increased water absorption and dilutional hyponatraemia. The consequences of hyponatraemia in cirrhosis can be severe and include neurological symptoms such as confusion, seizures, and coma. The management of hyponatraemia in these patients should be focused on addressing the underlying cause, such as excessive fluid intake or diuretic use. Various treatment options, including fluid restriction, diuretic adjustment, and administration of vaptans, have been explored. However, the optimal approach is still a topic of debate, and further research is needed to establish evidence-based guidelines for the management of hyponatraemia in patients with cirrhosis.

Colonoscopy during an attack of severe ulcerative colitis is a safe procedure and of great value in clinical decision making. The safety and clinical value of performing colonoscopy during severe ulcerative colitis (UC) attacks were assessed in this study. A total of 37 patients with active UC were included, and colonoscopy was performed during acute exacerbation. The procedure was found to be safe, with no serious complications reported. Colonoscopy provided valuable information for clinical decision making in 78% of cases, leading to changes in management plans, including alterations in medical therapy, surgical intervention, or further diagnostic evaluation. These findings suggest that performing colonoscopy during severe UC episodes is a safe procedure and can significantly aid in clinical decision making.

Transitional cell carcinoma of the upper urinary tract: prognostic variables and post-operative recurrences. Transitional cell carcinoma (TCC) of the upper urinary tract is a relatively rare malignancy with limited data on prognostic variables and post-operative recurrences. This study aims to identify prognostic factors associated with TCC of the upper urinary tract and assess the rate of post-operative recurrences. A retrospective analysis of 120 patients diagnosed with TCC of the upper urinary tract was conducted. Histopathological features, including tumor grade, stage, lymphovascular invasion, and surgical margins, were evaluated as potential prognostic variables. The median follow-up period was 48 months. Results showed that T stage, lymphovascular invasion, and positive surgical margins were independent predictors of worse overall survival and disease-free survival. Additionally, the rate of post-operative recurrences was 32%, with a median time to recurrence of 14 months. These findings highlight the importance of accurate staging, careful evaluation of surgical margins, and close surveillance for early detection of recurrent disease in patients with TCC of the upper urinary tract.

In vivo leukocyte migration in arthritis. Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic inflammatory disease characterized by synovial inflammation and leukocyte infiltration. The migration of leukocytes, particularly neutrophils and monocytes, plays a crucial role in mediating the inflammatory response and disease progression in arthritis. In this study, we investigated the in vivo leukocyte migration patterns in arthritis using a murine model. We utilized intravital microscopy to visualize leukocyte recruitment and extravasation in the synovial tissue. Our results demonstrated a significant increase in leukocyte migration into the synovium compared to control animals. Furthermore, we observed a preferential accumulation of neutrophils at the inflammatory site. Interestingly, the extent of leukocyte migration correlated with disease severity, as measured by histological scores. These findings highlight the importance of leukocyte migration in arthritis and provide valuable insights into the inflammatory processes underlying disease pathogenesis.

Paediatric urolithiasis in Greece.  A group of 44 patients, aged from 10 months to 14 years, underwent surgery for urinary calculi over a 7-year period (1982-1989). Paediatric urolithiasis, or urinary calculi, is increasingly being recognized as a significant health issue worldwide. This retrospective study aimed to evaluate the characteristics and management of paediatric urolithiasis in Greece. A total of 44 patients, ranging in age from 10 months to 14 years, underwent surgical intervention for urinary calculi between 1982 and 1989. The majority of cases presented with symptoms such as flank pain, hematuria, and urinary tract infections. The stone composition varied, with calcium oxalate being the most common type. The surgical approach included open surgery, percutaneous nephrolithotomy, and ureteroscopy, depending on the stone location and size. Postoperative complications were minimal, with successful stone clearance achieved in most cases. This study highlights the need for early detection and appropriate management strategies to prevent long-term complications associated with paediatric urolithiasis.

Unusual haemostasis for an unusual tumour. We present a case of a 45-year-old male with a rare and aggressive tumour characterized by unusual haemostatic manifestations. The patient initially presented with spontaneous bleeding from the gums and nose, accompanied by petechiae and ecchymosis. Laboratory investigations revealed thrombocytopenia and prolonged clotting times, suggestive of a coagulopathy. Imaging studies showed a large pelvic mass, later confirmed as an extraskeletal osteosarcoma, an exceedingly rare tumour with only a few reported cases worldwide. Further evaluation revealed excessive production of tissue factor, a procoagulant protein, by the tumour cells. Aggressive management strategies including surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy were initiated, along with interventions to control the bleeding disorder. This case highlights the importance of considering rare malignancies in patients with unusual haemostatic abnormalities and the need for a multidisciplinary approach in their management.

The management of the painful first metatarsophalangeal joint in the older patient. Arthritis of the first metatarsophalangeal (MTP) joint can cause significant pain and functional impairment in older patients. This study aimed to evaluate the management of painful first MTP joint in this population. A total of 45 patients over the age of 60 with symptomatic arthritis of the first MTP joint were included. Treatment options included physical therapy, intra-articular corticosteroid injections, and surgical intervention. Patients were followed for a minimum of 12 months. Results showed that physical therapy provided significant pain relief and improved function in 75% of patients. Intra-articular corticosteroid injections provided temporary relief in 60% of patients. Surgery was required in 20% of patients with severe joint destruction. Overall, a multidisciplinary approach tailored to individual patient needs is recommended for the management of painful first MTP joint in older patients.

Management of soft tissue sarcomas of the extremities. Soft tissue sarcomas of the extremities pose significant challenges in terms of management. This retrospective study aimed to evaluate the outcomes and identify prognostic factors in patients with soft tissue sarcomas of the extremities. A total of 78 patients diagnosed with extremity sarcomas between 2000 and 2010 were included in the study. The majority of patients underwent wide surgical resection, while a subset also received adjuvant radiotherapy or chemotherapy. The five-year overall survival rate was 65.4%, with local recurrence observed in 22.1% of cases. Tumor size, histologic grade, and surgical margin status were identified as significant prognostic factors. This study highlights the importance of aggressive surgical resection and further explores the role of adjuvant therapies in the management of extremity sarcomas.

A randomized trial of the effect of three non-steroid anti-inflammatory agents in ameliorating cancer-induced fever.  Paraneoplastic fever is well known, and is not an uncommon problem in daily practice. Cancer-induced fever is a common manifestation in patients with malignancies and often causes significant morbidity. Despite its clinical importance, there is limited data on the effectiveness of non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) in managing cancer-induced fever. This study aimed to evaluate the effect of three different NSAIDs on ameliorating cancer-induced fever. 

A randomized trial was conducted among 60 cancer patients with documented cancer-induced fever. These patients were divided into three groups, each receiving a different NSAID: Group A received ibuprofen, Group B received diclofenac, and Group C received naproxen. Fever parameters including temperature, duration, and recurrence were monitored for seven days. 

The results indicated that all three NSAIDs effectively reduced fever in cancer patients. However, Group A, receiving ibuprofen, demonstrated the greatest reduction in fever parameters compared to the other groups. No major adverse events were reported in any of the groups. 

In conclusion, among the studied NSAIDs, ibuprofen showed the most promising efficacy in ameliorating cancer-induced fever. Further research is warranted to establish the optimal dosing and long-term safety profile of NSAIDs in this patient population.

Reproducibility of growth hormone testing procedures: a comparison between 24-hour integrated concentration and pharmacological stimulation.  The purpose of this study was to compare the reproducibility of two approaches to the evaluation of GH secretion: the integrated concentration of GH (IC-GH), a physiological test of GH secretion, and pharmacological stimulation tests. A total of 32 adults deemed to have impaired GH secretion were enrolled in the study. Each participant underwent two separate testing sessions, with a minimum interval of one month between sessions. The IC-GH was measured by collecting blood samples every 20 minutes over a 24-hour period. Pharmacological stimulation was done using two different agents, clonidine and arginine, on separate days. GH secretion was evaluated by the quantification of peak GH levels. 

Statistical analysis revealed that the IC-GH demonstrated higher reproducibility compared to the pharmacological stimulation tests. The coefficient of variation for IC-GH was 8.2%, whereas for the pharmacological tests it ranged from 14.5% to 18.9%. Interclass correlation coefficient analysis also favored the IC-GH, with a value of 0.92 compared to 0.79 and 0.68 for the clonidine and arginine tests, respectively.

In conclusion, the 24-hour IC-GH test showed better reproducibility compared to pharmacological stimulation tests in evaluating GH secretion. This suggests that the IC-GH may be a more reliable and practical method for assessing GH secretion in clinical practice.

Hemibody irradiation in advanced prostatic carcinoma. Hemibody irradiation (HBI), also known as strontium-89 therapy, has been considered as a palliative treatment option for patients with advanced prostatic carcinoma. This report discusses the outcomes of HBI in a cohort of patients with advanced prostatic carcinoma who were not candidates for other treatment modalities. A total of 25 patients were included in the study, and their response to HBI was evaluated using the pain score index, serum prostate-specific antigen (PSA) levels, and overall survival. The results showed that HBI led to a significant reduction in pain score index and serum PSA levels in the majority of patients. Additionally, the median overall survival was found to be significantly prolonged in patients who received HBI compared to those who did not receive any treatment. These findings suggest that HBI can be an effective palliative treatment option for patients with advanced prostatic carcinoma, particularly those who are not candidates for other therapies. Further studies are warranted to validate these findings and determine the optimal dosage and timing of HBI in this patient population.

Giant benign mesenchymoma of the breast. Giant benign mesenchymomas of the breast are rare tumors and pose unique diagnostic and management challenges. We present a case of a 36-year-old female who presented with a progressively enlarging mass in her left breast. Imaging studies revealed a large, well-defined tumor with heterogeneous enhancement. Core needle biopsy showed an abundance of spindle-shaped cells with minimal mitotic activity, consistent with a benign mesenchymoma. The patient underwent a wide local excision with negative margins. Histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of a giant benign mesenchymoma. Postoperative follow-up showed no evidence of recurrence or metastasis. This case highlights the importance of considering rare benign tumors in the differential diagnosis of breast masses, as well as the successful management through surgical excision.

Hepatic infarction in preeclampsia. A case report. Preeclampsia is a multisystem disorder characterized by hypertension and proteinuria during pregnancy. Hepatic infarction is a rare complication of preeclampsia that can lead to significant morbidity and mortality. We present a case of a 34-year-old primigravida with severe preeclampsia who developed hepatic infarction during the antenatal period. The patient presented with right upper quadrant pain and elevated liver function tests. Imaging studies revealed segmental infarction of the liver. Prompt recognition and management with anticoagulation therapy and close monitoring allowed for successful resolution of the infarction without any long-term complications. This case highlights the importance of considering hepatic infarction as a potential complication in patients with severe preeclampsia and provides insights into its management.

Translocation (9;22) is associated with extremely poor prognosis in intensively treated children with acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Translocation (9;22), also known as the Philadelphia chromosome, is a chromosomal abnormality that is associated with a poor prognosis in children with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). This study aimed to evaluate the outcome of intensive treatment in children with this specific translocation. Forty-five children with ALL and translocation (9;22) were included in the study, and they received aggressive chemotherapy and stem cell transplantation. Despite the intensive treatment, the overall survival rate in this cohort was found to be extremely poor, with only 20% of patients surviving more than two years. Additionally, these patients had a higher risk of relapse and a shorter event-free survival compared to children without this translocation. Therefore, alternative treatment strategies should be investigated for this high-risk subgroup of ALL patients to improve their prognosis.

Endoscopic placement of a Foley catheter across a stricture and rectovaginal fistula to perform a barium enema.  Evaluation of enteric fistulas is often best performed with barium contrast studies. Enteric fistulas, including rectovaginal fistulas, can cause significant morbidity and require accurate evaluation for appropriate management. Barium contrast studies, such as barium enema, are commonly used to assess the anatomy and function of the gastrointestinal tract in these cases. However, in the presence of strictures or fistulas, traditional administration of barium can be challenging. We report a case where an endoscopic technique was employed to overcome these limitations. A Foley catheter was placed across the stricture and rectovaginal fistula under direct endoscopic visualization. This facilitated the administration of barium through the catheter, allowing for thorough evaluation of the enteric fistula. This technique proved to be safe and effective, providing valuable diagnostic information for guiding further management decisions. Endoscopic placement of a Foley catheter across strictures and fistulas presents a feasible approach in situations where conventional barium studies are hindered by anatomical abnormalities.

The risk of large bowel cancer after partial gastrectomy for benign ulcer disease.  The relative risk (standardized incidence ratio [SIR] for colorectal cancer after partial gastrectomy for ulcer disease was examined in a population-based cohort comprising 6459 patients operated during 1950 to 1958.  Follow-up through 1983 revealed 131 cases of colorectal cancer versus 150. The study aimed to investigate the risk of large bowel cancer following partial gastrectomy for benign ulcer disease. A population-based cohort consisting of 6459 patients who underwent partial gastrectomy between 1950 and 1958 was examined. The standardized incidence ratio (SIR) was used to determine the relative risk of colorectal cancer after surgery. Follow-up was conducted until 1983, and during this period, 131 cases of colorectal cancer were observed, compared to an expected number of 150 cases. The findings suggest that there is a slightly decreased risk of developing colorectal cancer following partial gastrectomy for benign ulcer disease. However, further research is required to fully understand the underlying mechanisms and long-term implications.

Amyloidosis of the small intestine: findings on double-contrast radiographs. Amyloidosis is a rare disorder characterized by the deposition of amyloid protein in various organs, including the small intestine. Double-contrast radiography has been suggested as a useful imaging technique for detecting small intestinal amyloidosis. We present the findings of double-contrast radiographs in five patients with confirmed small intestinal amyloidosis. The radiographs demonstrated characteristic findings, including multiple nodular mucosal irregularities, thickening of the folds, and luminal narrowing. These findings were more pronounced in the distal small intestine. In addition, luminal ulcerations and strictures were seen in some patients. Double-contrast radiography was able to provide a comprehensive evaluation of the small bowel in patients with amyloidosis. It can aid in the diagnosis and assessment of the extent and severity of small intestinal involvement in amyloidosis.

Hemolytic transfusion reaction following transfusion of frozen and washed autologous red cells A case of hemolytic transfusion reaction, accompanied by hypotension and followed by transient renal failure, occurred after the transfusion of 1 unit of previously frozen autologous red cells. In this case report, we describe a rare instance of a hemolytic transfusion reaction following the transfusion of frozen and washed autologous red cells. The patient experienced hypotension and subsequently developed transient renal failure. This adverse event highlights the importance of carefully monitoring patients during transfusions, even when using autologous blood products. Healthcare providers should be aware of the potential risks associated with frozen and washed red cell transfusions to prevent such reactions and ensure patient safety.
